description:
My Tofu House is a shining example of how all you need to succeed is to do one thing and so it really well. Definitely recommend coming here to get your soft tofu soup fix, complete with claypot rice, fried croaker and all of your usual suspects of banchan.

Parking along Geary can be a bit rough, especially during peak hours and expect to have a bit of a wait. My only detractor would be the price. To put things in perspective, a seafood pancake will set you back more than a Jackson. Regardless, do come here if you're feeling hungry or cold, the soup will fill you right up!
author: Tyler W.

description:
We came Sunday for early dinner about 6p. It wasn't crowded; by 6:30, a lot of groups arrived.   The tofu soups (combination and fried ramen) were all very yummy.  The warm soup suits the San Francisco chilly weather.  We also ordered short ribs and they were very yummy.  Not too fatty or over cooked.  This place does the cooking in the kitchen, it's not the bbq at your table type of restaurant. 

The rice came in stone pots at every table.  The servers would scoop the rice for you. Afterwards, our server pour rice tea into the rice stone pot to make rice porridge like they would in Korea.  Very home feel.  

Prices were okay.  I didn't find it over priced.  

Cleanliness was good for an older restaurant.  

Service was very good. They come by to ask if you need anything.  

They take credit cards.

This place is good for small and large parties.  

I saw a lot of young couples and also families.  This place is suitable for everyone.
author: Lynn W.

description:
G's favorite Tofu House.

And their dumpling soft tofu soup is bomb. Probably one of the best dumpilings I've ever had. I got the hottest level (it's totally doable for someone that can tolerate a lot of heat). I would probably do the same spicy level again or go for a medium.
author: Lilian L.

description:
GF and I came for dinner at 5:30. Seated right away in a booth. 

Just after we took a seat, the waitress served us hot barley tea (my favorite!!). 

GF ordered the kimchi soft tofu soup with beef and mild spice, and I ordered the original soft tofu soup with beef and medium spice. The spice in mine was perfect, not over the top at all! 

Along with our soups we were given a spread of banchan to share, and each had a broiled fish. Yum! 

Will be back, for sure.
author: Peds P.

description: After reading some of the reviews, we made sure we arrived at the restaurant before 6:30 on Sunday. Good thing we did because we were seated right away.  Restaurant filled up and a wait started within 15 minutes after we were seated.  We ordered Original Tofu Soup with beef. We asked for spicy and it definitely had some spice to it.  We love spicy food so I plan on ordering it extra spicy next time.  We also ordered bulgogi.  I liked the onions and mushrooms in the bulgogi.  It comes out in hot cast iron platter so it kept the food nice and hot. I purposely burnt some onions and mushrooms to make them crispy.  Hot pot of rice is also unique.  Cucumber salad was very fresh and good.  Quick service and everyone helped out.  You didn't have to wait for your waiter or waitress to come by if you needed something.  We will definitely be back!
author: Jennie R.

description:
NB: review mainly on sundubu

When I want very authentic flavors / crave Korean sundubu in SF, I come here.  I've even gotten my boyfriend addicted to this place.

Venue / Service: it's not exactly the nicest place I've been to for Korean restaurants, but it's not a dump either.  It gets a little dark, especially if you sit toward the back away from the windows since the lights are a bit dim, but at least tables and seats are clean.  Service-wise, they are on the quicker side, depending on how busy they are.  Probably the most we've waited was 20 min, but they at least brought out the banchan so we could nibble while waiting and came by to update us on our food.

Foodwise, I've had the non-spicy versions of the Dumpling Sundubu and the Combination Sundubu (both $14.98), since I can't handle spicy, though my boyfriend usually gets the mild version of the Combination.  They also bring you a fried croaker (fish) and a large stonepot of rice from which they serve you rice and then use the leftovers to make nurungji (crispy rice scrapped from sides of the stone pot with barley tea).  Raw eggs are provided that you crack on your own into the soup- I like to break my egg immediately so the soup becomes richer and thicker though some people like to eat the whole cooked egg.  

While I can't comment on spice levels (my low-tolerance boyfriend liked his mild versions) I will say that the non-spicy is still quite flavorful with the rich, soybean taste.  I also like how they give you a LOT of stuff in the soup other than the tofu- there's enough tofu but also a decent amount of meat / seafood / veggies / dumplings.  I think I prefer the Combination Sundubu since it had a better flavor profile, mixing seafood with some beef.  

I've tried a few places in the area and so far, this has been one of my favorites.  Even my other Korean friends love this place.  So if you are craving for some good sundubu in SF, this is a spot to try.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Their seafood pancake is legit. Filled with hearty portion of delicious seafood. They give a good variety of banchan. And their tofu soup is warm and comforting. 

I came here again after a hiatus of a few years, and I'm glad I did. The prices are on the higher end, but it's cool. Will pay for good food.
author: Joanna L.

description:
In 6 years, a tofu soup here went from $11-$15... Whoolad. I think this place may have been THE spot back in the day but the high pricing for what was supposed to be a cheap comfort meal has probably rendered this place less appealing...

My Tofu House has decent tofu soups, subpar banchan, subpar jasmine rice (served in clay pot but resteamed bc we got there late so no crunchy rice) but a clean and bright interior. Tofu is very soft and soup was not bad. Was not a fan of the fish egg soup; maybe cooked fish egg tastes too rusty for me. I didnt get to try their meats but it smelled very good.

I probably wouldn't go out of my way to come back... However it does comfortably accomadate groups of 4 or more so maybe sharing some of the items may be more worth it. Food qualitywise, tofu soup was quite megh.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
There is a time and place for everything.  We came to My Tofu House for some hot spicy stew on a cold, rainy day. They offered a limited selection of Korean comfort dishes that we have all come to love  - Tofu Stews, Bibimbab, Korean BBQs and savory Pancakes. The menu is small and these traditional favorites made up the entire menu. We ordered the Seafood Tofu Stew, Bibimbab and Fried Noodles Soft Tofu to share. Some entrees were missing the wow factor. One was particularly hearty and outstanding with a good kick. Prices of some were steep for what you get. I was taken aback by the sky-high price tags on the Pancakes and BBQs. Lightheartedly, we needed to save face and not behave like el cheapos by leaving! So we did the right thing but skipped the pancakes and BBQs!
 
However, where Tofu House surpassed others was in their banchan. Every dish of banchan from the proverbial kimchee to the fish cakes, daikon, cucumbers and bean sprouts were garlicky, deliciously marinated and seasoned with authentic Korean spices. The standout was not kimchee but the small fried yellow croaker fish. They were nicely salted with delicate mild flavors.

The Seafood Soft Tofu ($14.98) was served in a steaming cauldron of soft tofu stew. The stew was teeming with clams but they skimped on other ingredients. There were a few small shrimps with heads and shells and one piece (yes, one piece) of oyster. Nonetheless, I have to admit the stew tasted phenomenal albeit a little briny, which was expected being a seafood stew. The little clams stole the show! Then, there was this 'crack yourself' raw egg and the servers were funny by displaying their nonchalance towards customers not in the know what to do! The egg added more aesthetics to the cauldron now looking like fiery volcanic lava! This was the best dish for the evening and one of the best renditions in the city. (5/5)

Then came the disappointment mainly on the value department. The Fried Noodle Soft Tofu ($14.98) was priced the same as the Seafood Stew but all you get were tofu, carrots and onions plus a few mouthfuls of ramen. Although the broth tasted the same as the Seafood Stew, it felt like a rip considering the meager ingredients! If you are into ramen, Marufuku Ramen in Japantown gives you a better bang for your buck and a more substantial bowl of ramen. (2/5)

I love my rice bowl be it Chinese or Japanese! Bibimbab is the classic Korean rice bowl with just as much flavor, texture and color. We ordered the no meat version -the Mushroom and Vegetable Babimbab ($17.98). Rice was served in a stoneware, topped with sautéed veggies and 'gochujang' sauce on the side, which was a savory, sweet and spicy condiment for flavor enhancement. Again, there was this raw egg smack dab in the center but this time the yolk brought out the sunshine look! It was a pretty presentation, good tasting but certainly not mind blowing.  For a vegetarian bowl, I felt the price was up in the clouds as well! (3/5)

Service was efficient as they were staffed with energetic young boys! There wasn't time for friendly banters as the place was jammed a half-hour after they opened! The décor was elegantly appointed Japanese style with an emphasis on wood. It is not trendy but is a quite charming old school design.
author: Geoff G.

description:
THEY OVERCHARGED ME MORE THAN MY RECEIPT! I HAVE PROOF. Read below for context.

I typically don't leave reviews for restaurants unless they are SPECTACULAR or ABSOLUTELY ABHORRENT. Unfortunately, this review falls under the latter... I visited this place last week, and received terrible service period. It wasn't even a packed house but yet, I did not get any attention from the service staff. I had an empty water glass as early as 10 minute into being seated. It stayed empty until I left 45 minutes later. The staff was walking by me constantly because I was seated between the front and the kitchen and yet they took absolutely no care to notice... I have a simple rule when it comes to tipping. At the VERY MINIMUM, if they are able to keep my water filled, I will leave a tip. They couldn't even do that! And so I did what I rarely do and did not leave a tip.

A week later I check my credit card statement and I see that I was charged $18.51 for a bill that was only $16.26. I am baffled by this. I like to think this was a singular act by a rebellious employee but ON THE RECEIPT it says my waiter was MY TOFU HOUSE. I have all the reason to believe that the restaurant bears all responsibility. Absolutely terrible! Thankfully, I got the chargeback from my credit card company, but this place will forever leave a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Besta W.

description:
Are you in desperate need of the warm, enveloping comfort of a hot meal? Get in here stat. The seating is cozy, with every table in its own little wooden booth. Price point is higher than some Korean (especially vs. South Bay spots) but the quality is so worth it.

The banchan is amazing- the cucumbers and kimchi are perfect, and they serve you a whole fried fish that is super tasty. 

Haemul pajeon is so damn thick, a savory seafood and veggie stuffed pancake with a crispy outside and smooth, custardy texture on the inside. Yes, it's $24 but it's enough for multiple meals.

Bibimbap with mushroom- it's all about that crispy rice on the bottom. Sauce is on point, not like some places at which it doesn't taste fresh. 

You'll spend some hard earned money but leave happy and full. It's everything you want when you're looking for a warm Korean meal.
author: Annabelle V.

description:
My Tofu House is a wonderful choice for Korean Comfort food. 

Their food is always consistently good and tasty. I especially like their Soft Tofu soup with pork or the combination soup. Bibimbap is okay not great so don't expect fantastic.

However prices are pretty good and the setting is warm and cozy if not a little dated.
author: David G.

description: If we had only ordered the tofu soup, this would be a 5 star review. Alas we also ordered the combination pancake and kalbi. The pancake was too cake-like for my taste, and the kalbi lacked flavor. The tofu soup and complimentary fried fish were perfect comfort food for a chilly San Francisco day. A great meal if you stick to the namesake!
author: Marie S.

description:
San Francisco had so many nice Korean restaurant so I honestly don't understand why this place is rated so high. Menu is extremely simple - tofu soup and 4 or 5 types of grilled meat. I was a bit shocked to see that an order of Galbi was $29!! With that price you can go to an All you can eat BBQ place and have unlimited Galbi along with 20 other different kinds of meats. Despite the price, i still ordered it partially out of curiosity to see whether it is superior than other places. I also tried the mushroom tofu soup.

My conclusion is that both dishes were tasty and authentic, but nothing special or memorable. It was the kind of comfort food that I wanted for the moment but I've definitely had better (better variety and value) Korean food elsewhere. If I were to come back, I probably will just stick to the tofu soup and pass on the Galbi as I really can't justify the price!
author: Songyi W.

description:
I'm always very pleased everytime I visit this place. The food quality is excellent. I know that it's very difficult to prepare the Korean food before it's ever cooked up and served so there's a lot of work that goes on before the front doors open. The place is always busy. So you want to plan between meals to drop in and parking in the area is a little challenging. Because it's on Geary Avenue it's very busy in the neighborhood so arrive early to find parking in the area.

If you arrive between meal Russia's like I always plan to arrive, and are lucky enough to find parking nearby, you walk in and tables become available pretty quickly. By the time you finish your meal though if you're headed toward a busy stretch the lines will be deep. But people are usually satisfied watching the game on the big TV on the wall at the entryway. The TV isn't really there for the entire restaurant to view its more to give people that are waiting for a table with something to do while they wait.

The staff is in constant motion because of the amount of people that walked through their doors. So though you may not get that warm friendly feeling when you walk in you know that they're there to take care of you and make sure you get seated and fed right away. So I understand how they have to take care of everyone quickly.

When the food arrives it starts with hot tea that has the toasted rice in it that gives it that special flavor. And on a cold night the food is especially rewarding. The presentation is an array of color and dishes the little appetizer dishes make sure of that. The entree arrives steaming and bubbling at your table you're very surprised that it almost looks volcanic if you order the soup. All the dishes there including the meat dishes the presentation is stunning. The flavors are just as I would expect, true flavors.

The food is always plentiful and I understand why it's a little expensive because of the time that it takes to make these specialized dishes. You can order soup meet fish vegetarian or combinations. They are famous for their tofu soups kimchi soups and meat platters.

First busy as it is the staff is still able to be fairly friendly even when crunched. Just remember when you go to this little place that you allow time for parking come between the meals so it's not too busy and have an idea of what Korean food you like so you can order without waiting too long.

THE BUZZ: 

Parking - It can be tricky, busy neighborhood
Greeted/Seated - Very busy took a minute
Atmosphere/Décor - Simple pine Asian look
Service - Fast and friendly though hurried
Cleanliness - Constantly clearing tables for the rush
Menu Selection - Only a couple pictures to show the many Korean delights
Vegan - Several veggie dishes offered
Presentation/Portion - Love the way it looks on the table great eye appeal
Outdoor/Patio - None
Take out - Yes
Unique Feature - Zagat rated and high marks from many reviewers posted
Kid Friendly - Yes
Pet Friendly - No
Music/Live Music - Not that I could hear
TV - On in table waiting area
Dress -  Casual
Value - A bit expensive but worth it
Cash/Credit - Yes
Handicapped Friendly - Yes
author: Thomas B.

description: The best tofu soup! I always get the tofu soup with oysters, spicy. Super filling, comforting and delicious!
author: Kara N.

description:
Came here for lunch one day and there was no wait! I was really craving some tofu soup and thought where else but tofu house! The decor inside is what comes to mind when I hear the name tofu house haha

My friend and I decided to split the Combo Tofu Soup, Seafood Pancake, and and order of Galbi. Of course, the first thing that came out were the banchan (the fish cake was my favorite), and everything came after. Everything was super tasty, but it was just extremely pricey compared to places nearby, and the service was just mediocre.

Overall, I'd probably come back if i was in the neighborhood, but otherwise I'd venture to a more affordable spot.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Brought my parents out for dinner and my mom was really looking forward to it because she heard a lot of good things. 

Atmosphere. 4.5/5
Nice and cozy. There are a few booths to side in and it really feels like a "family meal" kind of vibe. Perfect for going out with my parents 

Menu: 4/5 
Very limited amount of options. But I mean its called tofu house so their specialty is tofu stew so I'm not really complaining. Prices though? Expensive in my opinion. Especially for the meat and the portions they give :-((

We got the kalbi $27 (pictures with my review). Very well marinated and smoky the way my parents and I like it. But $27 for that amount? As tasty as it was, i honestly don't think I'll be getting it again. 

We also got the kimchi and combination tofu soup. Really good but would definitely prefer the combination over the kimchi. There was more flavor to it whereas kimchi was just straight up kimchi and we got beef in it so it got kind of boring for us. Still good though! 

Ban Chan: decent amount and came with a grilled mackerel yuuuum! Kimchi was kind of bland though? Maybe it was just us. 

Service 4.5/5
Everyone was very welcoming and attentive for the most part! 

Would I come back? For tofu soup yes. For everything else? Maybe.
author: Kimberly T.

description: Nice service, and many korean side dishes that we love them. We ordered two tufu soups. Yummy!
author: YoYo Yao Z.

description:
Oh myyyyy, what can I say about My Tofu House that hasn't been already? Hands down the #1 place to get soondobu in the city! A little out of the way (Inner Richmond) but trust - it's worth.

This place holds a dear place in my heart. It's helped me through rainy days, cold days, Sunday evenings after a long weekend, after a long day of studying - a great way to end the day.

I usually get the combination soondubu, mild. I've been to places where they have a hard time grasping what mild means. Here, they master it each time and it's just the perfect amount of kick! I also like to substitute my shrimp for more clams because I'm lazy to peel the shrimp lol but also clams make the soup more flavorful IMO. 

Other things that I have tried - their Kalbi (mmm served sizzling) and variations of their pancakes (seafood pancake is popular). Everything is served in stone pots / grills which makes them SUPER hot. 

They also have amazing banchan and a large variety! The fish is super good. They also have free refills hehe.

This place is definitely on the pricier side for Korean just as a warning, but if you live in SF, you know there isn't legit Korean restaurants out here. So yes, it's worth it!
author: Vickie Z.

description: Used to go here regularly but after today, I will no longer come here, as I walked in servers did not greet us, so we just stood awkwardly in the front door, 2 servers just looked at us.  I am to old to play these kinds of games, to me its a sign of understaffed so dont come here, not afraid to walk out so my familu just instantly walked out and went elsewhere.
author: Leon L.

description:
This restaurant is a great place to satisfy your Korean-tofu-soup cravings.  The menu is rather limited, in my opinion, but there are the classics that you would expect to be paired with a bowl of hot, sizzling tofu soup.  Do not come here expecting to cook some raw beef on a shared grill.  The routine is rather ritualistic for me (and it seems to be with other tables I usually see around me).  I shall explain further below.

I typically order a bowl of tofu soup and a plate of beef short ribs (kalbi) to be shared with me and another person.  That's it!  And that's all you need because the restaurant will provide you with banchan, which is a variety of small dishes such as kimchi, fish cakes, bean sprouts, and much more.  Moreover, the server will also bring you rice prepared in a stone pot that fills three individual bowls.  The server will empty the pot before you and pour fresh tea into it, which will turn into porridge later!  

The food all comes out fresh:  the soup is still boiling, and the kalbi is still sizzling on its iron skillet.  I love how they give you a raw egg to crack into your soup.  Do not make the mistake I've once made by asking for an extra egg to add to the soup; two raw eggs in your tofu soup will make your soup tastes like nothing but eggs.  The soup is piping hot, so don't sip on it right away.  I tend to scoop spoonfuls of soup onto my rice as I wait for it to cool down.  The beef is always tender and never overcooked.  

There can be substantial waits during lunch and dinner times.  But when you order--the food comes extremely fast!  The staff is very attentive.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
I really love this place because of how classic socal tofu house it is. They give you fish, tofu soup, and the burnt rice soup thing (the water they pour into the stone pot after scooping out the rice is for you to eat!!).

Only weird thing is that they put mushrooms in it, so I just ask them to take that out. Also seating is pretty limited so be prepared to wait at least 20 minutes.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Normally would not write a review but felt compelled to inform other people who plan to go to My Tofu House. So let's start with the food.  

The food is "ok" but nothing to rave about.  And for the prices they charge which totaled a $154 for 4 people was way too high for just "ok" food.  Now let me talk about the service.

Tables were available because my family arrived early on a weekday and we were seated right away.  But the server gave us a "stare" when we asked for a high chair for my 17 month old son which was a sign that the service was not going to be good.

Food came within a reasonable amount of time (which was a credit to the kitchen not the servers).  But when I requested an extra bowl of rice, the server came back and practically threw the bowl at me!  I knew we were heading towards the point of no return at that point.

This was a birthday dinner and we asked the server to clean the table so we could have space to serve the birthday cake.  That was not an unreasonable request but the server refused and indicated he was too busy.  Really?

I have been to this restaurant on a few occasions and never recalled having this kind of experience.  But this will definitely be my last visit here.  There are other Korean restaurants more deserving of your business!
author: Steven W.

description: Been here a week back on date. It's very hard to find parking since the street it is on has a lot of restaurants and there is only street parking available. It's a decent sized joint, not very fancy but you can get your own booth for privacy. It's a limited menu but has everything that Korean cuisine has to offer. I ordered a chicken Bibimbap that was perfect. There's hot tea served and they make sure it's refilled regularly. Overall a satisfying experience.
author: Man0 P.

description:
This place has definitely above average sundubu's on their menu, and their panchan is similarly superior to most tofu/bbq spots I've had in the city. 

Menu is maybe a bit on the limited side, with a rather pricey list of pancakes (I think all $20+) vs some spots that will even throw in a seafood pancake for free! (Although these places are exceedingly rare and found certainly out of the city more like Santa Clara).
author: Sam R.

description: Good Korean food with generous portion! delicious side dishes but the service is always lacking.
author: Souris L.

description:
Great authentic (as far as this Puerto Rican girl knows) Korean spot!
Service was fast and perfunctionary and the food was pretty good.  I got the vegetable bibimbap which was pretty good but not the best I've ever had and all the apps were great.  My friend said that these guys are known for their tofu soup so that's what I'd get if I find myself here again.  Really seems like a nice neighborhood spot.
author: Allana D.

description:
Solid Korean restaurant for soft tofu stew. My boyfriend and I came here for a Friday night dinner around 8 PM and were seated in ~15 minutes.

We both ordered the dumpling soft tofu stew (mild and a non-spicy). We considered ordering a pancake too, just in case we wouldn't be full, but it is $$... all their pancakes cost $23, even the seafood vs vegetable pancake. Luckily our food came with a plethora of side dishes, including a plate of kimchi and two pan fried fish. A large stone bowl of rice is also included. 

As for the dumpling soft tofu stew, it was good but not great. It lacks a heartiness and flavor (in comparison to my favorite soft tofu stew in Berkeley.) There was a good balance of dumplings, rice cake, beef and tofu - though I think there should definitely be more rice cakes (there were only 3!) and beef. Also, as other Yelpers mentioned, the spice levels here are lower - my mild was not even spicy to me, and I have low tolerance for spice. The side dishes also were low on the spice level. 

Last thing to note is the rice in the stone bowl. When the server brings it to the table, he/she will scoop out bowls of rice, then fill the stone bowl with the rest of the rice with tea. According to a server, this is like a refreshing tea/rice soup that some Koreans like to eat after their meal as a way to calm their taste buds after all the spice of the meal. I thought this was cool!
author: Christine L.

description: The front facade is very unassuming.  We were seated very quickly at 3ish in the afternoon on Sunday.  You walk in and you think the restaurant used to be an old gyukaku place.  There are vents above every seating. The food was good, the service was good.  We had the original tofu soup mild.  Delicious and much needed warm soup for this cool weather here in sf.  It's good old fashion Korean hot soup perfect for cool weather.  I feel like the booths could use an upgrade as the seats were cracking etc.  Friendly service and good food.
author: Puna C.

description: Great food!!! Practiced my korean with the kind waiter haha. Highly Recommend the kalbi pork ribs. Wouldn't recommend the seafood pancake. The complimentary fish and small dishes are so yum
author: Alicia Xiaorong Z.

description:
My Tofu House serves up some very tasty Korean food. As with all Korean places, this restaurant provides delicious side dishes to go with the mains. With a name like Tofu House, you'd think we'd go there and get some tofu. Well, that wasn't the case. We did, however, go for the a BBQ dish and two bibimbab dinner plates.

I'd have to say first that My Tofu House is a bit more expensive than your average Korean restaurant (which is already a little more than your standard eatery). So expect to pay around $20 per person at around dinner time. Lunch prices are more moderate, however.

I had a craving for some BBQ so I chose to order the Kal Bi, a Korean short rib dish (on bone, of course). It was probably the most expensive item on the menu at $27, but YOLO I guess! The meat was very delicious with a pretty generous portion on short ribs on a bed of cooked onions. I really enjoyed the dish, but sadly when you order this... it's all you get aside from the appetizers and a bowl of rice. It's a meat lovers go-to for sure though.

We were celebrating my moms birthday and she had the pork bibimbab. My wife went with the beef variation. The dishes were pretty similar and came packed with rice, veggies, and other fixin's. These dishes also had a little bit of heat to them... but not too much. If you like it hot, these wouldn't do it for you, but they were perfect for my mom and wife.

I think to really give this restaurant a fair shake, the next time I come I'll have to go for one of the tofu soups. I mean... why go to tofu house if not to get some tofu?

Overall Tofu House is a solid Korean restaurant that sits a little on the more expensive side of things. The food is very good and the atmosphere is clean and welcoming. This is definitely a worthy choice if you're hankering for some Korean food in the city.
author: Luke C.

description:
Love this place. Portions were kinda big.  Definitely brought home some leftovers,  with ordering 3 entrees amongst 2 people. The Seafood Pancake was frikin amazing along with the Tofu Stew. BiBimBap was also good, but nothing tooo special. 
Prices are stupid high for Korean, kinda worth it though.
author: Natasha G.

description: My tofu house is a great spot to go to for those cold rainy days. I always opt for the dumpling tofu stew in medium spicy. It's not spicy at all but has a great kick to it. Anything less than medium spicy is a little too bland for my taste. The Kalbi here is really tender and the serving size is very generous. You can also get your free refills on the small dishes they provide for you. You usually get cucumbers, fish cakes, bean sprouts, kimchi and their Crocker fish dish. Sadly, tonight, the lady did not give us our Crocker fishes. My boyfriend was pretty upset because that's his favorite side dish. The lady also seemed pretty rude and gave my boyfriend a stank eye. The male server, on the other hand, is very jovial and attentive. If it wasn't for the shady service from the lady, this place would definitely be a solid 4 stars.
author: Ada H.

description:
Ban chan: Fish cakes are bomb! They give each person a grilled mackerel. Kimchi was fresh and delicious too.

They do soft tofu right! All the soft tofu stews come at the same price so it opens up a world of possibilities for you. I personally love dumplings so I chose the dumpling soft tofu stew which came with dumplings, rice cakes, and beef. All the tofu stews come with a raw egg for you to crack it in yourself. You also get rice and if you are in a large party, they will give you a big stone pot of rice to share instead. You can customize the level of spiciness for your soft tofu. Medium gives it the best spicy kick and is my recommended choice. Mild is actually quite bland and my friend had to flavor hers with some kimchi sauce to give it some spiciness. 

The seafood pancake is huge and definitely meant to be shared amongst your group. Their pancake was almost like a deep dish pizza with how thick it was. Since it wasn't a thin pizza, it wasn't crispy all the way through and had a doughy center with the seafood ingredients. I didn't particularly like it since I like my pancakes thin. 

Price-wise, it's more expensive than average and it can probably end up being $15-20 per person. Although their menu offers bulgogi and bibimbap as well, I would only come here solely just for soft tofu. After all, that's what they are named and known for. They do not take reservations and you can put your name down on the waitlist when you arrive. The place does get packed but the wait isn't too terrible. Very home-y atmosphere and with their booth seating, you get a great sense of privacy.
author: Diana C.

description:
You know a man like me loves tofu and this place packs it into the soups. The soups were just the right amount of spice and flavor and definitely recommend the combo (shrimp clams and tofu). All of the meats we got were very tender and fresh and were served on hot plates with onions underneath. Veggie pancake stayed crispy and warm throughout the station of the meal 10/10.

Friend who is picky about Korean approves and said it is their new go to spot in SF. Really fit my vibes on a foggy night. Great for sharing plates family style. 

All of the seating is really cozy and the staff were all friendly. Got there at 7 on a Saturday and waited for half an hour to get a table. The waiters didn't come around and refill our sides, but it was ok because we had plenty of food.

Vibes: 4.5/5
Service: 4.5/5
Food: 5/5
author: Bito M.

description:
I used to come here yearsssss ago, but haven't been in at least 5 years. But I went last night and omg I forgot how good it was!! I've had soft tofu soup in many other places but there is just something about this place that makes me feel happy. 

I've tried about half of the soft tofu soups here and they are all delicious. I always feel stuffed and happy when I walk out of this place. The side dishes are ALWAYS fresh. I think they have the best variation of side dishes. The rice pot is also fun because they put their tea in the pot after they scoop out the rice for you. Save room in your stomach so you can have some of that after your meal! It's nice to wash down your meal with some of that rice tea mixture. 

I feel like parking can be difficult since it's located on Geary but you just have to be lucky ;) 

Now that I've revisit this place... it's going to be my go-to!
author: Joyce S.

description:
Love their kimchi tofu soup with medium spice and kalbi! I didn't taste any spice when I had the mild for the tofu soup, but medium always has just the right amount of kick for me. The kimchi tofu soup comes with lots of soft tofu, meat of choice (beef or pork- I always choose beef), kimchi and mushrooms. The kalbi is tender and cooked slightly burnt just the way I like it which I can't seem to get at any other korean restaurant in the vicinity. Just make sure you eat the kalbi while it's still hot/warm. I find it isn't as tasty once it cools down. Can't forget all the awesome sides too which also comes with one (sometimes two) delicious croaker fish per person. One of my favorite parts of the meal is drinking the toasted rice tea from the rice clay pot (the waiter scoops the rice out for you then fills the rice pot with slightly leftover rice that's stuck to the pot with tea). The toasted rice tea makes me feel warm and brings me back to my childhood memories. 

All the times I came here they seem to be busy during lunch hour and every night, even during weekdays, but wait times go fairly quickly esp for a small party. Oh, and I can't forget about the service. Despite being very busy, they're attentive & efficient and I can see they work very hard. I make sure to tip well every time!
author: Donna M.

description:
I decided to come because My Tofu House was the #1 most rated Korean restaurant in SF on Yelp! Located just 10 minutes away from the Presidio park, this place has close proximity to Pacifica hiking areas, Sausalito and Point Reyes National Park. So if you are looking for a Korean dinner after a long day of hiking, I recommend My Tofu House. 

Located on the main street of 11th avenue, it is easy to spot, but parking can be challenging, Fortunately, if you go on the weekend, parking is free after 6 pm. Waiting time can be anywhere from 10-15 minutes. The interior design gave us a sense that we were eating in our own home. There is a roof over the top and ledges that separates one table from another to give a sense of privacy. Our table felt homey and cozy. 

The service is swift with refilling your barley tea. If you want water, you have to ask because the barley tea is their default for water. We ordered Korean pancake, soondooboo, and bibimbap. For a college student on budget, this place has a more up-scale price and a little over my budget. But other than that, the portion is filling and the food is a solid five star. The unique thing the server he will add some barley tea to the left over rice in the stone pot. My Korean friend said this is like an after meal dish that is very common in Korea. The taste is bland, but you are supposed to eat it with banchan, korean side dishes. Cool! I learn something new everyday.

Overall, a good pick after a long day of hiking and fulfilling and satisfied meal!
author: Kim H.

description: This is my favorite tofu soup place. Simply the best!  I like spicy food so I order spicy and it's perfect. Not ridiculous spicy where you can't taste the food. The sides are a perfect complement to the soup. They give you a raw egg to crack into your boiling soup when it arrives. Soooo yummy!  Flew here from Hawaii for this. A must have in SF.
author: Jessica E.

description: I recently went here for dinner with two other people. We ate well. Lots of choices in the menu. Because of the name of the restaurant, I thought it was a vegetarian restaurant, with lots of Tofu. Sure, it has tofu, and many kinds of it. Still: it has meats and seafood as well. One thing I really enjoyed was the Korean pancake. This reminded me of a okonomiyaki, at a Japanese restaurant. Maybe a little cakier. All in all, I think this is worth checking out, if you are at all interested in Korean food. Delicous!
author: Jason P.

description:
I've come here time and time again and the quality never disappoints. If you're looking for delicious Korean tofu soup, this is the place!

It is a small restaurant and it does get crowded, so be sure to plan accordingly. There are always tons of Korean families here eating so you know this place is legit!

I've be the first to admit that some of the dishes on the menu come with crazy price tags. Korean pancakes are $23 each, bibimbabs are $17 each, and meat is like $24-$27 each for dinner (lunch is cheaper for meat). I have gotten the pancakes before, which are a splurge, but they the fluffiest and thickest pancakes I've had, full of toppings, so I think you should go for it if you're feeling a pancake! I've also had the meat which is really good, but probably overpriced.

And everything you order comes with a large number of delicious side dishes and grilled fish. They also will refill your side dishes as long as you ask nicely!

But honestly, what you really come here for is the soft tofu soup, which are around $13.99 each. 

I love the combination soft tofu soup and the seafood soft tofu soup, and you can choose the level of spiciness. Each tofu soup comes with a raw egg, which you crack it in when the soup first comes, so it cooks with the soup :) 

The tofu soup is probably my favorite in the entire bay area, and definitely not that expensive if you think about all the sides you are getting.
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
Food = good.

Soon dobu (combo: beef, shrimp & clams) = excellent. The name is no lie. She enjoyed it. $14.98.

Bibimbap with beef = good--he loved and I thought it was boring. Not sure but I thought it was missing something.  $17.98.

Daeji bulgogi = plenty of meat and spicy.  It's a fairly large platter for the price. $23.51.

Banchan = excellent. More fishcake, kimchi & cucumbers please!!

Yes, definitely eat the crispy rice leftover in the large stonepot with the tea. (They pour the hot tea in after serving the portions of rice.) Worth it. 

Service = efficient & mostly friendly. 

Prices = moderate. Dinner for three came out to $61.27. With some leftovers.

Parking = street. Some things never change. Good luck. Bus stops nearby.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Coming from LA, I have pretty high expectations for sundubu (Korean tofu soup). This place was pretty good and I am satisfied.

I ordered the mild dumpling tofu soup which came with dumplings, beef, and rice cakes. Everything tasted great but honestly the mild was a bit too mild and I'm letting you know right now that I CANNOT take any spice (I grew up in the Midwest, sue me). So if you like stuff spicy order one more than what you would normally get.

BUT NOW TO THE REAL GEM OF THIS PLACE: THE SIDES. Okay honestly My Tofu House has some poppin sides. They give you that delicious fried fish, pickled radish, kimchi, spicy fish cake, mung beans, and cucumbers. Literally the only thing that would make this place even more amazing is if they had potato salad. They give a good serving size for two people. We didn't ask for more. 

Keep in mind this place is kinda small so if you go during peak dinner time, you'll be waiting. It also opens at 5 so get there early. 

Note: the parking lot next to the building is for JACK IN THE BOX CUSTOMERS ONLY.
author: Michael L.

description: Spacious, clean, and cozy! Service is fast and friendly. They're quite generous with their size dishes - includes free fried fish! And they have great tofu soups. However, their pricing is a bit on the higher side. $24 ~ $30 for pancakes seems a bit much in my opinion. But since their soup is so good I'd be curious to perhaps share a pancake with friends next time!
author: Mandy H.

description:
Solid korean place specializing in tofu soup in the area. Having lived in socal for a few years, there's plenty of restaurants that serve tofu soup and this place compares. SF isn't known for it's korean food but I know this place will always have my back if I'm craving dumpling tofu soup with all the banchan and rice. 

Expect a wait at peak dinner times since this place is small. And the parking here can be tough. 

Also, there was a huge table of elderly Koreans enjoying tofu soup as well. If your grandparents are eating here it must be legit
author: Carissa G.

description: Appetizers were great - they were probably the highlight. The tofu soup wasn't as flavorful as I was use to but it was pretty good. A little on the pricier side for tofu soup compared to other shops.
author: Liv T.

description:
We came here on a Tuesday shortly after they opened and were seated immediately. I can see how this place can get packed quickly. 

The food/ service was good. I wish they had more banchan to choose from. 

We ordered a little bit of everything off the menu. The seafood pancake was great. The short ribs were alright, portions were a lot smaller than expected. Lastly the tofu soup was pretty good as well. 

Would come here again.
author: Anna C.

description:
My first sign we'd made the right choice for dinner, the place was packed. On a Thursday night at 6:15 and it was standing room only. We were seated almost immediately at the last two top available. The line started behind us, our timing was perfect. 

This place is busy, servers all moving efficiently and the staff are all professional and courteous. Our server greeted us at our table with warm rice tea water (a part of the meal) and took our order. The smells of BBQ and sizzling food lofts through the restaurant.

Traditional Korean Bibimbap, Korean style pancakes, Tofu multiple ways and BBQ are some of the main attractions on the menu, we ordered a chicken Bibimbap and a veggie pancake to share.

The Vegetable pancake was served on a hot stone top plate with a wooden base (sizzling hot) and is more than enough for two to share. About an inch thick and roughly 10-12" across, cut into wedges, golden brown and loaded with cooked veggies, wonderful flavors and a great crunchy texture - reminded me of a quiche of sorts, with great flavor. A little hot chili sauce and you're set!

Our chicken Bibimbap with mixed vegetables, was served in a large hot stone bowl, loaded with golden rice, an assortment of seasonal vegetables and chunks of tender chicken.  Components separate, you mix it all together at your table. The rice had a crunchy edge to it from sizzling against the stone bowl - wonderfully cooked vegetables mixed in a savory Korean style sauce with lots of nicely cooked chicken meat, again more than enough for two or more to share. 

Along with the traditional sticky rice and assorted cold pickled veggies served as a starter (a part of the service), this was a great meal and an excellent choice for our evening. We plan to return again the next time we're in the area.

Dinner for two 45$ + a tip - by San Francisco standards cheap. 

4 stars - a solid traditional style meal. Well worth the effort to try. 

00430
author: Ray F.

description:
Get the tofu here. The bibimbob is above average. The line can be long on weekends but well worth driving across the bridge to eat here. 
The side dishes are also great. 
Next time I want to try the seafood pancake in addition to the tofu dish (this is a must). 
I would give 5 stars except for the parking, which can be difficult to find.
author: Tom C.

description: Love this place. My boyfriend and I always come here when we want tofu soup. We go once or twice a month. Usually we just get the tofu soup, but sometimes we get the seafood pancake as well. I don't have anything negative to say about MTH. Great spot!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Boyfriend and I came in on a Friday night and we managed to get in just before the dinner rush.. Good thing or we would have had to wait at least 40 minutes. We were seated and served a cup of hot tea from the get go. After ordering, the servers shortly brought out the side dishes, which included two fried fish, kimchi, pickled cucumbers, fish cakes, and bean sprouts with sesame oil, along with rice. Side dishes were like a meal in itself!

Seafood tofu soup was pretty good. One of our shrimp had the little eggs in it, which was nice. There were chopped pieces of beef in the soup, which I thought were kinda odd, but everything tasted alright together.

Seafood pancake was surprisingly not as oily as I was expecting, and it was crunchier than I was expecting too. It was a little too dough-y for me and I thought the bell peppers were overpowering, but they put in a decent amount of seafood, which was nice. The clay pan kept the pancake nice n hot throughout our meal too. 

Seafood bibimbap was good. Rice was cooked well (I've had problems with soggy rice at other places), and they didn't skimp out on seafood.

Overall the bill came out to $60 something after tax, which I felt was a little pricey, considering the seafood pancake alone was about $27. The servers were alright, since they were nice when serving our meal and asked us once if we would like more tea, but they were not attentive to us when we ran out of side dishes mid-meal. Maybe because they were too busy? It was an overall good meal but would not come back and wait just to eat here.
author: Bonnie N.

description: Horrible service.  Our fish came and it was very salty and when we complained we were given bad attitudes.  When we asked for more banchan and  had to wait 15 minutes before getting in and of course it also came with the attitude.  Will never come back to this place.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Yum! My Tofu House has some really delicious, comforting food! I visited yesterday, and we waited around 25 minutes to be seated. There is a small waiting area with a few chairs. 

I ordered the spicy tofu soup with mushrooms, and my friend ordered spicy tofu soup with beef. They came with rice and the typical side dishes, all of which were extremely delicious and flavorful. The cucumber salad was my personal favorite! Although we ordered spicy soups, they were not spicy at all. To be fair, we have high spice tolerance, but it would be nice to have a higher level of spice for people who need the extra kick. We added kimchi to add a bit more spice. Still, the food was absolutely delicious. It stayed hot for a long time, and the texture of the tofu was absolutely perfect. 

The service here is a bit slow (most likely due to the fact that it's so crowded). We had to wait a bit to order, and we had to flag down the waiter to get refills for the sides, but it wasn't too bad. I will definitely be returning here soon!
author: Ayushi A.

description:
Pretty typical Korean tofu soup (soon-doo-boo), but they are generous on the side dishes and also serve their rice from a stone pot. (so you can get the crispy rice pieces on the side of the pot)

I like their booth seating as well. Overall a bit pricey but food quality is decent.
author: Joseph L.

description: No croaker, even with 2 entrees and soup seen served to someone that only order 1 soup. Not sure if the waitress had something against me but all in all with restaurant service you should never let your personal behavior  mess with people's food. Deeply disappointed in this restaurant that I've been going to since I was a kid.
author: Timothy C.

description:
This is more of a 4.5 star place. We came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. The place was crowded but we got seated at a booth pretty promptly. That's a big plus considering snaking queues at other good lunch spots. 

We had the beef tofu bowl and the beef bibimbap. 

Beef tofu bowl: so nourishing on a cold day, which it was. The tofu tasted very healthy and the soup was flavoured just right. We went through two bowls of rice with the soup. 

Beef bibimbap: a little pricey at $18, but on point and delicious. I loved that it was traditional style with a yolk sitting on top the stone bowl (my last encounter with bibimbap was a sunny side up on top of the ingredients - so wrong). 

Special mention: the meal came with Korean side-dishes and the kimchi was awesome. The cabbage is not as sour or tough as other restaurants.
author: Lindt C.

description: The heat can vary, but the flavors are always good. Korean places are definitely pricey and this one is ok....if you go for meat dishes yes it's expensive, but if you come here for the tofu soup then you're at the right spot. Yeah, service isn't the greatest and you almost always have to flag them down, but it's not a surprise to me in my book, that's how the culture operates. If you need anything you simply have to ask. We usually come on cold days to warm the soul back up, and I recommend that you do the same!
author: Guisela L.

description:
Food: I tried the combination tofu soup, pork bibimbap and the seafood pancake. Overall, I think each meal seems to lack meat. My tofu soup only had a few tiny bits of beef, clams, and 2 pieces of shrimp. I expected the pork bibimbap to actually have bigger pieces of pork but am quite disappointed. I did like the fried fish that came out as a banchan. 

Service: Not the best. They served us the food slowly and basically never came back. I was surprised at how they came out with two large stone pots of rice, served the rice and just left the stone pots there even when there was nothing left. Isn't it common courtesy when you see that the table is so full, to offer to remove some empty dishes? They also did not refill our banchans.  

Overall, I wish I could like this place because other reviews seemed so promising. But for the price of each item, I am not satisfied with my experience here.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Service - Good. Employees seem more thrilled about you leaving ("Bye! Thank you so much!!") vs. when you enter ("How many? Ok...").

Interior - Warm, cozy, and filled with booths. It has the smell of a tofu house but you don't leave smelling like it. 

Banchan - Solid dishes included fish cake, string beans, bean sprouts, and...potato? None of them are spicy.

Pickled cucumber - Excellent. Had to ask for seconds.

Kimchi - Not spicy, flavorful, salty. Add it to your non-spicy tofu pot for a burst of flavor.

Fried Yellow Croaker - Surprisingly warm, steaming, soft, delicate, and easy to eat. Most of the bones are chewy and can be swallowed.

Assorted Mushroom Tofu Pot - Not spicy, filled with mushrooms, and not overly stuffed with tofu.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Went for lunch and I think it's totally worth it (~$35 for 2). There's no BCD Tofu House in SF, so this is a great alternative.

Banchan (side dishes): very decently sized and we were given each a grilled makerel, yum.

Soondooboo: I got the mild and my friend got the extra spicy. The mild one is super mild and suitable if you just want a little kick of spiciness. The extra spicy is way too spicy. I like the taste here, not msg-based and tasted very homie. 

Went for a late lunch so no wait at all. Definitely will come back.
author: Connie T.

description:
After 10 years and over 50 visits, My Tofu House continues to rock.

It appears that my relationship with My Tofu House has outlasted many others. (Not only with restaurants but also with people. Hmm...)

Well you can't go wrong with consistently, wallet-friendly, Korean mama approved, comfort food. 

NOTHING. BUT. LOVE.

https://youtu.be/VJEbfeG2oAE?t=38s
author: Amy C.

description: Great food, service very good and good price point. It's a solid place to take the family.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Hands down the best soondubu jjigae (SOFT TOFU SOUP) in the city! I've been a fan for the past five years and hope their soup never loses its signature taste! There are so many kinds of tofu soup to choose from-- my favorites are the combination and mandoo tofu soups. All of their tofu soups come with a raw egg that you can crack into the deliciously bubbling mini stone pots. Either let them simmer or mix it to your heart's content. Just don't drop the egg in, expecting it to hard boil 

I always expect at least a 30 minute wait during peak hours, but the tofu soup here is definitely worth it. Also, their banchan game is really strong. I'm a big fan of their fried fish and fish cake. 

The servers can be a little preoccupied in this bustling restaurant but are always happy to help once you get their attention. The assorted fruit hard candy they give you at the end of the meal with the bill is a nice touch.
author: Brian L.

description:
It's pretty good despite the fact that it's overpriced. Banchan is average; nothing special but it ain't bad. Both the kalbi and bulgogi are super flavorful. The meats are what kills on the bill though. Of course, the tofu soup is the favorite. Note to self: stick with what's in the name. Also, spicyness is on the lower end of the spectrum, so if you like spice, up your ante.

Good service which I really appreciate! Wait can be long for dinner.
author: Denise L.

description:
My Tofu House was awesome!

We were seated immediately on a Monday evening and the service was quite fast. You need to ask for iced water because otherwise their default is tea. 

I got the spicy original tofu soup with beef (my bf got chicken) ($13). So yummy! The sides were delicious as well. The pot of rice is quite big so that was plentiful, so probably not necessary to order additional rice for most. We also got an order of the bulgoki ($25 for dinner price). The portion was enough to feed the two of us and we even had a lot of leftovers. My bf was absolutely in love with the quality. I'm not a huge fan of bugolki in geneal but this one was good and I'd eat it again. 

I'm definitely not used to these prices (I'm from SoCal) but I think the quality is great and worth going to. I think the waiters could've checked on us (they didn't stop by after we received our food), but they were nice and easy to flag down. Overall a great lunch or dinner spot!
author: Kay H.

description:
My Tofu House.

Find me there almost (every) Sunday! It's become a ritual for our friends to end our week at MTH with sundubu and short ribs. Is it the best I ever had? Definitely not. Is it the best I'll ever find in San Francisco? Most definitely. If you come here after 7pm on any night, there is always a line! It's crazy. But people will wait the wait because there is just something so damn comforting about this restaurant. Maybe it's the yummy ban chans? Maybe it's the subpar service? Maybe it's the slightly high prices? Or maybe it's part of their weekly ritual, too.
author: Stephanie B.

description: 3.5 Stars. Bonchon dishes are delicious! Since they are called "My Tofu House", I would definitely recommend getting one of their tofu soups. That's probably their specialty. The bibimbap was alright, but it tasted a little weird to me. They do give you a lot of food in the bibimbap.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Lines can be long so be prepared.
Simple menu in terms of primary offerings which include Meat, Tofu Soup, Pancake, and Bibimbap. Within these 4 entrees there are multiple options which can include meat, seafood or vegetable. Sides or Banchan are served along with rice so the meal is hearty. Extra sides when requested and gladly served. The sides alone are a meal from the fish (yes, fish) to the kimchee, cucumber, bean sprouts, daikon, and fish cake. All yummy, yummy 
No disappointment tonite as the food is tasty, hot, and gut busting filling.
Saff is friendly, efficient, and accommodating.
This is a solid place for Korean food and well worth the visit.
author: David H.

description:
Have come here once or twice before for lunch, and quality has been great and consistent, especially on my most recent visit.  It starts off with the Banchan, an assortment of small plates of cool refreshing vegetables, which they do well in serving.  Big fan of the assortment and taste of each one.  For the main, I had the vegetable and beef bibimbap, which was all served in a great big sizzling hot stone.  After stirring up the ingredients -- all while everything is still very warm and sizzling inside -- it is so good.  There's a decent amount of spice which I like as well, and some of the rice gets crispy as it sits in the stone; great taste and texture overall.  The portion was pretty sizable as well. I'm convinced bibimbap can only be good in the hot stone.  Also had some of the Dak (chicken) as well, and it was very tasty as well.  

The waitresses were nice and accommodating, although there were only two of them to handle the lunch crowd.  And while the inside isn't super large, it's definitely comfortable to sit inside.  Price for lunch may have been a little high ($40 for two people), but it was well worth.
author: Jarrod Y.

description:
I'm very fond of sundubu (soondubu? did I spell that right?) and most of the menu is dedicated to tofu soup, so that is pretty much the only thing I have ever tried here. It comes bubbling hot in an earthenware pot. You can choose your level of spice, which is not as spicy compared to a lot of Korean restaurants. I usually choose mild, because even 'mild' at most Korean restaurants is pretty spicy to me, but here 'medium' is much more suitable for me.

All the tofu soups are around $12. Not a bad price, but not so cheap anymore. But hey, there's always banchan. Here they serve bean sprouts, seasoned cucumber, kimchi, fried tofu skin, spicy winter melon, fried fish, and raw eggs to crack into your soup. Is it just me or did there use to be more variety with their side dishes?
They're all pretty good. The silky tofu falls apart and absorbs the flavors of the soup. 

I've tried the...
Original - w/ mushrooms, beef or pork or chicken:
I'd say choose beef if you're picking a protein, because it gives the soup the most flavor. 

Seafood - w/ oyster, shrimp & clam:
The seafood is not great. The shrimp are tiny and difficult to eat, and the rest of the shellfish get lost in the soup.

Kimchi - w/ kimchi, mushrooms, beef or pork:
The kimchi loses its distinguishing kimchi traits as the seasoning washes off the cabbage leaves and seep directly into the soup.

Dumpling - w/ dumpling, rice cake, beef
My favorite of the bunch, because it's very filling. The dumplings are not bad, pretty meaty and the skin is very soft. Sometimes I dip a spoonful of rice into the soup to give it flavor, but I usually can't finish the rice after I eat all the dumplings.

If you are interested in trying one of the BBQ dishes, come for lunch, because the dinner price is nearly double the cost, and I don't really think it's worth it.

Service is very good. I respect all the servers carrying around piping hot dishes and carrying out all those tiny banchan plates.

Sometimes there is a wait for the dinner crowd. I'm a little surprised. It's quite good, but not quite good enough to warrant a line. There is a good amount of seats with a lot of booth-style tables and some sectioned-off cubical-style tables. In the back, there is a separate small dining room with more tables. If you're in the neighborhood, it's a good option to get some food to warm you up.
author: Joy W.

description:
I like Tofu Soup. It's nice warm and fills you up on a cold day. We drove out here after our show at the Orpheum for an early dinner. We lucked out and got parking off the street right next to it. We walked in, there was barely anyone in there but then again we were there kind of early for dinner!

The staff was courteous. Now...was the meal very memorable? Yes because I was with the bf, but other than that, I don't think anything in particular stood out to me about their tofu soup. They did give you a ton of rice even though we only ordered one soup. I was stuffed with soup and rice by the end :)
author: Carolen M.

description: I love this place!  I keep coming back especially on a cold night!  The line seems to be shorter around 5:30-6:00 on weeknights.
author: M Y.

description: Honestly, it was pretty decent. Well made seafood pancake (crispy outside, ample amounts of seafood mixed in), tender kalbi, and flavorful soonduboo. My only reservation was that my "mild" soft tofu stew was not spicy at all and we had some trouble getting refills on our water. I'd still come back and just be sure that I go for the "spicy" stews.
author: Cici T.

description: Love this place so much. When we lived in SF, we come here a lot. Now we move out of the city but still find time to visit here. The fired fish is great side dish that I have never seen other Korean place has it. So special for me.
author: Paweena L.

description:
They say home is where the heart is...and my heart is in My Tofu House.

My Tofu House will give you warm fuzzy feelings. It's perfect for the cold weather or if you're just craving for some super delicious Korean food. 

I always order the Kimchi Tofu soup with beef and mild spice. Even though I'm a weak sauce with spicy food, their spice is not too strong. I've also ordered the bulgogi. The dishes come with delicious side dishes, such as kimchi, pickled cucumbers, and spicy fishcake (to name a few). 

I love that their tofu soup is engulfed with tofu and the broth is well flavored. The bulgogi is also tasty and juicy. Service is fast and attentive and with reasonable prices! 

A simple restaurant, but simplicity at its best! This is definitely one of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city.
author: Kristal D.

description: Came in during lunch, it seemed pretty busy but we didn't wait too long for a table. It was a chilly day in SF and so I initially wanted some soft tofu soup, but ended up getting the mushroom veggie beef bibimbap. To my dismay, it was sort of a disappointment. It had a lot of ingredients but the flavors didn't shine through, even the beef was a bit bland. It really wasn't bad at all, but at that moment, I did wish I ordered tofu soup instead. No complaints about the service. Our server was polite and very efficient. Not the cheapest Korean joint but not the most expensive either.
author: Heather S.

description:
I went here with 2 friends.
We ordered #1, 2 of #4.
All of them are great!!
The service is a little bit slow, but it's worth it!! :)
author: Candice L.

description:
When it's cold and rainy outside, just head over to My Tofu House for some outrageous comfort food that's sure to warm your tummy and soul. (wow was that overly dramatic or what?)

No but really - when all those little banchan start appearing on your table in preparation for your future engorgement you can't help but get a little giddy.

If you come here, you've gotta try their Kalbi. It comes steaming hot on a sizzling hot plate with the best sizzling beef smell. Tender, juicy, sweet, and with just the right amount of smokiness from the grill - the Kalbi here is a definite can't miss.

The Kimchi Soft Tofu was good - it didn't really stand out versus other Korean places in town with similar offerings. I'll probably try the Dumpling Soft Tofu next time though..
author: Henry W.

description: Always has been one of my favorite places for tofu soup in the city. There's usually a line so be prepared for that, but the waiting time is reasonable (although the space is tiny so you might end up waiting outside). They are very generous with the banchan, particularly because everyone at the table gets a fried fish in addition to the shared portions on the table. The soondubu itself is delicious. The spice levels are on the milder side, but the stew has more than enough flavor and ingredients to help you savor every spoonful. I like that they have quite a few varieties of tofu soup to choose from, and they're all priced the same. The rice is mixed grain and steamed with peas, so that was really nice as well.
author: Tony D.

description:
My Tofu House is comfort food at its finest. When I went, it was cold and raining so I think that shot up my expectations for this place.  I wanted something hot and the soondubu here was steaming. Literally, the stone pot kept the soup bubbling for a good 5 minutes after the waitress put it in front of me.  There's many iterations of the soup but I got mine with dumplings, which was good but I'm going to stick with my classic order and do the mix of seafood and beef next time. 

As with all Korean establishments, the banchan is what really makes or breaks the experience for me. I'm happy to report back this place does it quite well.  The fried fish is addicting but can be dangerous to eat. I found myself getting a few bones stuck in my teeth and gums during the process. I should point out that this is no fault of the restaurant and is purely me being an over-efficient eater who likes to leave nothing behind. 

My only gripe is that we came and there were 3-4 tables empty as diners before us had left. However, they weren't cleaned right away and we had to wait.  They only proceeded to clean those tables when additional parties came in after us so they could seat everyone at the same time. That was a minor annoyance but the soondubu warmed my heart and I'll let it go this time.
author: Quoc N.

description:
In all honestly this wasn't our first choice for dinner. The original Korean place I wanted to go to was almost a 2 hour wait. So this was our 2nd choice, ok maybe 3rd....

While it was a little busy we didn't have to wait too long for a table. Staff was attentive and our food came out in a timely manner. Let's all be real, Korean Banchan matters!!! If a Korean joint doesn't have quality, tasty banchan it shouldn't qualify as an authentic Korean restaurant. My Tofu House's banchan was meh to say the least. Banchan was good but variety was lacking. 

We ordered: kimchi soft tofu with pork - ordered medium spicy, but it wasn't spicy at all!
Bulgolgi - hmmmm ribeye was sliced perfectly and it was marinated nicely.
Seafood combo pancake - Fried to perfection!! easily the star of the night. 

The menu didn't have some of my favorites: missing japchae and duk boki. But nonetheless service and food were OK. I'd come back again if my other 2 Korean joints are packed =T
author: Caye Q.

description:
I've been coming here for over a decade and an truly say that the service has never been worse. 

I can understand if you're busy but if you have time to bring me my check to rush me out w/ the restaurant half full, you certainly have time to get me the kimchi I requested and waited patiently for over 10 mins for. What I also find perplexing is the fact that one of the girls asked how many bowls of rice I want when I have the stone pot. Don't ever tell them 1 because they will repo the other bowl yet leave the stone pot sitting there mocking you. 

This is not based on a singular experience, rather a culmination of the last several experiences throughout the year.
author: Julie L.

description: DO NOT ORDER the pancake. It was hard and thick. Such a waste of money. Customer service is mediocre. The dishes lack in seasoning. I have not tried the tofu soup as I'm not a fan, but my friend who ordered it said it was good. Maybe since they're called My Tofu House, they should stick with just tofu soup as the other korean dishes we tried was a disappointment.
author: Lo L.

description:
Still in the search for a decent Korean place in the city. This place had decent reviews, was popular, and seemed pretty legit, but it was a let down :(

There is a small parking lot by the side of the restaurant, which is useful. I came on a Sunday evening and put my name down on a list inside. 

First, I was surprised at the prices: 
$14 for soup (this one's fine), $18 for bibimbap, $27 for galbi or bulgogi. And this isn't in fidi. it's in Richmond 

Most of us ordered the soup (in varying spicy levels). They brought us tea, and after asking two or three times, they also brought us cold water. The side dishes are mostly very basic: radish kimchi, kimchi, fish cakes, bean sprouts, cucumbers, and (this was nice) fried fish. They served us rice from a large stone pot for the table. Refills for the side dishes had to be requested two or three times each to actually get someone to do it. So, service? not too great, but not rude.

The tofu soup, which I assume would be their specialty, came in rather small stone bowls and they brought us eggs to crack in to them. A strange ingredient that I found in all of our soups was mushroom. Other than that the ingredients in the tofu soup seemed pretty good and had a good ratio to the soup. But what's tofu soup with out the good rich flavor of the soup??
Their soup had nothing. It was red and looked like it should have a lot of flavor, but it wasn't spicy, it didn't taste like any broth, and was very, very bland. 

Do I most likely have high standards having grown up in Korea and then near LA Koreatown? maybe. Did this soup lack flavor and goodness beyond subjective bias? probably.
author: Grace P.

description:
Great place for traditional Korean food. Comes with side dishes you can refill on, and each person gets 1 fried fish. You get complimentary hot tea and rice if you order the tofu soups. The staff are very friendly and service was prompt.  Price did raise but it's still worth it.

If you're vegan, you can order the vegetable tofu soup. Vegan bf got it spicy and loved it (he loves spicy and has a high tolerance) since the flavor was good and was actually spicy enough. There was a good amount of tofu and vegetables in it. He added a bit of rice and was full off of it. 

I ordered the combination tofu soup (shrimp, beef, clams) mild and it was just the perfect amount of spice. I added in 2 eggs which brought out the flavor in the soup. It was creamy and I didn't even need to add rice in to be full. Generous amount of clams and tofu, 2 shrimps in it. 

Overall, a great place to come get some fantastic Korean food at a decent price.
author: Sharon L.

description:
I feel bad for the waiters. They do everything there. From being the host and calling customers in, doing their actual waiter job, and then bussing the tables. On a busy Saturday night, they had only two waiters taking care of there place. They had one more who as far as I could tell was responsible for bringing out there side dishes and taking care of there checks. This waiter abuse is likely part of the reason why the wait can be soo long. Sooooo long. 

The foods is not bad. A bit expensive for the quality of food. Their pancakes are $23 which I feel like most of my Korean friends would laugh at new for paying.
author: Rich L.

description:
Great korean tofu house

Damn I can see why this place is so popular. It's not exactly in the downtown area but when we got there it was packed and we had to wait.

The food here is excellent. You get a free "fried fish" at the beginning as a starter, and the Banchan (starter dishes) had a lot of variety and all tasted fresh. They even refill it for you constantly. Nice!

The tofu stew was excellent, as was the stone bowl bibimbap. For the tofu stew, they serve the rice to you in a large stone bowl, and the staff scoops out the rice from the stone bowl once they bring it to your table. After that they put some sweet water in it and cover it, so that when you are finished with the tofu stew you can eat the rice "stew" at the end as a desert. Pretty authentic korean stuff :)

Definitely the go-to place for korean tofu stew
author: Henry L.

description: For the price point, this spot is a gem for those tofu soup cravings. The banchan is very basic, with the exception of the croaker. I always order an additional croaker because I can't really find them offered at many other places. As far as heat goes, I generally cannot go very spicy (mild or none everywhere else) but medium is perfect here. You can't beat this for comfort food to warm your soul on a rainy day.
author: Anna Z.

description: Absolutely loved the kimchi tofu soup! The bimbap was definitely more rice heavy but overall the food quality was great!
author: Maham K.

description:
This is where I will go from now on when I get those cravings for BCD (although it's not as cheap as BCD). ~$13 per order. 

Side dishes: I think this place has some of the best banchan I've ever had. They all seemed so fresh. Fishcake, kimchi, fried fish, bean sprouts, radish, and cucumbers. The cucumber was sliced thicker than most places I've been and the cool crunch it produced just paired so well with the hot tofu soup. 

Dumpling/rice cake tofu soup: Their tofu soups are legit and the perfect comfort food. There's just something about watching that little pot bubble as you crack an egg into it. 

I almost came back here the next day. It was that good.
author: Jen P.

description:
We arrived at the restaurant less than 10 min before closing and they still served us with a party of three.  

After taking our order the food came out in less than 5 minutes, hot and fresh, with friendly service.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant and will visit again the next time I'm in the area. 

I accidentally left my credit card at the table and left the restaurant and was about the drive away when the server came running out to bring my credit card.  Outstanding service!
author: Jack J.

description: It has been many years since i've been to this place. Came here with my brother on tuesday night to catch up. There wasnt a wait when we came in so we got table right away but had to wait a little for the waiters to get our orders since theres only 2 workers that does the order, clean up, and bring out food. Theres always a table being taken up once someone leave. Had the Combination soft tofu, mild for $13.38: comes with rice and side dishes. They bring out rice in clay pot and then serve the rice in the rice bowl. Its kinda pricy for a tofu soup but i guess the the side dishes makes up for it. Although i got mild combination tofu soup, i felt that it want enough flavor. The mild flavor just gave a tiny extra flavor but wasnt enough. Anyways, all the food that i had was enough to get me food
author: Julie N.

description: This place used to be good but my recent visit makes me wonder what happened to the business.  The food was not up to par and the Korean seafood pancake ($28) came out gross and not Korean style at all.  I didn't enjoy my tofu soup ($15) and the service really sucked. I will never come back to this joint and am very disappointed to see this restaurant go down hill.
author: Mary W.

description: One of my favorite places to go and have sundubu-jjigae! BEST! I would go really often with my girl friends when we are craving something soupy. They have a lot of side dishes too and well.. who doesn't like a good hot soup with the weather in SF? I do!
author: Lingling M.

description: Yummy soon du bu in the city! It looked like they also had a lot of other options like bulgogi, bibimbap and seafood pancake. Service was a bit slow, but the food kept us nice and warm on a rainy night.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Ok, I have had soon tofu everywhere, in so-cal i.e.. BCD Tofu House, various Koreans restaurants in LA.. a lot in SF (Han Kwan) and I have to say although it's pricey, it's probably to best soon tofu I've had so far. I usually go with the Combination soon tofu and it has a much more savory taste then most other places. You have this after taste that makes you crave more. The tofu is really soft to the taste and melts in your mouth, highly recommend this place..
author: Richard K.

description:
Before you commit to the wait here do look into other Korean restaurant options.
.
Service is good and their ban-chan comes with a fried fish for everyone in our group. And, when our ban-chan ran low, refills were offered.  
.
Note: soft tofu comes with a fresh egg on the side. 
.
For $13.38 The Seafood Soft Tofu arrived bubbling hot like molten lava but was lacking in seafood variety and the medium spicy was quite mild. The one large shrimp and two small ones in it came full body.
.
For $23.50 the Seafood Pancake was not worth the price. Tastes good but is over priced when compared to other neighborhood Korean restaurants.
.
Overall, for what they offer, they are a bit expensive but definitely do-able, enjoy...
author: Caesar A.

description: My tofu house's soft tofu stew is very delicious ! I've been coming back here multiple times and I'm impressed by their consistency in quality of their famous soft tofu stew and the kimchi pancake. The portions are also generous and their sides flavorful. The waiting time here is around 30min consistently no matter when I come, it is that popular !
author: Amanda C.

description:
This place serves the best Korean Tofu soup you can find in the city.  All the tofu soups comes with a big cast iron pot of rice.

The menu is quite limited however.  I'd suggest avoiding the meat as the portions are small and quite expensive.  Stick with the Tofu soups and bibimbap.

Also, no alcohol at this place
author: Andy L.

description: I love fish eggs so I had fish egg tofu soup. It was very satisfying! Bulgogi was fine. Bibimbap was a nice choice too.
author: Yeseul S.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant.  I've been going there for years.  The hot soft tofu pot always warms my stomach.  The quality of food has been consistently good for years and the price is reasonable.  The place is always packed among which many are returned customers.

What's  amazing is that the young owner seems to remember each and every one of his return customers.  He remembers what you like and what you don't... You feel like home when you eat in this restaurant:-)
author: Jannet L.

description:
Not as great as I expected from the reviews.

The banchans were my favorite part but as for the seafood tofu soup. I've had better. Not that much seafood in my soup and the medium spicy was NOT AT ALL even close to it. It didn't even taste like mild, it tasted like non spicy.
author: Yvonne L.
