description: We had lunch here a couple of times. Each and every single time the customer service was stellar. The people there were just so friendly. We felt welcomed and comfortable enjoying our meal there. They frequently checked each table to fill up waiter or banchan. When they were busy, they would still acknowledge your request, and return later to serve. We appreciated this type of care.
author: GR Z.

description:
Awesome Korean restaurant but definitely on the pricey side. There was a short wait about 15 minutes on a weekend for dinner. Nice service and good ambiance. They were able to accommodate a large group.

Good banchan variety - loved the entire fried fish each person gets. We ordered the seafood pancake ($23) and a plate of kal bi (short ribs) for the dinner price of $26 to share with the group. Both were soo flavorful and delicious but I am pretty surprised at how expensive it was given the serving size was just standard.

Got the combination tofu soup that has beef and seafood ($12) and comes with rice and an egg to crack in it. Mild spice was about right for someone that can't handle too much really spicey dishes. The tofu soup was really good and worth the money but the appetizers were overpriced in my opinion. Would definitely be back here for the tofu soup!
author: Linda X.

description:
What's with the hype?  He's been wanting to try this place and we were surprised that there was no wait around 6:30 on Thursday night because it's always crowded.  

We shared the beef bibimbap and the dumpling tofu stew.  The beef in the bibimbap was so chewy, but happy that the stone pot got hot enough to make some of the rice crunchy.  The dumpling tofu soup was okay; plus that it came with some beef.  I found the flavors in both dishes lacking.  This place is pricy too; if memory serves me right, the tofu stew was about $12 or so and the bibimbap $16.  Banchan dishes were standard, except they gave two pieces of fried fish, which we don't eat, but we took them to go and gave them to someone else after.

I ate ice cream at home after because I wasn't very satisfied or full.  I totally miss Soon's in Foster City for some delish tofu stew soup.  I'll be fair though, of the few other Korean places I go to in SF, it's mostly for grilled dishes or other items vs. tofu stew and bibimbap.
author: Cat C.

description: Definitely the spot for Korean comfort food. Their tofu soup was amazing and very filling! Service is great. Definitely recommend going!
author: Nicole N.

description:
Most proper tofu soup in Sf proper. The tofu soups are so rich in flavor and the tofu they use is so fresh and good. The soup has the right amount of red pepper flakes. Super satisfying on a cold day.

The rice is steamed with peas as it should be and the variety of banchan is great. 

On the same level as some of the joints in Santa Clara.
author: Megan L.

description:
Descent food for descent price. But it's tiny in there and they do not have much of a waiting area on a busy night so you're kind of forced to stand along a short wall next to customers already eating. It's a bit awkward...

I ordered the combination tofu soup and it was good. I'm not the biggest fan of tofu but this place makes it work!
author: Stacey D.

description:
I really don't see why this place needs another good review. So this is going to be short.

It's hot, it's yummy, the portions are generous, and the people are nice!
author: Cori N.

description:
Great place for Korean style comfort food on a cold day in the city. There was a wait when I came here on Sunday night, but the line moved fairly quickly. The restaurant was bustling with families, couples, friends, etc. The guys who ran the place were very efficient and our food arrived on time. 

Skip the tofu salad. It's a salad with iceberg lettuce with 4 pieces of uncooked tofu and a tiny amount of corn and carrot on top. The salad was drenched in watery soy sauce dressing. On the other hand, the tofu soup was very spicy and flavorful. I was surprised at how big the shrimps were. Be careful not to burn your tongue...the dish came out steaming and bubbling. Just when we thought we weren't going to get any rice, our waiter came by with a huge bowl of rice and scooped the rice into small bowls for us.

The banchan was great. Everything tasted authentic and paired well with our food. I tend to judge a Korean restaurant by their kimchi. Their kimchi was extra saucy and tasted great. Our tofu soup came with a fried croaker and an egg.

What I don't understand is that they charge $23 for pancakes. At that rate, I'd rather get their BBQ meats.
author: Helen C.

description:
I used to eat here pretty often years ago. The food tasted completely different from what I remembered. The appetizer is decent, comes with lots of varieties. The only reason I gave a 2 star. 

I ordered the mild beef kimchi tofu soup. It was not mild! The soup tasted like salted water. Beef was chopped in very tiny pieces, didn't event notice that was beef at first. Kimchi has no flavor., just over cooked cabbages. The mushroom didn't taste fresh at all. Food was not served boiling hot, just warm. My egg never got cooked.
author: Congjing Z.

description:
Dinner prices are so jacked up, $27 for 1 dish of kalbi when you could just take that money and have ayce instead. The wait for the food is so long and just asking for water takes forever. Don't see why this place has 4 stars.
TLDR; Too expensive for the ok food and crappy service. Better places out there.
author: Carol C.

description:
What a letdown...

Tofu soup wasn't bad but didn't live up to what my friend claimed to be the best tofu soup in the city.

BCD in socal is light years ahead.

Also tried the bulgolgi which wasn't memorable either.
author: Jensen S.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars for their soondooboo! I've been here twice on rainy days so all I wanted was some soup. Both times I went, there was a wait but it wasn't that bad-- I maybe waited for 20 minutes but it was worth it! 
Their soondooboo is so good- it's also not too pricey as well which is a bonus!
They give you a huge pot of rice and lots of side dishes (including mackerel for each person which most tofu houses I go to, they don't give that out). I got the seafood tofu soup and had them make it the spicy- the level of spiciness was perfect for me and the portioning of the seafood was decent. 
I would definitely come back here again for the tofu soup!
author: Lina T.

description:
I usually don't like to eat out at Korean restaurants unless it's for KBBQ, because I feel that korean food is generally expensive or overpriced. However... that might actually be because I'm Korean, and my mom cooks these food for me at home for what can cost less than $15 to feed a whole family.

This place is one of many korean restaurants I try to avoid, because their food is a bit more overpriced than other restaurants. It's about $14 for one order of soft tofu soup, which you can order for $10 at other places. The couple of few times I've been here, I always ordered the very spicy combination soft tofu soup and all those times, I left being very thirsty. I think the food is too salty for me..either that or too much MSG.

Side dishes are tasty though. I love that they serve a fried fish per person but Idk... I have mixed feelings about this place. I wouldn't come out to eat here unless my friends wanted to go.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Had the Kimchi & Beef tofu soup and the Bulgogi. As a Korean, I'd rate the food as very good. The side dishes were well prepared, the tofu soup had depth, and the Bulgogi was tender.

The service could use a bit of work as the waiter mixed up our orders with a different table and gave our tofu soup to another table. Would go back again if I had a chance.
author: Alex C.

description:
Oh my god! The food is amazing! 
I went here with my girlfriend, we ordered several items, and all of them are very tasty.
The tofu soup is highly recommended! 
Already bookmarked this place. 
Definitely will come again.
author: John Y.

description:
I gawked a bit at the prices, but My Tofu House served some of the best seafood pancakes I've ever had. There was so much squid and other seafood in each one, and the pieces were huge and chewy. The ban chan was great too! They gave us a vast spread of things, including fried fish, fish tofu, cucumbers, and really good kimchi.

The bulgogi was a bit dry, but my friend loved it. I wish we ordered the galbi instead.  

The combination tofu stew was not anything to write home about but it still hit the spot. I enjoyed the big clay pot of rice with peas mixed in and complimentary barley tea. 

Although it's on the expensive side and the atmosphere/service is no frills (read: don't expect much fanfare), I will come back for the seafood pancakes alone. The booths are great for 2-4.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Heard a lot of good reviews about this place having the best tofu soup in SF. Well this is the first time I have tofu soup ever since I moved up from South Bay, but from a quality standpoint, this is still far behind many joints in Santa Clara.

Came on a Thursday night, my friend waited in line for 15 mins and got a table for 2. She said it usually takes at least 30-45 mins during weekends so I guess we came at a good time.

Banchan: B.
Fewer selections than a lot of other tofu soup houses I have been to. I guess here serves the fish dish so it's a plus (yes that's pretty good). But other than that, kimchi was so-so; fish egg/bean sprouts etc were all average or below average.

Kalbi: B+.
Not bad, but far from exceptional. Standard marinated short rib. 

Seafood Pancake: B.
Both my friend and I thought it was too thick - felt like eating a pizza and felt so stuffed afterwards. I think the amount of seafood they put in was decent, but because of the thick pancake I couldn't really enjoy the whole dish too much.

Fish Egg Tofu Soup (Medium): B.
I think medium is the 2nd highest spiciness level but even though for a person who can't eat too spicy food like me, it was not spicy enough. I guess I should have gone all the way up. Not sure whether this restaurant uses MSG but my guess is no or only very little, because the soup only had very little taste... Fish egg portion was small, I think I could only find three chunks. Other ingredients in the soup were pretty standard.

Although the food was okay overall but definitely not an impressive experience. I would rather save my tofu-soup-crave for much nicer South Bay (or LA) tofu soup restaurants.
author: Simon C.

description: Having just moved here from Seoul, we are familiar with Korean food.  We loved this place!   It is expensive, but Korean food in the States is.  My partner had the traditional tofu soup and it didn't disappoint.   It was spicy and flavorful.  I had the beef bibimbap and it was delicious.   The portion was large.  The banchan was tasty.  The kimchi average.   The sprouts and cucumbers were a bit salty-even for Korean food.    Oh, and they don't serve alcohol here.    :( I would definitively visit again.
author: William G.

description: I always go to this restaurant when I'm in SF and craving Korean food. My go-to dish every single time is the soft tofu soup since the flavor is absolutely amazing. The banchan is plentiful and they offer free refills if asked. At first, the crocker fish side dish put me off since I was afraid it was going to be really fishy but to my delight, it wasn't fishy at all and quite pleasant to eat. Service is attentive so my water and tea glasses are never empty. Overall, a good dining experience and I will most definitely be back.
author: Julie L.

description:
One of the best soondubu places I've found in SF, which unfortunately isn't a very high bar. That being said, I really enjoyed My Tofu House. I got the spicy seafood soondubu + dweji bulgogi (spicy pork), which both came in relatively generous portions. The spicy soondubu was not very spicy, and we had to ask for extra chili pepper - but the taste was there. The spicy pork was delicious, not too oily and the right amount of flavor.

Overall, a bit overpriced but still definitely a go-to whenever I want tofu soup. The decor is very minimalistic, but feels clean enough.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Came here 4.5 years ago and was not the avid Yelper I am today. Came back 4.5 years later and finally am a Yelper to review it! YAY!!

Place is very clean, simple, and brightly lit. Employees are kinda friendly. Their prices are no longer accurate on the full menu on Yelp. Prices have went up :(

original tofu soup $12.88: I asked for mild spicy and it was.. MILD! (had traumatic experiences with korean places where I ordered mild and it was like... lvl 10 spicy...) You can choose different types of meat chicken, pork, beef. They give you a raw egg to crack into the soup, and egg makes everything better! The tofu is super soft and the soup is flavorful. Nothing out of the ordinary WOW though.

meal came with many appetizer dishes (banchan dishes). the fish tofu was very spicy. 

Parking was easy on a Sunday night at around 8pm. 

Overall, a pretty expensive decent dinner, but which korean place in SF isnt hella pricey for dinner?
author: Chena N.

description: love the tofu soup here. beware there might be a line when you show up, it really is worth it though.
author: Vanessa S.

description: The foods are so good, I love the tofu soup which was I favorited. Tonight we had a great time out there and the service was great. Thanks for the candis..
author: 芒果

description: I think the service was good but this place doesn't serve traditional and local Korean dishes. I think the tofu soup tasted very fusion and basically got no taste. The rice was okay. If you are looking for the real Korean food, just skip this one!
author: Dessert L.

description:
Quality of the food here is just perfect. Their banchan here is also very delicious. I love the service when you ask for more of a banchan you just completely devoured as well. They don't skimp here. 

We've had their seafood pancake, bulgogi, galbi, bibimbap, and tofu soups. Everything here is seasoned to perfection. Not a bland dish ever tasted. I'd say this is my go-to place for Korean food in SF. Just make sure you come early. The line does get pretty long.
author: Marlene T.

description: The food was amazing overall. I ordered mushroom tofu soup with medium spice. It was not as spicy as I thought for medium level. There was so much food and given the decent price, it was worth it!
author: Rickie H.

description:
Came here few times already but for some reason I never got to leave a review. Came here on Sunday for Valentines day and the place wasn't too packed on a Sunday night luckily. I think it maybe bc we got there close to closing lol. Anyways, we got there around 8:45 and put our names down. We waited roughly 20 to 30 minutes. There were few names ahead of us and it wasn't too bad of a wait. We ordered the kalbi, seafood tofu soup, and tofu salad. The kalbi and seafood tofu soup was definitely tasty. Lots of flavors. The tofu salad was a bit disappointment. I thought it'd be a good choice of veggies but it was really just lettuce, cucumbers, and tofu and dressing. Honestly it's overpriced for this salad which wasn't even good. The kalbi was good but I felt like that too is overpriced or maybe I'm just being cheap. It was around $23 or so for a plate of 10 pieces? I forgot the price but somewhere in the 20s. I like that they gave us side dishes and gave us refills for free. Customer service was okay. We got sat in the corner so it was kind of hard to get the waiters attention sometimes. They didn't really come and ask how everything was even though the restaurant wasn't that busy. 
I would come back here though even though I only gave it a 3 stars. It's a good place to get your tofu soup. Just don't order the tofu salad ($9?)!! Other than that, everything was good.
author: Monica W.

description: Been coming here for the past ten years, My Tofu House still has consistently good Korean food and is hands down my favorite Korean restaurant. They have the best beef bibimbap and ban chan. In the past, you could get seated immediately. With increased popularity, expect a wait during peak hours. Went last night at 7pm and there was about a 10-15 minute wait. In that time, ten other groups came to put their names on the list. By the time we had finished eating, some of those groups still had not been seated. The only thing that could be improved is to make a taller barrier between the people waiting and seats by the railing. Often people hang their elbows over and watch you like a hawk.
author: Monica H.

description: Korean food here is not that bad but prices here are sorta ridiculous in my opinion. I know Korean food is generally more pricey, but a seafood pancake for $22 is not worth it. The seafood pancake was too thick for my liking and lacked flavor. I enjoyed the sides, which  includes the typical korean dish from kimchi to fish cake etc .There was a variety of rice sides and free refills on sides. Staff are friendly and polite but there are definitely some dishes that are just too overpriced for my comfort.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Around $80 dinner for two. My boyfriend and I ordered the original tofu soup, bulgoki, and the beef bibimbab. The tofu soup was nothing outstanding to me and in my opinion, not worth $15. It was basically a few blocks of tofu boiling in a hot pot in kimchi soup. I really liked the bulgoki! The bibimbab was very spicy although I did just want it mild spicy. Along these, we were given side dishes so we were really full.

Another thing that really bothered me the entire dinner was that the bowl given to me was dirty... I could see the kimchi stain from the previous person who were using it! I told the guy that I wanted a new bowl and he didn't bother to listen. He just scooped me rice into the dirty bowl. I didn't even bother to touch that bowl of rice all night.
author: Karen C.

description:
My go to spot for tofu soup. I love their side dishes especially the fish. Idk of any other place that gives you fish. 
The tea also has this roasted taste and isn't watered down which I the way I like it.  
As for tofu soup, I always get the dumpling tofu soup which is flavorful on its own without any spice. Convenient for people who can't take spicy. It contains 4 pieces of dumpling that are meat filled and a couple of smaller dumplings (rice cake perhaps). 

& shoutout to the staff. These pots are heavy and extremely hot and it gets busy here,  imagine the labor it takes to run around with these pots all day. &  having to wash the mess that gets stuck to the bowls. They're not even grumpy when they serve you and don't give you dirty looks for asking for more side dishes! I also love the bouquets they have here under that one spot of light. Everytime I come there's a new bouquet and it's always beautiful and in full bloom. Not fake either. Props for whoever picks the flowers.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I was craving korean soft tofu soup and my husband found this place during his search. We ventured out to the Inner Richmond around 8:30 on a Saturday night. The place was completely packed, which is always a good sign, isn't it? We waited for maybe 15 minutes and once we were seated, the servers were quick with water, tea, and sides. Boom- hunger subsided. We decided to over-order because, duh, why not? Korean food is just one of those foods that are sometimes better the next day, isn't it?! I ordered the Original Soft Tofu soup (tofu with beef and mushrooms) and my hubby got the Combination Soft Tofu soup (tofu with beef, shrimp and clams). Just a heads up--the prices of the current day menu are not the same as the ones you'll see here on Yelp ($9.45 on Yelp whereas the real price is $13.38--a really weird number, no?). We shared the Haemul Pajeon (seafood pancake), a small order for fried yellow croaker fish, and an order of kalbi (broiled short ribs)--when I say we over-ordered, we REALLY over-ordered. But it was all so worth it and so delicious! The soup had awesome flavor and came out piping hot. Crack your egg and stir it well and you have yourself the perfect rainy day meal, which cured our rainy day blues last night. I highly suggest ordered the yellow croaker to eat along with the soup. The spice of the soup is balanced really well with the fish's saltiness. We really enjoyed the seafood pancake and kalbi, but barely touched either one because we were so stuffed from all of the food already. And they were even better the next day for lunch, I swear! Particularly the seafood pancake. It's a mix of different seafood (clams, shrimp, squid, etc.) which wasn't fresh, I assume, but tasty nonetheless. It was actually my first time trying it with red peppers and I loved it.

Really happy we found this place and will definitely be back soon, even before another rainy day here in the Bay :)
author: Monica T.

description:
I've been here a couple times for dinner and the food's been decent but one thing that I've noticed that cost them to lose stars from me was the service. 

I came here with my boyfriend and his family for dinner on a Saturday night and surprisingly it wasn't that busy. We ordered two bibimbap, two pancakes, two soft tofu soup, a bulgogi, and a kalbi. They also provide you with a variety and generous amount of banchan which includes a mackerel for each person. 

The seafood pancakes are made thicker than what I'm used to compared to other places since they are very generous with the toppings, but it does bring out a lot of flavor. 

The bibimbap was a bit on a sweeter side, maybe cause of the sauce that comes with it. I'm used to more of the spiciness of it rather than it being sweet. But overall, it was good. 

The kalbi was really delicious. It was cooked perfectly and the meat was really tender. Very easy to bite off the bone. The bulgogi on the other hand was also a bit too sweet for my liking. 

Now comes the soft tofu soup. I ordered my usual favorite, the dumpling soft tofu soup. We also ordered a seafood tofu soup for my boyfriends grandma. I asked for medium spice for mine since the mild I had last time was more on the bland side & a mild spice for his granny. The waitress came out with our orders switched resulting in his granny having the medium spice tofu soup where she can't handle. I kindly asked her to change it because she clearly messed up the order but she being really rude about it. She kept looking back at her notepad trying to claim that it was ordered correctly and making the situation harder and more complicated than it needed to be. All I asked for was to have the tofu soup remade to mild and I even kept my mild tofu soup so it would be less trouble for her. Eventually, she took it back to have it remade but didn't come out with the new one till end of dinner when his granny was already full from eating off of our other dishes. 

Overall, food is decent for what it is but for the price, it's def more on the pricey side for the usual Korean dishes. Service on the other hand is what keeps me from coming back here especially after my most recent encounter with the staffs.
author: Cindy Jane Y.

description:
This place was awesome!

Granted, the fact that it was freezing the day I went most likely played a big role in making the Tofu Soup all the more enjoyable.

If you like Korean food, this place is a solid choice for the Inner Richmond area. The traditional prefixes are good, it would be nice if the cucumbers were drizzled with some spicy sauce, but they're good. 

I look forward to coming back and trying out the rest of their menu, but the Tofu Soup is solid.

Note: If you like spicy, the medium spicy is super weak, so up the spice.
author: Aaron C.

description:
With over 1200 reviews on Yelp and a solid 4 star rating, I thought My Tofu House was going to have some bomb soondubu, but my experience was a bit lackluster.  I got the beef soondubu and the soup broth didn't have much flavor and the beef chunks were pretty small. It was also more expensive than other places like Dae Jang Geum in Daly City, which I actually think has better tofu soup overall. 

I will say that the banchan is fresher and more authentic here though, which is a big plus. They give you six dishes and even give you two pieces of fried fish! Watch those sneaky little bones though. I also like how the rice comes in a stone pot that they scoop out for you. Presentation points! 

The pluses weren't enough to push my experience to four stars though, since the soodubu is really the whole point of coming here. Maybe I didn't order the right thing or it was an off day...but I don't see what all the fuss is about. Service wasn't all that great either. Friendly, but once they deliver the food you won't see them for awhile. The restaurant has mostly booths, which provides a more intimate dining experience. They also have a section where they can put tables together to accommodate larger groups. Perhaps worth a try, but I don't think I'll be back.
author: Deanna Y.

description: LOVE THE SERVICE, YES TO THE FOOD. Was hot asf even after a whole hour. Waiters were nice!
author: Jess T.

description:
After landing at SFO from a weekend in Vegas, my friends wanted to come here.

Place is very small so I expect it gets very crowded on the weekends.

I've never had korean soup before with the egg and all but I enjoyed mine.

The side dishes were absolutely delicious, we had to ask for seconds on most of them!

Price however is the only reason I'm giving them a 4 star, but if you're not a college/high school student or you have a good job, this place is a must try.
author: Da X.

description: One of my other favorite Korean restaurants!  Went here for dinner on a weeknight and they were pretty packed.  We had to wait awhile but it was worth it.  The tofu soup at this restaurant is so delicious and they give a huge amount!  I ordered the dumpling tofu soup and the korean pancake.  So good!! Highly recommend!
author: Mikayla M.

description: My friend recommended this place.  Everything is tasty.  They have the best tofu soup!  We're coming back.
author: HQ S.

description:
This place is the bomb, minus the wait. I will preface that they don't really know how to deal/handle with the slickness levels and the service can be hit or miss-- but mostly, My Tofu House is a solid place that knows how to make a great soondubu. They even do the whole giant rice pot with tea in it after if you order a soondubu. It's super authentic and hella grinds.

I got the kimchi soondubu with pork, mild, and wished I had asked for it medium because mild was sooo tame. It definitely was swimming in kimchi and they gave us a raw egg with it, so clearly, it was amazing. I couldn't finish the whole thing because the portions were huge. I will say that even when I added the kimchi juice to it, it didn't add much more spiciness to my soondubu. Next time, I will ask for medium or even spicy, because if this was mild-- I'm not afraid to see what their other levels of spice are like. My BF got the dumpling soondubu at medium and he enjoyed it. He ate the whole thing and asked if we could go again the next day! (My boyfriend is a white dude from Europe, so you can tell how tasty it was.) 

The only qualm for me was the wait and the service. We had to ask the waiter like five times for water before he brought it out to us. Other than that, it's busy and delicious. Go here!!!
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
This place is pretty good. I normally go to Korean BBQ places so my experience with regular Korean food isn't that extensive. 

We came here for dinner and noticed that the kalbi was a lot more expensive than it was for lunch. It came in a sizzling plate and was pretty tasty but I don't know if I'd spend around $26 again for this during dinner time. 

Since it was dinner time and just the two of us, we only ordered the kalbi and the seafood combination tofu soup. The soup was pretty tasty and came out in the sizzling pot as well. I liked the tofu soup a lot and would probably get it again. 

The rice came in a huge pot and was enough to fill 3 small bowls and then they poured barley tea inside of the pot to soak up the rest of the rice that was left over. It was tasty but I like the crispy rice at the bottom of the sizzling pot. Maybe next time I'll get the bibimbap so I can get the crispy rice at the bottom. I saw the table next to use get the bibimbap and it looked delicious! 

The side dishes are also really good. They gave us 3 small fried fishes between us two and it was more than enough. The bones are pretty thin so you can eat most of it but you might need to remove some of the harder ones. 

Overall, I think this is a pretty good non-Korean BBQ place but is more on the pricey side, especially during dinner. 

Pros:
-Friendly staff
-Tasty soup
-Great side dishes 

Cons:
-Pricey 
-Parking lot on the side is for Jack in the Box
author: Paul U.

description: My first experience at a Korean restaurant and it was amazing. The ambiance was very casual and village like. It has that nice wooden look in it which almost felt like home to me. Me and my friend got there around six pm perfect for dinner time and it was almost already packed in there. We got seated right away and the service was very quick. Gave us our teas and let us look at the menu for a good while before asking if we'd like to order. Their menu is quite small so it's not hard picking what you want to eat. We ordered two items since it comes with side dishes and rice so if we were still hungry after, I could easily order more. We got #5 assorted mushroom tofu soup in mild level and #13 beef and vegetable bibimbap that my friend recommended. The side dishes came first and since we were super hungry, we just started picking at that first. I never had side dishes before so everything was a first timer for me. The fried fish was really good, reminds me of my mom's cooking. The other one I really liked was the fish cake because it was spicy and flavorful. Right after that, our rice came, like a lot of rice that I'm pretty sure we aren't going to finish. The lady poured hot tea into the rice stone pot so all the white rice would come off but I accidentally threw my napkin in there, not sure how but it happened, so we didn't touch that anymore(it's okay we barely finished everything). The beef stone pot came and it was so pretty and colorful, just like how it is in kdramas(anyone watches that here cuz I do!) We started mixing right away because we wanted the egg to cook and it smelled so good that I wanted to eat it right away(careful: burning hot). You really get what you pay for because the stone pot is slightly more expensive than other places(according to my friend) but it was a huge stone pot. The tofu soup came and it looked super good. I never had tofu soup before as well so I was really excited to try it. I quickly took a spoonful in my mouth and it was scorching hot, felt like my insides died a little. I was expecting the soup to be bigger than the bibimbap for some reason but it looked tiny(guess what, it really isn't with all the other food). We barely even finished everything, our bellies were popping when we left. Total came out to be $40.00 with tip, delicious food and amazing service with good proportion sizes. Will definitely come back soon!
author: Lisa W.

description:
My second attempt to try My Tofu House proved disappointing because it was closed.  We had plan to come here for lunch.  The time here on yelp states that is opened from 11:00am-3:00pm and from 5:00pm-9:30pm.  On the door is says it's closed and opens at 5:00pm.
I wished they would update their time on yelp and elsewhere on the internet. 
One star is because I can't rate this and I must put a star but I am disappointed that both times I paid a bunch for meter parking just to see the sign on the door saying that it is closed.
Just for others, It is not open until 5:00pm.  If I ever get a chance to try this place, I'll give it a true review.
author: Gloria H.

description:
My Tofu House is definitely one of the better Korean restaurants around here. I usually get takeout but have dined here once or twice. This review in particular was for my last takeout order a week or so ago. 

My GF loves the fish egg soft tofu soup here and not many places in San Francisco make it better than they do. As mentioned in previous reviews, their highest spicy level wasn't spicy enough for her but for me it was just right. For me, it was that good kick of spicy without having to stop to take a break to eat more. While she chowed down on the fish egg soup, I ordered an order of Kalbi (beef short ribs). It tasted like standard Korean fare which is not a bad thing in my book. It was definitely tender and juicy!

The employees here aren't the fastest but they are very friendly whether I'm taking out or eating here. This place gets extremely packed from Friday to Sunday so keep that in mind if you're planning on eating here. I think the food is slightly overpriced but I don't mind paying for it as long as the quality is there!
author: R C.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco with a few friends and stumbled upon this place because of its proximity to the Golden Gate Park.

We came here around 6:00, and the place was quite busy. We were promptly seated and ordered the seafood tofu stew and the bulgogi. Be warned that the menu is small, but it still has your typical Korean dishes.  A standout in the meal was the banchan or side dishes. I liked how they gave us a large plate of kimchee, which was quickly devoured. The spicy fish cakes were very good, and they also gave us two whole fried fish which I've never seen before as a side dish. The seafood tofu stew was standard yet tasty. Maybe I've developed more of a tolerance to spicy dishes, but I thought that the mild was too mild. I had to dump some of the kimchee into the stew to get more flavor. I only tried a bit of the bulgogi, but it was also quite delicious.

There was nothing to complain about with the service. However, the prices are on the slightly higher end. I didn't like how they posted both the lunch and dinner prices on the same menu. For the bulgogi, it was almost a $10 increase for basically the same portion. Why would they want diners to know that? Overall, My Tofu House is a solid Korean restaurant.
author: Joy L.

description:
I have eaten here before
Last time was about two years ago 
This time I went with a group 
We ordered the pancake 
Veggie pot
Bbq (2)
Fish we ended up getting 10
And it comes with rice
We ate everything it was all so good
The service was fast and precise 
The place was packed 
There were a lot of young people there 
They have two flat screen tvs
They have a waiting area 
They have a back room for private events 
I will be coming here again
author: Jennifer G.

description: i was thoroughly surprised when i came here.  Was impressed w/ service and quality of food.  Great place for soon do bu.
author: Jason P.

description:
Korean style comfort food. The perfect meal to warm you up and help you forget about a tough day at the office.

No advance reservations, just a sign up sheet.

Great banchan, especially the kimchi, fish cake and fried whole fish.

My Favorites

Kimchi soft tofu soup with Pork and mushroom - awesomely good

Vegetable and mushroom bibimbap - very good

Daeji Bulgoki - Broiled sliced spicy pork - very good


Skip the seafood pancakes, they are bland and a little boring.
author: David T.

description: This is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in Bay Area. They have such great food that all my friends loved their food too-! I took my mom and her friends when they visited me from Japan and they all loved their food as well-! Highly recommended-!
author: Jang R.

description: This restaurant hits the spot on a cold San Francisco night.  The famous tofu soups are so perfectly hot and delicious.  Another favorite is the seafood pancake, generous amount of seafood, truly a treat.  The condiments are fresh, love the fried fish plate, could be a course.  Nice spot to warm up with a scalding hot tofu soup.
author: Carole W.

description:
I've been craving tofu souppp and finally fulfilled my craving! MMM. Ordered it in mild - maybe I'll go for the medium next time - get more of a kick! I serious love their tofu soup and they are known for having one of the best tofu soups, hence, "My Tofu House."

Also ordered the kalbi and seafood pancake! Meat was juicy and marinated really well. It was just a tad tough. The seafood pancake was delicious. There was a good serving of seafood - shrimp, octopus, calamari, + onions, bellpeppers. The pancake was not too doughy or too thin. It went well with the sweet dipping sauce. It was presented on a sizzling pan so it was warm/hot/crispy throughout the entire meal!
 
Unfortunately, the banchan is nothing special. The only 'something out of the ordinary' is the fried fish! It's good, but it's a pain taking out all the tiny bones. Refills on banchan always though! Fishcakes delish!

I wish this place had the purple rice... but the flavor of the dishes are great!

I recommend coming here for lunch... lunch vs dinner prices... big difference.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
One of the best places I've tried. The food was great and it came with generous portions of side dishes! The only set back was the waiting time, dinner hours are quite busy and we were waiting for around 30 minutes to be seated. 

Bulgogi - very juicy and cooked well. Tasted good with the mushrooms and onions. Good portion size for sharing.

Original tofu soup w/ beef - delicious but portion size is made for one. Don't forget to add in the egg! 

Overall good service, we will be back (:
author: Shari T.

description:
Ordered the pork bibimbap and combination tofu -- both were good but we left feeling so bloated and heavy afterwards. The meal was quite heavy. 
This place is decent, but can sometimes have long waits. 
Would go again.
author: Mima G.

description:
+ THE FOOD
The food is pretty good here! I had the mushroom tofu soup and it was pretty satisfying. They do give a LOT of tofu and there ends up being very little soup left. They give a small side of fish for pretty much every order and  it's delicious! The galbi was good and was on the sweet side. The portion size is pretty fair but the price of the dishes is more on the expensive side. 

+ THE SERVICE
We had a very large group and the restaurant was going to close within the hour but they still let us in. We got seated in the back room and had a lot of privacy to ourselves. Even though we stayed past when the restaurant closed, everyone was very friendly to us. We were never rushed to leave or anything. All the servers were super nice and checked up on us often to 
make sure we were satisfied.
author: Cindy C.

description:
The big table was occupied so there was a little bit of a wait for our party of 6. We eventually got a booth. Grandma liked how clean the restaurant was. 

A few of us got the original tofu with pork, chicken, or beef. Daughter #1 got dumpling soft tofu. Daughter #2 had BBQ chicken. Husband got bulgoki. All enjoyed the silky, soft tofu especially Grandpa. Yellow croaker, the small fish, that came with banchan was good. Daughter #1 liked the duboki with her dumplings and tofu. Medium spice on tofu was not enough for Daughter #2. She could have taken more heat, so spice level not equivalent to spice levels in Korean restaurants in SoCal.
author: Belinda L.

description:
New favorite "low key" Korean place! Although Han Il Kwan is still the best, My Tofu House is our now go-to place for simple Korean food for dinner. Their menu is small and perhaps slightly pricey, but so far, everything that we've had has been delicious. 
The KimChi Tofu Soup is perfect for rainy weather. We always add ramen with it for an extra $1. The raw egg that comes with the banchan is meant to be cracked into the hot soup, fyi! Speaking of banchan, they also have mackerel as a banchan dish, which I rarely see at other Korean places. 
Expect a long wait on the weekends, but weekdays aren't too bad.
author: Denise D.

description:
It was Saturday night, and we waited about 30 minutes for a family of 5.  When our name came up, the waiter led our group to a back room without checking with us in the front.  Why did he bring us there?  Afterwards, I think it is because we had our grandmothers with us, and there were younger people dining, or we're were speaking Chinese.

The room was bland, empty walls, minimum ceiling height, and had a old ac unit sitting above the end of the table.   We ended up being the only party in that room the entire time.

We won't be coming back.   Just a bad feeling about the restaurant being the only group placed in a back room.
author: Kai Y.

description:
This place is okay but not amazing.

Their service was quite slow and you may expect a long dinner wait. However, the food was great!

Order their kal-bi which is basically Korean beef and their clay pot rice and an assortment of vegetables and Korean sides. However, resist ordering their Korean pancakes as you can get a better deal at Manna on Irving Street in the Sunset.

Overall, the experience here isn't superb but the atmosphere here is that of a restaurant in Korea.
author: Junming G.

description: The best place for soft tofu soup. I always go for the combination tofu soup. Trust me I've given other Korean restaurants chances, but this is hands down the best. When you order the soup, it comes with not only a bubbling bowl of tofu soup... oh no it comes with a big stone pot of rice, all the side dishes, and a little fried fish. So yummy! I'd come here to treat myself because it is a little more on the pricey side, well at dinner. But if you just get the soup that's definitely enough for a whole meal. I have yet to try the seafood pancake!
author: Marisa L.

description:
I came here for lunch with my brother, my dad, and my aunt's friends.  Parking was almost non-existent but we found one in front of the Jack in the Box.  The restaurant was small inside and busy when we got here.  The waiters were nice and helpful as well.  The menu had pictures of some of the food but not all.  We ordered the Vegetable Soft Tofu ($11.50), the Fish Egg Soft Tofu ($11.50), Bulgoki ($11.50 for lunch size and $21.18 for dinner), Daeji Bulgoki ($11.50 for lunch size and $19.32 for dinner) and two Beef & Vegetable Bibimbab ($15.87 each). 

It sounded like a lot of food but it wasn't with 5 people in our group.  The free appetizers came out and they tasted good from the few I ate.  The Bulgoki tasted great as well as the Daeji Bulgoki.  It looked like it was very little but it was just right for us.  I had to hold back to let everybody have some but definitely my favorite out of everything we ordered.  The Vegetable Soft Tofu was good and was what I was expecting from other Korean restaurants I've been to.  The Beef & Vegetable Bibimbab was good but definitely will make anybody full.  Everything was still pretty hot (temperature-wise) as I got close to the bottom of the stone bowl.  

Good Korean food here and I'd recommend it!
author: Daniel H.

description:
Good as always but the prices went up! We ordered the following & requested less tofu & more soup:

-Fish Egg Soft Tofu (Good)
-Dumpling Soft Tofu (Good)

*Good service
author: Wendy L.

description:
I really do love this place. You can't get great Korean BBQ in SF, but if you want some good comfort food in the form of tofu soup or bibimbab, you'll find it here. You can't go wrong with any of their tofus or bibimbab. Nothing is heavily seasoned with salt, so you don't have to worry about the Korean food salt bloat aftermath. If you're a huge meat fan, I don't really recommend the kalbi or bulgolgi. They're called My Tofu House for a reason. Stick with their specialties, and you also get to alter the spice level. That's pretty awesome. If you're feeling the pancake, you can't go wrong with a massive, fluffy combo pancake, chocked full of seafood and kimchi.

Prices are what they are, so don't expect SoCal-cheap bills. Service, however, is excellent. They do a fantastic job for such a large space and so few servers. On top of that, unlike many Korean places, there's no bell to ring, but they're still great at coming around to make sure you're okay. Meal comes with 5 banchan dishes - cucumbers, sprouts, kimchi, fish cake, and daikon (mu). Once your meal begins, you will also get a complimentary broiled yellow croaker. Good times. Look out for the bones though! Who doesn't love a piping hot plate of food?
author: Danny C.

description:
Nicer on the inside than it seems on the outside! I got the BBQ chicken and it wasn't what I expected. It was too sweet and saucy -- it tasted more like teriyaki chicken. It wasn't grilled and crusty enough for my liking. 

 Definitely get the soup if you go. It's in the name, after all!
author: Diane Y.

description:
I was visiting from LA also known as the mecca of Korean food so my standards were set pretty high walking in. Place was pretty busy with lots of folks coming in and out. We got the dumpling tofu soup (mild), vegetable tofu soup (spicy), chicken bibimbap, and chicken bulgogi. Everything just hit the spot. The spicyness was perfect to each out request. The hot tea they provide was great. And it was perfect for our hangovers. 

On prices - At first we were turned off by the price of the chicken bulgogi ($24~) but it's about 2-3 servings worth and with all the side dishes it's more than filling and easy to share. Portion sizes in general were pretty satisfactory. You'll definitely get your belly's worth
author: Michelle Y.

description: Upgrading to 5 stars. I consistently find myself coming back here. The tofu soup is so good, especially on a hot day. The only negative about this place is that all the other dishes are insanely expensive.. Other than that, though, no complaints!
author: Kazu O.

description: Disappointed. Got the dumpling soft tofu soup to go tonight. I ordered it medium level of spiciness, and for some reason, it was so bland. Tasted watery with very little spice. I really love this place, and have been here more times than I can remember. Not sure what happened with the food this time, but it really wasn't good. Maybe it was just an off night, but felt like a waste all the same. Hopefully next time, it'll be back to usual.
author: Stacey L.

description: To start off, let me say that the food is pretty good, but prices are ridiculous here! That being said, I did enjoy the dish that I got (bul gogi skillet). The side dishes were good too, and my dining companion seemed to enjoy his seafood tofu soup as well. The service was also pretty fast, which is why I'm giving this place 4 stars.
author: Jane H.

description:
My Tofu House is bigger than it looks from the outside. At least I thought so. Upon walking in, I was surprised to see a good amount of booth seating, which makes up the type of seating here. There are booths for bigger groups and booths for pairs. 

The banchan, including kim chee, daikon, cucumber, bean sprouts and fish cake were all tasty. We had to get refills of the cucumber and fish cake. I really liked the addition of the fried fish which I've never had before with an order of tofu soup. The tofu soups (I tried combo and dumpling) were loaded with tofu and their respective ingredients. The soup itself wasn't the most flavorful but still satisfying. One thing to note is that heat level of the soup seems to be one less level than what was ordered, e.g. I ordered medium and it tasted like mild. It was cool to see the rice scooped out of an actual stone pot though. 

Service wasn't that inviting when we got to the restaurant but the wait staff seemed to warm up during our meal and were more friendly. Also, with your check, you get a piece of Haitai melon gum but you'll probably want to go elsewhere to fulfill that sweet tooth since the flavor of the gum lasts about 11.8 seconds after you first starting chewing.
author: Maya S.

description:
I've only been here once and I crave their tofo soup every day. I got the seafood tofo soup, which I will be getting again the next time. 

I can't stress enough how much you need to try their tofo soup!!!!!!!!!!

Rookie mistake: they give you side plates, which included one egg. I thought it was hard boiled and I got some of the yolk on my leg lol. Now I know you're supposed to mix it in with the soup haha.
author: Ron D.

description: Food was ok, not many options compare to other Korean food. 20% tips forcefully added to the bill when I only have 4 people. Been eating here once a while but probably go somewhere else if I have better option.
author: Tango N.

description: Visiting from LA and had the worst customer service here from one of our waitresses and she's the restaurant owner it turns out. when asked if they had sliced lemon and she just says no with a very rude attitude. Later we asked for side dishes to be refilled(b/c they never stopped and asked) and our server instead cleans table without telling us to wait or anything. It wasn't busy time and there were several empty tables so cleaning can wait. So we complained about her rude attitude and service. She then walking pass us by and murmuring to us to have manner. If you have something you need to say, stop and say it in front of your customer.
author: Jinny J.

description:
This restaurant is located in the Inner Richmond which it is easier to find parking there than downtown.  
I had dinner on Saturday night around 7pm. Fortunately, I could sit down not to wait but It was very crowded inside.

The atmosphere in the restaurant was democratic and simple.
The service was average but it depend on the servicer. 
The value was reasonable. 

There are standard menu items and the restaurant doesn't have alcohol items.
This is One of my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. 

(Rating: +++ is perfect) 
Original Soft Tofu +++: 
I couldn't stop to eat after I took a sip of it, though the soup I ordered "medium" and chicken was a little spicy for me, there were chicken, smooth Tofu, vegetables into the soup. I could enjoy putting a raw egg into soup.
 
Kalbi +++:
Kalbi was so juicy and the sauce was sweet and rich. 

Korean style appetizers were Kimuch, cubed daikon kimuch,  spinach namul, bean sprouts namul and fried fish.
 
The rice boiled in a stone pot was nice.

How well organized everything!
author: Hiromi S.

description:
Probably one of the best tofu houses I've been to. Came here on a Saturday for lunch and was able to snag a table immediately. Love the ban chan options- my favorite are the fish cakes and the fried fish. We ordered the kalbi  ($25) and original tofu soup with pork and mushroom ($11). The tofu is so soft and the soup is very flavorful. Although the kalbi dish is more on the expensive side, it does come with a lot of meat. I love picking out the grilled onions from underneath. 

Love how they pour tea into the stone pot of leftover rice so you can drink a rice tea soup at the end. Service is great and they are very friendly. Request a refill on a banchan or your drink and it's immediately done for you.

Metered parking is plentiful but try searching for residential spots. Wasn't too difficult.

You will definitely leave full, satisfied, and with a bag of leftovers.
author: Lauren K.

description: The seafood pancake was not fully cooked, bulgogi was overcooked, taste so dry! Waiters were super rude!! It was from my 2012 visit to the restaurant! Hope they change now, I have to post this because it was such an awful experience! I wanted to treat my mom for a nice lunch but it turned out that we were both upset after!
author: Chelsea L.

description:
I came in for lunch one day before heading to Baker's Beach and left happy with a full stomach! My boyfriend and I ordered the kimchi tofu soup with beef and the lunch size spicy pork. The food was on the pricier side, but what isn't in SF? 

-Tofu soup: Tons of large chunks of tofu and the soup itself had a lot of flavor and didn't need much added spice
-Spicy pork: Really flavorful and pretty big portion for lunch. Not very spicy

I would say these two dishes are the perfect amount to share between 3 people.
author: Estelle C.

description:
all the soondubu was on point, boiling hot and delicious.  banchan not a big variety but was very good and fried fish too.  the best part was the rice, otherwise I would only give it 4 stars.  the rice made it 5 stars for sure.  the most hot and silky fluffy korean rice i've had in a long time.  gotta be a metal bowl and out of the stone pot with the rice stuck crisply on the sides.  Add hot water at the end or rip some off to just eat like that is both awesome.  The rice water is so clean and full of rice flavor.  I felt as if I was cleaning my system with super clean rice water.  It was refreshing and so healthy, lol.  Most great korean places have fantastic rice, and this is one of them.  

galbi at $27 for a ok portion was pricey but pretty good.  the size reminded me of BCD in Los Angeles but BCD is much more flavorful and at $10 or $12.

But i'll be back to my tofu house on the regular.

grew up in SF, never been cuz they ain't got any hite or soju.  but its ok, when i want a good meal and not have to drink so much, this is the place to be.
author: Kevin L.

description: Every time I come here the food is consistent and sometimes there can be a line but it usually goes by fast. I usually get the original tofu soup which is great and the short ribs are amazing.
author: Prescott C.

description: Great food and great service! We ordered mushroom tofu soup and it was delicious! They have a great selection of side dishes (including a fried fish). I shared a soup with my friend, and it filled us because of all the side dishes. :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
This is one of our favorite places for a nutritious meal!  My husband and I love their food so much; we at least eat there once a week.

Awesome food!
author: Tiffany S.

description: Alot of hype. The place is usually jam packed and has a waiting list. I came here on july 3 ,16 for dinner and was fortunate we (table of 2) got seated in fifteen minutes. The side dishes that come out are A1. I believe the kimchi is made fresh from the kitchen. The fish is a bit salty but I would say A2. The panacakes are hype but believe me they are goooooood. Tofu Soup has pretty good broth and not too spicy and just right for me (go da mild). Barley Tea is on point. Tofu Soup hits your palate at all angles. You can taste the beef and tofu and broth with the same intensity. Good when karl (fog) is out. When I finished I was put into a food coma real quick like 0-120.
author: Brian C.

description:
I love My Tofu House!! This is my favorite place for Korean lunch! They have lunch special from 11am-4pm (Weekdays only) in which you can order meat dishes for lunch pricing (~$10 cheaper). Portion is not as big as the dinner dish, but it is definitely enough for 2 people. We usually order a combination soft tofu and a galbi or bulgogi for the both of us. Comes with rice. 

As for side dishes, you get a good amount of them (kimchi, radish, cucumber, fried fish, and more). Oh my gosh, the fish is so good, I even take my fiancee's fish!! Everything is refillable, except for the fried fish. Extra fish is around $1.50! Totally worth it! 

The servers are very attentive and great service. Never once did they mess up our orders. That's very important. They always came to fill up our tea. Oh yea! You get complementary candies, sometimes gum, when you get your bill^^
author: Jamie T.

description: Best soon tofu you'll find in the city. We came in on a weekend night so it was pretty busy but not too long of a wait. The servers were also very attentive and came by our table multiple times to make sure we had enough water and side dishes.
author: Jamie K.

description:
I've been to lots of good Korean places in California. When compared to those places, My Tofu House is pretty average.

I ordered the baked tofu and veggies bi bim bap and it was pretty good. Perfect for a light dinner. The ban chan was average though, and there wasn't a whole lot of variety.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Food for the Korean comfort soul! One of the best Korean places in SF that leaves you with a warm belly and a full heart. Huge amounts of food for a great price (~$15-$25) My good friend says he comes here to refuel for the week and I left agreeing whole-heartedly. 

Amazing tofu stew - original with beef and kimchi spicy is my favorite.

Get seafood pancake.
Come with lots of friends or it's a great place to be a pig with a loved one.
*They do not serve alcohol, but there's a cocktail bar across the street
author: Kristin C.

description:
I like their tofu soup here. comes out piping hot as heck so be careful and let it cool down before eating. 

the service is pretty good here. I got my tea refilled twice without asking and it is rare at times especially when the place is crowed. 

not a lot of banchans here but you get a yellow croaker. and the fish is my favorite part of meal. 

couple of flat screen tv and had the Giants game on. Bonus!
author: Jules L.

description:
Mediocre soondubu. I want to say that I like this place but i don't think I do. Although it was on the list of "Things you must eat in SF before you die," I felt like I could have passed away without trying this. Don't get me wrong, it didn't taste bad. It just tasted... okay. I got the seafood soondubu with no spices which I always do and was underwhelmed. The bf got the spicy dumplings soondubu medium and he was a little happier than me. The ban chans were whatever, the service was okay. They didn't give us our free fish until I had to ask twice - which slightly irked me. The barley tea in the stone pot was ok, nothing to rave about.

All in all, mediocre. I'd try another restaurant if you had the chance but if you must have soondubu, this will suffice for the time being.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
This is our goto place for Korean soft tofu soup. You select your soup, meat, spiciness. I like it spicy.  Rice is included and is served in a stone bowl to keep it warm. You also get 5 sides (banchan) as well as fried fish (croaker). Bulgari is OK and costs more at dinnertime. 
It's a satisfying meal especially on a foggy evening.
author: Shane C.

description:
The food was amazing!    

The service was less than amazing.  The wait staff were polite and nice, but very overworked.  I think there were only 3 of them for the entire restaurant with a line out the door.    Luckily, the food was good and we could easily overlook the short coming. 

I'll be back!
author: Matt V.

description: Although the price is higher than what I'm used to in LA, the food is better than your typical late night soondubu joint. My family of four ordered three soups: Kimchi, Mixed, and Fish Roe Soondubu, and they came out extremely hot (just how we like it) with rice cooked in a stone pot (so fresh). We also ordered a family sized seafood pancake, and it was easily the crispiest Hamuel Jeon I've ever had (although pricey). We came to SF on a family trip, and we were craving some good Korean food (we can't go a day without it haha), and My Tofu House did not disappoint. The fish roe soup was surprisingly good. It's the first time I've seen it in tofu soup, and I now wonder why people don't make it that way. Really recommend for people who are looking for good Korean food in the city. I realized there aren't too many!
author: Sarah P.

description:
Consistently great service. Tofu soups are amazing. But the bi bim bap could be improved. So can the seafood pancake, which is inconsistent the few times we've had it.

Get the tofu soup and you're golden.
author: Emma T.

description: A really tasty spot for Korean comfort fare (soft tofu soup, bibimbap, etc). Service is friendly and they're quite efficient, tables turn quickly so even if there is a bit of a wait, just sign their list and you'll be ok. It's got Mom-and-Pop charm, but without the typical Richmond total-hole-in-the-wall thing. Interestingly they don't serve any alcoholic drinks, but they've got tea. Loved my bibimbap and the overall vibe, especially on a foggy and cold SF night!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
So i discovered My Tofu House a couple years back and im happy to say im still in Love with this resturant!  Hands down my Favorite Korean spot in the City!!(S.F.) my wife and i regularly travel from Sacramento just to eat here!(foodie)
The food here is Seriously Amazing!!! I almost feel like im eating grandmas cooking whenever i dine here.. along with Every meal a complimentary side of Fried Makerel is served that melts in your mouth like Butter!!! All the tofu soups and bbq dishes are cooked to perfection. The ambiance and decor of the resturant make you feel like your right in the heart of Seoul!! Now the wait time for a table is usually a little bit but who really cares when you know your about to experience a FoodGasm!! All in all this is a Must Try if your into Real Authentic Korean food!!
author: Michael D.

description:
I've been soul-searching for some decent soondubu jjigae and I've found it! Most of the Korean restaurants in the Bay Area pale in comparison to My Tofu House (they just can't get the broth right). I'd recommend getting the Combination Tofu Soup and the Kalbi! Although I agree with the prices being a bit high, I think it's fair considering the place is located in San Francisco where EVERYTHING is expensive. 

If you're looking for a quick seat here, I'd come here way in advance. I was looking for a table for two around 9:00pm (a hour before it closes) and it was still a hour wait. No parking, really small lobby area to wait around in, but worth the wait! Don't forget to sign your name up at the front!
author: Angie Y.

description:
I love My Tofu House -- they have the very best tofu soup, and their banchan is really tasty too. The only downside is that it seems that everybody else likes My Tofu House as well, so there's often a pretty long wait, especially if it's cold outside.

I usually order the original tofu with beef, medium spicy. The banchan that comes with the order is really tasty too, my favorite is the sliced fish cake, but the kimchee, radishes, pickles, and sprouts are good too. The banchan comes with a delicious fried fish -- the bones are soft and edible, and are an excellent source of calcium too.

The tofu is delivered to your table at a raging boil -- be sure to crack the raw egg into it while it's still boiling so that it can cook. 

When I go to My Tofu House, I almost always get the tofu, since that's obviously their speciality. However, their seafood pancakes, bibimbap, and bbq pork are excellent too.

Did I mention that My Tofu House is a terrific deal too? $12 for the banchan, tofu, and rice. Wow!
author: Allen T.

description:
The wait here is gnarly, we didnt sit down til 9:00 on a Saturday, but its quite worth it! I was taken here by an actual Korean who has really high standards for his tofu soup and he says this place is almost as good as K-Town in LA. I am not a Korean food expert, but what sets this place apart from other places are the fried fishes with side dishes, and the soupy tea-rice porridge they prepare for you at the end. I was so full by the end of the meal, I didn't try it but it sounds pretty interesting..

I guess I'd try coming early or during lunch!
author: Katie S.

description:
Only I would go to a Korean restaurant when I do meatless Mondays.. lol. So my options were very limited that night! I ordered the Vegetarian Tofu Soup and it was lovely! I asked for medium level spice and it was not spicy at all! Next time, I will go for the most spicy option. The portion size for the tofu soup was def more than enough for one person so plan on sharing if you're going to order up more dishes! 

Lucky for us, we waited maybe 5-10 minutes for a table. The service was just okay-  I think they forgot about us as soon as our food came? But don't worry, I'm coming back again when I'm not going meatless that day!!
author: Michelle L.

description: I always look forward to going to the Tofu House because they have the best tofu soup! We ordered the mushroom soup. Great flavor and not salty! The small dishes of cucumbers, Kim chee, sprouts, spicy radishes and fried fish were delicious. We also ordered the seafood egg pancake. It was fluffy in the inside and crispy in the outside, again delicious. One of my favorite parts of the meal is when they put tea in the iron rice bowl.  The 'soupy rice' is a real treat. What more can I say? 5 stars!
author: Lena L.

description: Food is fantastic! We had the bolgogi, kalbi, and chicken, combo soup and bibimbap. All were very flavorful. Good quality meat. Because the dishes were prepared in the kitchen we didn't have to leave smelling like other BBQ. Service was excellent; they are very attentive. Great place for Korean cravings in SF.
author: Heather L.

description: Love the food. Loathe the service. We've been coming here for years and they still serve consistently delicious Korean food with mediocre service. They often forget our drinks and have to be reminded at least twice or we have to ask for soup bowls even after we said we were sharing. There's usually a long line at night. Same story this past Friday with the line and service but we didn't mind because we knew it would be worth it. Also, they don't serve or allow alcohol so you don't get the true Korean experience until you hear loud voices slamming down cups of soju but at any rate, they have the best Kimchee Soup and their Pancake is very good. All of the BBQ meats are cooked well, hot and tasty and their Bi Bim Bap are very good. The veggies are fresh and there's enough of everything in the clay pot. For all their dishes, the requested spicy hot level is always perfect. I'm glad they still include the dish of whole fish in their Bon Chon but they never ask if you want anymore of the little dishes. They'll bring more if you ask though so that's fine enough.
author: Jen L.

description:
Growing to adore a particular restaurant can be heartbreaking.  My favorite Mexican joint led me down an agonizing path that emulated the arc of a long term relationship slowly falling to pieces.  A long-time Thai favorite exhibited a more slippery slope, moving from stratosphere to ho-hum in the course of two visits separated by a long swath of time.  

I have no relationship with My Tofu House but I do have a relationship with a more favored (by me) Korean place where the food is cheaper and, by my estimate, better.  I hesitate to brand that place as a favorite for fear that the minute I do so it'll begin to leave me wanting.  But that place is the one against which I've now begun comparing others and, for better or worse, is likely the reason I wasn't wowed by My Tofu House.  

I ordered up the Kimchi Soft Tofu Soup ($11.99) with beef (pork is also an option).  This item, from this restaurant, made the 2010 Big Eat SF List of "100 Things to try Before You Die" and honestly?  It was fine soft tofu soup but I prefer that from the other place.  It might be authentic, but I wasn't overly fond of the flavor imparted by the egg, self-cracked into the soup, where it cooks up in the bubbly broth.  

The Beef & Vegetable Bibimbab ($16.59) was ordered by my dining partner who liked it, complimented its level of spiciness, then closed the meal by remarking "the other place does it better", which pretty much says it all.  

Banchan, including two fresh-fried fish, were good and refills were happily offered.  Tea is poured and refilled by a server into individual cups.  

My Tofu House closes earlier than many of the nearby Korean joints in this, the area I've dubbed "the KBBQ District" and their prices are in line with those nearby places.  That said, dinner here (with tax, but without drinks or tip) came to $31.  The same dinner at the other place, including tax and a beer, ran $25.  Hell, I'm just going to say it:  I do have a favorite Korean restaurant.  Let the heartbreak begin.
author: Tracey A.

description:
One of my favorite places to go to for Korean food, especially tofu soup. I love their banchans because they give you the fishes which are absolutely delicious! Not all Korean places offer this. 

We came here on a Saturday weekend and was so surprised at how full the restaurant was by 6:00! We had to wait 30 minutes for a party of 4 so it wasn't too bad. The tofu soup has never disappointed and it was extra good given how cold it has been lately.

We also ordered the bibimbap and the short ribs. Never ordered be short ribs because I feel it is a little pricey for how much you get, but the flavors were spot on. For those who are more on a budget, I would advise ordering two tofu soups and bibimbap for two people and you will most likely be full. Parking can be difficult since it is in the heart of Geary area but you can be lucky at times. Arrive early because there is always a wait!!
author: Wendy Z.

description: Love this place! Great service and delicious Korea meals. My favorite is kimuchi tofu soup. Some Korean restaurants don't have good flavor of soup but this place does. Highly recommended.
author: Haruka Y.

description: I am really sad to give a bad review to this place as the food is wonderful. The reason for one star is that I had a real shock when I saw all those rats from the overflown dumpster next to the restaurant literally jumping around and going into the restaurant's building through the holes in the wall! I was scared that one of them would jump into our car. It was disgusting and scary. Please fix it.
author: Lela B.

description: All good things must come to an end. We have been dining here for over 15 years and have many fond memories of time wit family. Including the kids standing on the seats looking through the slats at other diners. This past year we have seen prices climb and quality drop.  No longer a value and no longer tasty at any price.  So long old friend.
author: Jenny M.

description:
For my friends birthday, we decided to go get Korean food.  Only one area came to mind that would satisfy our need for authentic korean food, Richmond District along Geary Boulevard. Along this strip, there is a korean bbq spot on every block so it can be a little overwhelming. I was told that My Tofu House and Brothers were the two places worth trying. 

We decided to give My Tofu House a shot since there wasn't enough of us to fully take advantage of Brothers grill station. Next time, I hope to get at least two more people and head back to Brothers to see if it is any good.

We decided to order Kimichi Soft Tofu, Kalbi, and Bibimbab Bowl.

Kalbi: super tender, juicy cuts of meat lacquered in a sweet and savory sauce. Accented with a gentle charcoal smokey flavor

Tofu Soup: abundance of silky tofu swimming in a rich kimichi broth. 

Service: fare, attentive enough

Overall Thoughts

I would easily come back to My Tofu House for their BBQ
author: Eddie W.

description:
I think that it is good as much as BCD in LA. 
The service was the best besides the best Mandu Tofu which is my favor.
author: Woody K.

description: Pretty good meal, however, after paying and starting to walk out, the cashier was quite rude repeatedly saying, Tip? No tip? Where's the tip? Not going to give a tip? Like really, I gave a tip. He's lucky that I still decided to give them a bit extra despite his rudeness.
author: Cameron L.

description:
It was just okay.
I got a Kalbi plate for dinner. The portion was not big but kind of pricey, $27. I would rather go to AYCE place in Japan town or something if I really want some decent/ok meat like they have here.
author: C M.

description: Hadn't been here in a while, not by choice, but because my usual dinner dates aren't into Korea cuisine. Dined here last week, the food was fine, but something seemed to be missing. I finally put my finger on it - the nice family that used to staff the place has been replaced with wordless, unsmiling young robot-dudes. The day after I stopped by, I supped at Mandalay a few blocks away, and the difference in attitude was stunning. No longer welcoming, so I don't have the urge to go back anytime soon.
author: Nick C.

description:
Tried this place on a cold night perfect for some bubbly hot soup.   

Their service was pretty accommodating, we were sitting in the back room, so it was kind of hard to flag down a waiter.   

The back room is perfect if you are rolling deep with a crowd up to 12.   There are 3 tables that can seat up to 4.   

I love tofu soup but compared to BCD Tofu House in and around L.A, this place is aiight.   

This place needs more flavor, and their mild or medium is barely spicy.   So don't be afraid to order spicy if you actually want a little spice.    

Other than that, it's perfect for any time of day.
author: Roxana N.

description:
My go-to soondubu restaurant in the city.
Your typical Korean joint that has a small menu and horrible service- seriously, horrendous service. 

Their soondubu is pretty standard and they offer different levels of spiciness (but I've found that their spiciness scale is prettttty weak).
author: Mandi W.

description: fast service and all those side dishes are ON. POINT. i have recently become obsessed with korean food and am constantly on the look out for great places. the waiter also gave us a free order of rice since they were about to close. i will be returning.
author: Alyssa L.

description: This place is awesome. Even Tho they do not have a lot choices from menu but the food here is enough to fill 2x as much in your belly with satisfaction. The meat here taste great and authentic steamed rice in stone pot very Yummy. I'll definitely come here often. Another Favourite restaurant check from my list.
author: Unyo N.

description:
Busy place!

They give you a free fish like BCD. :) Yum yum.

Flavorful soup. Yummy gal bee. Good side dishes. Everything was tasty! 

Can stop by the Korean grocery next door on your way out.
author: Audrey L.

description:
This is my go-to restaurant whenever I start craving Korean Tofu!  I've tried other restaurants before but for some reason I always come back here in order to satisfy my craving.

The wait was about 30 minutes which was expected on a Saturday night.  But I was with friends, so I didn't think it was too bad.

I love their variety of banchan.  My favorite was always the fish cake! And, they also have a fried fish that's pretty good! I often don't see other restaurants offering fish, so it's pretty nice that they offer one per person.  It's just the right amount of crispness without being too dry.

I also thought the servers were really nice and friendly and occasionally came up to see if we wanted more tea and water.  Although it's expected at restaurants, not all other places do this so it was really sweet of them to.

This time I did try their seafood pancake, which we thought looked very good when another table ordered it.  I thought it was just okay though and it wasn't something super special that wowed me.

My favorite was always the tofu soup here. It has a great amount of tofu with a flavorful broth.  I always end up coming back here because I haven't yet found another restaurant that had a flavorful broth in the area yet.  I'll stick to this restaurant until I do find another but this is already hard to beat! I left super stuffed and satisfied!
author: Teresa W.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant in town! I have tried so many places but this place is the best.
author: Surada L.

description:
Good food but wooooah I didn't expect the bill. And not in a good sense either. The amount we paid was a bit ridiculous for a group of five not to mention the guy didn't even care that we needed refills. 

Someone please tell me what's up with places giving you small cups of water. It only creates more work because you have to continuously refill my water. 

The tofu soup was pretty good though
author: Katherine L.

description: Great tofu soup especially over rice. I like the original tofu soup with beef or pork extra spicy. The assorted side dishes are good too.
author: Katherine W.

description:
I can't believe I've never reviewed this place after eating here so many times through the years, but maybe it's been awhile since I've visited!  We came here looking for something warm to fill our tummies and I thought the soondoobu would fit the bill nicely.  I got the original soft tofu soup and love the fact that you can choose how spicy you'd like it to be.  The tofu in the soup is great, so smooth and silky and the fish they give you as one of the ban chan is always very tasty as well!  

The only thing that I don't like about this place is that the price has gone up quite a bit over time.  Working in finance, I definitely understand the concept of inflation, but it seems like it's starting to get to the point to where it's become an every once in awhile kind of place for me instead of a go-to place.
author: Jeff C.

description:
If you're on the hunt for tofu soup, I would only suggest you come here for it if you are already in the area.

First of all, My Tofu House is located in the Richmond, which is somewhat far for anyone that doesn't live in the neighborhood. Second of all, it's $13.38 for soft tofu soup, which is on the high end for tofu soup in the city. Though the food is quite good, I don't think it is worth the price, especially given the location.

If you're looking for good tofu soup, you can find it in more convenient locations and at cheaper prices! I'd suggest 707 Sutter. Their tofu soup is $10 with a free raw egg, rice, and refillable side dishes, and is located near Union Square.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
The fried fish that comes with the banchan is delicious! Watch out for the small bones though...but so long as you are careful removing the spine, you'll be fine. Now I've actually gone to my fair share of Korean tofu restaurants, but it's actually the first time I've had banchan that featured such an item. The rest of their fair was pretty standard: chilli fish cakes, pickled cucumbers, kimchi, bean sprouts, and radishes. These dishes, with exception to the whole fish, are refilled by request.

I had the medium spicy original soft tofu soup. While it was very red in color...it was not spicy...at all. Wish I had known this. It did feature a good amount of tofu and thinly sliced button mushrooms though (enoki would have been better). I ordered mine with pork, but there really wasn't a lot of it...just a few pieces here and there...kind of disappointing.

Service-wise, they are kind of odd. They actually let one of my friends who arrived early sit in a booth for over 30 minutes while the rest of us arrived...I mean, it was cool that we had a seat right away, but I can't see this being smart on the business end. And I'm hoping it was an odd coincidence, but they kept refilling one of my friend's and my tea cup, but blatantly skipped over my other friend (not Asian) multiple times...despite his cup being more depleted than ours.

Overall, I found the food to be good, but not amazing. It's price point is San Francisco standard, but I'm not sure I'll be back when I know I can get equal or better quality for $3 less (as far as tofu soups go)...I can't even begin to justify a $23 seafood pancake, so I won't even try.
author: Elaine Y.
