description: Probably one of the better tofu houses in the bay area, and their kitchen is pretty quick on orders. Unfortunately, they only have 2 or 3 servers at any given time. Better to come during non peak hours if you can. The sides they give you include a full fried mackerel. Will definitely be back.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
I had a pretty good experience here. I've tried coming here before but the wait was crazy long so I went somewhere else. There are times when the wait is completely empty so I hope you get lucky. 

The service here was okay. A little disappointed that the sides and rice did not come out before the main dishes, but I'm not sure if it was because they were busy. Anyways, our food came out with some complimentary fried fish, possibly mackerel. This is one of my bf's favorite parts about this restaurant. Also, they bring out a pot of rice and leave it on your table. It serves about two and a half bowls of rice and then they refill the pot with water. I thought this was because they didn't want the rice to stick to the pot butt bf said that it could be a dish also since they leave the pot on the table. 

We ordered the seafood tofu soup with mild spice and the spicy pork. The soup was good but I felt that the mild spice had no spice, or at least there wasn't any kick to it. I enjoyed the pork. It had a red chili pepper next to it warning you that it would be spicy. I can't remember if it was medium spice or not, but I thought it had a good amount of spice to it.

Would I recommend this place? Sure why not! It was on a list of places to eat in SF so check it out for yourself!
author: Cathie N.

description:
Pretty good food! Only thing is they are understaffed = poor service and a little pricey.

FOOD:

- side dishes (free): FRIED FISH! this was actually really good, and surprised they gave us 3 for free. 5 other side dishes were ok. 
http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/25JWaA3q41VJVqil7fmlIg/l.jpg

- assorted mushroom in soft tofu soup ($10.60): mmm, the tofu was actually really soft. really good soft tofu, and the soup looks like the most popular dish at this restaurant. also, mild spicy isn't that spicy at all when in other places it's a little spicy. http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/09aQIjVgA_VCjTfftphPHg/l.jpg

- grilled chicken/Dak Gui ($18.21): sweet, yummy, tasty! cooked with onions to a delicious hot plate
http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WLQZ8v5QWFfTaC1R1Z5kEg/l.jpg

- seafood pancake ($17.28): good too! make sure to ask for dipping sauce that didn't come with it, because it tasted so much better. it wasn't only seafood, but they had green and red peppers as well. 
http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SdwQlToDDMA25tyoR0qt2w/l.jpg

SERVICE:

3 servers and about 14-15 tables... took us a while to order, a while to refill our tea, a while to get our bill... Tofu House, hire another service please!!!

AMBIANCE: 

busy korean restaurant, flat screen tv on the side so only a few tables can watch, lights that looked like you were in a cruise ship. Casual attire/ambiance. It's a typical busy korean restaurant atmosphere

OVERALL: 

3 stars.  Good food, bad service, maybe i'll come back in the future.
author: Raquel Y.

description: We were blown away with every bite. It's rare to go to a restaurant where literally every dish that is served tastes great and this was it for us. Everything from the banchan to the kalbi and soondubu that we ordered was delectable. We loved how they also give you the fish as a part of the banchan and everything came out steaming hot and fresh. We are hoping to make our way here regularly, even though it's pretty out of the way for both of us.
author: Annie S.

description: Bulgogi and banchans were very delicious, so flavourful. They give a lot of bulgogi.  Very pricey as well. This is my new korean spot! But only once a month! Lol
author: Anna M.

description: The tofu soups are amazing- we ordered the seafood, dumpling and mushroom. All are very good! The side dishes are delicious and the kimchi is nice too. The beef bulgogi was a perfect complement to our tofu soups too. Definitely highly recommended!
author: Fanny N.

description:
Food (4/5): I got the vegetable soft tofu soup w/ mild spiciness and dumplings ($1 extra). I wish there were more veggies and dumplings, since they were so good, but overall I thought the food was really flavorful. I liked their banchan too! My friends ordered soft tofu soups as well, and they both enjoyed their orders. 

There's also complimentary tea! If you want water, ask for it. 

Service (4/5): Service was good albeit a bit slow - I think they had two servers working in a packed restaurant. They messed up my order by giving me ramen instead of dumplings, but they fixed it quickly. 

Value (3/5): I think this is a bit on the pricey end - it seems like prices went up in the last few years. Each tofu soup was listed at 13.88 on the menu, although on Yelp I see some pictures showing below 10. The prices only go up for other items like bibimbap, seafood pancakes, and the grilled meats, so don't come here expecting a cheap meal.

My Tofu House satisfied my craving for soon dobu, and I'd definitely come back for more!
author: Abby S.

description:
The only reason why I would be so hesitant to come back here is because of the service.. there were two waiters running around and they seemed like they were taking their time seating people, cleaning dishes, taking orders. The restaurant isn't THAT big, but were they understaffed or does this always happen? My sister and I came here around 1:30pm and there was a 30 min wait, so we came back around 2:45 and got seated 10 minutes later when there were clearly empty tables and NO line except one group of three in front of us. Before we got seated, we took a look at their menu so we could decide what we wanted to save time. Right when we got seated in a booth, our waiter probably took another 10-15 minutes to take our order and give us tea even when I told him immediately we were ready to order.

By glancing at the menu, I could tell the highlight is their tofu soup (hence their name.) They have a good variety at 11.50 each for lunch and dinner. However, they do have a selection of meat such as bulgogi and kalbi that vary in price depending when you go (lunch is roughly $11-12, dinner is about $21.37 I think? Odd pricing). Lunch prices only go up to 4PM, excluding weekends and holidays I believe so go during a weekday if you can. Each dish comes with a pot of rice and banchan (kimchi, cucumber, sprouts, fish cake). My sister and I shared the original tofu soup with chicken, and one plate of bulgogi. I have to admit, I was REALLY full afterwards. They even gave us a plate of two fried fish.. maybe mackerel? Not too sure. 

Definitely only coming here for their tofu soup in the future.. maybe I'll try the one with ramen noodles in it. Do NOT come here if you're looking for a variety of korean dishes... unless you're craving STRICTLY spicy tofu soup. Go somewhere else instead.

Also, forgot to add that I wanted the tofu soup medium spicy. Was barely spicy at all (almost felt like there was no spice at all). Oh and they put the egg on the side for you to crack. Do it while it's still sizzling!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Food: 
Side dishes: ( The worst kimchi I ever had among all Korean food..and others weren't good at all. They really need some improvements !)
Service:( Bring your own water and napkins,,, )

Overall the food are okay.
author: Lyn Z.

description:
On a previous visit, there was a kid wearing pretend knight armor. No such medievalry on my most recent trip. Instead I got 2 tables of 3 ajumma each, back-to-back, both directly across from me. One set was Asian American, speaking English; the other was Korean. It was interesting to note the differences in gossip and interaction. I sort of referred to the groups as flip-flops vs. boots. Can you guess which was which?

The lunchtime / early afternoon menu was limited, but it still had numerous dishes I wanted to try. Next time I go, though, I don't want to watch another muted football match (Newcastle United 0-2 Manchester City). This restaurant should take some TV channel selection cues from Dong Baek, Wooden Charcoal, Zazang, or Casserole House.
author: Dan B.

description:
I've been here a couple times over the years.  For San Francisco standards, it's pretty solid.  The soondooboo is around $10 and pretty good.  I would note that their spice levels are pretty weak, though.  So, even if you think you're a weakling, I'd suggest you go a level up.  For example, I'm weak, so I asked my soup to be "mild."  When it came out, it was pretty much white.  I tried my sister's "medium" soondooboo, and I would consider that to be mild.

The banchan selection is decent, but not amazeballs like some places in, say, the Temescal area of Oakland where they give you like a dozen items.  Here you get a fried fish, kimchi, pickled cucumbers, some bean curd thing, some bean sprouts.  Decent.  

The meat dishes are pretty overpriced for dinner portions.  It's like $20+ for each BBQ platter, which is really a bit much.  

Overall, the food is good and it'll probably hit the spot if you're craving Korean in San Francisco.
author: Vivian C.

description:
As you can tell by the name, this place is known for its tofu soup. I've been here twice and I must admit that they do serve the best tofu soup out of all the korean restaurants that I have been to. Their tofu always has the perfect soft texture and the soup is super flavorful. However, besides the tofu soup, everything else tastes just mediocre. In addition, this place is way too expensive. Today I was here for lunch with a friend, and we ordered one tofu soup, one bibimbip, and a kalbi, and the total came out to be 70+..... like wtf really?? O_O With that price, we could easily get a much decent lunch at a fancy restaurant in downtown. Service was subpar as well. Although the people who work there were not very slow, there were simply not enough people working there given the high volume of customers. 

In conclusion, because of the poor value, I don't think I would come back to this place again, unless I'm already in the area and have a lot of money to blow ._.
author: Ying Y.

description: I liked the seafood tofu soup, which you can customize the spice level. The appetizers (banchan) were good too, I always enjoy the salted fish. The dinner price of BBQ dishes are very expensive compared to other Korean places, and it's very tough to find parking!!
author: Alice S.

description:
My favorite Korean restaurant in SF for lunch. I only come here for their lunch deal which is from 11AM-4PM (not including weekends and holidays).

Their BBQ meats are less expensive during lunch than during dinner. Plus, their lunch and dinner BBQ meat portions are the same size also.

I usually order the Kal Bi/Spicy Pork and Combination Tofu Soup ($11.99). 

Love their banchan (Korean side dishes) here especially the fish cake. The banchan they serve to you are unlimited, you can ask for more with no extra charge --except for the fried fish, they will charge.

Kal bi lunch: ~ $17
Kal bi dinner: ~ $26

Bulgoki lunch: ~ $13
Bulgoki dinner: ~ $23

Spicy pork lunch: ~ $12
Spicy pork dinner: ~ $21

Boneless chicken lunch: ~ $12
Boneless chicken dinner: ~ $21
author: B. R.

description: What better way is there to warm up on a cold, foggy night in the Inner Richmond? My favourite is the Dumpling and Tofu soup, spicy of course. Seriously, get spicy (it's not that spicy). They also have some of the best kimchi I've had in the area. Although I felt the banchan was otherwise not very extensive. Perhaps the Korean joints in South Bay have spoiled me!  But the service was good and always offered to refill our banchan plates. Either way, solid spot!
author: Andrew D.

description:
Nice that they have vegetarian options, but the bimimbap just wasn't the best. The rice didn't get crispy which meant my craving wasn't satisfied. The pancake was good, it's the fluffy variety. 

The booths seat 6 adults. If your group is bigger, not sure what the seating options are.
author: Shal J.

description:
I was the only Caucasian in the place... cool... I knew I was in good hands!
My favorite Korean restaurant Muguboka was closed for Mother's Day so we followed the advice of fellow Yelpers and explored My Tofu House.  The guy next to us was eating Bulgogi and he had some sort of angelic halo about him... so I had to have what he was eating.  It was really amazing.  My only criticism was that the spicy was not as spicy as I like it.  The server was busy but did not ignore us, and he even made time to ask how our meal was.  A small thing but worth premium points in my book.  Good job guys!
author: Craig A.

description:
Solid location for soondubu!

Stopped by for lunch on a Sunday after spending some time in Golden Gate Park. I had no problem getting a seat and I ordered the mushroom soondubu with mild spice. The waiters were attentive but gave me my space when I pulled out my book to read which was awesome. 

The banchan here is great! They give you an entire little fish which was really flavorful and yummy. My favorite banchan is the cucumber dish and it was perfectly seasoned with rice vinegar; the kimchi was very good too: two kinds! (cabbage and daikon). Aside from these there were bean sprouts and fish cakes which were solid.

My mushroom tofu soup arrived steaming hot with a raw egg on the side to crack into the broth. They also brought me an entire pot of rice which was way more than I could have finished but it was delicious with a few green peas and chick peas sprinkled in. The mushroom soup had TONS of mushrooms which was great because sometimes when you order a tofu soup with beef (or another item) it seems as though you only receive a couple pieces. Not here! I had around 3 or 4 different types of mushrooms and they were delicious! The tofu was plentiful and soft and the broth was good too but I would recommend ordering medium if you want some spice as mild was a bit too mild for my taste.

My Tofu House is waaaay better than the korean places near my place, I wish it was closer to me!!
author: Sam F.

description:
When the fog comes into the bay of SF and it's cold, my choice is often the spicy tofu soup with either seafood, chicken or beef and their beef short ribs!  It surely warms the stomach and soul.  I love how they provide a raw egg for the soup because it adds a more flavorful taste to the tofu soup.  

Owned by Korean owners and often crowded during the evenings for dinner time, this place never disappoints on their dishes!  I have went here a few times now and have tried most of their dishes they have to offer.  I do recommend that if you don't feel like short ribs, then go for the pork or bulgoki.  All of their meat dishes are relatively juicy, sauced up, and drenched with onion flavor!  Their meat dishes are pricier during dinner time by an increase of 10 bucks!  SO go for lunch if you have the time to instead of dinner!

What's special about their side dishes compared to other Korean restaurants I have tried thus far is that they provide fried fish!  

I love how cozy the place is and their waiters are service friendly!  Gotta love the mama papa ambiance to this place!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
My go-to order here is the dumpling soft tofu! It comes with ~5 dumplings, rice cakes and a little bit of beef. The servers are very efficient and are more than willing to refill your table's supply of banchan! I've never tried the meat here - I can't get myself to pay the dinner price for it - but my husband and I have made this our soondubu place!

Be prepared to wait for a table if you come around 7pm. I like that they do have a couple of TVs mounted - makes it easy to catch the Warriors or Giants games!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Overall my experience there was good. Came with a friend and there was a short wait. Their banchan is good and unique because they give you grilled fish as one of the dishes. The tofu soup was really good. We also ordered the seafood pancake which was thick and filled with lots of ingredients, but heavy. The portions were on par if not just slightly on the heftier side. 

The only downside was the service. They were decently busy but we asked multiple times to refill the banchan. The server acknowledged us both times we asked, but never came to refill.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This place was crowded on a Friday night and was packed with locals. There was a long line to get a table. You would think if a Korean restaurant is packed with Koreans, the food must be outstanding & authentic. Much to our disappointments that was not the case. 

Salty kalbi & bigolgi & lackluster tofu soup. Will have to give only 2&1/2 stars.

The service was nice though.
author: Quinn V.

description:
Food is great, banchan is great, little to no wait if you arrive before dinner.

Order the mixed soontofu, medium spicy. You have the choice of either pork, beef, or seafood (extra $, i believe). 

They bring out a variety of traditional korean sidedishes as a service (bean sprouts, kimchi, fish cake, fried mackerel).

Service, on the other hand-- questionable. We asked close to 3 times for a refill of our banchan/water. They said ok and walked by us -- four times. 

While I do understand that it gets busy during dinner, this is simply unacceptable for paying patrons. 

While the food is delicious and cheap, I couldn't help but feel like my business was appreciated. 

Hoping for a better experience next time.
author: Andy K.

description:
Man oh man this place has one of the best soft tofu soups in SF... in my opinion of course. BOMB SOUP IS BOMB.

::All soups comes with 4 options of spiciness (Spicy, Medium, Mild, and Non Spicy)::
::comes with side dishes and rice (all meals)::

-Dumpling Soft Tofu ($11.50): My favorite soft tofu soup to get at any restaurant just because DUMPLINGS ARE LIFE. It came with 4 dumplings, some beef bits, several rice cakes (they look like boobs), and of course, tofu. I'm glad that they cut down on their tofu since in the past, There would be a TON of tofu left whenever I go there. Now, there's more soup instead, which I like. It was flavorful and delicious, perfect for a cold day (: It also comes with a raw egg which you crack in right when your soup comes! MM MM MM!

-Dak Gui or BBQ Chicken ($11.50 for lunch portion): Pretty tasty but I wish that they made it a little more dry on the outside since it's broiled chicken. Other than that, it was great!

The only thing that prevents me from giving it 5 stars is the price and the service.
Price: I feel like $11.50 for tofu soup is a tad bit overpriced. If you look at the old menu on yelp, it used to be $9.45. The tofu soup is delicious here, don't get me wrong, but yea.... lol.

Service: The waiters and waitresses were extremely friendly! However, they don't really notice their customers and are pretty forgetful. I had to ask for more tea 3 times until I got a refill. Also, it took me a long while to get the check since they didn't see me wave my arm around ): I guess it was because it was somewhat busy that day?
author: Jackie T.

description:
Came here with some friends and Mr. Piano for a dinner, and it was nice. The weather was cold, so it was a good day for soon dubu!

I'm glad they were able to accommodate my vegetarian request (used water instead of broth), and I enjoyed my mushroom soon dubu well enough. My companions had a little bit of a mixup regarding the spiciness--I guess they're not super reliable on that front unless you order the completely mild version (which is what Mr. Piano and I did). The other two ordered a spicy and a medium, and the spicy came out not spicy at all somehow (as in the medium was spicier, but the medium is what the person ordering it wanted so that was good). Apparently they've been here before and had some issues with getting the spice levels right, too, but hey, I wanted mild and got mild, so I personally can't complain :P Not sure how anything else outside of the soon dubu is, but hey, if you're going to a tofu house, you're probably here for the tofu, right?

Anyhow, there's a good chance I'll be back again, because it was a nice tofu place and I like having hot soon dubu on a cold day (and SF is often chilly, at least by my standards).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Delicious tofu stew! I love the side dishes and the fried fish.

Side dishes: 5/5

Beef tofu stew: 4.5/5

Seafood tofu stew: 4/5

Bulgogi: 4/5

The workers were attentive and fast. There's usually a wait, and it moves at a moderate rate.
author: Ruby K.

description:
Wow this place is wayyyyy over hyped. I don't understand the rave reviews at all. This is pretty below average to average. But what kills me is how expensive this place is! 

Seafood pancake for 23 dollars?! On top of that it wasn't even good! It comes on a stone plate so you would think it's super crispy and delicious but they make the pancake so thick that it's just mushy. I also think maybe they have too much veggies inside the pancake which makes them too soft.

We also ordered Kalbi and the mushroom tofu soup. Which were both yummy and had good flavor. Tho I've never had Kalbi that I didn't like. 

The pan chan was also pretty average. The fish was really great- super crispy and delicious. However, the kimchi was a bit off and bean sprouts weren't very fresh. They also didn't have any potatoes.

Bill came out to be around 70 dollars total. Yowzzers. 

I'd say 3.5 stars for the food, but definitely taking points off for the exorbitant prices.
author: Beryl Y.

description:
Came here last night for my friend's surprise bday dinner! =) Got here around 7 and it wasn't too crowded luckily. I ordered the seafood tofu soup in mild since my friend said that one is pretty good and my bf ordered the bulgolgi. After we ordered we got our side dishes which consisted of kim chi, pickled cucumbers, spicy fishcake, brussel sprouts, and some sort of radish. Out of all of those I really liked the fishcake. After 15 minutes or so our food started arriving to the table. My seafood tofu soup was hot and boiling when they set it down. They also dropped off some raw eggs for us to crack into our soups. Yummm...perfect for a cold chilly day. 

The seafood tofu soup consisted of only 3 pieces or shrimp( 1 large one and like 2 baby ones!), some clams, and alot of tofu. While the soup was pretty good, I didnt feel like it was a little spicy at all for mild. Maybe Ill go for medium spicy next time. The bulgogi was really good and flavorful. They also give you a good amount and bulgogi comes on top of a bed of sliced onions. Both the soup and bulgogi was good with rice, which comes with our orders. We also got complimentary fried fish with our orders, which was crunchy and flavorful. Everyone seemed to really enjoy their meals. Overall, this place is pretty good but the service can be a tad slow since they are always busy.
author: Mary C.

description:
They need to hire more servers and/or cooks. Slooooow service, but not because they're goofing around. They're seriously just overworked. Took about 45 min from the time we were seated till we got our food. Not a place to come if you're in a time crunch, or need to feed a meter for parking.

Soondubu could be more flavorful. Bibimbap developed a nice crust, though they served it with a generous amount of red sauce on top, not on the side to add at your preference (bad move). Banchan selection is decent, although we had to remind them to bring our yellow croakers.
author: Pauline D.

description: Love this authentic Korean spot! Perfect for a cold rainy day to be tucked into one of the cozy wood booths. I get a funny little excitement when the pan chan dishes arrive - the small fried fish is delicious! You can pretty much eat the entire fish, bones and all, if you're adventurous.
author: Christina J.

description:
Came here on a chilly afternoon after a visit to the Legion of Honor, so the hot tofu soup really hit the spot.

I'd highly recommend the Kalbi - such meaty goodness. I got the combination hot tofu soup which had plenty of clams and beef. The spiciness level seemed to be on the lower end, so you can order up a notch.
author: Linda X.

description:
I'm a fan of this place! We ordered the bulgogi, beef tofu soup, and chicken bibimbap. Everything tasted really yummy and the flavors were all there. The soup was one of my favorites because it had the perfect amount of spice! But overall everything was great! 
Service was pretty good too. The only downfall is that this place can get super crowded.
author: Alyssa C.

description: This place is hands down my favorite place for some warm Korean tofu soup (soondubu)! I just wish that the prices didn't keep increasing. I always order the pork soondubu and it is enough to fill me up! The banchan usually includes kimchi, fish cake, bean sprouts, radish, and grilled fish. The grilled fish is absolutely delicious! I highly recommend this place. The downside is the wait as it is usually packed during dinner time.
author: Henry P.

description:
After having passed by this place for 30 years while clogging my arteries with Jack in the Box, I was finally happy to try them out.  The soft tofu soup ($10.50) was pretty good, the mild was barely spicy so if you want a bit of a kick, get medium instead.  Sides were OK, the kimchi and pickles were nice and tart.  Didn't care for the fried fish and they didn't have the soy sauce potatoes.

Overall, a solid dining experience.
author: Alice L.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I just continue to become more and more disappointed each time I come back here. 

The food is good, I'm not going to lie, but to come here for dinner is absolutely ridiculous. For a dinner entree of short ribs it was over $20.00. Are you serious?? I might as well spend a few extra bucks and go to an all you can eat buffet or buy myself a nice juicy steak. 

The side dishes are good and refillable so I appreciate that, however, service is slow because there are usually only two guys working the front and it's honestly a lot of tables, they're understaffed. 

It's gotten to the point already where I ask for a water pitcher to be set at the table when I come in so that I know I won't go thirsty in the middle of my slightly salty meal. Whatever the case, I don't think they'll be seeing me or my money any time soon, unless it's lunchtime and I'm really desperate for some korean food.
author: Cara O.

description:
My tofu house has the BEST ban chan! I absolutely love the kimchi, spicy fish cakes, and the fried fish they give out. Their kimchi is the best I've had from any restaurant. Having a good ban chan really sets the temp of the restaurant. 

I always get the daeji bulgogi( spicy pork) and its very flavorful but the spiciness isn't over powering. The rice comes in a heavy and sturdy stone pot which produce really rich and tasty rice. 

The pork bibimbap is also a nice treat as well!  

The atmosphere is really nice and comfortable. The seating is spacious and the tvs are pretty big for the size of the restaurant.
author: Calvin Y.

description: Went here for a late lunch and they were busy we waited 20 minutes,they need to be more organized when seating people ,they gave this guy a table for 4 ,the food was expensive but taste ok had better.would not go back , slow service
author: Joe S.

description: Solid Korean food. Nice variety of bibimbop veggie options. Very comfortable atmosphere to dine in! Easy to get to (28 or 38 bus)
author: J K.

description: My best friend took me here. Good area, good food. Known to be one of the best Korean tofu soup places in the area, it lives up to it. Street Parking can be hard to find.
author: Amy Y.

description:
After a week long vacation in Puerto Vallarta, the last thing I wanted as my first meal back in the states was Mexican food. I wanted something new and satisfying, like Tofu House in San Diego, and stumbled upon a joint called My Tofu House. With a name so similar, it's got to be good!

I ordered the combination tofu soup with shrimp, clams, and beef. Served with side dishes and rice, it was mighty hot and tasty and was great on a chilly SF evening. The side dishes were all great too and the whole fish were definitely the highlight. Ice never had those before as a side dish and they were delicious!

Prices are reasonable and service was friendly even after we stayed past closing time. It's located next door to one of my favorite Korean BBQ places too so that block has pretty much all the good grub I can handle. While it's no replacement for the cheap Chinese joint I frequent, I will most certainly be back for more tofu soup.

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: My favorite Korean tofu house in the city. I normally get their dumpling tofu soup with a kimchi pancake to share. Food is always hot and comes rather quickly. Their menu is extensive so there's something for everyone. Be prepared to wait after 7pm. They always seem to be busy. We came a couple of times after 7 and they ran out of pancakes :/
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My Tofu House is an excellent choice on cold evenings when you need something warming in the belly to get your body temperature back up to 98 degrees.  As we all know, the Richmond tends to be cold and damp at this time of the year.  So the location at Geary and 10th Avenue in the heart of the district is ideal.  As a kind of Asian warming hut, it's top notch.  At $11.50 for a hot bubbling bowl of tofu soup, tea, tons of rice, a fried fish, and a bunch of little appetizer plates typical of Korean cuisine, it's affordability is hard to beat.  It's truly an excellent deal.

If you're like me and dislike waiting, I advise an earlier 6-6:30pm arrival time.  I arrived at about 6:45pm last night, and I waited about 10 minutes.  There are plenty of tables, but crowds do descend at peak times and a line does form quickly then.   This is not a fast food spot, so expect to wait a bit because they do get busy.  But you won't be waiting forever.  Their menu is relatively simple, and they've thus got the service system down well.  After setting down tea, I ordered the Combo Tofu soup:  tofu with beef, shrimp, and clams. 

The small plates are a treat.  If you're hungry and your chopsticks are poised, you'll tuck into these as soon as they appear.  There are meat strips, cucumber, daikon, sprouts, kim chi (naturally), a raw egg (for the soup), firm tofu, and a small fried fish.  Most of these items come dressed in Korean spices.  You have to like Korean flavoring, in other words, if you want to hang at My Tofu House. It's all Korean, all the time.   It's all good for you, and high in vitamin C.

The soup arrived boiling in a clay pot.  Take caution, the pot is burning hot and is no joke.  The soup is very hot, too, so save your tongue and let it cool, but not too long.  It's best eaten hot.  You'll find loads of tofu in the soup, with ample pieces of shrimp and clams.  I could have used more beef, so if you want a lot of beef, order the Beef tofu soup.  It felt so good to eat- so warming, so comforting.  I was trying to fend off a cold I felt coming on, so it did me good.  I felt my sinuses clearing any my body warming quickly with each spoonful of piping hot soup.

Rice is de rigeur in Asian spots, and they give you a ton at My Tofu House.  The server leaves the hot rice pot at the table for you.  Once all of the rice has been scooped into your silver metal bowl, he slowly pours hot rice broth into the empty rice pot.  The toasted browned rice stuck to the sides of the pot soak into the broth, producing a warm rice soup that is enjoyed at meal's end.  All very good.  

On the whole, My Tofu House is very representative of affordable Asian fare in SF.  It's affordable, authentic, no nonsense, and efficient.  That is to say, hole in the wall prices but authentic, delicious food.  If you're ever in the Richmond on a cold, foggy evening, My Tofu House is warming hut to try!
author: Roland C.

description:
Tofu soup two days in a row? While I'd like to respond with a resounding "hells yeah", My Tofu House, like Jang Su Jang, was not quite as stellar as I was hoping - their dumpling tofu soup (a little over $10) was quite tasty, but their "spicy" lacked kick. As a big plus though, despite having a smaller selection of banchan than most places, one of these is a tasty fried fish, something I don't see served very often.

Prices are a tad higher than other Korean restaurants, but not unreasonably so, service is quick and friendly, and the restaurant is kept clean (and looks much nicer inside than one would expect from outside). Overall, a good 3.5 stars, and well worth revisiting.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Pretty decent Korean tofu place, with other dishes such as bibimbap, different kinds of Korean pancake, and bbq.

I got the soondoobu (of course), with extra tofu. The broth was on the thin side with little flavor. Maybe the seafood one has more flavor. I didn't think there was actually extra tofu in mine, so I was a little disappointed. There were some bits of beef, a clam or two and shrimp. I thought it was a little skimpy, but whatever, it was hot and it had tofu.

The banchan was okay. I didn't expect there to be a lot since it's a tofu place. Pretty typical banchan - bean sprouts, cabbage kimchi, radish kimchi, fish cake, cucumber, and fried fish.

Not the best Korean food I've had (my standard = New York), but pretty decent for SF.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I'm still full. So so good. I ordered the dumpling tofu soup and my friend ordered the original soup. I got mine HOT and it was perfect.

Let me just say...if I had to be Asian, I'd want to be Korean.
If I had to marry Asian, I'd want him to be Korean...so he could cook me this weekly.
I kid. 

Service was great and attentive. The gum they provide at the end of the meal (with the bill) is notorious for losing flavor after about minute or so. 

Great spot for dinner, date, friend's catch up etc. ONLY THING (if I had to say something that could use improvement) is location. I rarely go to the Richmond. Ppl who live in the Richmond though should eat here at least every week.

Overall, pretty darn good.
author: Carina M.

description:
Usually I'm a quality over quantity type of gal but Tofu House really impressed me with all their ban chan. Let me if I can remember them all: cabbage kimchi, pickled cucumbers, pickled tofu sprouts, tofu strips (?), radish kimchi (?), whole fried fish (wow) and a raw egg (which I put in my soup). Yes, all of that for just me for lunch. 

Then they came out with a big pot of rice and proceeded to dole out 1.5 bowls of it. Again just for me for lunch.

Then came my order of kimchi soft tofu soup w/ pork & mushrooms which I spooned over the rice to eat. The tofu was good and had a nice silky texture. However, I expected the dish to be at least slightly spicy since I got medium but it was more like mild. I was hesitant to get the "spicy" in case it was too much but I guess I shouldn't have worried because the spice levels have been westernized. Kimchi tofu soup really should be super spicy. Like nose running, head sweating spicy. 

Don't be put off by the exterior. It looks like a dive and it's next to a Jack-in-the-Box but inside it's clean, spacious and frequented by Asians - even at 3 PM on a weekday for lunch. That's saying something.
author: Jean K.

description:
The food here is pretty good, but nothing amazing. I would give it an extra star if the service was not SO SLOW. They might as well hire turtles to work here! Absolutely no urgency when there are 5 tables that need to be bussed and 10 people waiting!

Would not order the tofu again, tasted watery and not very flavorful. I would get the bulgogi again though and probably stick to take out!
author: Clarice C.

description:
Now that Tofu Village on Irving has gone to the dumps since they sold/changed owners, became a Korean/Chinese fusion, to now just Chinese Food-- My Tofu House is my new go-to for sundubu! 
I've noticed that their prices are a little bit more expensive($12.88) than usual places I've ordered tofu soup, but I'm willing to pay a little more if they do it right. My Tofu House delivered! Had the dumpling tofu soup spicy, and it was perfect with the raw egg cooked inside!
BANCHAN: all really good!
+ Kimchi
+ Fried Fish
+ Fish Cake
+ Cucumber
+ Bean Sprouts
+ Radish

SERVICE: On a Friday night at 7pm, my mom and I snagged one of the last few tables. There was a list with several groups waiting by the time we left. Service is pretty typical for Korean restaurants. Not the most friendly, but efficient.

Will definitely be back!
author: Jenna H.

description:
The wait was long, but it was eventually worth it. Service can be a little slow, but once the food sets foot, it all piles up. The place is very crowded, but had a peaceful ambiance. 
Now for food, we ordered Seafood Soft Tofu Soup, Seafood Pancake, Vegetable Bibimpap, Beef Bulgogi, and Kalbi. 
The Seafood Soft Tofu Soup was great! They bring rice and serve it to you from hot clay pot dishes, then you spoon the soft tofu soup onto the rice. The soup leaves you nice and warm and it's great for cold weather. 
I would not get the Seafood Pancake again. There wasn't much flavor, for it was bland and needed salt. The texture also kind of bothered my friend. They also give you a spicy sauce that can give the pancake a little more flavor.
Vegetable Bibimpap was not that great either. There also wasn't much flavor, bland and sad. It did have a little kick. It was just bland, bland, bland! They put an egg on top so be sure to mix everything together.
Beef Bulgogi was delicious! We all enjoyed it and it tasted good with rice. 
The Kalbi was the best. It had great flavor and it was nice and tender. It had a great char taste that proved it just came off the stove. 

Overall, I would definitely come back for the meat and the soup! The ban-chan (appetizers) was also really good! You get free refills and they served fried fish that tasted super fresh! The service was good and the waiters were on point. Though, they were a little slow, they were still great and helpful. Although, this place was a little expensive. The tea was excellent!
author: C Y.

description: Food is fine, not the best tofu soup but not bad. Got plenty of rice and reasonable price. Just don't come in on Monday night when the restaurant is understaffed, I stood there for 10 mins and waitress just pretended they don't see me since they are too busy at taking care of others....but seriously, not even a basic greeting?
author: Zijian W.

description:
My Tofu House is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in SF, especially for soft tofu soup.

I've only ever had the kimchi soft tofu soup with pork and the pancake. Both are really delicious. The kimchi soup has lots of big pieces of tofu and great flavor - a great dinner to those foggy nights in the Richmond. The vegetable pancake is also especially good - it's thick and substantial without being heavy. I also love that you get a fried croaker on the side of your tofu soup! And don't miss digging out all of the crispy rice from the stone bowl of rice. 

Not surprisingly, this place is not about atmosphere - a number of stark tables with very little adornment. On a weekend night, you can wait up to 15-20 minutes. Service is pretty speedy.
author: Wendy L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were really craving Korean food but our favorite, go-to place was packed so we decided to try My Tofu House instead. 

Luckily there was no wait, but not surprising since it was 6pm on a Tuesday night. The woman who greeted us was very friendly and we were sat the second we walked through the door which is always appreciated! The menu is small and standard: tofu soup, bibimbap, bbq, and Korean pancakes. I ordered the beef and vegetable bibimbap and my boyfriend ordered the seafood and vegetable bibimbap. Our waitress took our order and brought out the banchan quickly, but that's the last we saw of her until it was time for us to pay (even when we were out of water and/or tea).

The banchan was also standard: bean sprouts, fishcakes, cucumber, kimchee, and kkakdugi. Notice how I didn't mention the coveted fried fish everyone else is talking about? Yeah that's cause we didn't get any. Though every other table seemed to like theirs so I'm sure it's good!

Food came out promptly and was nice and hot, but I did notice that they added mushrooms even though it wasn't mentioned that they would be adding it. Not a big deal, I just wish I would have known so that I could have asked for it without mushrooms cause it's a bit of a pain to pick it out. Anyways, the bibimbap was good, standard just like everything else. The biggest upside is that they do not skimp out on the meat, so I didn't have to spend time portioning it out so I could get meat in every bite lol. 

Overall it was okay, a bit underwhelming. I think what really killed it though is the price. It was $16 for each of our dishes! The most expensive Korean food I have ever eaten! But most everyone else seems to love it so I would say it's worth a try! It's just that my go-to Korean restaurant is nearby, much cheaper, and way better quality (with more banchan too)! So compared to that in addition to the way too expensive dishes, I just can't love My Tofu House and won't be coming back.
author: Belle M.

description:
The layout of the restaurant gives no privacy to the patrons eating where the barrier is separating the waiting area since there are two TVs on both sides of the restaurant.  One of the waiters actually told us to turn around the other way to give their patrons more privacy.  Quite frankly, they should just put up a glass barrier and/or remove one of the TVs to fix that problem.  I didn't mind when people were facing our table while they were waiting.  

Compared to most Korean places, this place is not very friendly.  The seafood pancake came out BURNT BLACK on half the pancake and late - way after we received our tofu and with no apologies.  And it wasn't even good since it had tons of batter and not enough ingredients.  And it cost $19.32.  I don't know why they have such to the cent pricing here.  The side dishes were solid, nothing special.  They give you fried fish, which I don't bother to eat since the bones are too small.  The tofu is solid.  Skip the pancake.
author: Chris L.

description:
I would definitely come back for the soup! I loved everything we ordered! My only gripe is the waiting area which is literally a hole in the wall.

But the service was great, food came out on time, and would come back again if we didn't have to wait so long. Our log wait was expected since we did come on Valentine's Day.
author: leanne s.

description:
We got in there early before the dinner crowd...good thing we did that. Service was kinda slow, took awhile before they got our order. Its a place I come often when I'm in town.

Great soft tofu soup variety....when the food comes you kinda forget about the slow service as you chow down the food.  Banchan nothing great, the nice fact is that they will give each person a fish dish. Nothing spectacular, I wished they fry the fish a little longer and make it crispy. 

Overall experience is good.
author: Eddy N.

description:
If you wanna get Korean soft tofu soup in SF, come here to enjoy one. Banchans are great. Tofu soups here are amazing. They give you the stone rice pot to get rice into bowl. When you're done with the stone rice pot,  you can pour tea inside and scrap for any rice leftovers!!!!!

In Daly city folks, go to Dae Jang geum tofu house. It's the best you get over there as here in the city.
author: Silin N.

description: The SOFT TOFU SOUP!!!!! This place is definitely worth the hype. I ordered the seafood tofu soup and pork bibimbop and my boyfriend ordered the dumpling soup. The flavor is great not overly salty or spicy. The bibimbop is okay. The price is a little hefty but the soups are definitely worth the try!!!
author: Jessie S.

description:
My mother and I have been going to My Tofu periodically for years, and always went away happy campers. We went again tonight for old time's sake and were REALLY disappointed. The prices have gone WAY up and the quality WAY down. 

We both ordered bibimbap dishes. The seafood in mine had the texture of rubber, and was doused in some sort of ketchup like barbecue sauce that overpowered everything. The rice was super greasy and did not crisp up in the hot stone bowl the way it should when bibimbap is properly prepared. 

My mother had better luck with her "baked" tofu bibimbap. The tofu had a nice texture and was not drowned in sauce, and her rice crisped up. The portions are generous. Under normal circumstances, we would have been eager to take away what couldn't eat at the time and enjoy it later. However, in this case, we were only too glad to see it taken away, albeit to waste so much food. 

Even the side dishes were insipid compared to our previous visits. No spinach or little anchovies. The spread was fairly monochromatic. The only saving grace was the serving of fried little fishes at the beginning which seemed appropriately cooked with a nice texture crispy skin. 

The hot tea is served out of glass pitchers into water glasses, which may be practical, but aesthetically unappealing. It reinforced the generic BLAH feeling of the whole eating experience.  

The service was decent but the food so insipid that we will not be going back. Relative to other Korean restaurants in San Francisco, My Tofu, which used to be a great moderately priced place to go with yummy satisfying food, now offers very poor value for what you pay.
author: Buthi D.

description: Banchan is diverse, tasty, and fresh! Rice was perfect. Me and a friend were both impressed with the food! One of the best tofu stews I've had in a long time!
author: Tangible H.

description:
It's solid most of the time. Service is lackluster but let's be honest, service at Korean restaurants is not their forte. The food is good, ban chan is good and the fried croaker fish is a nice touch. My only gripe is that they must have changed their fish egg (arhl) b/c it doesn't have the texture and crunch it used to have. It's now smushy...

Would still go back b/c there are few other decent alternatives and everything else is good there.
author: Benny M.

description:
3 stars for the food & service.

Actually the food could have been a 4, since it is solid Korean food. Nothing crazy or wild, and I'm normally not picky. But service-wise, no one greets you when you walk in, you have to flag down someone to refill banchan, and no one really has a smile on. I had to wait a while, period, for someone to greet us at the table once we'd been seated. 

Wait is ok, about a 20 min wait at 7pm on a Friday night. We got the bulgoki which was good, but expensive for the portion size. Tofu soup was normal-sized and decently priced. Also got the tofu salad, which I didn't care for but my friends liked it. Overall food was good, service was "eh." 

Would go back again, but wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This is probably my favorite Korean place in SF. I almost always get the original soft tofu soup, which you can customize to whatever spiciness level and meat type you want. But occasionally I get the bulgogi or kalbi. There is so much meat! And they're really tasty, too! But, the food here is a little pricey. 

The servers are nice and always ask if they can get you anything else.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Their tofu is like silk! And our soups came sizzling. Be careful not to burn your tongue ;). 

I don't mean to sound like a snob, but I just wish their soup was a little more flavorful. I used to live in LA and have been exposed to a bunch of different tofu houses, making me predisposed to criticize little things about their soup. I loved it regardless, especially because it was so cold outside and the idea of hot soup sounded heavenly. Their soup is really filling, so $10-12 is a pretty good, standard price!

Get boba after dinner! :D
author: Hannah P.

description:
I've been here so many times and just realized I never wrote a review on it. First learned of this place from the 7x7 100 Things To Eat in SF (you can find lots of amazing things on this list).

Came by here last night because a friend was visiting from Boston, and he wanted some kind of Asian food that took credit card (he had to track his work expenses this way). Two other friends joined us, and I was shocked that they had never been here, despite living in SF for years.

While waiting for your food, they'll bring you an assortment of ban chan (Korean small appetizer plates traditionally served before a meal). You'll find all of your standard Korean goodies here!

The dish that this establishment is well known for is their soondubu (or whoever you spell that). It's a Korean soft tofu soup, and they have various kinds (original, kimchi, dumpling, etc) and you can also choose the spiciness level for it.

Other times I've been here, I've also ordered the kalbi, which is served to you on a sizzling platter. The meat was juicy and delicious! 

Definitely stop by if you're looking for something flavorful and hot on a nice cold San Francisco evening. Great place to take out of towners. Just keep in mind that there is sometimes a slight wait in the evening/weekends (c'mon, I bet a lot of people go to cross this off their SF food bucket list).

*edit* I forgot to add, two months ago when I was last here, they completely forgot to bring out my friend's dish, the bibimbop. We waited for so long and wondered why his dish never came (I was already almost done with my soondubu), and finally, we mentioned it to them and they admitted to forgetting it. It was a little insulting that they didn't offer him anything to compensate for him waiting the entire time. We left and I got him food elsewhere. Sorry, had to take a star from my review for this, otherwise, I would've give this place 4 stars.
author: Melissa D.

description:
my favorite tofu soup soon du boo place in sf. theres a reason why the lines are so long. the menu is small but it means that the chef is a master at each of those dishes. if you get there before 6pm, expect a wait.. a long wait.. we always go early and/or on off days. 
be warned. the service is slow because they are short staffed and they are very busy. expect to wait to get service, tea, order, side dishes, food but its worth it.
author: Jen S.

description:
The food itself is 4 stars, but be aware - especially for dinner, the prices are a little high compared to Asian food in general (which tends to be reasonably priced!).

I would summarize the food here as good & classic.  As in, made the typical way that I'm used to eating and made well.  No unusual surprises for us here.

- Seafood pancake: crunchy on the edges, plenty of seafood, thick batter
- BBQ pork (bulgogi) plate: classic. good.
- Tofu soup: classic & good
- Free-refill side dishes: decent
author: Grace C.

description:
Came here with two friends for a late dinner after a night out in Pacifica.

This place is pretty crowded and has considerable wait times. The waiter wanted to seat me and my friends in their little backroom, but we asked for a table out front. Booths are nice and comfy here with very good and frequent service to check if everything's okay.

Looking at the menu, it's a bit on the pricier side, but everything's great.

We went with the kalbi, which was cooked perfectly and seasoned well. The meat was chewy enough and fresh.

I went with the combo tofu stew at a medium heat. It wasn't that spicy at all, but was more hot to the point where I couldn't eat it so I ended up eating really slowly. All of the side dishes were mediocre at best. I was a bit sad they didn't have any honey potato.

This place was a little out of my usual price range as a college student, but definitely delighted my taste buds.
author: Davinci L.

description:
I'm not sure why it's taken me so long to write a review on My Tofu House. I've eaten here for many years and it's still my all time favorite soondubu place in SF. I heart this place!

Their kimchi tofu soup is delicious. I love the banchans that they serve as well. My favorites are the spicy radishes, pickled cucumbers, bean sprouts and the kimchi. Most places don't give you the yellow croacker, but this place does. It's one of my parents favorite banchan. 

The service is decent, but sometimes it can get difficult flagging a server when they're busy.
author: Candice H.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed My Tofu House before! When I lived in the Inner Richmond 2 years ago I use to come here every week- no joke! The prices have gone up since, but it's still my number 1 tofu stew/soup place to go to. You choose what kind of broth you want- I always get original with beef, then you choose your spiciness (no spice, mild, spicy, etc). I always get mild which still has a little spice to it, but not super overwhelming for my taste. The raw egg you crack inside is a perfect addition & I couldn't have it any other way! 

It also comes with the typical Korean sides- bean sprouts, fried fish (love this too!), kimchee, spicy dikon, etc.

I have since moved out of the city, but recently moved back! So I will be fancy-ing my love often once again. Dinner time there is a long wait so beware- you can wait 30+ minutes during prime time, especially on the weekends.
author: Alysha K.

description:
For me if I want to go eat some good Chinese food I rely on my Chinese friends because they know best, especially if you enjoy authenticity in the cuisine you enjoy. I say this because the tofu here is pretty decent for me to recommend it but I'm very disappointed in the pajun.

The seafood pajun (seafood pancake made of squid, onion, green onion and shrimp) is absolutely overpriced here ($22) and mediocre in taste. The flour is too thick-- there should be more seafood than flour so you don't feel like you're stuffing yourself with just flour, yuck. I don't recommend it.

The tofu here is pretty good. Just like any other Korean tofu shop, you get to choose a specific kind of tofu soup- seafood, beef, kimchi, pork, dumpling etc and of course they all come with tofu. You can also choose the level of spiciness: very mild, mild, mildly spicy and very spicy so you can customize to your taste! 

** if you want to do it the Korean way, pour water in the rice pit after rice is served so that after your meal you can eat Nooroongji which is burnt rice soup at the end of the meal. 

I would have given a four if it wasn't for the pajun and the unfriendly cashiers guy. Also the fish that comes as a side fish was cold.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I don't get it.  I was excited to try this place out due to the awesome rave reviews as evidenced by Yelp.  However when I tried their soondubu, I was underwhelmed.  We ordered the kimchi soondubu and the fish egg soondubu.  We asked for our kimchi soup to be spicy and our fish egg to be medium.  I was so disappointed in my "spicy" kimchi soup - it was not spicy at all.  In fact, there wasn't much taste, just hot heat, but no stand out flavor.  The fish egg soup was OK, but nothing to rave about.  The banchan was OK.  Service was nice, and our waitress was able to tell us about their most popular dishes when we inquired.  Overall, the soondubu fell flat of my expectations.  I'm looking over other people's reviews, and it's looking like the food is falling short in taste - I have to agree with some other reviewers on this.

 :\
author: Viva C.

description:
Sketchy from the outside but super clean and tidy on the inside. This is a true Korean restaurant. What other place knows to put tea into the bowl of rice at the end so you can finish off your experience the traditional way?!

Disclaimer: the mild soondubu was hot so it took forever to actually taste the deliciousness.
author: Regina D.

description:
Service was a little slow and the seafood in the seafood bibimbap wasn't fresh. Banchan wasn't super flavorful, but my group liked the fish! When we finally got seated and got to order, our food came out pretty quickly, but it did take a while to get a server to come to our table.

I like any place that'll have bibimbap that's not with beef (I'm not a red meat person) so I was pleased with the choices (especially since it was in that stone pot and had the egg, yummm), but I don't think I picked the right one. Still, it was a good amount of spice. My mom loved the tofu soup so next time I'll try that!
author: Katie V.

description: This place is quite authentic as well as affordable. I always come here for easy lunch and dinner when I feel crave the homey korean feel and want to be surrounded by fellow koreans.... Recommend kalbi or their tofu stew.
author: Bora Y.

description: Great food, preparation, and service. The appetizers are pretty good and generously bottomless (except for the fish) The fish appetizer was really good and unexpected. Just look out for bones. Of course you cannot go wrong with the tofu. Great for cold days, as it comes bubbling. Tips: No parking in the Jack in the Box lot, even though it is right next to the restaurant. Put the egg right into the bubbling tofu. We got transfixed and forgot! Don't forget to eat the tea soaked rice that is burnt on the bottom. Some like this better than regular rice.
author: E. W.

description: My usual go-to korean spot, but my last experience was a little disappointing. It took forever to get my tiny appetizer dishes and for the people to take our order. But, the seafood tofu soup (mild) is my favorite with the kalbi or spicy pork/bulgogi. The soups are the way to go and the small dishes are always good. They also give you a watermelon flavored gum wen you pay for your check, but the flavor lasts less than 5 minutes. Other than that, my go-to place but the service could improve a bit.
author: Amanda C.

description:
For a Korean place, they sure have a small menu. I was hoping there'd be some noodle dishes....

One word to describe this place: pricey. I wanted a korean pancake, but it's almost ~$20 for an order! I got the dumpling soft tofu soup (comes with dumplings, rice cake, and beef) and my boyfriend got galbi. The soup was average in my opinion, nothing special and expensive for what it is ($11.95). Had few bits of beef, but there were about 3-4 dumplings, which were good. The broth thickened pretty quickly so it was not as liquid-y as I would've liked it to be. The galbi was alright as well, but didn't seem anything special. The pieces were a bit more on the fatty side. The side dishes were OK, I was expecting more variety. 

In general, I was expecting more from this place after seeing the ratings and reviews. Just something to note: I'm a college student so this is what I consider average food for its price. I would probably not come back here.
author: Mary X.

description:
Great food, service is horrible.  The wait is usually very long and while the food was delicious, it definitely wasn't worth the price (the pancakes are double the cost of what they'd be at other Korean restaurants).  

The ambiance is pleasant, however and as usual, they have the typical assortment of Korean appetizers, which offsets the cost a bit).
author: Matthew W.

description: Came here on a cold day in need of some hot soup. This place's soon doo boo hit the spot! Prices are decent, place is clean and neat and most important to me customer service was on point! 5 stars Definitely coming back!
author: Eddie K.

description: Bibimbop, yum! Very nice to our toddler and all the little appetizer dishes that come with the meal were delicioud
author: Dacia M.

description:
I had the soon dubu with beef for lunch. The bubbling-cauldron was terrific, umami without being too salty. Good banchans too, especially the fried fish (nice touch). Place gets crowded at all times (always a good sign). Lots of street parking. 

Slipped into a food coma soon afterwards haha.
author: Derek N.

description:
Nice, but could be better.

Ostensibly, a typical Korean joint in the mid Richmond district of SF. The program is somewhat different than the norm. The menu is small, either you get a soft tofu soup, or a barbecue, or a pancake, or a bimbap. Other than the pancake all are equally amazing.

Service is desultory. They have hoods over the tables but I don't think they let you cook it for yourself. If you do order an expensive-ish meat dish they cook it for you in the kitchen and bring out no extra service or sides, just a large tower of cooked meat. 

On the other hand MTH is seriously good food. The Banchan (random free dishes that come out with your meal) is limited and spars. When they bring six things out to your table instead of the usual twelve it feels like a ripoff, until you taste it. Each of the six items (deep fried little fish, fish cake, bean sprouts, pickled cucumbers, kimchi, and kimchi daikon) is excellent and ample.
author: Gil S.

description:
I was pretty impressed with this hole-in-wall looking restaurant! Once I walked in, I was stunned by how clean it was. I guess most Korean restaurants I visit are oily, stinky, dirty and looked like they haven't been cleaned in years, but My Tofu House had such a clean feeling!  My friend was craving tofu soup so we decided to go here for lunch.

I got the Mild Pork Original Tofu Soup. My friend said she had been before and wasn't gutsy enough to try mild, but I had to get a little bit!  It was just a hint of spiciness. Barely anything, but enough to taste. Definitely no heart burns after lunch today!  I kinda wished it had a bit more spiciness though. The kim chee was definitely more spicy than the soup. 

Back to the soup....I loved the presentation. It came bubbling in a stone pot, and you have the option of cracking your own egg into the hot soup!  WOW. It doesn't cook all the way, but enough for the egg to be warm and runny, just the way I love it!

The restaurant also served us the typical appetizers one would expect to get at a Korean restaurant, i.e. Kimchee, bean sprouts, cucumber, marinated textured tofu. But they also had the fried anchovies which was surprisingly delicious! Two whole anchovies, about 6 inches long! I was impressed.  Cucumber was delicious too, as well as that cold textured tofu. 

Service was friendly, they checked in to see how we were enjoying our meal. Also, they let us switch tables after we found out it was too cold sitting next to the door. 

Can't wait to return!!!!!!!! This is great for a freezing day in the Richmond District.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
3.5 stars!

7x7 #9! Their tofu soup is good, and you can customize it (aka add whatever ingredients you want to it, at an additional charge.. $1 for 5 rice cakes = not worth it). The banchans are alright, though limited - just your standard pickled radish, kimchi, fishcake, and bean sprouts, but they do throw in two grilled fish in there which is pretty nice - though not a fan. BF had the bibimbap, but said it wasn't too great. Would definitely come back for tofu soup, and tofu soup only. Okay, maybe a plate of meat too because our neighboring table's dishes smelled really good.
author: Michelle L.

description: Not giving this place anymore chances! The food is shit! Customer service is crap! I used to love this place!
author: Ty N.

description: Came with a group of 8 around 7:15pm and was seated within 20mins. Ordered the vegetable and mushroom bibimbap. It was delicious and one of the better bibimbaps that I have tried. The rice was heated by the sizzling stone just right so it became crispy. The dish was mild, which was standard. Very flavorful and packs a slight spicy kick! I love the side dishes, which was fresh. They give you generous portions of the side dishes as well as a fried fish dish. The dishes came out quick.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Horrible place to eat. Pathetic service. The staff is really rude. I didn't  like the food neither my friend. So we decided not to  tip them but they forced my friend to pay the tip then to 20%. When we refuse to pay, they said its California law and we have to pay the tip. My friend she paid it because they weren't letting us to go. They not only forced but they mentally harassed us to pay tip. This was one my horrible experience in my life. I would suggest everyone specially school going student should avoid this place. They do this specially with students.
author: Rachana H.

description:
Great food and all.
But service was total trash. It was gloomy and everyone seemed like they did not want to be there. Then when we were still in the middle of eating, they placed the bill on our table as if they were rushing us out. They then collected our payment and we asked for our change. They took the bill and about 10 minutes later came back asking if we needed anything and we asked for our change once again. We got our change and left a small tip because the service was not up to par and to us, obviously did not deserve 15%. We left and we stood outside for not even 10 seconds before a man comes running after us demanding a 7 dollar tip when we paid about 3 dollars. It was rude and embarrassing. I will not be coming back, come if you are okay with being rudely chased after your meal.
author: Joyce M.

description: The food here was good but comparable to other Korean restaurants. I'm not sure what the hype is all about. The reason I gave this place 2 stars is due to the poor service. My friends and I felt that the waiters were not polite nor attentative. While we stood inside waiting for a table, the waiter told us to move out of the way so he had room for his bus boy cart rather than asking us politely to move. The waiters also seemed to avoid us and not want to help us when we wanted to ask for refills on our Ban Chan (small dishes) and to order more food. Overall, we were unhappy with the service which ruined our experience here.
author: Lynn T.

description: The service is kind of slow and it took them about 15 minutes to get us our condiments but the food here is good and decently priced. I like getting the combination soup!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Okay I really wish Yelp had half stars because 3 stars don't do this place justice - but 4 stars is a bit much.  3.5 would be my pick.

Really enjoyed the mushroom & vegetable bibimbap here.  I was craving for some Korean food, and this totally did it for me.  It warmed up my tummy and I love the crusty rice in the bibimbap.  Maybe I just can't take spicy foods, but I think the spiciness really overpowered the other flavors of the dish for me.

Also, what's up with the lack of variety of ban chan?  Ban chan is one of my favorite parts of a Korean restaurant, and they really only give you the basic of the basics... kimchee, bean sprouts, and sardines.

Nevertheless, it's a solid Korean restaurant.  Come here early because it's always packed!
author: Christine A.

description: Good quality. Fresh side dishes. Good service. Great portions for the price. Have tried their soft noodle tofu soup and the veggie soft tofu soup. Both have not disappointed, more authentic than a lot of other Korean restaurants in the city.
author: Aneesh K.

description: Great korean tofu place, a bit far from everything though. The soon dobu is very much like the ones I've had in Ktown in LA. The other places in SF aren't as flavorful, nor do they have that many ingredients. The seafood pancake is a must get but it's on the pricier side. I should be able to get a half-order instead!
author: Joyce M.

description:
One of my favorite places!everything is delicious! Downside is that they don't have jap Che there :(
The tofu soups are all good! The Kalbi is tasty, a bit pricey. Bibimbap is good too! We always get the seafood pancake! Go early it gets crowded, expect to wait!
author: Y W.

description:
The restaurant is called Tofu House, you should follow the sign and order their tofu soups. Kalbi and bulgogi here are delicious bbq meat options but definitely get a tofu soup.
All meals are served with a serving of fried yellow croaker and banchan side dishes. The side dishes are the usual served at other Korean restaurants, but I wish they served boiled seasoned potato as well.

I've been here a few times and the staff is usually pretty friendly, although their English skills are sometimes not so great. On my last visit, they screwed up our order and gave us the wrong tofu soup, but they corrected our order and quickly replaced it with the right one.

My only complaint is that the lineup here takes a while sometimes as it gets busy for dinner most days. Otherwise, a solid Korean dining spot.
author: Jeffrey Q.

description: Bread and butter Korean tofu place.... Not the best one I had, but pretty descent....  The kids like the bolgogi....  Tofu soup cater to what you requested....  Side dishes were OK....  Price is normal for the type of food....  Not a great deal, but not a rip off either.... Portion is quite generous....  Good value....
author: Steve D.

description:
Spicy beef tofu soup with pork bi bim bop if f*cking delicious.  Almost always.  There's a lot of korean tofu places in SF, and I'll be honest and say I've only been to a few.  The closest one to me is Manna in inner sunset, so that is what I'm mainly comparing it to.  

The side dishes were good.  They didn't have my favorite side dish though-this seaweed thing, but it did come with a fried fish.  (I'm not a fan, but I know that's a huge plus for most people).  I also felt the cucumbers were really thick and thus didn't have much flavor.  

The ambiance was fine.  We came right before they closed so there was no wait whatsoever and we were the last people there.  

The pork bi bim bop was good.  Very well done in a stone pot with all that nice crispy rice on the sides.  I thought there was too much meat in the dish- generally I like it for the rice and vegetables, but the BF thought there wasn't enough.  Does that mean there was the perfect amount for normal people?  If we had just ordered that, that dish would still be a 4-5.  3-4 for the side dishes.

The spicy beef tofu soup was good, but not great.  I felt like i was pretty average.  Maybe it was just because I needed it a lot more spicy.  I like it when my mouth feels like its' burning a little bit.  Then again, I have a really high tolerance to spicy food. 

Anyway, I would go back if I were in the area, but wouldn't make a special trip.
author: Aly A.

description:
Banchan selection was ok - 5 items (fish cake, kimchi, potato, cucumber, bean sprouts) + a fried fish.  I wish there was a little more variety, mostly I wished that they had seaweed.

I've had the combo sundubu twice.  It's really good, but I prefer the taste of the broth at Doobu (in Japantown) more.  The rice comes in a stone pot so they get presentation points for that, but it's kind of a waste when the rice that's stuck at the bottom doesn't get utilized at the end.  Some places will pour hot water or tea into the stone pot as a sort of broth at the end.  I also wish that they had purple rice instead of the white rice (which is available at Doobu).

The food comes out pretty fast.  Service is good.  There's usually a line of people, but if you come during non-peak times, you can get seated right away.

The check at the end comes with some fruit-flavored gum.  Hurray!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
What is unique about Tofu House is that they serve fried fish as a side dish, but it's not unlimited like most other side dishes. Other sides include dried anchovies, bean sprouts, kimchi, and pickled cucumbers.

Tofu House has pretty legit tofu soups, they taste similar to my favorite So Gong Dong Tofu House in South Bay. They also have different combos of like Ramen Tofu Soup (not recommended, they just throw in some dry ramen), and Fish Egg Tofu Soup.

The meat dishes cost $20/person at dinner. What?! That just seems crazy to me, but that is pretty typical for Korean in SF.
author: Jess C.

description:
Sardine for side dishes? wow it was good..

i had the original chicken tofu soup..mild..it was good! not greasy or anything..

they spoon u about 2 1/2 bowl of rice and leave it there..the side dishes were ok.not too many variety..does come with an egg for your soup..

the prices weren't bad, i would think that they would have more variety on the menu..but its a tofu house n known for their soup..but overall good..bubbling..delicious!
author: Minerva L.

description: You get a yellow crooker that comes with the side dishes. Great tofu soup. Prices are very reasonable. Rice also contains goodies.
author: Yi L.

description:
The food was alright but the service was pretty bad. We left a small tip after eating and our server followed us out the door and demanded that we leave a bigger tip.

There are a lot of places around the city with the same food that are also less pricey.
author: Kevin W.

description:
What can I say about My Tofu House? Well, it is definitely a place to go for Korean food in San Francisco. My Tofu House has one of the better tasting BBQ Short Ribs (Kalbi) and BBQ beef (Bulgogi). Their soft tofu soups are really good too (honestly, I'm not a big fan of Korean soup so this place is an exception). 

I came here many times and never missed an order of Kalbi beef and soft tofu soup. I also got the Bimbibap and Bulgogi Pork which were both flavorful. In San Francisco, I would consider My Tofu House to be decent price for both lunch and dinner because Korean foods are not cheap. They also give you a whole piece of grilled fish on top of the many kimchee appetizers (unlimited), which makes them pretty unique. 

If you're on a low budget but want to eat Korean food, I would suggest coming here for lunch because the BBQ entrees are half the price of dinner. Of course, the portions are also smaller than dinner but it is worth getting. 

The service is good. The servers are friendly and will consistently give you refills on the appetizers whenever you ask. However, they need to move a little quicker and actually serve the appetizers first like other Korean restaurants. Sometimes, it takes a while to get service for larger groups (like your check) so they need to install the Korean service bells at the tables. Overall, I would recommend coming here for decent Korean food and price.
author: Monica C.

description: Had lunch here today and it was amazing!!!! I got the kimchi soft tofu soup with medium spicy level and it wasn't really that spicy so next time I will go up one level. It is a little pricey (~$13 for soup) but it's worth it! It comes with delicious side dishes and rice. Their house tea was tasty too, I think it's rice tea. The staff was friendly as well. They were really busy when we were seated so service was a little slow, but I could tell they were doing their best to be efficient. I highly recommend trying My Tofu House to get your Korean food fix!
author: Michelle T.

description:
This. Is. My. Favorite. Korean. BBQ. Place. EVER!

I always come here for Korean BBQ only because it tastes soooooo good and the service is always quick and efficient! This place is a bit expensive but totally worth it!

I totally love this place. I usually get the bulgoki, and tofu soup in mildly spicy.

Definitely coming back here.
author: Mabel Y.

description: The tofu soup with fish egg was delicious. Choose spicy and it was just right for me!!!!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
"we do not serve alcohol" said the waiter politely.
"what about SOJU?" asked by someone who clearly does not know that alcohol is an umbrella term. (just to throw it out there, I wasn't the one who asked)
"we do not serve ANY alcohol" responded the waiter with a slight smile.

For all the alchies out there, My Tofu House does NOT serve any alcoholic beverages. However, they do serve a mean bowl of soondubu. (ranging from vegetarian to seafood to dumpling, etc- in different levels of spiciness). The perfect bowl of spicy & silky tofu to accompany these long winter/ rainy nights in SF.

In addition, they also serve a bunch of Korean dishes.
Kalbi (marinated shortribs) and bulgogi (marinated beef) and the beef bibimbap (especially the burnt rice) was among the more popular items in our group. Served fresh off the grill, perfectly seasons & marinated- delicious sums it up. 

The seafood pancake on the other hand was very thick and doughy- lacking in seafood- wouldn't recommend. Otherwise, the service was quick and friendly. They were there to refill our teas and gave us extra banchan (spicy cucumber and fishcakes) with a smile. Something that differentiates this place would probably be the whole grilled fish (mackerel I believe) they served each of us- quite tasty and free, which probably added to its tastiness.

Overall, highly recommended as one of the better soondubu places in SF, but with a name like My Tofu House, I'm sure you aren't too surprised.
author: Ada C.

description:
How can a place that puts so much emphasis on tofu be good? Seriously? Well it is. 

I got the Combo Tofu soup, it had shrimp, oysters and beef with Medium spice. I'm the biggest wimp when it comes to spiciness and I could handle the medium spicy level with minimal swigs from the complimentary tea. 

I wouldn't recommend the combo soup as I am not a fan of shrimp that still have the whiskers (or whatever they are called) still on them, but nonetheless, the tofu and broth that it was in was exactly what you are looking for when you're in the mood for Korean. 

Wait staff was pleasant and the restaurant itself was clean and not crowded (We came at noon on a Sunday). But that could have been due to the fact that we came during the 49ers game.
author: Molly S.

description:
Whoa, thought I wrote a review for My Tofu House already since I came here so many times. This is one of our usuals, since me and my friends don't know much other Korean restaurants in town. 

It's a nice little restaurant that gets packed over the weekends. The waitresses and waiters are nice but barely has a smile on their face probably due to the capacity of people that needs to be served. They don't have much of a variety, and it's pretty pricey to me. Their soups are around $10, their bimbimbop is around $15 so is their pancakes and their bulgogi is around $20. Overall the food is good though! They have unlimited refills on the appetizers and they include fish! (which I don't see at the other Korean restaurants I have tried) Their portions are also pretty small, but if you do family style, you'll definitely be satisfied!

The last time I came, I shared a kimchi bimbimbop and a soup with a friend and we were both super bloated! Everyone else that was with us weren't full though, since they only had soup or bulgogi. So we decided to grab some dessert at Kowloon Tong which was a couple blocks down. But I was dying at that point, I couldn't stuff any more food in me. This is definitely the place to grab some yummy Korean food nearby, but make sure to go there an hour early if you have 4+ people. And don't even think about stepping out, the waiter will call your name once...twice...then he moves on quickly to the next name on the list.
author: Linda K.

description:
This is My Tofu House. Not yours. Mine. Deal with it. I know it can't be easy realizing after years of patronizing this place that you discover in one shocking moment that it's mine. But it is.
