It has been for years... except I've never been here before last weekend. Actually Jamie W. and I weren't planning to come here at all. We stopped by Korean Village a couple of doors down Geary, but we were taken aback by the huge pricetags on their barbecue dishes. We made a hasty retreat into the dark with only this place or Jack-in-the-Box within view. We made the right choice, don't you think?

I had to pull Jamie into this place since tofu is antithetical to the dietary sensibilities of a Detroit-raised, meats-and-potatoes eater. He did relent once he saw the menu had a lot more than tofu. It's a clean white place, the diametric opposite of Brothers which always looked (and smelled) like a third-world sauna to me. We got seated in a spacious booth - a nice change from the cramped corner we were relegated to at Boboquivari's the night before. 

The menu is standard Korean fare, but as we were waiting, we noticed the $8.75 Kimchee Tofu Soup (Soon-Dubu Chigae) was listed in 7x7 as a must-have. We ordered a steaming bowl of it with medium-hot kimchee and strips of pork, and it came in a volcanic state that took a good twenty minutes to calm down completely (see photo). I didn't know I was supposed to crack the raw egg into the boiling broth since it came much earlier. I cracked it over my bowl of rice since my Japanese heritage made me think of sukiyaki. It was spicy-tasty once the heat was under control. 

Of course, we were already munching on the banchan, which consisted of six plates of goodies - salted sardines, little dried anchovies, pickled cucumbers, bean sprouts, two types of kimchee (see photos). We ate most of it over the rice that was steaming in the big metal crock left on our table. The massive pile that were the $15.25 Broiled Short Ribs (Kal Bi) came soon afterward, and it was savory delicious (see photo). That was a whole lot of food, and it certainly makes a most satisfying Sunday supper. Best of all, I don't think Jamie or I reeked afterward as was the result of our dining experience at Brothers. 

FOOD - 4 stars...quite a tofu soup to be had, but kal bi is the real bomb 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean with plenty of elbow room for all the hot crocks and small dishes they leave on your table 
SERVICE - 3 stars...a little fast on the draw...could have used more instructional guidance on how to eat everything, including what to do with a raw egg 
TOTAL - 4 stars...could quite possibly turn int my go-to Korean since after all, it is My Tofu House...MINE!
author: Ed U.

description:
Came here because my group wanted some good ole' Korean food at the end of our food run. My Tofu House is a nice restaurant, with a clean interior and quiet ambiance. Staff were a little standoffish, but attentive.

As for the food, I personally have had better. Banchan were a little disappointing. I usually hope for some pickled daikon for a little bit of sweet to offset the spice. However, there were only 6 types: fishcake, picked zucchini, kimchi, bean sprouts, fried fish, and kimchi (?) daikon. It was more salty than sweet, and I felt a little bit overwhelmed without a little palette cleanser. The fried fish was actually very good with the tofu stew, and I quite enjoyed it.

The tofu stew was a little bland. I got the mushroom tofu stew, mild spice. I guess I should have gotten medium, but I still was hoping for a little bit of a kick with mild. There were lots of mushrooms and tofu in the stew, which I appreciate. They also give you a raw egg to crack in your stew, which I love.

Oh, and a warning: If you're used to getting a  bibimbap sans spicy sauce, be careful. My friend ordered the bibimbap and it already came with spicy added to it. It ended up being a little too much for him (he usually adds some sauce to his liking when it comes without).

Overall, if I were in the area and was craving Korean, I might give this place another shot. This time I was a little underwhelmed.
author: Denise C.

description: First time here and coming from southern cali local, I am happy to have found a good Korean tofu! The tofu and kalbi were delicious especially in this cold weather
author: Richi K.

description:
The Banchan was a little on the sparse side - only kimchi, anchovies, brined cucumbers, bean sprouts, and spicy radishes.  But they were all good with strong flavors.  

The Tall Vegetarian was impressed by the vegetarian options for the $15 Bibimbap, and all were served in hot stone bowls.  Thank goodness that the Tall Vegetarian was satisfied or else she would have ripped our heads off, as all tall vegetarians are prone to do when hungry and unsatisfied.

The Short Carnivores got meaty soft tofu soups.  My $11 Combination Soft Tofu Soup had a good mix of super soft tofu, beef, and seafood (mostly clams), although I didn't much care for the previously frozen shrimps.  I opted for ramen (+$2?) to add some carbs to my love handles and fat tushy.  The Real Authentic Korean commented that the soup wasn't as "bold," but nevertheless, the soft tofu soups are always good enough for special trips out to Richmond.  The Fried Yellow Croaker on the side was cooked perfectly but possibly too salty for some tastes.  To further balance out the evils of the Tall Vegetarian, the Short Carnivores did a good deed by also getting the $21 Bulgogi, which was kinda fatty - both fatty meat and oily, but that's what makes it good, right?

And melon gum sent us off into the cold, foggy night.
author: Kevin W.

description: Went here with my friends and got their Korean rice bowl. The rice was quite burnt so it tasted a little dry and with less flavor. I don't think I will come frequently. The environment is definitely nice and very intimate I would say.
author: Eva H.

description:
Who would have thought that some chunks of soy bean curd in a boiling bath of red liquid would be so good?! 

My Tofu House has some of the best Korean food in all of the Bay Area, and in my opinion, is even better than their more famous rival, Brothers. Their banchan dishes are flavorful and refillable, although maybe not spicy enough for my tastes. Their fried fish has a wonderful salted crust and is quite tender. Their rice is not over or under cooked, but regular cooked. And they pour tea into the stone pot to extract the rice stuck to the sides, which is a great idea. Their main dish, the tofu soup is filling and can get fairly spicy if you ask for it. They can filled with copious amounts of differing ingredients and proteins. Most of their combinations seem to work. Also, they never to stop boiling, so watch out!

The perceived cleanliness of the restaurant is always a plus and makes me quite comfortable to eat their without having the germophobic side of me flip out. The wait staff tends to be quite sweet and attentive as well.

The best part is that this all can be had for a great price, even in an expensive city like San Francisco. Great place!
author: Alan H.

description:
Anybody who knows anything about Korean food would tell you this place is absolute garbage. I didn't come in with high expectations. I left completely disgusted.

Service: Trash. The waiter guys looked at the empty water cups and the empty banchan (sidedishes) and did absolutely zero. They did have time to talk about some girl on the other table (yes, I understand Korean). When I did eventually flag them down, they had the nerve to look at the empty dish, and tell me they would refill when we are finished. We were finished about 20 minutes ago, dickwad. 

Food: Trash. Want to know what MSG in soondubu tastes like? Come here. Probably washed down 3-4 cups of water trying to eat the soondubu. Deep fried fish served was cold. Literally, my tea was warmer than the fish. Kimchi was barely descent. Banchan was very limited and extremely basic (fishcakes were hard. Hard to taste the staleness with the chili sauce). No stonebowl rice soup with bori cha (barley tea) included with the meal. Keep in mind this is very standard for most soondubu restaurants.

I will give them this. I had the "haemul" seafood soondubu. The three shrimps in the soup were HUGE. I was quite impressed.

Price: Keep in mind this review is for dinner. Soondubu price was average for this area. It was what I was expecting.

I would love to tell you how the korean pancake or korean meats were. But I would have to be a complete idiot or didn't know any better to order those. The korean pancakes are more than $20 and the meats vary, but all above $20 (Dinner prices). Seafood pancake for $20?! It was so laughable I did LOL. I did check to see how good the $20 pancake looked because the table across from us did order one. Sorry folks, no gold flakes or rubys coming out of that flour.

Overall, as you can probably tell, this place is trash. It is beyond me how this place got 4 stars. Im giving it 2. One for the huge shrimp, and one because I just feel so bad for people who actually think this is good/descent Korean food. God bless you folks...
author: Justin L.

description:
I recently returned after a long absence.  Why?   Because a really good Korean restaurant specializing in tofu stew and bibimbap located near my office has been satisfying my cravings for this most comforting of dishes.  However, My Tofu House is my go-to place in the City for soondubu jigae.  

On my visit my visit I was lucky enough to have snagged the last open booth.  I decided to order the #3 seafood tofu stew with oysters, shrimp and clams, with medium heat.  It came at a rolling boil and had the perfect amount of spiciness for my level of tolerance.  There was more seafood than I've seen at other places in my bowl.  The tofu was soft and creamy.   We shared the seafood and vegetable bibimbap and it was good, but would have been better with a bit more seafood and/or vegetables to go with the rice.  The banchan included sprouts, kim chee, cucumbers, daikon radish and fried fish, which was moist and flavorful.  Although I'm used to seeing more variety of banchan, I still appreciated that patrons are allowed to ask for more of each item.

Service was friendly and very efficient.  Our food arrived quickly and piping hot.  The rice was a good texture and flavor.

Patrons tend to consist of the younger crowd, but there were a few families as well.  Prices are very reasonable.  The menu consists of tofu stews, grilled meat, savory pancakes and bibimbaps.  Small, yes, but with enough variety to satisfy just about everyone.
author: Melissa L.

description: Rude services and never come back again.  If they have zero star, I would rate that instead.
author: T N.

description:
We were very very disappointed with this restaurant.  We wanted some Korean food while on vacation in SF with our 3 kids, and we love tofu soup.  

First of all, the service was horrible.  The guy serving us was so rude, never said a "thank you," or even apologize when he brought us 2 wrong soups.  We're Korean, so we could understand him talking rudely about customers.  

Secondly, the soups were not bad, but the bulgogi was terrible.  It had a weird after taste to it, and just not very good.  I guess it's okay for non-Koreans that may not know what it's supposed to taste like.  Also, our fish was burnt...all 4 of them!

Lastly, omg...why so expensive for what they're serving?  It's tofu with a few vegetables in it.  Our bill was $90 for 4 soups and 1 bulgogi.  


All in all...it's pretty bad when Korean food in Houston tastes like gourmet compared to this place.
author: Susan P.

description: It was my first time here and I loved it! I ordered the kimchee tofu soup in mild. I should've ordered it in medium because there wasn't enough kick to it, but it was still delicious. I loved the side dishes, and the fried fish was good.
author: Sara L.

description: The worst ever! No any customer service. Food is so so but expensive. I won't come ever never!
author: 苏

description:
Wow, I didn't know this place was so popular.  

Maybe it's because I've been so spoiled by all the delicious Korean restaurants in the OC and LA... this place was just A-OK for me.  

The wait was average.  However, we were starving so it felt like it took forever!  

Service was kind of slow (and they don't have that little buzzer!!  Every Korean restaurant has that little buzzer.. it makes the institution Korean!!! jk, but it's such an awesome idea to have a buzzer on your table to call the waiter only when you need them).  It took a while to get our food and our check.. ehh..

Now to the food:  The side dishes were fine, but my tofu soup.. hmmm it was delicious.. however, towards the end.. I got a stomach ache.  I don't think it was the soup since everyone else I was with said they felt fine... Well, that experience didn't make me feel too peachy.

Overall, I'm very mediocre about this place.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I'm in the neighborhood craving Korean food.. MAYBE I'll stop by
author: Cecilia S.

description:
I love this restaurant.  I always order the dumpling tofu soup (mild).  I first assumed that all their soups were vegetarian because of the name, but was happy to know that's not the case.

The soup comes with all the traditional Korean side plates (like kimchee, sprouts, fried fish, etc) and is more than enough food.  I also love that they bring out a raw egg for you to break into your boiling soup when it arrives. 

I would eat here once a week if I could!
author: Gabrielle L.

description: Their happy hour special (11-4pm) is amazing! Spicy Bulgogi for $11 compared to the usual $20!
author: Ray W.

description:
Nom nom nom I would eat here every weekend if I lived in SF. 

Came here with a seasoned Korean eater, who guided us toward the right stuff. Honestly I can't tell you what we ate, but it was all delicious and filling.

You know it's a good sign when there's a wait, but thankfully we didn't have to wait too long. Looks can be deceiving, the waiters are good at cycling through groups in a fashionable manner.
author: Sarah G.

description: It's really good if you are craving soon dooboo. The service ain't bad and the banchan are great. However, my only qualm about this place is that it's definitely much more expensive than most other soon dooboo places that I've been to in Toronto. I miss the dirty and cheap places that I went to in ktown.
author: Joanne W.

description: The soup is delicious and has an authentic flavor. And the side dishes are very good. Sometimes the restaurant is slammed so prepare to wait for a table during dinner time, especially when it's cold outside. The food is worth it, and you will leave full and happy.
author: James P.

description:
I have to say this Korean restaurant  must be the best in Town. Friendly service, great food.
I usually order spicy beef kimchi tofu soup with bbq kalbi. Compare to the other place in Sf. It's more traditional flavor.

Sometime you have to wait for 10-20mins. Bit trust me, it's worth to wait.
author: Momo G.

description:
Although the place is a tofu house, I found the combination tofu soup average at best.  If I ever return, I'll follow suite like my friends and get the bibimbap plate instead. 

Combination Tofu Soup - 2/5. Tofu was wonderfully soft. However, soup was average and the extra spicy was just barely spicy. Shrimps were bland, clams were okay. 

However, I was very pleased with the fried fish, bean sprout and cucumber sides.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
My friends warned me before I moved to SF that there was no good Korean food in the city....silly pessimists!! I found one already, HA! Tofu House offers solid soondubu in a variety of combinations (seafood, beef, kimchi, dumplings etc.), and their menu also offers bibimbap, pajeon, and kbbq. We only got the soondubu this time. Overall, I was quite satisfied with the meal, especially because the banchan was varied and the kimchi was good. My only regret (and tip for new customers) is that I didn't go spicier. You can choose the spice level of your soup and i picked mild, thinking that the spice levels were going by the more intense Korean standards. In case you need a reference: I think Shin ramen spicy is the perfect level of spicy and anything too far beyond that makes me uncomfortable. The medium level spicy at Tofu House is less spicy than a Shin ramen, and the mild level is not spicy AT ALL. Thus, I plan to get medium or hot level spicy next time. Oh, and i thought the *seafood soondubu* was better than the *seafood + beef combination*, so get the former if you're having trouble deciding!!

p.s. there is a small Korean grocery store right next door to the restaurant, so you can pick up some essentials on your way home!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
This place must be authentic because it was only full of older Korean people.  

You get a lot of varieties of banchan including fried fish that I've never been served at any other Korean joint.  

I ordered the combination soondubu with shrimp, clams and beef.  I found it to be very bland.  Portion is huge though.  One order is enough for my friend and I, but we each ordered our own.  

A little pricy and bland, but good size portions and decent service.
author: Jenny L.

description: This place is one of my favorite Korean restaurant in Bay Area. I always order pork soontofu with kalbi and never disappointed yet! :) Only problem is its little difficult to find parking on the street.
author: Sakae O.

description:
After going back and forth for 2 hours about what I wanted for dinner, I finally settled for My Tofu House. I shouldn't say I settled because I chose it... and I felt like a genius after!

I opted to order take out since I called in and asked for the wait time. ~30 minutes for two on a cold Sunday night. 

I called in and order 3 beef tofu soups (2 mild, 1 medium), an order of bulgoki, and an order of kalbi. I asked if they provided banchans for take out orders and they said yes. I was super excited for that because a lot of restuarants do not include side dishes for take out orders. 

Stopped in front to pick up the order.. it was $87! Jesus Christ, a $87 take out order for 3.

Well who cares, I'm hungry and its cold. And I know the tofu soup is going to be worth it. 

Brought it home, soup was still piping hot. 

Included were 3 tofu soups, 5 fried fish, some kimchi, some cucumber kimchi, some bean sprouts, some other spicy goodie, and 5 small boxes of rice. Hmm... maybe they thought this meal was for 5...  

The kalbi and bulgolki were delicious! Marinated to perfection and the kalbi was grilled perfectly. I don't know if I could justify the price (which I don't even know because I wasn't given a receipt). 

The mild was pretty much what I would order as "not spicy" and the medium was barely a mild compared to other Korean restaurants. 

I'm sure this meal could've easily fed 5 people since I had leftovers so I'm not complaining too much about the tab. 

Key takeaways:
- Get take out if you want to avoid the long line, it's just as good!
- If you're ordering meats, get ready to pay top dollar. 
- Get medium or spicy soup

-1 star for forgetting the egg and not giving me a receipt to see what damage I've done.
author: Jessica L.

description: Still think My Tofu House is one of the better Korean BBQ and tofu soup places in the city. Came here the other day cause we felt like Korean and got Kal bi and beef tofu soup. The usual ban chan PLUS two fried fish are a big plus in my book. The variety was a bit on the smaller side compared to other places but its okay. The waitstaff was friendly and courteous but the place got packed and I never got my tea refilled so I was extremely thirsty and I had to flag them down several times to get their attention. They might want to invest in another server on busy days such as Sunday afternoons.. I'm sure they can use the help.
author: Tiff C.

description: First time visiting bay area and decided to go for korean food. I went to a couple by my hotel and checked the yelp review and was pretty satisfied there. Then went to take pictures at the golden gate bridge so crave kbbq nearby. My experience as an out of state person was disappointing. Out of my group of 4 , only 2 of us got waters. The waiters there did not really check up on us and only came when ordering and when the food came out. Although she was friendly when it came to patience since we ordered long, i was disappointed in the flavoring. 3 of us order 3 different kind of bibimbap and the food was really flavorless. The meat in the bibimbap was not as good as the one ordered separately. One person in our group ordered kalbi which tasted fine. I understand how it was crowded and did not mind the food since it was busy. But wish the waiters check up instead of calling them over each time. :(
author: Denise S.

description:
FINALLY!

After being back in Norcal for so long, I thought I'd never find a good soondubu place. My friend and I came here around 730 and I think we waited for at least 30 minutes. The place can get pretty packed plus it's rather understaffed. There were 3 waiters on a saturday night both waiting on people and busing tables. It was crazy. Once we finally sat down, we ordered a combo soondubu and a dumpling one. Also we got the seafood pancake. The banchon was pretty tasty. The kimchi was tasty and looked like it was cut up right before they brought it out. Anyways, the soup, super flavorful and tons of tofu. The dumplings were ok, but the soup was really the hero. Then came the pancake and boy was that tasty as well. The squid and other ingredients weren't overcooked and the outside was nice a crispy.

I highly recommend coming here if you are looking for some great soondubu in the city. Just be prepared to wait.
author: edward k.

description: Good food and good prices. I prefer to come here with a lot of people so that we actually finish the meat but I have never finished all the meat that we've ordered before. Came at night both times I've been here and we always chose to bbq. It's more fun and you can decide how you want to cook your meat. The prices are good for what you get! A plate of meat runs between $20 and $30 but it's totally worth it!
author: Cathy C.

description:
One of my favorite Korean food spots in SF. I usually get the Bibimbaps when I come here. The Bibimbaps are generally expensive but has the quality and taste to back it up. I just wish it was a bit cheaper though. They give you an egg to crack it in as well. 

Upon my last visit with a friend (which were months ago), I ended up trying their Mandu Soondubu (Dumpling Soft Tofu) because I was sick and needed something to fix my cold. We were quickly greeted and seated when we entered. Lots of tables were already filled since it was lunch but were we lucky enough to grab a table near the windows. As for the soondubu, you can choose the spiciness level on the soup. I chose mild since I didn't feel like wanting it very spicy. The dumplings were soft and the soup was super hot when it arrived to the table, which is means it was freshly made and served. Right off the bat, I cracked the complimentary egg into the steamy soup. The tofu was very soft and hits the spot well. Yummm. There were some seaweeds too and it blended well with the overall taste of the soup. Though I do wish they added more mandus, oh wells. Banchans were plentiful for the two of us, especially the pieces of cucumber and kimchi. We ended up cleaning house on our food.

The interior decor definitely felt homely as if I was at a friend's house, nothing too wild. There were TVs mounted on the walls for the dining experience. The place was clean. Service was good. Water was being offered and the waitress was kind enough to check on us even though we sat in the far back, hidden from view by the booths. Of course, we wanted refills on some of the banchans and the lady kindly refilled it for us twice without second thoughts! The guy waiter with glasses didn't look too friendly. Despite that, we were still pleased with our experience. Melon gums were given at the end. We will surely come back for more.
author: Tony C.

description: Really solid Korean food--my bf's favorite place to get sondobu. The only thing I don't like about this place Is that they give the small plates with your meal so if you're starving (we usually are) beforehand, you're not able to snack on anything. But overall, the food is always good and we come back here often!
author: Samantha S.

description:
The wait here at night can be long.

And the food is just ... meh. Their tofu soup is a good comfort food but there's nothing special about it. Bbq is also just ok. Bibimbap can be a little bland.

The service here, unfortunately is not good. It's a little better if you get seated in the front room, so you can call the waiter whenever you need something. Unfortunately for us, we were seated in the back room, and after we ordered, nobody came to check on us. We had to go outside and reminded the waiter that we needed a refill on our banchan, and on more time when we wanted the check.

I'd still come back from time to time, since it's so close to my place and it's not horrible food, just ok.
author: Ngan B.

description: The crispy fish side dish is definitely the best I've had compared to other Korean restaurants. I ordered the seafood soft tofu soup in mild but when my soup arrived, it was non spicy. Even though I did not receive what I ordered, the soup was delicious. I do recommend to have your tofu soup with some level of spiciness. At dinner time, the prices are more expensive.
author: Kelly O.

description: For the price, there's better korean out there. Shin toe Bu Yi comes to mind as a korean spot that in my mind is better. I got their original soft tofu with chicken and it wasn't bad but the value just wasn't there in my opinion. Free fish which is nice but it's pretty hard to eat because of all the small fish bones that you have to pick through to get some meat.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: There is a long wait for this place but there really isn't a lot on the menu. The meat or short ribs they have there aren't phenomenal, they were just alright. The ban chan and service was good, but the food wasn't the best I've had.
author: Cindy H.

description:
My Tofu House is definitely a winner in my book because the tofu is SERIOUSLY the best. It's so soft and the soup is so flavorful, not watery at all.

I've been here about 3 times already and always get the Mandoo Soondubu because the dumplings AND rice cakes are an unbeatable combination for me. Plus, the dumplings are REALLY good. They aren't soggy, but the perfect texture of chewy and hearty. They really don't skimp on the dumplings either...!

The kalbi is really good here too! Sometimes I worry about getting kalbi because you end up with more bone than meat, but My Tofu House gives you a heaping plate of it, so you don't feel cheated.

The selection of Banchan is minuscule..but they give you two little fried fish, which I have not seen anywhere else in the area. Ultra sad that they don't have ANY potato banchan..no mashed potato, sweet potato, cubed potato..::sniffles::

Great service, and try to get there early!! I usually don't have trouble finding parking around 6:30ish..but sometimes theres a wait if you get there after 7:00.

PS Don't ask for beer or soju..no alcohol sold here!! Whoops!
author: Jennifer S.

description: This restaurant is pretty pricey. The bibimbap was about $17 which is a lot compared to other restaurants. I ordered the Noodle Tofu Soup. It looked small but was surprisingly very filling! Especially with the extra rice they serve you with the banchan. The banchan is unlimited instead of the fried fish, they will charge extra for that. The soup was very flavorful as was the bibimbap that my friend ordered.
author: Carolyn H.

description: Came here on a Saturday night and there was surprisingly no wait to be seated. I ordered their seafood combo tofu soup with medium spicy. The soup went very well with rice and the raw egg. In addition to our meal it also came with dishes of banchan but at a small variety compared to other Korean restaurants but they did give a lot of my favorite which is the kimchi. I really liked their fried fish but it was a bit hard to eat when it came to the bones. They also give you free gum at the end of your meal. The service here tends to be very quick with food coming fast after you order.
author: Peter C.

description:
THAT KIMCHEE TOFU SOUP.

Thumbs up for the fishcake and bean sprouts banchans.
Bulgoki was good, but not my favorite.

BUT THAT KIMCHEE TOFU SOUP.
Man.
author: Emmeline A.

description: This place is pretty good! Came here during lunch with a couple of friends and we shared the dumpling tofu soup, mushroom & vegetable bibimbap, and bulgoki. The dumplings were really good in the tofu soup and it also came with a lot of rice. The bibimbap was alright, but the bulgoki was probably my favorite dish we ordered since it was really flavorful! Really great service, they kept refilling our water cups and tea cups.
author: Janessa M.

description:
This place is almost exactly the same as BCD tofu house in southern california, except it's not a chain. There's almost always a wait, but you get seated pretty quick. They give the same amount of banchan (side dishes) as BCD, so maybe like 6 dishes? Refills, yes. And they give each person one deepfried fish which is salty and on point. 
The RICE and the EGG is my favorite part. If you're into the semi raw yolk effect, bury that shit deep under all the tofu right when you get your soup and be careful when you eat it so you don't pop it. 

At the end they make, curin bap which is like noorungee with tea. Idk it cuts the spicy soup really well. ON POINT and effin' good.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Since the move to Bay Area, I've been looking for good Korean restaurant.  I love Korean food and was very spoiled with many restaurants in L.A.  So it has proved to be quite challenging to find any place nearly as good as the restaurants I used to frequent.  

So I was excited to find My Tofu House, I became very hopeful seeing the whole fried fish banchan-that's one of the sign of serious Korean restaurant to me.  

I would say My Tofu House didn't disappoint me.  My all time favorite Korean dish is  "Soon Tofu (sundubu jjigae)" and it's especially difficult to find good place even in L.A. I would say My Tofu House's Soon Tofu got very close to my favorite flavors I used to eat, so I was very happy !! Rice was also good !! Finally.....cooked in stone pot and came right out, served on the table.  Hot, fluffy and yummy.  

Banchan themselves are okay. Whole fried fish I usually love was a bit dry and not as fluffy as I usually like it to be.  Kimchi ?  I tasted so much better ones in the past including the home made one by Korean moms...so it's hard to criticize, however I can say all tasted good and better than any places I have been in Bay Area so far.  

I'll be back for more Soon Tofu !
author: Motoko H.

description: I love this place. Extremely fast service and their spicy tofu soup served in a stone bowl is amazing. So was their kalbi and spicy pork. I've never tried tofu soup before and they made my first experience a very flavorful one. I wanna try some other tofu houses now, but I'll definitely be coming back to this place :)
author: Nessa R.

description:
Probably the best Korean tofu I've had in the bay. Got the seafood tofu which was completely packed with tofu, oysters, clams, and shrimps. The small shrimp also had eggs on them. SO GOOD. 

The side dishes were also excellent. They gave 2 fried fish in the selection which were super crispy and delicious. 

The prices of the other dishes besides the tofu seemed high to me but looked and smelled amazing as they came out of the kitchen. Definitely will be tempted to try them in the near future. 

Service was slow as there were only 2 waiters working but they were good about refilling the tea. Can't imagine how long the waits must get on a busier night.
author: Kailin L.

description:
Came here for lunch after an appointment I had nearby.  Always wanted to try it because I frequent the Korean mart next door for their kimchi (yes, all the way from the Peninsula).  What can I say?  I had the seafood tofu stew.  Taste was pretty nostalgic.  Their ban chan dishes were a good portion size too.  They gave me two cooked fish when most restaurants usually only give one (but maybe because it didn't have much meat on it).  

I hear there's always a line and people have to wait.  It was true because I got there around 11:30 in the AM and there was a line by the time I got out.  I would go early if you plan to have a meal here or else plan on waiting.  Service was till good considering there were only two servers and the restaurant was packed.  I'll come back again when I'm in the area.
author: K. C.

description:
Solid service. Authentic tofu house. My go to spot when it comes to Korean food cravings. A little pricey, but the value is worth the quantities. Recommend for sure, as a Korean American myself.

Stipulation is the struggle to find parking. It's just the Richmond neighborhood. Nothing you could really do about it.
author: James N.

description:
The fish egg tofu soup is always amazing. 
I always get the extra fish egg with extra spicy. Good price.
It'd be great if they have more side dishes.
author: Iris C.

description: I've been here twice now and love it here. So much banchan. I had the bulgogi the first time I went and it was a huge serving. The second time I had the soft tofu soup which was very yummy. My only complaint is that I asked for it with medium spiciness but it was definitely mild. Did they not think I could handle it? I can handle the spice. Very crisp aesthetics inside and service is pretty good. Overall, great Korean place to check out.
author: Emily V.

description: This has been my long time to go to place! My most favorite Korean restaurant. (I have several favorites). The tofu soup is the best here and the service is always great and the side dishes, rice, are all really good. I want to try the bibimbap as I'm sure its wonderful here but I love soft tofu soup so much I can't not get it! I usually go in the afternoon when it is quiet, otherwise there are lines, maybe 25 min wait on a Saturday night but worth it.
author: marya k.

description: Probably my favorite Korean restaurant in SF.  The soon dubu, bi bim bap, kalbi, and the ubiquitous ban chan (regardless of your order) are all delicious.  Never any complaints, only satisfaction.
author: Erich D.

description:
Great tofu soup! Good price, $12 lunch or dinner for all the tofu soups. I had the combination soup with beef, shrimp, and clams! Comes with a fried fish as well! I got the medium but could barely taste any spice. Tried my friends spicy and it was perfect. Ban chan or side dishes were also really good. There was a spicy fish cake that was the bees knees and a tangy sesame cucumber dish that was good for those who don't like spicy. Other side dishes were just ok. Cabbage and radish Kim Chee was average. Bean sprouts were meh. But we still got a free refill of the side dishes. Don't be afraid to ask!

Seafood pancake was really pricy for how much you got and how good it was. Not bad but 22 bucks? Not worth to me. Service isn't amazing either but I don't eat for service so I don't care about it that much.

Overall great place for Korean tofu soup. From the hot barley water to the delicious side dishes and the delicious soup it's a great place to fill up. Pretty healthy too.
author: Edward P.

description:
Pretty standard korean tofu, or soon du boo house. Decent number of banchans and mixed grain rice.

I got my usual fare which was mild seafood tofu soup. Tofu was very silky, truly advertised. Decent amount of seafood and the soup was not terribly spicy. 

When we came around 7pm on a Friday dinner, there was a small line formed. By the time when we finished, the line was pretty long.

Also you can tell the place is under staffed as service was kinda slow
author: Ruxin H.

description:
Sometimes a gal just needs a piping hot bowl of soup to wrap up a long day. So when the sis and her family suggested Korean Tofu Soup for dinner, I was ALL in!

The wait was about 10 minutes--not too bad for a Friday evening at dinner time. Overall, service was pretty quick and friendly. Extra points for the speedy refills of our banchans. 

The BF and I split the Kimchee Tofu Soup ($10.95) and asked for it to be extra spicy. It came out bubbling away like a little cauldron of goodness. From the mass amount of chili oil floating at the top, I knew we were in for a good SPICY treat. And it was! Broth was super flavorful, savory, spicy, and had a fair amount of beef in it. 

The others ordered the Kalbi Ribs, Bulgogi, and Combination Tofu Soup. Both the meat dishes were REALLY tasty! The Bulgogi was really flavorful and juicy--as was the Kalbi ribs, too. My only disappointment was that both meat items could have been grilled or broiled a tad longer to get a little crisp char on them. Nonetheless it was good :) 

Banchans were tasty but there weren't as much variety as many other Korean restaurants. However, we did love their salted fish (sardines??) that aren't offered at many other spots.

I definitely recommend it and will be back :)
author: Nam N.

description:
If you ever get the chance to sit in a corner cubicle with a friend or date here by the window, it can get intimately cozy in a moment. This is my second time coming here and I found my experience to be mediocre compared to Korean Village restaurant 2 doors down (http://www.yelp.com/biz/wooden-charcoal-korean-village-barbecue-house-san-francisco). 
 
FOOD: 
Bulgogi (it was kinda like jerky)
Seafood Tofu Soup
Rice
Ban Chan
Tea

SERVICE:

Quick, friendly, soft spoken..hm.. o.O

Overall:

Soup is pretty good, came out boiling, however, when I dropped the raw egg in, it didn't cook very quickly like other places I've been to. Seemed like the soup was simmering and not totally boiling. Ain't that a shame...

Rice had like 5 garbanzo beans in there for presentation? Eh..Not impressed. 

Banchan..seems like they were skimping out on us when we asked for a refill on kimchi and fish cake. Shady dawg...

Maybe the third time will be a charm?
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Pros: accepts credit, good food
Cons: really expensive for dinner, gets very crowded and loud

My friends and I came for dinner around 6 pm and the restaurant was about 90%full. After being seated, our tea came out right away. Our food came out ten/fifteen minutes after ordering and when I saw how the portions were, I was a little flabbergasted. I wanted some tofu stew, so we decided on the regular stew with beef and we also got the seafood pancake. I could not believe how much the foods actually were. The stew was $12 and the seafood pancake was a whopping $23! Though I thought the food was okay and pretty good, my friends didn't think so. Throughout the entire menu, the waiters are very good about refilling your tea, but other than that, it was actually very difficult to catch someone's attention. Towards the end of our meal, around 7:30pm, I could tell we were being rushed out because of the massive line building up in the entrance. We paid and left. End of My Tofu House. I wish this place wasn't so expensive. I live and learn.
author: Alex T.

description:
This is usually my go-to place for soft tofu in SF. I always get the kimchee soft tofu and if I'm with a bunch of people, I like to get the seafood pancake (since it's a lot of food for just 2 and also a bit expensive ~$20). 

I like that they give you a fried fish as part of the banchan. Reminds me of BCD tofu house in LA's korea town which is one my favorites. I used to live 5 minutes from korea town so I was spoiled by some really good korean good. Hence, the reason I give this place a 3....even though it's 1 of the 2 places I go to for it in SF.

Got the bugolgi last time and I wish I got the kalbi instead.

If you're only going for soft tofu then this place is very affordable. If you plan to order meat, it starts getting more into the 20pp range for 2 people.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Let me start off by saying:

I LOVE TOFU!!!

* Disclaimer: but not as much as I love french fries *

So you know this review is already going to be a bit biased, since I usually just find tofu playing a supporting role -- but at my tofu house, it takes center stage.

It is superb in the kimchi with soft tofu soup.  You can have your soup either fiery hot spicy or not spicy at all.  I had mine mild, I didn't want to be crying and snifflin at lunch.  This soup is served BOILING hot in a claypot, has a silky broth and you can either have it with chicken or beef.  Charging you over $10 for this soup is expensive, but it's soothing on a cold day. 

Other must try dishes are their Bibimbap and Bulgogi.  I tried the seafood and veggie combo with prawns, octopus, mussels over rice. I loved scraping the burnt rice at the bottom of the stoneware! crunchy good.  While I found the Bulgogi well-salted  (MSG?) its tender meat also has a slight sweetness to it. 

Tofu house made my day and I got to check off #9 on my Big Eats SF list!
author: Janice C.

description: My girlfriend and I visited SF and stumbled upon this place. The environment is nice with lots of booths available and if you're a fan of old school music then you'll love their music selection. We both ordered the tofu soup (combination and seafood), however the menu was so small it didn't leave us with many options to begin with. They were fairly quick on making our food and it tasted pretty good. No argument there. Plus they gave us a fair amount of sides, including rice which I believe most places would charge extra for. The food was a bit pricey and the staff were not as friendly as I wanted them to be. I wouldn't want to return here but overall my experience was decent.
author: Otto A.

description: This is our go to place in the city when it rains. It's a cozy Korean restaurant with excellent food and service. The side dishes are delicious! You can't go wrong with their soups and meat dishes. I tried their bibimbop for the first time and was blown away! It is definitely enough for 2 people. There was an equal ratio of rice to vegetables which made it very filling (I'm used to eating bibimbop with more vegetables than rice). Great place if you're looking for some warm comfort food.
author: Darrevy K.

description:
Now I have two Korean bbq places to go to in my area (Brother's being the other). There's another spot that's actually a lot more closer to where I live, but, the first time I ate there...became my last. O_O

Anyway, this was my second visit to My Tofu house and this place gets pretty busy. I went with my parents and my nephew on Valentine's Day evening. The wait time was bearable....about 15 minutes for a table for 4 people. They serve free Barley tea (which I am a fan of) and it's pretty good. Has a nutty flavor to it. Water, you will need to request for it. But as long as I can get free Barley tea, I'm all good.

We ordered the seafood bibimbap and seafood soft tofu and kalbi ribs. The Kalbi ribs, barbecued just right, with all the right seasonings and good marinade. There were a few pieces that had a lot of fat with it, but I didn't care. I love kalbi more than I love bulgogi! 

The seafood soft tofu was ordered mild...actually more like absolutely spicey-free, only because of my father's preference. It was good, but I would've wanted the spiciness added for a kick. The tofu texture and soup were good, though.

The bibimbap was okay. My mom liked it a whole lot more, but, it was missing something...a little bland and it had a burnt taste to it.  Thank God there was ban chan to complete the entire meal. I may need to try a different type next time.

Last time I was here, the kimchee wasn't good. I still stand by that statement. I don't know what it is. The other ban chan tasted fine.

Next time, I'll order the samgyeopsal (pork belly) along with the kalbi. If beef and pork were healthier, I'd be eating them more. 

Just a FYI: lunch time prices are cheaper than the dinner ones. Lunch time prices end at 4pm.
author: Shall P.

description: The combination soft tofu was yummy yummy! The people I went with said that the non-spicy tofu is so plain and that the spicy ones are the best. However, I don't eat spicy and I think the non-spicy tofu was amazing! It wasn't plain and it had a yummy savory taste to it. I would definitely want to come back to this place.
author: Susan L.

description: Coming here I got the dumpling tofu soup. I was thinking of getting the kbbq but the dinner price was so expensive that we decided to pass on it. The soup was good, but nothing special. Don't expect too much meat outside of the dumplings. The sides were also ok, but the service of refilling them took like 10 minutes. Overall nothing special
author: Victor D.

description:
Key to a successful trip to My Tofu House: bringing two dudes who can eat a lot!

Came here a little before 9PM on a Friday evening b/c I was cold and hungry after a long day.  Was quickly seated at one of the few regular tables (everything else is a booth meant for 4-6 ppl) and ordered the original tofu soup, seafood bibibab, and bulgogi.  Total came out to around $46 pre-tax.  Not bad for a whole lot of food and banchan for 3 people.

Speaking of banchan, I really, really liked that they had yellow croakers.  Some Krn places don't offer that so whenever I do get it, I'm a happy gal.  Also, their kim chi is really crispy and delicious.  It's not tooooo sour and has a little bit of heat to it.  Not bitter at all!

The bulgogi was soft and flavorful.  They chopped up the meat into tinier pieces so you won't get caught with a long dangling piece of beef...yeah, that didn't sound too appetizing, huh?

The bibibab was HUUUGE.  It came in a really hot stone pot that stayed warm the entire hour.  The pot was the size of a large pho bowl!  The food was ok, but I didn't like the texture of the rice so I will pass on ordering this again.

However, I would definitely reorder the original tofu soup.  It came with plenty of meat (we got chicken), dried seaweed squares, and soft, soft tofu.  Mmmm, totally hit the spot and warmed me up!  Even though we ordered the "medium spiciness", it didn't even taste spicy at all to me.

Service was pretty decent, but it took a couple of tries to get the waiter to come and take our order.  We were one of the last people to be seated for the evening and while we were eating, I noticed that the workers were all really diligent about tidying up the restaurant.  Very awesome, but it made it kind of hard to make requests.  At least they came by randomly to add more hot tea to my cup.  Thanks!  :)

Overall, I'd want to visit MTH again.  I just wish SF area had a better parking situation.  Also, I noticed that MTH has mostly booths instead of regular tables.  If a few large groups showed up at the same time, they'd all have to wait or agree to be separated.  I did notice a tiny room in the back of the restaurant that had 3 tables meant for 4 people (total of 12 people in that room) and if you rearrange the tables, I guess it can fit a really large group.  Bla bla bla, details...details...
author: May W.

description: Decent tofu soup. Not the best I've had. I think they've increased the prices so that the soup isn't really worth the price IMO. The banchan made me feel better than the actual soup, that's how I feel about it. BTW, the soups I'm talking about are the combination and the kimchi.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
My friend has been pestering me to pay a visit to My Tofu House for a loooong time.  Finally, on a night out with another friend, I remembered this place.

It was about 9:15 and there was a party of 4 and two parties of 2 ahead of us.  There was a table of two who were done with their food for the LONGEST time but sat there chatting, delaying the people in line from getting a table and prolonging their wait by the door where a cold draft was coming in.  When you see a line and you're finished eating, PLEASE be considerate and LEAVE!

I had the tofu soup with seafood.  I love spicy, I love tofu, and I love seafood.  However, I do not like oysters and I didn't notice on the menu that there were going to be oysters.  Yuck.  Along with the soup you are given a pot of rice to share.  The soup itself was already very filling because of the tofu, but along with the rice you get reallly full.  It's probably not enough for a guy, but it's good enough for me.

Since my dinner here, I've been craving for the ramen tofu soup for the longest time..
author: Vivian H.

description:
"So Alex convinced Malissa to take the lunch budget and spend it on Taco Bell instead of the regular catering crew and there ended up being this ridiculously huge pile of food on the table which everyone passed by to go get lunch somewhere else."

Our little table at My Tofu House didn't really sit 7 that comfortably once the appetizer, banchan, and entrees all showed up. I was at the end in what I call "the King's Chair" at the end of the table while everybody else was sat in the booth seating. Luckily, the restaurant wasn't super crowded like it was when the same group of us ate here at the beginning of the year, so there was room for me to stretch and breathe while eating.

The banchan showed up first and these were probably my least favorite things. It all looked good, but the taste wasn't there on the kimchee, so I just gave up after one bite. I'm pretty sure the rest of the table felt the same way since the other little pickled dishes kind of sat there through the rest of the meal. This is too bad since banchan can be the best part of the meal at other Korean restaurants (especially Mom's where they serve those tiny little anchovies!). 

We split a vegetable pancake as an appetizer. This was good. Kind of like a Chinese green onion pancake if you've had one, but a little more egg-y and onion-y with a more runny center. I wouldn't advise biting into it right away when it shows up or else you'll get the equivalent of molten lava in your mouth! Once it cooled down, it was pretty damn delicious.

For my entree I got the beef and vegetable bibimbap. It came in that awesome little superheated stone bowl so that the rice on the sides gets crispy and crunchy. There was a small amount of beef (fine with me since I'm not a huge carnivore), a lot of diced up veggies, and an egg. I mixed the whole thing up and added a ton of hot sauce and dug in. To be honest, I probably didn't need the hot sauce since it was already spicy enough and soon I was mopping my brow to remove a bit of sweat. I almost finished the entire bowl which is a testament to how good it was since I'm not a huge fan of too much rice!

My Tofu House is clean and tidy and not too congested like Mom's Tofu. I've been there on two occasions now and I've seen the place crowded with a line out the door and then like this where there isn't much of a crowd. The service was friendly, but a little slow.
author: Jason W.

description:
The kalbi was good but the tofu soup was just ok.

They have about 10 different tofu soups on the menu. But it's essentially the same base, except with different ingredients. My friend and i got the tofu soup with ramen noodles, the kimchi tofu soup and the dumpling tofu soup...and they all tasted the same.
author: Terry C.

description:
My Tofu House was my first sundubu experience several years ago and I was amazed at how delicious it was! Since then, I've tried several other places for sundubu around in bay area and even in LA and this place still ranks #1 for me.

I always get #8 - the sundubu with dumplings...so delicious!  Always add the raw egg in when it's still sizzling!

My boyfriends favorite food is sundubu so we go here often.  It's solid comfort food :)  

I've been here at all hours and the line can range from nonexistent to 45 min long.  You can always do take out if the line is crazy.  One thing I'd recommend to the restaurant is for them to get more staff.  This place gets a lot of business, so 1 server  and 1 busser isn't going to cut it - you'd get more people in and out if you hire another server imo.  See you soon My Tofu House!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I visited My Tofu House on a Friday night at about 7:30 p.m. in a group of seven.  The restaurant was completely full; we put our name down on the clipboard/list and took a seat.  It took about 20 minutes and we were then seated and given menus.  The waiter quickly brought us hot tea and also water, after we asked.    

We then ordered and were brought out a variety of side dishes: kimchi, bean sprouts, cucumbers, potato, and some small fish dish.  They were all pretty tasty.  Next, the waiter brought each of us a fried fish, extra plates, our bowls of rice, and a raw egg for our tofu soup.

Each of us ordered a tofu soup and one person also ordered a seafood pancake for us to share.  
I ordered #1 ($10.28): the original tofu soup, medium spice, with beef.  The soup came out bubbling, it was really hot and quickly cooked the raw egg I cracked into it. The medium spice was just the right amount of kick for me. Another person thought the spice was a bit strong. There is an abundance of soft tofu in the soup and a few pieces of beef scattered throughout.  The overall taste of the soup is really good and it goes great with the rice.  

The seafood pancake, at about $17.50 is a bit pricey for an appetizer/side dish. But it is rather large and it's really tasty. The pancake had very large chunks of calamari dispersed throughout and the dish came with a dipping sauce as well. 

Overall, I was impressed by My Tofu House. Although it was really busy, and we had a semi-large group, our waiter was very attentive and the food came out quickly. Everything was hot and very tasty.   I think the prices are very fair and the quality of the food is high. I would recommend it!

Notes:
-Metered parking is free after 6 p.m.
-Tofu soup and kimchi is on the 2010 7x7 Big Eat.
author: Samantha L.

description:
it was okay.
banchan is not alot.they forgot to give the fish & serve it to us when we were almost done.ohwells we'll take it..its free anyways.& it was tasty.
the guy was a liitle rude cos he just doesnt seem to be friendly and he looks like hes just there..just coz.
& we asked for a refill for a fish cake & he looks so annoyed that the last 2 refills we asked..it was the other girl server who gave it to us.whatevs
about thefood...well i was suprised about the mild seafood soft tofu soup...i wans't expecting that the mild will be that mild..but it tastes so good.
i love the free gum that came with the bill..
gum sa ham nida
;)
author: Enah N.

description:
Warmth in a cold windy sf night!
Was there earlier than a friend but the guy just told me to take a seat..next thing you know, groups of people started marching in...luckily I got my seat.
Got soon do bu w chicken..chunks of chicken thigh w tofu and my cracked egg. Egg didnt completely cook leaving me a runny yolk w my rice. Love that rice comes in a stone pot..gives it a nice chewy texture. 
Love the fried mackerel and kimchi!!! 
I was so full and warm, I didn't need my snowman jacket anymore.
I'll pass on the melon gum with the pay check..runs out of flavor in 15 secs.
author: Linda T.

description:
I've been dying to try this place ever since I looked it up on Yelp! And true to the Yelpers, My Tofu House was just what I expected: yummy Korean food! Came here the first week of June.

We ordered beef & vegetable bibimbab, seafood pancake and I think bulgogi. We all split the food and ate the cute pickled side dishes. Since we were somewhat a big group, we got two of the same side dishes. I have no idea what the technical names for side dishes are called; all I remember are pickled daikon, cucumbers, kimchi, and fish. The daikon was my favorite because it was spicy and crunchy when I chewed it. It was hard to eat the fish so I stayed away from that. All I remember is that every dish we got to eat was oh so yummy. I especially loved the seafood pancake. The pancake was crispy on the outside and very chewy on the inside. The waiters/waitresses were pretty nice about letting us stay after to share a birthday cake with our friend to celebrate her (belated) birthday! They even allowed us to hide the cake. 

I will most definitely come back to try other dishes!
author: Vicky P.

description:
Best Korean tofu soup place in the city.

I have been to many Korean restaurants, and this one is my favorite. It's my favorite for two reasons. First, the tofu soup is very good. Not the best I have had, but probably the best in the Bay Area. Second, the restaurant is very homey. It's not extremely fancy -- or fancy at all for that matter. But that's what adds to its charm. The wooden booths, modest dishware, and plain decor makes the meal comfortable throughout. Not to mention if you park far enough away, the freezing walk over makes the hot soup taste even better.

There is usually a wait, but have never waited over 30 minutes with a party of two. The place is clean, and the service is bearable. Must try the combination tofu soup (seafood + beef) with medium spicy. Make sure the break the egg in as soon as the soup arrives, so it cooks!
author: Catherine C.

description:
I love their lunch specials !!
Good price and delicious food !!
The seafood tofu is the best with medium spicy !!!
author: Ashley G.

description:
My Tofu House has been around for I don't know how long and yet I always seem to drive right pass it and go straight to Brothers or some other Korean restaurant.  But if luck would have it, I was in a very ambitious mood for something new and different.  Why not give this place a try.

Went with a few friends here on a Thursday nite and low and behold the wait wasn't bad at all.  Actually no reservation, no line, no problem.  Now lets eat......

We were seated in a wooden booth comfortably.  We can chose to have it cook and serve to us rather than doing it ourselves.  We ordered the BBQ chicken, pork and of course the beef spareribs.  Absolutely very tasty and good.  Given that we are in a tofu house we gotta order the spicy tofu soup with mixed seafood.   This soup goes very well with their rice.  Love their sticky rice. That was very yummy.  And of course with any Korean dinner, we had a whole spread of condiments.  

One in particular that caught my attention is the fried fish.  Never seen that as one of their many condiments but nonetheless, a good one.  Given that this place does lack customer service, I still enjoyed the meal that night.  No ambience just plain good Korean bbq and tofu.

Prices here are very reasonable so I would definitely come back for more.
author: Angela L.

description:
This is my third consecutive Asian food review. Recently, the bff & I let someone into our very exclusive, very elite (suck on that, yelp) secret society of sorts;  she is a lovely filipina & when we go out for din, she picks Asian. I'm down for whatever, especially to my eyes being opened to something new & potentially delicious. 

I've had Korean food before. My family makes crazy-good KBBQ. I've eaten *IN* Korea. Compared to my previous experiences with this cuisine, My Tofu House wasn't *MY* favorite tofu house. 

We ordered:
-- dumplings soup tofu ($10.28): medium spice. You crack an egg into the boiling soup to cook it. Too many mushy things in one pot. I'm a texture whore. I needed something crispy or crunchy. 
-- baked tofu & veggie bibimbap ($14.62): I only tried the tofu, which was covered in a tangy BBQ sauce. 
-- kalbi/short ribs ($21.69): really great flavor & marinade, but really fatty (sorry, I'm a recovering semi-vegetarian... I will always complain about too much animal fat.)
-- bulgoki/ sliced rib eye ($19.87): salty marinade. I liked the short ribs better. 

Pricey, fairly long wait (20 min on a weeknight), so-so service. The bottom line is-- none of the four items we tried were all that appetizing to me, so 2 stars because I most likely will not return.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Another Inner Richmond favorite. Hits the points for the perfect last minute spot:
-Affordable
-Relatively quick
-Different 
-Seats you until 9:30p (open and accepts take out until 10p)

The side dishes were great. They also give you a larger plate of kimchi and lets be real, that's all we all really want.

Check this spot out!
author: Genevieve L.

description:
Super excited that we finally found a solid korean tofu house. Based on flavor alone, it is a solid 4-star!

However, the reason why I am only giving them a 3-star is as follow:
1. Overpriced, overpriced, overpriced!
2. Seafood pancake for $18 dollars, WTF? Yes seriously, $18 muther-freaking dollars. Why?! I have no idea. And it wouldn't so bad if it actually tasted OKAY. NO, sadly it tasted bad. Borderline terrible. The bottom came out burnt. Not good eats. 

So yes 3stars...
author: Cheung L.

description:
Thanks fellow Yelpers for the high ratings and reviews. 

This place hits the right spot for a late lunch. I had the beef tofu and mushroom bibimbap. Overall good flavor for both dishes. I only wish I ordered the tofu soup spicy instead of medium which was more like mild.
author: Hummus P.

description: I love Korean food and the  here did not disappoint. I had the kimchi tofu soup and I would highly recommend it. I ordered it with a medium spiciness level and it really wasn't too spicy. The banchan is also really good. My only complaint was that our there was some fish on the seat left over from the previous group and I got a fish spine sticking into my leg. But other than that it was great and I'll definitely be back.
author: Ashley K.

description: Regular here. Very good tofu house. Traditional Korean taste. Zhuoping doesn't like it.
author: Xx Z.

description:
This place has some mighty good soup.  I ordered the Original Soft Tofu Soup and added ramen.  It was really good.  We also ordered the broiled, sizzling pork.  It was an alright dish.  I do not like the little side dishes that many Korean restaurants usually give, and this place is not an exception.

The service is terrible.  They have one person doing pretty much everything.  I asked for water and the guy gave it to the table in front of us instead.  I asked again, and he comes back a while later.  If they do not want to be bothered, I would suggest not using tiny cups -_-.     Anyways, the tofu soup is the only thing that keeps this place afloat.
author: Victor L.

description:
The tofu soup here is amazing. I always get the dumpling soup with ramen.

3 stars is because their pancake is horrible. It's way too thick, tasteless, and when we told the waiter and she brought a new one, it was not the pancake we ordered.

I love this place, but they really got to step up their service.
author: Nina T.

description:
This used to be my favorite Korean spot, but this past year I've been on a Korean food hunt and got to try a lot of new places.  So this place isn't shining so bright anymore.

I usually only order the soft tofu soup when I come, but I came here with a group last time and finally got to try their seafood pancake, spicy pork, and kalbi short ribs.  They're short ribs were good, but their seafood pancake was mediocre, and spicy pork were more like spicy pork bits.  They defiantly over chopped the meat.  All the pieces were the size of a dime or smaller and the flavor was too heavy.

Their service isn't so great here either.  It took awhile to order, and they never checked up on us throughout our dinner.  We always had to wave them down and it always took awhile.

The soup and ribs in itself deserves a 5, but everything else was a 3.  I think this place really only deserves a 3... but their soup is too good to be rated that low.
author: Lynn L.

description: What is more perfect for the coldest week in SF.  Their tofu soup is really flavorful, I just want to keep on eating it.  The seafood pancake is always my favorite.  Theirs is really crispy and loaded with ingredients.  Be prepared to wait if it's a cold night, but at least you'll be warmed up quickly.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
You let the rice get crunchy in the clay pot before you stir. This is what my friend told me when she brought me here, as she munched away on little dried fish bits and pieces, and I nibbled on the kimchi. As she is much more of an expert, I agreed to do things her way. And she was right. It was yum. 

She didn't like spicy, so they gave me a side of chili sauce on the side, so I could have personalized spicy. We got bibimbop and tofu soup, and both were amazing after a day outside in lovely San Francisco weather (meaning...we were freezing!).

The food was more than enough for the two of us, along with the small plates they gave as part of the order, we had enough for leftovers. It was a great place for a cold day, and I would definitely go again.
author: Danielle L.

description: A whole fried individual fish for ban chan? Say what?! Yasss!! Upon arrival my party of three was seated immediately and the waiter was quick to assist us with our order. Our seafood tofu soups and ramen was brought to us promptly and was the perfect remedy to a freezing Wednesday night!! The soup was filled with tofu and I almost think that there was too much of it in there. You might ask, is that even possible?? YES it is because by the time I reached halfway, there was barely any soup left to accompany the huge portion of tofu still left! Overall very satisfying meal and unlimited Banchan refills!! Def. a winner!
author: Celina C.

description: Thanks for the great food. Had to wait in line a bit but tried seafood pancakes for the first time! Also got to try bibimbab with seafood and beef tofu soup. Takes really good, no onder there was a line. Thanks again!
author: Ameera D.

description: The reason I give this place only 3 stars is because of the service. The spicy tofu soup is very flavorful and delicious. If you can handle spicy, I would recommend getting extra spicy. The mild tofu soup was alittle bland the last time I got it. Very good side dishes and BBQ beef. But, the service was not that great. Whenever I tried asking for anything, such as more water, the people seemed annoyed or just ignored me. I've been here several times on weekends and weekdays and saw this pattern with the service regardless of how busy the restaurant seemed.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Just good Korean tofu soups
I like the side dishes that come with your order.


Service is okay.
author: Erica L.

description:
Quick and attentive service. Cup was never empty, and when I needed something it was easy to get their attention.
 
Comfortable environment. Despite the numerous ban chan on a table for 2, the table didn't feel overcrowded. Interior was neat and very clean.

Great value. A lot of mushrooms in my mushroom chigae. I ordered super spicy and it had a good kick to it.
Ban chan was generous. 6-7 cheops if I remember correctly. Plus fried croaker!! 

Delicious. Absolutely hits the spot, especially on a cold day.

10/10 would recommend and revisit.
author: Ashley A.

description:
whoa. this made the 7x7 Big Eats List for 2010 and I've been coming here since forever.. weird.

The only thing I really even order here is the Soft Tofu so that's the only thing I can really attest for. It comes really bubbly and hot, just how it should be. I usually get medium or hot for spiciness and its never too strong. 

Overall just a good place to drop by if soft tofu is what you're craving. This place is really really clean too if the thought of grimy oily vents makes you uneasy.

- Jenn
author: Jenn Y.

description:
CUTE WAITERS. OMG one is like model worthy and the other is more like a cute flower boy. Also there's the short one with spiky hair, who has a nice smile. :)

Food was good.
author: Sophia W.

description: I really wanted to like this place more than I did.  After reading all the reviews I was excited about getting their tofu soup!  Unfortunately I found it sooo bland!  We got the Original Tofu spicy and it was neither spicy or flavorful.  I was really disappointed.  And the seafood pancake?  So much starch and so little seafood.  I found it hard to eat!  I know this is a small restaurant, but we had to ask a couple of times for more side dishes and water.  One plus was that we didn't have to wait since we came right after work on a weekday.  Maybe I came on an off day, but I don't think I'll be coming here again.
author: Elena N.

description:
This place is awesome!! 
The soup is so good. I think the other dishes are also great, but the tofu soups are really what make this place really worth the trip. The service was great, but just a little slow. Still totally worth the wait.
author: Ana M.

description:
The food here was decent, I have had better soondubu with bigger portions for 3/4 of the price. But I have not found a decent place to soondubu since I moved back from Chicago aside from this one (so far).
My main complaint here is the service. I actually think the waiters here are students, but that is no excuse for having me wait 10 minutes just to get my check, one of the waiters looked right at me with my arm raised and ignored me.
Food is definitely above average but when it is packed, don't expect fast service
Also they are lacking some gochujang for the Bibambaps, I asked for it; never received it.
Come here if you want decent Korean food and don't care much about waiting.
author: Brian L.

description: This place make so much better Korean Tofu Soup than those in LA. Great experience! If you love enjoying Korean tofu soup. This is the place to be
author: James L.

description:
Lately Ive noticed that I am craving Korean food a lot more often than usual! I have to have it at least once a wk now at the very least. Tonite was one of those days that is perfect for a nice hot and spicy soon dubu. After hrs of studying with the gf it was time for dinner and Korean food was the first and only thing on my mind. Upon entering My Tofu house, I noticed that it was very busy and probably one of the cleanest Korean restros i have ever seen. I really liked the fact that they had many booth seats, always nice to be closed to love ones or friends while you are eating a family style meal!

First came the ban chan, which i thought was lacking. The usual suspects where there: Kimchi, cucumbers, bean sprouts and dried sardines. Compared to many other places it was sparse and non existent. They did however have the deep fried fish. yummy http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WhbaoCmPOBMTkQ9TV_SUVw/l

Next came the Kimchi Soon Dubu, we ordered it medium spicy with beef. It had very good flavor and warmed us from the inside out. soft tofu, beef, mushrooms in spicy soup. mmmmmhmmm marvelous! http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oLCn4I8P2gWaKa0E5GexOQ/l

Then came the BBQ Pork & Veggie Bibimbap. Bibimbap is one of the gf's favs, she loves when the rice gets stuck to the bottom of the dolsot. its becomes hard and crunchy. The Bibimbap had amazing flavor http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SyZDMjCa0sFXWzlnqYAfRg/l

And Then Dak Bulgogi- A very generous portion of Dak Bulgogi came out  sizzling. The flavor packed quite the punch to your tongue and mouth. Simply irresistible!!! http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/LrEY5r4P9WNLP4YoVCivgQ/l

Last but not least Seafood Pancake. My Tofu House's pancake is a tiny bit thicker than what i was used to it but it still had a crisp exterior and soft and delicious inside. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/KD7GCjBskgh_PiSOb_IDAg/l

When the check came, There was Korean Melon Gum! ^_^ http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Wl_8UObTSSro1pzOxa9zEg/l

My tofu house a very good soon dubu place! I will be back to try the others!!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
After living near K town in LA for a few years and growing up in an area full of good Korean food, my taste buds found My Tofu House to be just OK.

Six other friends and I shared a very pleasant meal here last night. Great conversations, laughter... happy times! After we were done, I knew that my tummy was full but honestly couldn't really remember anything about the kimchi tofu soup. 

Only thing I do remember is that it had mushrooms in it which I usually do not notice in kimchi tofu soup. Also, the small plates were minimal, we only got like 4 or 5 different things. It was pretty tasty but nothing that would leave an impression.  Service was great though!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Food - Tried the Combination Soft Tofu and Bulgoki which were both delicious.  Out of the side dishes, the fried whole fish and fish cakes were my favorites.  Slightly pricey for Korean food, but not unreasonable for SF.   

Service - They were surprisingly busy for a Tuesday night and there was a huge crowd at the door when we arrived.  We waited 25 minutes for a 4-person booth and got seated around 7:30pm.  Given how busy the restaurant was, they were generally prompt and good about giving us seconds for sides.

Ambiance - Decently spacious and somewhat upscale for a Korean tofu house.  

Overall - I would definitely come here again for the food.  However, due to their popularity and lack of reservations, it can mean a somewhat unpredictable wait time, even during non-peak hours.
author: Yun W.

description: Korean barbecue with soup! I got the hint from a friend. This location is totally worth five stars! Love it
author: Mark T.

description:
Assorted mushrooms soft tofu soup. I can't help but order the same thing over and over again because it is just SO good. The soup is served boiling with hearty chunks of tofu. I order it hot, but you can get whatever level of spiciness you prefer.

The assorted side dishes are very tasty too: standard kimchi, plus fish, bean sprouts and cucumber. 

In the end, it is all very filling. I recommend going with a big appetite. 

The restaurant is very simple, clean, and on the smaller side. There's usually a line. Service is pretty fast considering that there's rarely more than 2 people at a time working all the tables. Tip well! It's rare these days to see servers not only take orders, but also host, refill drinks, bus all the tables, and take to-go orders.
author: Gloria B.

description:
Tofu House you saved my RAINY morning with your delicious combination soon-dubu and bbq spicy pork.. The perfect combination after a long night of intoxication for a friend's birthday.  We came in around 12pm and beat the crowd from what it seems like.  The place is clean and simple with booths available for all parties.  Those 2 korean guys working the restaurant were typical kdrama look alikes... The scruffy tall types!  This place was delicious and decently priced.  

I must say.. Their claypots are like special or something because all of our dishes were still boiling and firing HOT all the way until we ate our last spoonful of food.. Crazy!!!

My favorite side dish of all time that alot of korean restaurants don't pass out was the MACKEREL :D

PS: Parking in the Richmond Area is a PAIN in the ass
author: Kathy D.

description: yummm thinking about Kimchi Tofu Soup already makes my mouth water!  Great service- a bit slow sometimes when theyre busy tho.  This place fills up quick!  Very reasonably priced.  The tofu soup can easily feed two but so can the bimbimbap(?) sorry if I'm spelling it wrong.  Anyways, very clean and inexpensive.  I'm a fan!
author: Gabbi d.

description: Food was good, I always come here for Korean food, but the reason why I'm writing his review was not because I don't like their food. I really like the food, I gave it a one star because the waiter lie!!! I asked to get seconds on the small appetizers , as I was waiting patiently for them to bring out the appetizers, they only brought back 3 dishes, the cucumbers, pickled radish, and bean sprouts. When I asked them where's the slicked fish cake, they told me it was out, I couldn't believe it. And minutes later, they served my neighbors fish cakes!!!!! I felt mistreated and I will never step in here again . It's only fish cake, really? You gotta lie , come on man!
author: Tyrone P.

description:
I used to come here all the time with the family and from what I remembered we all loved it. My parents used to get the seafood tofu soup and I'd get the bulgogi. We decided to come back for an early mother's day dinner last weekend since my mom was craving tofu soup. Got there on a Sunday night around 7pm and got seated right away. Surprisingly no wait! 

We each got our own tofu soup. I got the mushroom tofu soup, and they got the usual seafood tofu soup. I usually can't take spicy foods, so I got mild... But it wasn't spicy at all. My parents got medium but also said it wasn't spicy at all. All the tofu soups are the same price, so if I expected a whole lotta mushrooms but there wasn't very much. I don't know what changed, but everyone was very disappointed by their meal. My dad said there wasn't as much seafood in there as there used to be, and my sister said there wasn't very much soup in her tofu soup, just a lot of tofu. I glanced at what I used to order (bulgolgi) and saw that it was over $20! The portions aren't even that big, and it's good but it's not THAT good! We were also going to order the seafood pancake but that was about $18-19!! WHY IS IT SO EXPENSIVE?!

Sad to say, we will not be coming back. You can definitely find better korean food elsewhere, AND for cheaper. O V E R P R I C E D.
author: Jaime H.

description:
Ah, man!!
The tofu soup really hits the spot!!! I came here with friends after running a half marathon in the pouring rain... and no words can describe how perfect it was to eat piping hot tofu soup. Ahhh...

The soup was so flavorful.... love it. This place seems to be one of the few places near Sunset opened in the afternoon. When we arrived, the line was pretty long, but it was pretty quick... the food took awhile to come out, though. But I'm not complaining because the soup was so satisfying. Service could be better, as we were pretty much left alone the whole time. And try to come for lunch, because pretty much all their non-soup dishes' prices double at night. Eek.
author: Janet H.

description: Been here a handful of times. Kimchi tofu soup w/ beef and mushrooms. That's all you need on an overcast day in the Richmond to warm you up. It can get busy on weekends after 6, so be ready to wait. They don't serve alcohol. People complain that it's bland, but honestly, it's tofu soup, not bulgogi. It's not supposed to be packed with loads of complex and intense flavor. There's more than enough flavor. The rest of the menu is conventional Korean fare. For two people I always get a tofu soup with seafood bibimbap. Ends up about $35-$40. Which is also very standard for Korean food for those complaining about price. people need to accept that Korean food isn't Chinese food, and there aren't gonna be $5.95 lunch specials.
author: Elton F.

description:
I love this place! The wait is very much worth it. The food is delicious, sorry to to say but thee cutest waiters, on the house fried mackerel, and great tofu soup for cold days. 

Def a regular here
author: Christina L.

description:
The Kimchee Tofu Soup is pretty good, but what it's lacking is the Kimchee.  Whenever I make this dish at home, I always add lots of Kimchee, so I asked them for an extra side of Kimchee.  The problem is that the Kimchee looked and smelled like it was more store bought than homemade.  Pretty disappointing if you ask me.
