I know that when I make Kimchee it has more spices and is a little hotter.  

My friends ordered the Bulgoki, which was flavorful, but was a little overcooked and dried out.  The Pork Stoneware Bibimbab was the best dish by far and was perfect.

The service was prompt and polite, but they were so busy that there wasn't a lot of attention to the customers in my opinion.

I will say that the prices were reasonable for the area and not inflated as a lot of the restaurants in the Bay Area.

Overall Rating: 3/5
Service: 3/5
Food: 3/5
Price: 3/5
author: Matt L.

description: Still one of the best places for  (sundubu jjigae). Packed on a Saturday night. Ordered the bulgogi, the sundubu, the haemul pajan and the bibimpap. Hits the spot. Would definitely come back again
author: Allen W.

description:
This is the place where I first tried Korean Tofu soup, and man let me tell you it was the bomb! No other place compared to My Tofu House.

Lately though, they've been slacking. The taste of their tofu soup isn't as savory as it used to and their waiters are somewhat attentive but not caring. They also seemed to have decreased the portions for their short rib and rib eye.

All in all, their food is good not as great as it used to, but still good.
author: Oriel F.

description:
I will caveat this by saying ... I love love love Soft Tofu Korean Soup. So it's actually really hard to get it wrong for me. But I am super excited to finally find a place that actually specializes in it in the city. Woohoo!

My only complaint about this place is why it's so far away from where I live. It's so hard to get to Richmond by transit or find parking. 

I had the seafood soft tofu soup (medium). The tofu was very very good. The seafood could be more generous, considering they are charging 11.50 a bowl. The appetizers, as expected are very good. 

My husband wasn't crazy about the Bi Bam Bap. He prefers adding his own spices, since he prefers no spice at all. 

I love the layout of the place. Lots of seating; there is a wait, but it goes by quickly, as you read their wall posters about other delicious food in the city.
author: Winny F.

description:
In an attempt to get my entire family out of the house on July 4, I took them all out to Sutro Baths and then ended up wandering around Irving and Geary for a good eat. A friend recommended My Tofu house and we happened to pass by.

We went around 3pm (yes, we were hungry for lunch/dinner). The restaurant is a semi hole in wall (but that's just how I like it!). It interior is very clean and I enjoyed the booth style seating. However, I do wonder what they wold do if large parties came in. 

Their menu selection is a tad small in my opinion but I do enjoy the tofu and meat options. With 4 people, we only ordered 2 dishes, the Seafood bibimbap and the kalbi. This definitely filled us up since it came with lots of rice and the side dishes were my mom's favorite. 

The only thing I am a tad thrown off by is the lunch, dinner, and holiday pricing. Something about coming here for dinner and holidays seems not worth it if I can get it for about half off during lunch. 

Other than that, a pretty good eat for once in a while.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Server with the huge glasses and extremely rude attitude ruined our meal. I even heard him cursing at us in Korean behind our backs. Also, in Korean, all the servers were constantly complaining about customers and were speaking in a very condescending manner about all the customers. I made eye contact with him the man with the glasses and he even yelled at me "do you have a problem?"

Funny how people like this even manage to grab a job in an industry where being courteous and polite is crucial. 

The owner and food were okay, but the terrible rude servers ruined it.
author: David K.

description:
The place looked a little ghetto from the outside, but once we walked in it was a total 180.  The place actually looks very nice and clean inside.  It can get confusing from there since there isn't really a stand or a person there waiting to take your name.  Usually there are a bunch of people up against the walls of the entrance waiting to be seated, as you walk further in towards the dining area you'll see a clipboard hung on your right on the wall.  That's the waiting list for a table.

The tables are very spacious, even the two top booths.  They give a wide variety of side dishes, more then enough to almost make a meal out of.  We've tried a couple of dishes here and have never been disappointed.  We love the bibimbap and spicy pork, but on top of it all we loved their tofu soups.  Let me tell you first off that I really REALLY don't like tofu, like at all.  I hate the texture, the taste, and everything else about it.  I've tried it cooked so many ways and in so many dishes and NOTHING tastes good to me.  So with that being said, this is the ONLY place that I will eat tofu.  Weird, I know ... I thought so to.  It's different here, and I don't know why or what they do, but it is different -- otherwise I would've spit it out like I did all the other dishes I've had elsewhere.

The service is great and though the price is a little high I feel like the food fits the price.  I'm just glad I finally found a place with a tofu soup that I LOVE.
author: Pia V.

description:
We came around 6 on a Sunday night and were seated without a wait, but by the time we left at 7:30 there was a line. The banchan was good but I also would have preferred a few more options. The specialty seemed to be soondubu but it was just too warm out, so instead we had: tofu bibimbap, vegetable pancake, spicy pork, and bulgolgi. 

The vegetable pancake tasted great but was on the bland side, so the accompanying sauce was definitely appreciated (although it was mainly just salty). I like the big pieces of vegetables well-distributed through the pancake, and it was cooked well. I thought both the meat dishes were delicious, although other people found the pork to be just a tad too spicy. The onions and mushrooms in the dishes added a lot and were delicious in and of themselves. I was not as impressed with my tofu bibimbap. Maybe I was expecting more out of the tofu, but the whole thing didn't seem to come together, and I'm not sure why. 

The service was friendly but it sometimes took a fair number of attempts to get more water, etc. Like a moron I left my leftovers at the table, and they really nicely held on to them so when I went back five minutes later I could pick them up. I'd be fine to come back here but would probably try other places first.
author: Lisa K.

description:
(See pics)

Truly a tofu house. The piping hot and boiling bubbles tofu was very delicious. The pancake was also pretty good. Wish they served alcohol as the boiling hot bowl would go perfect with it.

This is more just an eatery with bright lights and simple practical decoration. Service was also pretty good and courteous.
author: T L.

description:
I've seen this place in my travels and finally due to the freezing cold weather, this seemed like the perfect choice.  I have had tofu soup at a couple of other places and I love it.  

There was a wait, we had 4 couples and 1 group of 4 in front of us.  There are big screen tv's and it appears the clientele is repeat so they stick around a bit to chat and such.  

We finally got seated and the waiters came over pretty quickly, with the menus and since there isn't a whole lot to select from, we had an easy time choosing.
I got the shrimp, clam and beef and my partner got the seafood ... soft tofu soup.  
There is no beer, wine or sake, so they kept pouring the barley water hot tea.  

The side dishes came out, then the rice then the sizzling hot soup.  Really as hot as you can ever dream and that is one of the things I love about this type of soup. 

I had ordered "spicy" but I found the soup rather tame.  

The check was around $25.00 and my partner said he would like to return, I think I will keep looking for another soup place.  

The service was pretty cut and dried, these guys are familiar with each other and they interacted with each other laughing and talking with each other.  They are all working hard but not really interacting with the patrons. 

So, it's worth a try, I'm sure you will like it.
author: BellaLissa B.

description:
Lunch is the best time to come here. The same BBQ Kalbi ribs is cheaper for lunch then dinner. My favorite dish here by the way. Side dishes are good, especially when the fried mackerel was just cooked and hot.

Tofu soup hits the spot on cold chilly days. And I love the option to go really spicy.

Side note, there are mostly male waiters here. Rarely do I see a waitress. If you speak Korean, you get special attention.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Yes, My Tofu House's Soon Dobu (Soft Tofu Soup) is the stuff of legends, but don't let that distract you from the rest of their impressive dishes. Not many Korean restaurants in the Bay Area offer yellow croaker as a banchan and this being my first time trying it, I found it to be a real treat.  Another of my favorites is their Kalbi Beef. The meat is thick-cut, tender, and comes out with a nice medium doneness.

Some may say the menu is more limited in comparison to other Korean restaurants in SF, but I prefer to think of it as being a menu of only their very best dishes. Usually, once I find good dishes, I prefer to stick to them in fear that a different dish might disappoint, but here, I've never had that feeling. I can be adventurous and always be rewarded for it.
author: Jenny C.

description:
This place is on the top 10 places to eat before you die in SF... there's always a huge line waiting to be seated. 

Honestly it's kinda overrated. There are lots of places in the south bay that are comparable like Tofu House. There are also lots of places in So. Cal Ktown that are much better. 

Not really worth the wait and it's kinda pricey for dinner. Oh.. it's also super hard to find parking.
author: Cynthia C.

description: THE BEST tofu soup in SF! Great selections and the guys working there are very friendly and helpful. I always get the seafood combo tofu soup. The bimbimbup is good too. Go there early or be prepare for a long wait!
author: William C.

description:
The kalbi here is no joke. It is delicious! My favorite side dish has to be the cucumbers. I always ask for about 3 extra plates... They bring it to me happily though :)

The service is super friendly. The lunch menu, however, doesn't apply to holidays... I came in on umm..Columbus day and found out. boo hoo. :(
author: Erica A.

description: We walked in @9:35pm...and assumed we seat ourselves with no hostess to greet us...young gentleman told us "sorry we are closed!" Yelp indicated open 'til 10pm... He kicked us out said "sorry..nothing I can do!" Restaurant was packed and was embarrassing to be kicked out!
author: MeeSun B.

description:
Went there on a recent Thursday night. We had to wait for a table as they don't take reservations and the line was relatively long. I would be a bit trepidatious about trying to go there on a weekend.

The dumpling soft tofu soup was amazing. I got it spicy which usually means not spicy enough, but they nailed it. The mushroom bibimbap was just ok. It lacked some seasoning. All in all, it was very good and I'll be back.
author: Brad C.

description:
My Tofu House, always a pleasure.  I LOVE Korean flavored meat!  I absolutely love the bugolgi and the chicken!  Mouth-watering delicious!!!

Of course as any other Korean restaurant, they come with a different variety of appetizers along with a fish per person.  

I love the simplistic decor of this restaurant.  It's nice.
author: Tina L.

description:
Sheesh. So many Asian spots in SF but so little time. What distinguishes My Tofu House from the rest? Well, it made its way on SF's 2010 Big Eat List. Congrats!

Try their Tofu soup with Kimchee, the list said. We obeyed. It came out sizzling and steamy. I asked for medium spice. It didn't taste spicy @all. It was good, but then again I'm not a Korean eater connosieur so maybe my word isn't golden. My gf Tammy N. did the honor and cracked that egg on top of the soup. I didn't know it was supposed to go w/ it. I just thought it was a random hard boiled egg included w/ all the other pickled and infused sides. Little did I know, right?

We also shared the braised Kalbi ribs. It was flavorful, tasty, & tender, but too fatty for my taste. It came out steamy, too, less the sizzle. Both the Kalbi ribs AND tofu soup went well on top of the white rice. I didn't realize soup complemented well w/ rice. Go figure. 

Overall: good Korean spot. List or no list, it didn't make my list of "favorites". I am still continuing my search for a "great" Korean joint. Any suggestions?
author: Joy A.

description:
So the whole rice in a stone bowl and then add water after? Not a My Tofu House thing. It's very common in Korean restaurants. Awesome, right?

Glad My Tofu House decided to bring that element. I had mixed feelings about their dumpling tofu soup. The soup was not bad, but the dumplings were not fresh. Their service... a typical Korean establishment with Korean boys who serve and think they're all that and a bag of chips. No. One word... no. Flip your hair elsewhere and be courteous. Kthanks!

Again with charging customers for extra banchan... are you kidding? No, no, no. You and To Hyang need to let loose. I want to end on a good note so I will say their kimchi was nomnomnommy.
author: Rosa L.

description:
Decided to venture away from the usual Korean BBQ places that we go to. I've always wanted to try a Tofu House, and this place seemed popular, so we strolled in.

The food is pretty good. I had the dumpling soft tofu soup. It came in a smallish bowl, but don't be fooled. I could barely finish it! There is a lot of ingredients in the soup, and not so much broth. Boyfriend got the chicken bibimbap, and said it was really good. Our plates came with the typical side dishes, although I've seen other places give you a lot more side dishes. However, the servers kept asking us if we wanted more, which is a first for me, so that was pretty cool.

On top of that, the service was prompt and friendly. So, if you don't feel like spending a lot for Korean BBQ, but have a craving for, I would say, pretty authentic Korean food, this place is worth checking out.
author: Sara K.

description:
I came here for dinner and the food is great! That explains the long line. 

This is a genuinely small place, ok service, they don't take reservations. The food comes in pretty big portions for an average teenage girl. The price is pretty cheap. I recommend the Tofu Soups! They come with some kind of Korean rice, and it's really good! Ahh, I'm definitely coming back again!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Mark Twain once said "The coldest winter I ever saw was the summer I spent in San Francisco." Oh Mr. Twain, if only you had some tofu soup from My Tofu House to warm you up!

Hmmmm, the tofu soup here is SOOooo good!! To be honest, I haven't tried anything else here hahh! On my last visit here, I got the Assorted Mushroom Soft Tofu and it was absolute perfection! :) Enoki mushrooms, how I love thee!
The side dishes are some of the best too because they include anchovies and an actual whole fish (mackerel?)!! Some other Korean restaurants I've been to don't have them :P Also, the server always pours tea into clay pot of leftover rice to make a nice rice "soup!"

If you're in the mood for something warm and reasonably priced, definitely think about stopping here! The servers are attentive and the decor is simple and comforting. I know I can always depend on My Tofu House to satisfy my belly! :) Maybe one day I'll branch out from their tofu soup and try something else...or not. It's just so good!
author: Kei H.

description:
WTF...walked in at 8:10pm. The rude waiter with a humongous glasses told me to write the name and wait. Waited for 20 minute. An old rude korean guy just walked in , passed me and sat down at the table infront of me. I checked in with that  waiter again when can I sit. He told me to wait for a few min. He then proceeded to bring that old guy tea infront of me. I just stood up and walked out
Soo craving for the tofu soup but NEVER EVER come here again as long as they have that stupid waiter with his glasses. 
PS to the owner. Need to check your server staff and their service. Hire someone with customer service and courtesy.
author: Nicole T.

description:
I have my first tofu food baby thanks to this restaurant. I usually pride myself on having some restraint when it comes to good food but I just couldn't put down my spoon this time. My Tofu House is normally packed at all hours of the night so I try not to waste my time trekking it from the suburbs. I haven't been here one time when the line wasn't at least 30 minutes long. One time I remember getting an order of fries from the Jack in the Box next door just to hold me over till we were sat.  

Tonight however, we were sat right away because we arrived at 8:30 and just missed the dinner rush. It wasn't one of the cozy booths flanked by the walls but a seat is a seat and I kind of enjoyed hearing the gossip and chatting flying above our heads so it all evened out. I never noticed till tonight how the menu was only two pages. Open the book and BAM, there it is-the left and right side of the menu and no other options. Not even pot stickers. Hmmm...

We ordered the combination and dumpling soondubu and anxiously awaited our banchan which consisted of dried yellow croaker and various little plates of cucumbers and kimchi. This is the only tofu house that incorporates fish with banchan so when you say, "that tofu house with the fish," people know what you're talking about. While we were waiting for soup, a server brought the rice over and served the standard 3 bowls out of the stone bowl they serve rice in. How is that not awesome? They cook rice in a stone dish that they normally serve dolsot bibimbop in and they put garbanzo beans and green peas on top. I love the little touches they add to their dishes.

So the soups arrive sizzling hot in their bowls and yes, the banchan is not the greatest but the spiciest of the stew is what sets it apart. If you've read my reviews, you know I like me some spicy soup and the capsaicin meter in my mouth is actually used when I'm here. The dumplings are delightfully plentiful and a hearty contrast to the mushy tofu. The spiciness of the dish is only accentuated by the temperature kept at a constant because of the stone dish. I hate eating cold stew and maybe it was because I was hungry or maybe it was because it was just that good, but soon I was staring down at the black bottom of the bowl. Always a good sign. 

I don't know about you guys but I also miss the days when restaurants gave you Korean gum with the check. It might be a Korean thing but again, I certainly appreciate those subtle details.
author: Jessica K.

description:
After reading about how great this restaurant I had to try it for myself. Even though the wait may be a little longer than you expect. I believe that it's worth it in the end.

Their prices are noticeably higher than most restaurants, yet the quality of the food is spectacular. I ordered the chicken and seafood tofu soup. The chicken had such flavor inside its delicious meat and the soup was very satisfying. The waiter's here are also polite and are patient when you order. This restaurant has a relaxing mood to it and it looked pretty clean. All of these qualities are sort of the reason why this place isn't that cheap. I thought that it was well worth coming here to experience this fine dining.
author: Ethan W.

description:
"It's not your turn."  WTF?  

I'm a little conflicted with this place.  I like the food - pretty good for Korean, particularly in SF - but the service leaves much to be desired.  I've come here many times and have always had to wait forever for the panchan, the bill, you name it.  It's always those two guys up front so they're probably understaffed but not really my problem except that service can be slow.

Tofu soup is good though pricey for what it is as well as the others but whatever.  I think their seafood pancake is one of the better.

What really got to me was the last time my wife and I went there.  As usual, we're seated and god knows how long went by before I asked about the panchan and he quickly replied  "It's not your turn" as he walked by.  I've been to a lot of Korean restaurants and this is the first time I've heard that. 

I shared this experience with my Korean bro-in-law and he was a little pissed hearing this.  I think they serve the panchan timed before our food was ready so we only have enough time to eat one serving of the panchan - an economic driven reason.  He thinks it's because they're lazy - that they don't want to keep bringing more dishes while you wait.

Anyway, it's a little off-putting and I'm not sure if it'll ever be there turn for us to visit them again as I'm used to the Korean restaurants that are a little more polite and deluge you with tons of panchan.
author: Keaton N.

description:
Good soup for a rainy night. The sides were decent and the service wasn't half bad. I guess the downfall was the waiting since it was full house.

Overall, food was good and I wouldn't mind coming back here again.
author: Richard C.
Steffie H.

description:
I try all the Korean tofu places every chance I get hoping to find better. There are few, one of which is the Tofu House in Los Angeles. As far as SF goes, this has the best flavor. I've been coming here for years and the price has been creeping up, but I still go. If they raise it a dollar more, I'm probably going to go elsewhere. 

Service is nothing to get excited about, but that's not unusual for places like this.
author: Brian Q.

description:
This place is overrated and overpriced. It wasn't a horrible dining experience. The food was okay. The kalbi was way too fatty. The side dishes were okay but nothing that wowed me. Stay away from the Seafood Pancake. $17 worth of dry, overcooked, and not very tasty pancake. 
The service wasn't the best but they attempted to stay on top of it despite being busy. The only thing worth recommending is the Seafood Tofu Soup. But other than that this resto is a definite pass.
author: Anna R.

description:
My tofu house is the only Korean restaurant in sf (that i know of) that exclusively soft tofu stew (although most Korean restaurants do). Their tofu soups are so damn good and the perfect hangover meal, I call it  my "Seoul" food.

I usually get the mandoo (dumpling), ramen, or kimchi tofu. You order your choice of meat (pork, beef, or none) and the level of spiciness for each stone pot. It comes with rice, side dishes, and grilled fish. Bon appetit!
author: Jane C.

description:
This my favorite korean restaurant in the bay area. The side dishes can serve as the meal itself. This restaurant gotta be the only one that serves the beautiful, delicious fried fish as a side. 
The rice is generous portion an d i especially enjoy when they pour in some hot water to complete the pot of rice. 
I am happy to say they will continue to replenish your favorite side dish without any fuss. 
Seafood tofu and chicken bulgogi are the main dishes we continue to order each time. Unfortunately there is no more room for other orders but each time we remind ourselves to try the others in the menu on the next visit. 
Always a satisfied meal and definitely 5stars for us. 
Bonus is we get to shop next door for our korean groceries after a wonderful meal
author: Nelle L.

description: We were seated and served quickly. The broiled chicken was full of yummy goodness. Well seasoned and very juicy. Ordered the tofu dumpling and I was very pleased with the level of spice and the dumplings. Glad there was side dishes and I cannot speak highly enough about the croaker fish. Yum!
author: Amy T.

description: Not gonna lie, but I was a little disappointed with this place. The only thing I enjoyed here was the barley tea. I've never had bibimbab so decided to give it a try. We ordered the bbq beef kind and some tofu soup. I was debating whether I thought the bibimbab was either good or bad. After a few bites, I decided it wasn't that good and I was just hungry. The banchan also didn't have that many dishes and was all average. Left here full, but unsatisfied.
author: Micah Anne M.

description: Baked tofu vegetable bibimbap..... is PERFECT! I am upset there isn't one similar in so cal. It has the right amount of everything. There service is pretty bad but the food takes away your frustration from their service haha I LOVE this place!!!!!!
author: Karen B.

description:
I can't believe i haven't review this place yet! This restaurant is FANTASTIC! Food are always delicious and consistent! If you think the price is a bit high, then come during lunch time; there is definitely a difference on your bill.

As a usual, i get:
- Fish egg soft tofu SPICY: goddamn its like heaven!! 
- dak gui (chicken): it's pretty sweet, so it's a great combination with my spicy soup
- spicy pork (forgot korean name): it's good, but of course it's not the main reason i go there.

And i forgot the rest of the other stuff i've tried. I can guarantee these 3 are excellent enough though!! 
Love love love their kimchi, cucumber thing, fried fish, etc etc. 

Oh and i love the melon gum they give on your bill!
author: Verdina P.

description: Absolutely a great place to eat tofu, I had tried a lot of Korean Tofu at several places, but nothing tasted better than this one, the staffs also very nice, just love it this place.
author: Terry T.

description: This place has great food.  A nice variety of food on the menu...not just tofu.  Restaurant is nice and clean and service is great.  Workers are very nice and hard working.
author: Jh L.

description: While there are many good aspects of this place, it isn't one I would go out of my way to go back to. But, I'm giving it 3 stars still because the biggest reason I didn't LOVE my meal is just my own pickiness. I had the beef tofu pot with medium heat, and I just didn't like that there were mushrooms in it. The medium wasn't that spicy either, so next time I'd get it hotter. But besides that, really, everything was just fine. The rice was fresh and hot, and if you were lucky, you got some of the crispy edges from the clay pot, which I love. There was a decent amount of ban chan -- kimchi, radish, bean sprouts, fish cake, cucumber, and fried mackerel. We also ordered a seafood pancake that came out a lot thicker and heavier than I'm used to, and I think I like it better at other places. So, a pretty average pot of tofu, but I've had better overall experiences at a lot of other places.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I'll admit, I'm rarely ever in the mood for tofu soup, but if I am, this is the place I would go to. As with any Korean meal, you get banchan. Order the tofu soup and you'll get some rice and a raw egg to crack in if you so desire.

The kimchee tofu soup offers a choice of beef or pork, as well as varying levels of spicy. I went for spicy and it definitely was, but not to the point that I was dying from the heat. (The heat you should worry about is the temperature, these soups are HOT!) I would've liked more  beef in my soup, but otherwise, it was delicious!

They also give you serve you rice from a stone bowl and then, pour tea into the bowl with the burnt rice - a good post-meal treat, if you're into it.

Service is a bit slow, but hey, come winter, this is where I'd want to be if I was looking for a nice warm dinner.
author: Ryan C.

description: How could I have given it a 3 just because of them having a short of staff night once-this place is a SF institution and is quite excellent.
author: Lantz G.

description: Great Korean food in a city that lacks it. Is there anything better than spicy tofu soup and little fried fishes? NOPE
author: Aaron V.

description:
ARGH!!! I thought I would really like this place...but...I can't say I do.  There are lots of pros and cons...but it just comes down to taste.

What I like about this place:

Really good service, clean restaurant, they have fried fish for ban chan! (first place in norcal I've found that serves it)

What I DON'T like about this place:

It's a bit pricey.  BBQ meats are ~$18 and the pajeon is $17.  WOW!  compare that to ~$13 for most places in the south bay.  You may argue that it's pricier in the city...but um, why I would I pay more for something that doesn't taste as good as the south bay?  Which leads me to my next dislike.  The soondobu stopped bubbling soon after it was delivered to our table.  That means you better get going and crack that egg kuz it doesn't leave much time for the egg to cook.  The soondobu was...kinda bland, but it was thick and full of tofu (so that wasn't too bad).  The Pajeon was bland too, you really needed the soy dipping sauce.  I found the pancake to be a bit too doughy.  I've had better where it was just full of seafood and veggies in a light batter.  Not worth $17.  And finally, the Daeji Bulgogi was pretty fatty.  Again, on the bland side.  Asked for spicy but didn't come out as spicy as I hoped.

The meal came out to be ~$60 including tip for 2 people.  Personally, I would have rather gone to a AYCE Korean BBQ for that price tag.  I did leave stuffed and with some left overs...enjoyable meal with a friend, and the soondobu did warm me up...But I think I'll stick to tofu houses in Santa Clara.
author: Thien N.

description:
Look how many reviews ! Sorry, sometimes you have to stand in the line a bit, but worth it...hmm, Love the Tofu Soup :P

We are Real people, Real reviews !
author: DontHurtMe T.

description:
I am a fan and the food is very good - just not overwhelming - and I consider 3 stars in Bay Area as very good - menu here is pretty straight forward and the quality of the ingredients is very good.

Have been here a few times and it is very good comfort (Korean) food - tend to like the Short Ribs and the bowls.
author: Richard D.

description:
This place isn't as great as what they used to be :/ I remember having really good stuff and decent prices...but their prices seemed to have gone up...Then again...I used to go years ago. 

The tofu soup is still good and their BBQ meats are decent...but their bibimbap was lacking... :/ Expensive and bland. Don't get it. Just stick with the tofu soup and the meats.
author: Justin L.

description:
For a place called My Tofu House, I thought I would be blown away by the tofu soup. The original tofu soup with beef was tasty, but the broth could have been richer and more flavorful. 

The banchan was much more limited than other Korean restaurants, but we did love the fried fish.
author: Annaliese D.

description:
Came here for dinner because it was on the 7x7 list. Got there around 6pm and there were only two tables occupied. They have this strange booth seating which reminds me of like mcdonalds or something. 

We ordered the tofu soup with kimchee and the bimbambop for two. The food comes out fast! I loved three out of the four side dishes! The salty fish was weird but everything else was really flavorful. 

This was my first real Korean cuisine experience besides Korean BBQ. I like how they give you a rare egg to drop into the tofu soup. They also give you rice enough for three bowls and they pour this tea into the left overs for porridge (tasted gross).

I liked the tofu soup more than the beef bimbambop, in my opinion it was more flavorful. It went well with the rice. I wished the bimbambop had a fried egg instead of a raw egg.

Service was fast but not super friendly. We asked some more side dishes and was asked for which ones. We got the new side dishes pretty fast.

By the time we were done eating, the place got really packed. The price was 27 bucks for two. Good amount of food for two. Got two complementary sticks of gum. Apple flavor. 

One bathroom for men and one bathroom for women. I felt like the door for the women didn't lock. =/
author: Sarah C.

description: Best tofu soup ever! The menu is limited, but if you're looking for tofu soup this is the spot.
author: Lioness C.

description:
Located in the Richmond district, I came here to meet up with my old roommates from college.  

We were seated right away, and we were waiting for the rest of our party.  It was nice that we didn't have to wait.  It wasn't too busy so that was nice.  But the head waiter guy didn't like that we were still waiting for the rest of our party.  Even though, we don't understand korean, I didn't like that hostility.  He needs to chill out.  

I got the BBQ pork and vegetable bibimbab.  This was alright, a little pricey than the usual bibimbabs I get.  I would prefer it with beed next time.  My boyfriend had the seafood soft tofu.  The shrimp tasted unfresh, I didn't like it.  

Overall, this place is a bit pricey with just average food.
author: Sheila K.

description:
Tofu soup: really great! Probably the best in SF.

Side dishes: great quality; includes a fried fish for each person.

Bibimbap: way overpriced. :(

Wait: horrendous.
author: Anna V.

description:
Currently checking out a church nearby.  After service, went here to have lunch with our godparents and the kids. It was nearby and had good reviews on Yelp so decided to come here.  
We got seated right away.  Seems like the server didn't speak much English or he just didn't wanna speak to us coz we hardly heard anything from him.  
I ordered bibimbap while everyone else ordered bbq. Our table had bbq galore!  It was tender and yummy!  Banchan were yummy  too.  Lots and lots of options.  I like the fried fish too.  Prices remind me of Filipino restaurants, pretty high... I never understand why.  Maybe the prep or the type of meat.  
Would like to come back to try their tofu soup and the pancakes.  Yum.
author: Claire J.

description: Finally a good soondubu place in the city! I love korean tofu stew especially on cold days. The tofu stew options were good and what you usually expect: original, beef, combo, mushroom and dumpling. The bowls come to your table at a strong boil and you add the egg to thicken up the stew. Banchan side dishes are fresh and good too. One note is that their spicy option is not that spicy but you can always add a kick with their gochuchang sauce.
author: Dora L.

description:
I don't get all the hype over the tofu soup. It's good, but tastes about the same as a lot of other Korean restaurants I've been to. The "medium" spicy level was also not spicy at all I think, more of a "mild" on my scale.

Also had the kalbi, bulgogi, and chicken. The kalbi was good, but again not a standout compared to other restaurants. The bulgogi however, tasted a lot more of ginger than I've ever had. The meat was also a lot thinner. Enjoyable if you like ginger. The chicken was below average to me. I really like the smokiness of the bbq chicken that most Korean restaurants have, but My Tofu House seemed to be lacking that. A disappointment.

On the positive side, their beef and vegetable bibimbap was the best I've had. I like that they add the right amount of gochujang for you so that the taste is spot on. Other places give you the jar and allow you to taste to your liking.. but I can never get it right haha.

Overall this is a good spot for a casual meal on one of many cold, foggy nights in SF.
author: Munnie T.

description:
Okay... So the food was pretty amazing but the service was not that great. 

I'll have to admit I didn't leave an amazing tip because of the service but as I was leaving the male waiter called me out on my tip. He called me out and claimed the service was good and I was supposed to leave at least a 15% tip.
author: Youstina B.

description:
3 guys multi-tasking as cashier, hosts, waiters, and busboys as a team. All with wet faces from sweat and adrenaline from their Monster drinks. You wanna complain about the wait? You don't realize how hard these guys work. Hell, think about the kitchen!! 

This is the place for soft tofu soup accompanied with good ol' Korean staples: BBQ meat, Bibimbab, Seafood/Meat Pancake, and, of course, the banchan. Choose your poison and you're set to go! 

Came here as a group of 4, luckily we all weren't too hungry yet since there were a handful of groups ahead of us. Waited for about 20 min til we got a booth, thank goodness a bunch of groups had left around the same time. 

The food is just... soulful. Made with the mom (& pop) love that would be served to their own kids. It's simple, hearty, and warms you up from the inside out. We ordered 4 dishes, 1 from each category, and pretty much cleaned everything up via family style. 

Oh, if you're waiting for a table don't be a creeper and watch ppl eat over the short wall. You'll get told to give those patrons privacy to enjoy their food.
author: Marie G.

description:
Tofu soup was pretty tasty. Kalbi was ok.

The menu was really limited, which I was sad about. =\
author: Lisa N.

description:
Although My Tofu House pales in comparison to the Korean food available in Southern California, you get a decent meal that will satisfy your Korean food cravings and also leave without your clothes smelling like BBQ. Regardless of what you order, you still get banchan (the traditional small Korean side dishes). I like that you get a sizable whole fried fish as one of them. The others include kimchi, bean sprouts, cucumbers, small dried fish, and pickled radish. They don't have as large of a variety of banchan as other restaurants. For example, they didn't have the fishcake or potato ones I like, but I guess the fried fish made up for that. 

For dinner, we decided to do it family style so we could have a little bit of everything. We got the seafood pancake, the combination soft tofu, kalbi (beef short ribs), and the broiled chicken. The short ribs had a bit more fat than I would have liked but everything was delicious. 

The service was good and our cups of tea were kept hot and full. The meal ended with a complimentary stick of chewing gum. It lasted about five chews before the flavor was gone. I think it's a much better deal to come here for lunch since you get the same meal at half the cost ($10 compared to $18-20).
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Over the years, MTH has been my go-to spot for Korean food in the city.  Still love the soon doo boo, although I think prices have gone up over the years (and I think there are better spots down in the South Bay).

Galbi for $20+ is way overpriced.  Also, the pajeon (savory pancake) is not very good or traditional.  It's much thicker with lots of batter (almost resembles a quiche) and to boot, it's bland.

The banchan (side dishes) are generally good, like the fish cakes or the small fried fish.  The cucumbers are ok although I've had better.  I've definitely had better kimchi elsewhere

Just stick to the tofu stew and you'll be ok though.  Get's really crowded so try to get there within the first half hour of opening to avoid a wait.
author: F. P.

description:
Moved out to bay area in 2010 and was frustrated by the Korean restaurant scene given I was coming from NYC. 

Basically two years later, my expectations for Korean food in the Bay Area has dropped...significantly.  That being said, My Tofu House is now my favorite soon-do-bu house in the bay area.  hands down.  Hate the line sometimes, but it's 100% worth it.
author: S R.

description:
Iono why thwy even hire this korean guy with glasses. I`ve been here for many yrs i meant not saying they have good service but at least they wont be rude to their customers. 
So i was here tonight again with my mom and my son and this guy sat us down by the door so i asked if we could have a table more inside thats not yet clean but no one is sitting there. He did not respond but he said in a very rude way wait over there. As we about to walk my son was a lil fuzzy so it took me like 5second to move. Well we r standing in a big open area and we are about to move to the waiting area. Then he was so rude and say again, "i told you to move over there" WTF you are talking when customer is only a few seconds slower and you shouldnt fking speaking to your customer in this way. How rude that was? I straight up confronted him that we are your customer and watch how you talk to your customer. 
I wanted to walk out of this business but my mom is super craving for it so i was like fk it...
During out stay, the only time he walkrd by was giving us a tea and he placed it down so loud and only the nice lady gave us the service. 
So .5star for their food and .5 star for the lady with nice service. And this guy lost my 3points from my last review just for his super rude attitude and service
author: Constance H.

description:
When is hot Korean tofu soup NOT excellent for a chilly winter's day?
When everyone else has the same idea to warm their bones at My Tofu House...

On a New Years day whim, my roommate and I decided to take a trip across the city to start the year off hot, with some spicy tofu soup. Also, we decided not to drive so that we would be forced to walk off all that yummy in our tummies. Although of this sounded delightful while we left ,and while we were on the way there... it was slightly less satisfying at the end of the night.

The wait was an hour long, even for a party of 2. This is because most of the sitting is booth styled, so whether you're a table of 2, 3, or 4, you're going to wait the same amount of time. Plus there isn't much sitting inside for waiting, so be prepared to stand for your food.

I recommend driving - as daunting as the thought may be if you live in the city. The bus only ran every 30ish mins that night, and there's plenty of parking in the area. Plus, despite all that warm food, we were freezing our butts off on the way home. 

The food is good - like other Korean places they will give you refills on the side dishes if you ask them. I really enjoyed their kimchi and the fried fish. I ordered the Original Soft Tofu with Pork, and it was pretty good. I ended up adding a ton of their kimchi in there to make it better though. On a side note, they only offer white rice.

The whole meal ended up being around $13 a person (including tip). This is pretty good for a dinner in SF- if it weren't so far and crowded, I would consider going again.
author: Lucia C.

description: The staff at this restaurant is so rude! We went there last night for dinner, put our name down, and waited inside the restaurant. When I went to the host to see how much longer the wait is, I noticed my name was crossed off. When I asked him about this, he said he couldn't read the name and then I proceeded to rewrite the name and he said he called that name already! That makes no sense whatsoever! What a liar!!!  I would've heard him. The restaurant isn't that big and we were waiting inside! And then I asked if we can get the next table. He said no and said I can put my name down again but at the END of the list. That is so unprofessional! I used to like this place but I'm never coming back here. There's plenty of korean restaurants in the city with way better service!
author: Nori L.

description: This place is delicious! Love coming here for dinner on a cold night. I always get the kimchi beef tofu soup, and have asked for extra beef before (costs an extra $1.50 and well worth it if you're hungry). My only gripe is that the last time we came we wanted to get the seafood pancake and they were all out of EVERY SINGLE PANCAKE =/. Other than that, this place is fresh, delicious, and affordable -- around $9 for a huge pot. If you order takeout, they also give you the appetizers which is also pretty cool.
author: Shirley L.

description:
i ordered the soon dooboo jigae (spicy soft tofu beef soup) and really enjoyed it. nice start with the banchan - anchovies, kim chi, cucumbers, mung bean sprouts and a small fried fish. they were all tasty. soon came the bubbling hot soft tofu soup and it had nice heat - both temperature and level of spice. i ordered it spicy (vs. medium or mild) and it was just right.  served with two bowls of rice served out of a stone pot, a raw egg that is meant to be cracked into the hot soup.  
after the rice is scooped out of the stone pot, the remaining rice stuck on the pot is soaked in hot tea. this is a pleasant refreshing finish after downing all that spicy soup. 
my recommendation would be to order this dish with a friend and share. it really was so much that i could not finish it.
jYW is a fan!
author: Jeff W.

description:
The service was HORRIBLE!! I can't believe the service can be this bad!
ok, cuz we sat around the corner, its possible to easily forget about us.
But is it too ridiculous that I need to walk to the counter to get my check and to-go box; walk to the counter to ask for side dish refill, and actually take the refill back to the desk myself? 

WTF?
really disappointed
author: Bella G.

description: When a restaurant states it is open until 10 and you walk in at 9:40 and they tell you they are closed and that they stop serving at 9:30, they should change their hours. Crappy customer service. Sad because I liked this place.
author: Christina S.

description:
They have fewer banchans than some of the other Korean places around, but they certainly make up for it with the addition of a whole fried fish for each person.  Now I am no "fish" "expert", but I believe that it's a fish called "yellow" "croaker".  Regardless of what it's called, all you really need to know is that it's delicious.

Their namesake dish, the tofu soup, is fantastic.  I like their seafood and original.  The fish egg one didn't add much to it, though the dumpling one is pretty good as well.  Make sure you crack your raw egg into the soup when you get it, or it won't have enough time to cook!

I've tried their non-tofu dishes as well, and they have been solid.  My favorite is the daeji bulgoki...it's definitely got a spicy kick, if you're into that.

Overall this place is one of the best places for tofu soup in the city, but the wait is almost always pretty long.  There's a chance you'll be seated in this back room that feels kind of like a converted closet, but the rest of the restaurant is nice and spacious.
author: jon y.

description:
Don't come here if your party is more than four.They sit people in order. Heck they sit 2 people on a tables that fit for 6!!!  So when our party of 6 turn to sit, we need to wait an extra half an hour...

Don't come here if you bring a toddler!!! We came with two toddlers. After waiting for half an hour to get to our turn to sit down, AND extra half hour for tables that would sit all six of us (WHILE LOOKING A PARTY of 2 sitting on LARGE TABLES) we finally got a chance to sit down. Then we had to wait an extra 15 minutes to get the high chairs to be brought to us...

Waiters here are not friendly (i was being nice when i said this)... After we ordered we expected our free appetizer to come... We waited some more, and they didn't come. We see people put their order after our got their appetizer., so we asked them for it. Our toddlers are hungry and getting restless. 10 minutes passed, we asked another waiter. She walked away. Instead of preparing our free appetizer, I saw her looking at the utensil, moving them around, wiping them. She basically STALLING on purpose. So I find a different waiter, and ask for the free appetizer, and this one said that they come in order. So I asked why did the people that order after us got their appetizer already. LIAR... I will never come back to this establishment..

BAD Management... Waiter with ATTITUDE... NOT kids friendly...
author: Y K.

description: My parents love to come here when they visit SF. It feels authentic. Sides are plentiful and their tofu soup comes in many varieties. I've tried their other dishes but just prefer the tofu soup. Parking is easy but metered. I've never had to wait long to be seated but it can get crowded during peak hours.
author: Logan N.

description:
Really good tofu soup! It's pretty much what they're known for, er, obviously. I like it spicy.

The non-tofu soup dishes were pretty good too. Sides dishes were good, bulgogi, pancakes, all pretty solid. Would return.
author: Thuan N.

description: I'm currently on a bland diet per doctor's orders, so that means I've been eating a lot of tofu soup around SF. My tofu house really good, but I think it's a close second to the soft tofu soup at Pyung Chang Restaurant in Oakland. I also tried Mom's Tofu House the other day, and My Tofu House is definitely better - the tofu soup had a better flavor and the BBQ  chicken dish was not nearly has charred.
author: Sarah L.

description: Was seated right away but it took 40 minutes before the food came. Ordered the chicken bibimbap and seafood tofu soup. The soup was hot throughout the meal and was delicious. The bibimbap was dry and the chicken was even dryer.... Won't recommend that. I enjoyed the side dishes. It was very busy, maybe that's the reason it took sooooooo long. The waitress was friendly and attentive,?Either way, I doubt I'll be coming back anytime soon....
author: Domingo D.

description:
Okay, I feel like I've been to better places

Ordered the combo pancake -good, but sauce was too salty

Kimchee tofu soup-ehh didn't really stand out

Bulgogi-okay

Kalbi-okay

Service, HORRIBLE. Didn't feel like they helped serve us. And when we tried to flag them down the girl made eye contact and then went back in the kitchen.

Overall, this place is over rated.
author: Sophie C.

description: + good, typical Korean food...not the best, but probably the best you can get in the city.
author: Margaret R.

description:
My Tofu House is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city. It's spacious with individual booths and is well ventilated so you don't leave smelling like BBQ. Come at the right time and the wait won't be too long. Even if you did have to wait a while, it's totally worth it! Prices are very reasonable for the quality and amount of food they provide...I've seen much more expensive items at other places. Great to eat here in groups so that you can try a little bit of everything!

Our dinner for 3 consisted of: 

assorted banchan - They gave more banchan than pictured and was able to bring more when we asked. Loved the bean sprouts, dried spicy anchovies, kimchi, and the fried whole fish! The cucumber was cooling for the mouth too. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KhG-jWIr7-TJj3isz3ZIFQ?select=Eu1eCi4IgNegESpcbrT2kQ)

soft tofu soup with seafood ($10.50) - We chose to get it spicy and it really warmed us up. The tofu was so silky and the soup so full of Korean flavors. Sluuuuurp! Be prepared to burn your tongue and break a sweat with the combo of temperature hot and spiciness hot though! Breaking the raw egg into the boiling soup was fun and they didn't skimp on the seafood. Looked small but packed a punch! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KhG-jWIr7-TJj3isz3ZIFQ?select=lSzHZgaUYtkP3cG1upSdZA)

beef bulgogi ($18) - Who doesn't love BBQ beef?? This is the Korean version and was oh-so-tasty! Marinated to perfection with that sweetness I enjoy and didn't dry out while still cooking on the sizzling plate. There was A LOT of meat so we didn't finish it but went well with our complimentary bowls of rice! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KhG-jWIr7-TJj3isz3ZIFQ?select=9HPOCeKvamG3Hcuu7KCo9Q)

veggie pancake ($17) - A go-to dish of mine when I eat Korean food and the one here was bleh. The doughy pancake was laden with green onions/bell peppers and wasn't evenly crispy or browned on the outside. The green onions were overpowering too! Couldn't they have added other veggies? They also didn't cut the slices up very well. I definitely prefer the seafood pancake. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KhG-jWIr7-TJj3isz3ZIFQ?select=NHasNArrhzrgRZ9OEYee1g)

Not sure if I got all the prices right but it was around that ballpark. Service was fast and efficient as usual. I seem to always get the same waiter whenever I come here too. haha Swing by for lunch to get the same food but at cheaper prices!
author: Karen Y.

description:
After seeing many positive reviews, I was excited to try this restaurant; however, was thoroughly disappointed. The food here was mediocre and on the pricy side (12$ for tofu soup and 17$ for bibimbap). The soup was amazing, but the bibimbap was bland. The rice wasn't toasty and was sitting in a pool of oil. It was the most disgusting bibimbap I've had. Sunnybowl in MV offers a much better option for half the price! 

Several reviewers mentioned the service was not great, but from my experience, asian restaurants tend to offer barebones services, but this place was one of the worst. See below for details:

1. Our group arrived at 4:30. We mentioned we were expecting a fifth member in 15 min, so if the waiter could come back to take our orders in 30 min, that would be great. He never came back. We had to go to the back to get someone to take our orders.

2. Ordered seafood pancake and it never came, but luckily we weren't charged for it.

3. The waiter came back with the check while we were still eating. He came back after a few minutes and said he wanted us to pay so they could close the check. The restaurant was only starting to fill up (around 6:15ish), so I'm unclear of the rush to get us out.

4. They informed us they did not accept American Express; however one member had left an AE card and had gone to the bathroom. We waited for her to swap out the card, but within seconds a second and third waiter came by to say "we don't take American Express". It was unnecessary to continuously repeat that message. We get it.

5. We noticed the check came out higher than expected, but it wasn't until we asked that they confessed gratuity was included. Nowhere did they mention gratuity is added for a party of 5. It's an unusual practice since most restaurant do 6 and above. Perhaps it was meant to intentionally mislead?

Overall:

Food: 3 stars
Price: 2 stars
Service: 0
author: Ngoc N.

description:
Best tofu in town, but pricey. 

They should give us more free side dishes just like how the other Korean restarant. But tseafood spicy tofu soup, OMG, So delicious!
author: Sam W.

description:
The food are awesome. I really recommend the tofu soup and BBQ beef. 
The fried fish are very delicious. The people who don't like fish can have a try.
 It's a pity that there don't have rice cake and some other traditional Korean food.  But I still like it . I will come back again.:D
author: Deng Y.

description:
Excellent service, delicious food. 

Ordered the kalbi, bulgogi, and kimchee tofu soup. Bulgogi was a little dry but that's a very minor complaint and I'm just being nitpicky. Everything else was delicious. Will definitely come back for more!
author: Ashley V.

description: long wait, but worth it. lovelovelove. got my spicy tofu soup kick. banchan was also yummy. so recommended! San Francisco has good Korean food and this place is evidence of that fact. Period.
author: Andrew K.

description: This was so delicious! I came here visiting my college roommates and hadn't really had authentic Korean before because we don't have it in DC. I was pleasantly surprised! I had the spicy dumpling tofu soup. There were so many flavors I'd never tasted before, but it was so tasty I couldn't stop. You get a lot of sides with your main meal to munch on, and a large pot of rice to go with your soup. Best of all, it was incredibly cheap for all the food we got. I couldn't finish mine! Would definitely recommend!
author: Lauren R.

description:
I've had my share of korean tofu house tofu and this place is average, I've definitely had better. They've got a pretty nice interior though, that's for sure. 
I felt like this place got a lot of hype so maybe I had too many expectations for the place. Just don't go in expecting the best tofu in your life, or speedy service.

I got the kimchi tofu. The broth was really lacking in flavor and robustness, and even though I asked for medium spicy there was barely any heat at all. The side dishes we good  though. It's about what you can expect from your typical top liner korean tofu shop, but I felt the servers were really hesitant to hook it up with the refills on them. Not quite the welcoming service I would like to see from an establishment I'm paying to eat at. I would like to note that we got there near the end of the lunch hour, so I can understand if the waiters were getting burnt out.
author: Andrew D.

description:
You know, this has been my go-to place for awhile, but lately I've had a repeat of my bland soon doobu experience here (see first review). I thought that the soup just needed to be spicier to have more flavor, but I've been kicking up the spice over time and yet I still had a pretty tasteless fish egg soon doobu here the other night. This was especially disappointing because I had an extremely flavorful bowl of soon doobu at my friend's favorite place (Mama's in South city) and was hoping my old stand-by would match up. 

Now that I don't live in the city, I'm not sure if this place is worth the drive. I do love the fried fish, which not every place serves, and their ban chan are really well done. Also, they staff is really friendly and attentive. Still, they mush up the tofu in their soon doobu and they need broth that is consistently good.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I don't understand Why some of you people complain about not getting your "free" appetizeranything from a restaurant, did u pay for it? Yet you still post a review and complain, have some class T.k. This is the problem with society today, everybody wants a million dollars for free, and I'm sick of reading reviews like T.k. I doubt you understand what it takes to run a business.

I came to this restaurant and they treated me with acceptional customer service.  They were fair in price and the food was great. When i check out a place for the first times i order somthing that sounds delicious and if the price is high I expect a tasty dinner/ lunch. I dont mind paying more for great food, but expecting free food come on!!! Thats called a soup kitchen, S.F. Has a lot of them, but I guess t.k would complain there too.  People, take responsibility for your own actions, if you have kids go to a restaurant you know will accommodate you for the night/day/ lunch. I'm sorry for the long review but business nowadays don't need b.s like this. Have a great week people!
author: Juan G.

description:
I guess my lousy review is that the only Korean food I understand is the BBQ type.  Many of the dishes which arrived at our table were "side" dishes. Not being familiar with them I asked a waiter how to eat it, and basically he just blew by us.  So the experience was limited by our lack of knowledge, and a waiter who was no help.
My real complaint is that about eight hours after eating I uninitiated and my stuff was bright red.  I had no pain anywhere so did not freak out, and three pees later it was all gone.  So maybe they use a lot of foods with far too much red color.  Never ever happened to me before.
author: Mike K.

description: This place will always have a line no matter when you come so be prepared to wait at least 15 minutes. This place also has the best Korean tofu soup that I've ever had. I got the pork tofu soup in mild and it was still very flavorful. I've had many tofu soups before but this one was noticeably the best. I enjoyed every single sip of it. Their Korean pancakes were superb as well. Think of them as fancier Asian pizzas with fresh meat and veggie as ingredients. Make sure to dip them in the provided sauce for the intended flavors. The prices are also reasonable considering the quality of the food. Highly recommend this place and it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Aron Y.

description:
I've come here several times over the course of 4 years, and although I am not a connoiseur of Korean food, I like this place well enough! 

Others have complained about the banchan, but I am happy to get so much variety and refills. It's the Chinese in me to love getting things for "free". Sadly, I am horribel at self-control and usually fill myself up with the banchan before my food actually arrives. I literally undid my belt bucket to get some breathing room.

I usually get the tofu soup (how can I not when the name has the word 'tofu' in it?) or the bibimbap. You can customize your soups for the level of spice, which is great for a blistery cold day. The mushroom and seafood options are my favorite.

The waiters work really hard here to serve everyone. Thanks My Tofu House/Waiters!

P.S. For you sports fans out there, they have 2 big screen tv's so you can keep posted on the game.
author: Tiffany C.

description: I've been coming here from the opening.  I really loved the simmering stonny pot during the cold SF evening.  it's lower calories healthy food with the impressive taste.  However I didn't understand the reason of closing every Saturday lunch time since I went there for nothing but I respect that owner is believer of Seven days adventist church hence he doesn't use the processed chemical stuff.  And he said that as long as I pay extra few dollars then I can get extra soup.  For all these thing this restaurant has been succeed.
author: bluemoon p.

description:
I HAVE NEVER WRITTEN A REVIEW FOR TOFU HOUSE?! I MUST BE CRAZY! 

My Tofu House is definitely one of the BETTER korean places to eat in San Francisco. It's also one 100 things to eat in San Francisco too for their tofu soup. My personal favorite is their bi bim bap with beef. They have these perfect stone pot bowls that gets the rice all nice and crispy later on after you leave it there too. 

Also, the tofu soup they have is perfect. the mild is not too spicy and just the right amount. They do not skimp on the rice they give you which is PLENTY of it. They also do not skimp on the side dishes (the cucumber is the best) and their awesome service backs it up too.

I've also had their bulgogi beef before and also the short ribs, and their korean pancake. everything is just TOO good here, i just wish the place was bigger!
author: Kenny L.

description: A bit too much of the flavor, but its not bad. Galbi is not highly recommended, but the tofu pot itself is above average.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Good Korean restaurant but nothing spectacular.  With all the praise and high reviews on Yelp, I expected this place to be exceptional.  On a Friday night at 7:30pm, we only waited for 10 minutes or so for a party of 2. The wait got much longer when we left at around 8:30pm though so I would recommend coming earlier for dinner.

Food:
-Kalbi (marinated short ribs) - $19.87
(Meat was well-marinated, very juicy, and tender. I definitely recommend ordering the meat plates. They give generous portions.)
-Original Soft Tofu Soup - $10.05
(Average tofu soup. I've definitely had better. The soup was a bit on the salty side and wasn't flavorful.)

Meal comes with:
-Banchan: kimchi, bean sprouts, dried fish, fried fish, cucumbers, radish
-Rice in a clay pot 
(I really liked their rice! They serve it to you fresh out of the clay pot!)

Overall, good food and average prices. Choices were limited (they don't offer Jap Chae and the pancake prices are on the high side).  It doesn't compare to Sahn Maru in Berkeley though (better meat, better prices, and they give you many more dishes of banchan!)
author: Angela F.

description: For some reason, I came here with low expectations.  Wow...was I wrong. The food here was so delicious.  Who gives you two good sized fried fish as a side? yum!  And the tofu soup, omg that was some of the best I've ever had. It actually maybe the best i've had.  Can't wait to go back for more tasty goodness.
author: Dilly M.

description:
The tofu soups are solid. For $11 you get a delicious meal accompanied by a traditional spread of small plates..

The BBQ dishes and the pancakes are a bit more expensive....and bummers that the place doesn't serve beers to cool down the heat.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Delicious soondubu!
I had the medium spicy dumpling tofu soup and it was yummy.  It has dumpling, rice cake, beef for $10.60 which is kind of expensive.  But it also came with lots of panchan. I love how they give each person a whole fish for panchan.  

The restaurant itself is kind of small, and the wait takes a long time but the employees try their best to get everyone seated as quickly as possible.  My Tofu House is one of the best soondubu places I've tried in the bay area.
author: Michell M.

description:
I have been here numerous times with the same person and we always get our tofu soup at the medium spicy level. Days before coming to My Tofu House, I randomly suggest that the next time we have Korean food, we should opt for spicy. Originally she gave me the "are you damn crazy?!" kind of response, but being the good friend that she is, she said she was down!

Came here last night (Saturday). Looked for parking and had to circle around for a little while. The entire time my friend was saying how she was nervous about getting spicy which started to make me nervous!

Got here around 7:20pm and there was 1 open table left for the both of us, awesome! Not a lot of banchan options, though that's not we were there for. Ordered a spicy dumpling soft tofu soup along with a dak gui (bbq chicken). 

When our food came, our eyes widened as to how red our tofu soup was. We even had to eat it together after counting to 3 because it was serious business to us. To our surprise, it wasn't even spicy to us! It just had a hint of spiciness that the medium level lacked. We were still able to taste the flavor of the soup, and never felt the need to drink water or cry for that matter. The dak gui was tasty! Good smokey flavor, and succulent chicken pieces. 

The decor is simple, service is great with a bunch of hip Korean boys to cater to your needs. My friend dropped one of her chopsticks on the floor (FAIL) and one of the servers gladly gave her a new one and always offered to refill our ice waters.

For all of you that are spicy eaters like us, go for spicy! Spice weenies, BEWARE! Next time, we are going to request for extra spicy! :D
author: Ada T.

description: My husband and I love coming here when we want good Korean food!!! My hubby has been coming here for years and once he introduced me to the place I always want to come back!!! Last night we brought our neighbors who lived in Korea for a few years and they've been looking for a good place!!! They loved the place. Some dishes I would recommend are the dumpling soft tofu soup, vegetable pancake, bulgogi, assorted mushroom soft tofu soup, kalbi, dak gui, and the beef and vegetable bibimbap. Not to mention all the awesome goodies they service before the main dishes come out. If you eat here be prepared for a lot of food!!!
author: Sayuri I.

description:
3.5 stars . . . but had to round down because whaaaaa . . . no beer???  What the hell.  And the server said BYO is not allowed . . . hrmmm . . .  Not to sound like an alcoholic, but a refreshing beer with spicy Korean delicacies is just a necessary part of the experience.  

Otherwise, the food was all good - we got the kimchi tofu soup, bibimbap, and vegetable pancake - and service was perfectly fine.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I was expecting a lot for a place called My Tofu House.  
We only had the soondoobu and it was incredibly disappointing.
The service was fine, staff was friendly but it couldn't overshadow the quality of the food.

The broth tasted like the instant broth in the Shin ramen instant noodles.
They totally skimped on the tofu (really? I get tofu for 99 cents).  I usually kill soondoobu but there was nothing to kill.
author: S K.

description: Very good.  Service is slow, but it was super busy so I get it.  Looking forward to coming back
author: Scott L.

description: Great Korean restaurant,  the tofu stew was great!we all liked it! The service was good 5stars for the service and 5 for the yummy food.
author: Mackenzie G.

description:
Yum, yum, yummy!
This place was so fantastic I had to send my Korean chef friend a picture of my meal. I was trying to make him jealous, yep. Who said Korean food was all about the BBQ? This place will leave you completely satisfied.
author: Norma ..

description:
My tofu house? You can take it away from me. I dont want it. 

Came here on a wednesday evening and put my name down for a table of 4. After waiting for ~20 mins. I asked the waiter about the status of our table and sure enough they overlooked us. Its ok people make mistakes all the time. We ordered and waited patiently for our water and food. We noticed that the table behind us that was seated well after us got their water and banchan before we did. Discrimination? Anyways we finally got our side dishes and water. The food came and they were nice enough to scoop us our rice. However, during the meal it seemed they completely forgotten about us. Several times I asked for refills for water and the side dishes and those requests went forgotten. 

Food
side dishes
kimchi, bean sports, cucumbers, and others. Not that impressive variety or quality.

kalbi
chewy and fatty. Not the best and for ~$20 the portions were not great.

combination pancake
too much dough and not enough vegetables and meat in my opinion. 

pork bibimbap
decent but could have used a little more sauce. Crispy rice but a little on the bland side.

combination tofu soup
very bland as the soup tasted like water. Mild was not spicy at all. Probably the most disappointing dish of the night.

Overall: bland food with horrible service. Avoid at all costs.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed My Tofu House yet...the BEST Soon Doobu joint in the city!  Really warms you up on those cool/chilly Richmond District nights (which comes more often than not), and really fills you up the way your gut would want to be.

Although they only give you a few types of ban chan, they cover the staples every Korean restaurant should offer - kimchee, cucumber, bean sprout, and the little anchovies.  The quality is there as it's always fresh, and they also throw in broiled mackerel (I think it's mackerel at least) for the table as well, which is super delicious, though a bit oily.

Over the years, they've expanded their soon doobu offerings, and they give you the option of adding in ramen into any of their tofu soups.  Spicy is the way to go for any of them, but you really can't go wrong (unless you get the bland spiciness level, you bland person you).  Even if you're here and you don't want soup, their Bibimbaps are probably one of, if not the best, in the city too!  They are served in a burning hot stoneware pot, and are ridiculously filling.  Be sure to ask for the hot sauce to make all that goodness that much good-er.

Like their banchan, they offerings of meat is limited to just four types.  However, they are so good!  Their BBQ chicken is probably the one of the more flavorful ones I've had, but there's nothing wrong with their spicy pork, bulgogi (grilled beef), or kalbi (beef short ribs).

Service is great, and any and all of the servers will help your table.  The whole place is clean and the menu is simple, but they do everything very well.  That said, there is almost certainly going to be a wait for varying lengths depending on the night and hour you're there, but it really is worth your time.  They hit on every note and fill you up at a decent price...how can you go wrong?  By not coming here, that's how...
author: Mike L.

description:
Whoever told me good Korean food didn't exist in SF must have never ventured to Richmond. Of course, it doesn't compare to LA, but at least there are options worth trying.

My Tofu House is awesome. Korean tofu soup, also known as soo doo bu, is my absolute favorite K-dish. This place offers a variety of different "flavors" including your typical choice of beef, seafood, fish roe, etc.--but also the option to add ramen and/or dumplings. Brilliant.

They also serve traditional barley tea, which is a nice and nostalgic addition to your Korean dining experience.

It's a little expensive for tofu soup and the lines can be long, but worth trekking.
author: Annie L.

description: This place is the place to go if you love spicy korean tofu soup. It is great on cold or rainy days, or if you have a craving for some good spicy soup. They have other korean dishes like Kalbi, korean pancake, or bibimbap. I had the Kalbi and shared with my friends and we each got our own soup. There is also all the standard korean side dishes that you can start on, But they are mainly known for their Korean soups. It is often crowded after 7. They don't take reservation and there is often a line if you get there too late. If you go early enough to beat the dinner crowd it's great, but if not well be prepared to wait for anywhere from 8-20 minutes.
author: Grant O.

description: It lives up to it's name. I love their tofu soups.
author: Stacy C.

description: I really enjoyed the original tofu soup with chicken.  It was loaded with soft tofu, yum.  splash a little rice in there and its delicious.  Tofu house also gives some of the smaller korean side dishes but they also gave us a couple of small grilled fish, which i thought was good.  I'll have to try the kimchi or dumpling soup next time.  good job tofu house
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place is probably the cleanest restaurant I've ever been to.

I've been wanting to try their bi bim bap, but somehow always got sidetracked with their tofu soup.  It's simply great comfort food, especially on a cold foggy, or rainy San Francisco night.  Prices are great and they give you all these little dishes of sides (with free refills) as well as a grilled (or was it fried) fish.

The giant bouquet of roses by the cash register area's very impressive too.

I still can't get over how spotless this place is.  I've sen hospital rooms in much worst shape.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Tofu soup doesn't exactly sound appetizing. HOWEVER, my first experience of it here at My Tofu House was surprisingly tasty & fulfilling. The wait, yes the wait is RIDICULOUS, but you can't blame a restaurant for being popular right?

I ordered the kimchi soft tofu soup with pork & it was oh so good! I loved how I felt like I was eating peasant food. It's very cool how they serve you with appetizers (like most Korean restaurants) and also with a raw egg that you have the option of putting in your soup. It was very tasty & I love the spice.

It would be very nice to come here again, I would just like to find out beforehand what their least-busiest hours are, because that wait is killer.
author: Junel S.

description: Visited MTH tonight and was very surprised by numerous followers. I stood in line with my gf for nearly 25 minutes waiting for a seat. Everything smelled delicious and with generous portions. First come first serve. I ordered the original soft tofu soup and she ordered the korean bbq. We were stuffed and couldn't finish it all. Happy with the food and service. Planning for my next meal!
author: Patrick W.

description:
Dear My Tofu House,

I know I don't visit you as much as I should and I never take the time out to tell you 'I love you' or do anything special for you to remember this. However, I do, and I would like you to know that you are in my heart and nothing will change that.

The warm soups that you concoct always leave me feeling cozy and sweet. Your delicious stone bowl rice waters my mouth and sustains me like no other.

Your kindness and beauty will always remain there for me. I will be back soon. Sooner than you can imagine, until then, please keep yourself presentable and lovely.

Your secret admirer,
Winnie
author: Winè C.

description:
Honestly, I don't see the hype about this place. Expensive dishes for mediocre food, when it can be so much cheaper at other tofu houses. We ordered the seafood soft tofu pot and the combo pancake for two people. The side dishes were alright (not as many options as milpitas!) but the croaker? was interesting. 

The seafood soft tofu only had 2 tiny oysters... way to trick us. It was also really plain and we barely even ate half of it. The combo pancake was burnt and was just a bad combo in my opinion. I had asked the waiter if he recommended the seafood/combo pancake and he said combo. Too much stuff and too much dough in it for my taste. We only ate a slice each. 

Basically, paid for a full lunch leaving unsatisfied with leftovers neither of us wanted. I'll stick to Tofu House in Milpitas!
author: Syd T.

description:
The name makes me imagine Ray Lewis giving a pre-game speech to his teammates: "WE DON'T LET NOBODY COME INTO OUR STADIUM AND BEAT US! THIS IS MY TOFU HOUSE! AIN'T NOBODY BETTER THAN US!"

The banchan and fried fish were delicious. That alone was worth the price of admission. They even asked us if we wanted any refills, which doesn't happen every time I go to a Korean restaurant. I tried to order the beef lunch special for $10 but that's only valid on weekdays, so be warned! I chose the pork pancake instead and it was good. It was a little on the burnt side but maybe that's how it's supposed to be. It was very filling and the size of a medium pizza. I appreciate that the staff took care of us despite the place being fairly busy on a Sunday afternoon. I'd come here again. 

My tummy gives My Tofu House...4 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description:
Sooon duboo! 

- Expect a wait and slow service and hot tea from plastic cups.
- Get soon duboo, we tried the kimchi one, and shared it among 2.
- Their stone rice bowl is yummy. I love the crispy rice that you can scrape off the side. Mmm.
- Kalbi was fatty and hard to chew but the seasoning and marinate was good, would pass on it and get the tofu soup.
- They don't serve alcohol here so no soju bombs or yogurt soju to go with your meal. bummer.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Coming here is a treat. I don't come here often cause of the long lines and slow service, but once I do, the food never disappoints!  

My Go-To's:
1. Original Chk Soondubu - with RAMEN NOODLES - so flavorful
Comes out PIPING HOT - NO TOUCH

The soup is packed with saltiness and spiciness for a kick, yet balanced out by the soft and creamy tofu. Then you add in ramen noodles and you have a perfect marriage of awesomeness. 

2. Kaibi and Bulgogi - both really satisfying for meat lovers. 

The kaibi has just the right amount of crisp and burnt ( you know what I mean) and finger-licking good marinate. The bulgogi is also worth trying and very tasty.

Their rice comes in a huge pot and is really soft, a basic must at any asian restaurant. 

BTW, boo for difficult parking but yay for credit card allowed! 

With the limited options of good Korean restaurants in SF, this is probably your best bet for consistent good-quality Korean food.
author: Lily S.

description:
My Tofu House is not my tofu house of choice.  To me it was just okay.  I've been to better, cheaper Korean restaurants in Palo Alto and Concord...with bigger portions too.

Things were overpriced.  We got a pork tofu stew for about $10 and a plate of bulgogi for about $20.  This came with an array of unimpressive side dishes- kimchi, pickled cucumbers, bean sprouts, little sweet & spicy dried fish and two larger bland, cold, fried fish.  I was hoping for some cold clear noodles or potatoes in sugar and soy sauce, but nope.
