The service was pretty bad too. There were only two people working in the whole restaurant and at one point they were eating their own meals and not paying attention to customers' needs.  My boyfriend had to ask for water at least 3 times. Womp womp.
author: Sherry C.

description:
I've never written a review for My Tofu House?! 

AH I freakin' love this place. Whenever I want Korean, I COME HERE. It's the best and super close and convenient. I always get a tofu soup and their BBQ chicken ... it's awesome. 

Now I'm craving Korean ...
author: Chrisy Y.

description:
Yum Yum!  

This place makes some good soondubu!  aka soft tofu stew...but be careful, it's served NUCLEAR hot in a dolsot.  When the waiter brought the tray of soup I was pretty scared he would drop it on me and I'd get 3rd degree burns in some bad places.  Seriously, 10 mins later and they thing was still bubbling!  It could stand to be a bit spicier, but it was tasty nonetheless.  Unless you're a complete wuss when it comes to spicy foods you can get the spicy and not have any problems.

There's about 10 different soondubu on the menu so you can choose what you like.  Also lots of other korean staples.  The sides are good, you even get little fishes!  yummy, the kim chee I liked, seemed homemade and it wasn't too sour which is how I like it.  

The rice even comes in a dolsot and they scoop it out and then pour tea in it to get all the nice crispy rice bits.  

I'll be like Macarthur and SHALL RETURN
author: Jason Y.

description: Do not get the pancakes here! I can't believe how bad it tasted... None of us liked it, and we eat a lot at Korean restaurants. And for this price, I was expecting far better food. Other Tofu houses are usually one half of their prices with bigger portion in LA and San Jose so idk if this is just Bay Area or wat... Anyways, very disappointed. And plus, they don't hv combos....
author: Monnikka M.

description:
What?

I heard a lot of hype about this place and allowed my soondobu expectations rocket into the Inner Richmond night sky. But then I ate here. And found that it was over-priced and mediocre. The soondobu was bland, the seafood pancake was bland, the side dishes were lacking. There were only 5... and the fish side dish was so salty, we couldn't eat it. Also, the table was too far from the booth seats.

I have had much much better tofu soup for much cheaper. This apparently is not my tofu house :(
author: Julie N.

description:
I was enticed by my sister saying this place is "Rated a top 10 places to eat before you die in SF"

I was told this place gets packed!!! SO be aware if you come with a big party or during prime time dinner. 

For starters, I love Korean food. The bbq ribs, spicy pork, bogolgi, and such is, and can be my kryptonite. 

On this night, my sister like always orders more than what she can muster down. AND me being the savior of NO TO GO meals, I took it upon myself to clear the items on the table. 

Started off with,  TONS of kim chee 
-yellow sprouts
-cucumber
-fried fish
-white radish
-lettuce kim chee 
*Note: they are not shady with kim chee refills ++ 

Tofu (kim chee pork soondubu) - $10.77 - It came out like usual, a bowl of boiling red broth. Fairly spicy, but you won't run out the door in seek of more beverages.  Good taste, soft tofu.

Kalbi bbq ribs - $17 - Decent portions. Sweet marinade. 

Octopus pancake - $10? - .. Slightly crunchy top and bottom. Soft in the middle. Didn't dig it that much. 



Overall, a very solid place for Korean in the city. Good service and friendly. 

For Top 10 must tries in SF, I would have to say.. a must if you like Korean food.
author: kent c.

description:
5 stars because I have become a fan of Korean tofu soup! 

The soup was seriously soooo good! I had never added a raw egg to my soup before and truth be told, I was a little hesitant at first. But it turned out to be the best idea ever! I loved all the mini side dishes, especially the fried fish! I got stares from our friends at the table for wanting to take everything to go with me (I got stuffed pretty easily that day) but I didn't care! It was so good I couldn't leave it behind! The bf didn't think it was out of this world but we have agreed to disagree.

I live in LA and have been searching Yelp for a spot out here that compares. It's only getting chillier so I'm hoping I find a reliable spot soon!
author: Krystle R.

description: Tofu soup and fried yellow croaker are delicious. My tofu soup was spicy but not ridiculously spicy that I cannot taste anything else in the soup. The banchan were okay, not spectacular. Service was minimal. They came by to scoop out rice for you initially but beyond that, nothing else.
author: LeTran B.

description: Cheap for the amount of food we got; two fish with tofu soup. Not the best korean food I ever  had but probly the cheapest one.
author: Joelle K.

description:
This is THE place for soondooboo in San Francisco. I'm not sure about the Bay Area in general, but I do hesitate when it comes to Korean food...

I have been to this place so many times, but the first time that I came here was right after I moved up to San Francisco from southern California, where in some areas, there's a soondooboo place on every block. Of course, not all of them are good, but at least in socal, there's a lot to choose from!...Unfortunately, this does not hold true in SF.

I was a bit afraid because honestly, if soondooboo isn't even that popular up here to begin with, how good could this place be, right? Anyway, I came here with three other non-SF Koreans and we all loved it!

I love their dumpling tofu the most... the dumplings actually don't taste gross/frozen (re: my article on Zazang). You can also add ramen to your soondooboo, which I didn't know for a long time! That's a delicious option, but sometimes it can take away from the tofu, so beware.

7x7 list worthy? I'm not too sure about that... perhaps because I've had a lot of good soondooboo while growing up. However, I'll definitely remain a loyal customer as long as I'm in SF!
author: Angela K.

description: I went here for the first time last week for the dumpling tofu soup...and I can't stop thinking about it. So delicious! The perfect comfort food.
author: Mindee K.

description:
It has been about a year since my last visit to My Tofu House.  My tummy always felt warm and satisfied after a My Tofu House visit and this time it did not disappoint.  The prices have gone up since the last time around but I still felt there was value for the money.  

The banchan side dishes were very fresh with triple portion kim chee.  We declined the two salted fish side dishes and got some more cucumbers and bean sprouts instead.  It is cool how the rice comes in Korean stoneware right out of the oven.  The soft tofu soup with dumplings was wonderfully savory.  The kalbi ribs were perfectly grilled on a bed of caramelized onions.  The spicy pork had just the right amount of sweet and spicy.  Children will like the grilled chicken since it is not spicy and has a sweetness to it.  

At the end of dinner, my tummy once again had the familiar warm satisfying feeling.
author: Hugh Y.

description:
It was a cold Sunday, and I didn't feel like making dinner. What better way to warm me up then with a piping hot bowl of tofu stew? This place usually gets packed, but we got there early enough to beat the rush. 

If I'm hungry, NEVER let me be in charge of ordering. Everything looks good, and I will want to order EVERYTHING! I ordered Kalbi( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/tsDdHTGv7eNFT8fy3LifhA/l ) and 2 orders of the Kimchi soft tofu with beef( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/9rRyIjNqFGw8BKTxWosTXQ/l ). I order my tofu stew mild...I'm a wuss....and then I add more kimchi later. I wanted my own tofu stew, but in the end, I realized we could've shared one. My dinner buddy stopped eating, but I kept going...finished my tofu stew and the kalbi! I was uncomfortably full by the end of dinner! 

I like coming here because the prices are reasonable, and the food is very tasty. Its always a plus when they give you the side dishes, too( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/DQ949ACrZZYbfmHV3RQh1A/l ). Service is hit or miss. If its really busy, it might take a while to flag down a waiter, bu tthey're always very nice. 

I'll be back to stuff my tummy again!
author: Patra I.

description: Dishes were ok here but the service was terrible. The waiter didnt have any patience at all and was kind of rude to us. Never come back again and won't recommend it
author: Chen L.

description: Love getting take out from here because they still give you all the side dishes!  An order of tofu soup with less tofu and an order of Kalbi is perfect for two people to share.  But beware, dinner prices are a lot more expensive than lunch.  An order of Kalbi during dinner time costs about $28 now.
author: Tina L.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Seafood Pancake
2.) Tofu soup - the best was the tofu soup. mmm!!! hit the spot!!!
3.) Kalbi beef
4.) Side dishes
*mmm, everything was good.


SERVICE:
Very good. Hard workers.


ATMOSPHERE:
Feels like... a korean bar... so... it's fitting... except it's brighter than a korean bar bc it's just a restaurant...
author: Angela L.

description:
Looking for a cheap korean lunch place that isnt crowded? This is the place. For two people you can get away with just about $20. I usually share the beef bulgolgi because they give a lot and they also provide rice (in a clay pot and add water to the crispy rice to make a nice tea). They also provide the traditional small plate starters which you can always get refilled.

The price is great, the food is good and service could be a little better but isnt bad. You can also find parking on the metered streets or residential area if you dont mind walking 1+ blocks.
author: Tim M.

description:
There is a certain comfort, a sort of emotionally filling moment, putting the finishing touch on a meal.  As I break an egg over the boiling, mini-caldron of spicy tofu soup it brings on satisfaction.  Once it cools a little, it also works as a physically filling lunch (with a little rice).  

Its a small example of a simple meal that adds to a food diversity that one is not going to find outside of a port city like SF or NY or NOLA.  I just happened to be in the neighborhood looking for lunch and the next thing I know I am having a great meal.

Most people in the world live their lives eating the narrow band of food that marks their homeland.  That is it.  Or worse, that is it until Mickey-Ds or KFC arrives.  While the various cultures battling for supremacy in a place can make for some strange times, the battle of food makes those times tasty.

BTW.  Pickling is kind of popular at some of the more edgy restaurants in town, but it has been a standard side dish of Korean food for quite some time.  And it comes with every meal.
author: Kevin R.

description: Food is ok, service is horrible, especially the waiter with thick glass. It seems we owe him something. Will never ever go back again!!!! If there is negative star, I will choose it!!!!
author: Felix L.

description:
Be prepared to wait. I have never been here and seen an absence of a line. There is always a line. But it moves quickly....sometimes. If I crave tofu soup, I try to come here on a weeknight. Forget the weekends unless you come early. 

To be honest, I have been here more than a couple of times and I always get the tofu soup. I either get the kimchee or the mushroom one. I have not ordered anything else on the menu. It all looks good and decent enough, but I love my tofu soup. This always hits the spot. This meal is simple, yet satisfying and I really do like the banchans here. 

I am not sure if there are other tofu houses in SF, but this seems to be the best one. I've been to quite a few all over LA.

The service is quick and no non-sense, but they are polite.
author: Caroline L.

description:
It's an alright place.  The outter dining area is scenic and pretty.  The inner dining area faces the bathroom and has no windows.  

The tofu soup is okay - I've had better at Hamn Ji Bak in New York. 

The banchan was pretty good.  They served two fried herring/sardines that were delicious.  The cucumber and bean sprouts were also good.
author: Di Yin L.

description: Stingy on all their dishes.  Don't even try asking for more rice without being charged.  Super expensive dinner menu with mediocre service.  They won't even leave a pot of tea on your table, let alone asking for refills on kimchi.  All the common dishes were missing - you're lucky if they have daikon.  We should have gone next door to Wooden Charcoal Korean BBQ or Brothers.  Customer service sucks here, and they don't have an option for you to bbq at the table.  They don't even offer complimentary tofu soup, hence the name of their restaurant...things that make you go hmmm!  I will never step foot into this place, go next door people.  Wooden Charcoal offers dessert & soup on the house with friendly service, can't beat it.
author: Christine R.

description:
Such a fan of this spot!  There aren't too many good Korean restaurants in SF that serve tofu soup so having this little piece of heaven in the Richmond District is great!  

I love coming here after a long day of work with the normal crappy SF weather and a bowl of tofu soup can turn that frown upside down!  We normally order Tofu soup, Veggie pancakes and a meat BBQ.  Their food is very consistent and you receive quality LARGE portions.  I leave completely stuffed all for about $40, which can probably feed 3 people, EASILY!  

They have the same servers and they're always very quick and polite.  The second you sit down you're instantly served with tea, iced water and all their yummy side dishes (unlimited dishes btw!)

The problem with this spot is that since there are so few quality Korean restaurants, there's usually a wait so prepare to put your name on a list and patiently wait for yummy goodness!
author: Sandy L.

description: While I had last rated this place a 3 star, since then, I have gone back at least 3 times. That being said, if I didn't rate it a 4 star, I would have to admit that I've been going to an "o-kay" restaurant on multiple occasions, on my own accord. I think this place is comfortable, friendly, and the soft tofu soup is good. Price is a bit steep but the side dishes are probably worth it. It has become my go-to place. My Tofu House, I appreciate you and I'm sorry I gave you a 3-star rating when we first met.
author: Vicki T.

description: The food was good but the service was terrible. Our server was very rude - he asked me to "take our your spoon" with a super arrogant face when he was serving the rice. Also, we didn't finish the food since we were too full. When the server came to clean up the table he was talking to another server in Korean (probably thinking that we wouldn't understand). But we actually do and he was basically complaining about the fact that we didn't finish all the food. Wow what is this? Racism?
author: Lacey L.

description:
Where do we go on a cold, windy SF evening? Let's get something hot (temperature and spice-wise)! Actually, mama always knows best... sorry, dads. She picked this spot for the "heat" and knowing parking wouldn't be too bad (as long as you get there before 6:30 pm). One of the most common complaints in eating Korean cuisine is that you go home selling like dinner. Not here, since all of the cooking is done in the kitchen. Here's what we ordered for a party of four: 

Original Tofu with chicken (not spicy - dad's choice) - Bubbling hot crock filled with soft tofu, chicken chunks, mushrooms, and seaweed... add a raw egg and watch it cook. Think chicken broth soup with the above. 

Combination Tofu (mild - didn't want to go overboard) - Bubbling hot crock with soft tofu, two or three prawns, beef, mushrooms, clams, and seaweed... again adding a raw egg. This had a subtle kick and, like the above, is great with rice. 

Kalbi - Hot platter of marinated short ribs on a bed of onions that grill as it sits on the hot plate. Hearty plate for the meat lover (my brother). Nice flavor and great with rice. 

Dak Gui - Hot platter of marinated boneless, lean chicken meat on a bed of onions. Nice flavor again and... I'm beginning to see a pattern, great with rice. 

Banchan - We were given six different appetizers consisting of Kim Cheer, spicy radish, marinated bean sprouts, marinated cucumbers, marinated little silver fishes (not the bugs), and grilled king fish. I'm not big on the fishy ones, but my parents made up for me. 

Rice - Served in a black iron pot, topped with peas and ginkgo nuts. After they empty the pot, they add tea into the pot to soften the crusty bottom which are nice for second servings. 

Tofu Salad - Four firm tofu cakes are served on a bed of iceberg lettuce, julienne carrots, sliced mushrooms, and corn niblets in a tangy vinaigrette dressing. 

I like this meal for its variety of flavors, from sour to sweet to savory to spicy. We arrived shortly after 6 pm and were fortunate to be seated in an extra dining area closer to the kitchen, as the line grew. Be sure to put your names and party # on their waiting list. The service is very homey and nice as there are basically three people working the floor (orders, serving, and busing). It was nice that a waiter remembered us and served the tofu salad as a bonus to our meal (we didn't order it). By the time we left at 7:30 pm, the line was out the door. They are definitely doing something right and it's certainly not a secret.
author: Mike C.

description:
Very tasty food!  We had the beef ribs and they were very tasty.  I like the ribs so I had to get two plates for myself.  The little dishes you get are also very good.  I recommend trying the fish, it's very flavourful.  
I will be coming back soon.
author: Just J.

description: I rarely write reviews, but this place was disappointing. Food was ok, but expensive, and the service was horrible. Over 25 dollars for a pancake that didn't even taste that great. And when we asked for extra side dish refills, the wait staff was hesitant and slow to refill for us. And after that, they never came back around. We had to wave them down twice for more tea refills. For the price they charge, they should be able to have more wait staff. It seemed to me this place is interested in making money and less about providing quality food and service. I will not be coming back. Totally overhyped and not worth it.
author: Mar C.

description:
I liked my #1 spicy tofu soup and I love tofu, but I just needed more broth. I came in expecting a kimchee stew much like the soups at Arang on Fillmore, only with much more tofu. The tofu soup here has much more tofu than soup, so just be prepared for that! It arrives boiling and with several Korean staple side dishes you can munch on as the soup simmers down. I love how you can order it as spicy as you please, and the menu is rather basic so you can trust they do tofu really well. Their tofu very light, smooth and pillowy (though Yelp spell-check suggests that's not a word).

If they offer you a table in the back room behind the curtain, don't take it. There are three tables and the waiter only periodically came back to check on us, so the meal dragged on a little longer than it should have. At times, I thought they forgot about us back there.

One more thing: nothing goes better with spicy Korean food than a cold Hite beer. Contrary to what this Yelp page says, they do not serve alcohol. My Tofu House, get on that!
author: Chelsea P.

description: Tofu soup was good. But stick with that because our party ordered the bulgogi beef and chicken and it was so salty! The bimbimbap was alright. Nothing amazing here..
author: Vivian L.

description: This place was very good, great for a large table sharing.  Bummer there is no alcohol allowed!  Overall, very good.
author: Emily W.

description:
one of my favorite places in SF -- stumbled on this place after shopping on geary for grocery. there was a 20 minute wait.

dumpling tofu casserole is amazing, order moderately spicy. Great balance of tastes, with perfect thickness of the dumpling skin and yummy filling. I tried other casserole (beef tofu casserole) and dumpling one is absolutely the winner (and the recommendation of the waiter).

best value in town -- free little korean dishes before the main dish. If SF didn't have so many great restaurants, I would be coming here every week!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Came here two days in a row! Its so good there must be crack in this food!

I L0VE the seafood soon do boo + dumplings!!! ( 3X SPICY....OMG SO FULL OF FLAVOR!)
I L0VE the kal bi gui!! (except picking off the bone...boneless some day??)
I L0VE the bul go gi ! (SO SWEET)
I L0VE the BBQ Chicken ( SO SWEET!)

The kimchi and cucumber sunomono were good!! And I got a stick of gum after to get the taste out of my mouth. 

The only reason it gets one less star from 5 is because I think they are understaffed(...or something) and they don't like to give water. They first bring you tea. I don't like tea and wanted water...and a lot of it because i love the spicy soup.

Other than that..this is a MUST! I will drive 3 + hours to get it again.. in fact I just got back from SF... but i AM willing to drive back right now for MY TOFU HOUSE!
author: Samantha H.

description: I've been here over three times. Really like the spicy soup. (Actually just looks spicy).
author: Ruo W.

description:
My favorite place to get Korean in the city, and I can be pretty picky when it comes to Korean food.

- Great selection of banchan, including a fried croaker!

- Get the tofu soup. Make sure to eat it with the egg cracked in, and spooned over rice like it's meant to be eaten :)

- More limited selection of dishes than compared to other Korean restaurants, which I accept as a quality over quantity thing.

- Unless you come at a weird time, expect at least a 15 min wait. They don't take reservations.
author: Christy W.

description:
I'm sick of sick reviews, so this one will be the last.
Day six - the cough may sound horrible but at least I'm not contagious (well, I don't think I am).

The first time I came here, I was rather disappointed.  I haven't had a lot of soon do bu but considering all the accolades this place received I expected something tastier than a watery bowl of tofu.

We recently found ourselves around the neighborhood and cautiously gave it another try - it also helped that we were famished.
There's something to be said about making the most of your second chances and My Tofu House came through in a big way this time around.

My spicy kimchi soon do bu was awesome - the rich red broth was tasty and packed some serious heat.
The wife experience the same satisfying flavor with her beef soon do bu and appreciated the generous serving of tofu.

Overall, I enjoyed my meal and won't hesitate to come back.  My only warning is the service can be suspect.   But when you consider only one person is taking care of the whole place, I guess it was understandable - in short, try to be patient.
author: Dan B.

description: It's all about the soondubu here.  The soup broth is the best I've tasted.  My go-to is the dumpling, mild spicy because I'm weaksauce.  I love that the ban chan comes with the little fried fish--fun to pick at while waiting for your food to arrive.  There's always a line, but it moves fairly quickly.  Service is always pretty good too.  And like most Korean bbq/tofu spots, you'll leave smelling like food...delicious food.
author: Thi D.

description: This place is great!  The fact that we get a small grilled fish with the rest of our banchan is awesome!  The food was really good and I requested a super hot pot for my bibimbap and it was great!
author: Edgar C.

description:
The food is very good but overly expensive. The wait on a Saturday at 7:30PM was about 20 minutes which isn't bad. The banchan here was some of the best I've ever had if only the place wasn't so pricey! The service could definitely use a fix. There's three waitresses serving like 14 tables yet we couldn't get service when we needed it. At some point we got aggressive trying to wave them down for water, to order, etc and they probably got annoyed. The bulgogi and short ribs were flawless but small for the $24 portion you pay; there's like 12 pieces total so you're paying $2 for each short rib - ridiculous!... Tofu soup was definitely to die for (in my eyes). The waitress gave us our check when we were not done and when we requested refills for water, she asked "Aren't you guys done?" and looked at us with confusion. In total, it costed about $20 per person. When we finished and was ready to go, one of my friends went to the bathroom and when he came out, the waitstaff glared him down. 

Good food, too pricey, I'd rather go to an AYCE KBBQ place that also serves complimentary tofu soup (It will probably cost you the same price). Oh, and the service. Oh my god. Please fix something, maybe they were all having a bad day but seriously, I felt like an outcast while eating!
author: Ryan L.

description: The price was way too expensive for what it was. Their food was only mediocre. $35 for bulgogi and tofu with a few sides; they didn't even include the pancake. I've been to all you can eat restaurants in LA that was cheaper and tasted much better.
author: Alice D.

description:
I was craving for some bimbimbap and was in the neighborhood and decided to check this place out on a weekday.  We were quickly seated, but it took a while for waiters to take our order.  Looking at the menu, the food was a bit pricey, but figured the quality of food would make up for it.  My husband and I were looking forward to the banchan, but when it arrived, it was a bit sparse.  The only new item I've never seen in a banchan was the fish.  The kimchi tasted watered down.  We ended up ordering the beef and pork bimbimbap and the seafood combo pancake.  The bimbimbaps were filling (egg, vegetables, meat,and rice).  However, the pancake was a bit bland that we would dip it into the "soy sauce" to give it extra flavor.

The annoying thing about this place was the service.  We had to request ice water at least four times until we finally got two cups.  We practically asked every server (only 3 on that day for some weird reason), but it took forever to get the water.  By the time we left, they were down to two servers...and it wasn't even 8pm yet!   Basically, the servers were doing everything, from bussing tables to serving the patrons.  By the time we left, there were a lot of people waiting to be seated.  I'm not sure if I would come back to this place for bimbimbap after this annoying experience.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Used to come here almost every week during my school days. Some things haven't changed, some have.

The tofu soup is still very tasty. Good flavor and the tofu was a good consistency. The stone pot rice was very good.

Prices have really gone through the roof. Yes I know we are in a recession and  my memory is probably playing tricks with me, but the prices go up, up, up every time I come here. I remember when the tofu was around $6 and the bbq plates were all under $10. 

Everything is still pretty good, it just makes me long for the days when the place wasn't packed all the time and the prices more reasonable.
author: Dom L.

description:
Ahh it breaks my heart to give a Tofu House 3 stars, but such was my experience, and I gotta keep it real.

Ambiance: Cute place!! The decor is nice. We were seated in a small room with only 3 other tables because the place was so busy, but that didn't really detract from my experience.

I had high expectations for this place, and it was definitely decent soondubu, but I am a soondubu fiend. While it was good, there was something about the beef soondubu I wasn't impressed with. I think it was missing an extra pang of flavor. Maybe I was being too critical, but I didn't enjoy it as much as other places...It was also pretty pricey.

We also ordered the veggie pancake because we were super hungry, but that tasted sort of bland and not only did we not finish it, we didn't want to box it either.

Also, the side dishes didn't have the cool Korean potato things or fish cakes. Those are my favorite :(

I want to give this place another try, but for the time being, unless I have an automobile to get over there, would not be worth my time on public transpo.
author: Adele Z.

description:
I went with some friends because we felt like korean food. This place is pretty popular because it is authentic but I think the popularity drove up the price a bit. I think if you are just getting tofu soup, it's pretty good. However, if you want anything else, you might want to go elsewhere because there is no tofu soup/meat combinations. I got the spicy pork to share with my brother and the meat was in little small pieces but the marinate was good.

Definitely come here for the Tofu soup but the side dishes and other food is just okay.
author: Pin X.

description:
San Francisco's version of BCD Tofu House

Food is solid, the rare soon-dubu I get that I order extra-spicy and it comes out extra-spicy.

The tofu soup also comes with complimentary fried fish which is a great starter.

I would give four stars but it's kind of pricey (tofu soup at $11) - if I'm driving out to inner richmond I shouldn't be paying downtown prices
author: Noah P.

description:
There's sometimes a wait, but worth it. Authentic Korean food, but the tofu soup is their specialty. They also added the Korean pancake to the menu - awesome! I wish they served chop chae too though. Lots of side dishes like fried fish, cucumbers, and kimchi to hold your appetite until the real food gets there. The place is a bit small and not good for large groups. Service is friendly, but sometimes you might have to flag them down to refill things. Nonetheless, one of my favorite places in the city for Korean food.

- Kalbi: yummmmmmy, flavorful, and the onions soaked in the oil underneath are good too
- Seafood & Beef Pancake: a little too doughy, but not bad

I've been coming here for years. I remember when it used to be a hot-pot place before it was My Tofu House. Then there were the little old ladies working and every time my friends and I went, they would fill up my friend's bowl with extra rice and said you need to eat more because she was so skinny. Hahaha memories .  . .
author: Linda C.

description:
Combination tofu soup - flavorful broth, but lacking a lot meat/seafood.  Add a bit more and I'll be a happy camper. 

Loved the fact that for one of their banchans, they provide a small fried fish.  Kimchi wasn't so great.

10.00 for soup + banchan = delicious food and its better for your wallet =)
author: Kathy N.

description: I'm honestly surprised this place has so many reviews. The food was good, but just average. It didn't really taste any different from the other Korean places I've been to. Reviews also mentioned the sides being refilled, but that wasn't the case for my table. For the price (especially for dinner), I don't know if I'd go back again.
author: Michelle H.

description:
this place serves the soondaboo i judge all other soondaboos by.  it is my all time fave.  i have been searching and searching around hawaii for an equal and no place lives up!  

i always get the dumpling soondaboo, spicy and it comes with dumplings and rice cake in it!  YUM.  i also like that they give you an egg (which i've started to realize doesn't just come automatically at all soondaboo places!).  

i went for lunch with a friend last week and we split the soondaboo and an order of bulgogi.  there was actually a surprising amount of meat that came with it.  it also came with lots of yummy side dishes (though i do prefer the ones at tofuhouse in socal).  they give you some weird ones (fishy things) that i am not korean-at-heart enough to enjoy.  :P  

cons:  location is far (you need a car), parkings not ideal, service can be slow if it's crowded, and they serve warm tea water (i prefer ice water with my hot soondaboo!  i'm sure i could have asked but i'm always scared to ask for things at korean places for fear of being scolded/yelled at :P ). 

despite those things, every time i'm in SF i try to go here!
author: Sara H.

description: So four years later, updating my Yelp review. The tofu soup is still as good as it was. But I am only giving this a 3 stars now due to the very slow service. Arrived at 6pm on a Sunday night, there were 3 of us, ordered 3 tofu soups. Two servers and maybe 2-3 empty tables that have not been cleaned/bused. The wait was over 30 minutes for food after we order, cold dishes didn't get to the table for a good 20 minutes after we order. They got my order wrong and forgot our beverage that we ordered. Just not sure if they were understaffed that day or was it because they've got newer servers? Wouldn't recommend coming here if you have time constraints......
author: MissJ J.

description: It is a good restaurant, Korean food is my favorite. But I recommend dining in rather than taking out. The food will taste better when is hot.
author: Gong L.

description: This is my go-to Korean BBQ restaurant in San Francisco. The original tofu soup is so clutch on a cold day!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Located so close to Chinatown! After a long and cold morning in the streets of Chinatown I'm glad we seeked refuge through the tunnel and ended up at My Tofu House! Usually this place gets really packed around lunch time so my friends and I decided to go ~11:30 while most people were still in church so we'd beat the crowds. When noon came we were happy we did because the line ended up winding around entrance to past our field of vision.

The moment I walked into to secure a spot for lunch, a waiter quickly found me a booth and before I even got a chance to look through the menu my tea was in front of me! As my friends filtered in each one had their cup of tea within moments of being seated, very attentive if not scary-quick service.

Naturally since we were at a tofu house, I ordered the pork tofu soup, medium, my gf got the kalbi because it seemed like a large portion for ~$12 and our friends shared a bibambap. As we waited of course, we were served side dishes that varied from bean sprouts, daikans, anchovies, fish cakes and each of us got a deep fried mackerel. Each side dish was very refreshing and definitely helped prep us for our lunch. The mackerel also really surprised me! Personally I had always had trouble eating them because I couldn't peel them well. My friends laugh as they explain you can eat the fish with the skin on! It was delicious and made devouring the fish so much easier!

As our food arrived you could smell each of our respective dishes as they smoked and sizzled on their way to our table. I felt almost bad that the people in line were only feet away from us, but the early bird gets the worm right!? My tofu soup was like most, really flavorful and really warmed my core, but what stood out with this particular restaurants tofu soup was that they had more tofu present that I've ever had in this dish, which was a great surprise for me personally. Since tofu does a really good job absorbing the broth its in, each bite was as incredible as the last. My gf's kalbi was also really well cooked, with slight char on the outside yet still noticeable juicy on the inside. 

The only downfall of our trip here was that we had first thought for lunch the kalbi was $12; however, because it was a Sunday all entree dishes are automatically dinner prices, so we ended up paying $22 for the dish, which after finding that out, didn't make the portion to price ratio that appealing. Perhaps we missed a notice, but we looked at the menu before over many times, so maybe it wasn't posted well enough? Not pointing fingers though, because all our dishes and the service made our experience here very fun and memorable; we're sure going to try this place again, and but we'll definitely be on the look out for edited prices!
Sundays = automatic dinner prices!
author: Jon K.

description:
From the exterior, the place looks like it should have more seating than they do. There's almost always a line, but it's worth every minute of the wait. The menu isn't as vast as some other Korean establishments so most parties are in and out.

Good to order:
Tofu soup
Vegetable pancake
Bibimbap
BBQ plates

Yeah, I listed almost all of the stuff on their menu. You can't really go wrong here. I only wish they served alcohol. A part of me only associates Korean food with beer and/or soju.
author: Dennis L.

description: One of the best place for Tofu soup in SF. There isn't much Banchan to offer and their BBQ is decent. If you are craving for tofu soup, best place in the Richmond District.
author: William C.

description:
Pros
Good food
Good service
Clean

Cons:
20 minute wait in line
expensive
lots of young people
author: Christina G.

description:
After visiting My Tofu House twice now, I can say it's pretty darn good! The first time I visited was when my friend brought me here, who had a recommendation from a family member. The service is friendly here, and luckily I didn't have to wait on my recent trip since it was pretty late in the evening.

They only give you a few appetizers here, but at least they give you the fried fish, which I love - and the rest of the appetizers are good and staples. The Soon Dobu here is pretty good and solid. Haven't really been to any other Korean spots in the city since I'll always head to El Camino for Korean fare, but My Tofu House is good. Definitely my choice in SF for Soon Dobu, unless you tell me of a better place!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I go here whenever I feel fat.
Never can go wrong with their stew.
Fresh tofu stew with seafood is my favorite here.
The service is fast and price is right.
author: Nick C.

description: Four stars for the excellent soon dubu at My Tofu House. My mom loved hers with fish egg, and for the same cost as all other combinations, it was definitely a good deal. Didn't like the chicken in mine though. Chicken wasn't seasoned well, and I prefer white meat over dark. I wouldn't order anything other than the soon dubu here. Not as crazy about their bibimbap or bulgogi.
author: Sophia B.

description: Good! Not impressed with lack of side dishes. Pretty authenic but nothing compared to LA
author: Alison W.

description:
3.5 stars.

Came for an early dinner on Friday night and there was no wait but from what I could see all the tables were full. We were seated in the small room in the back with 2 other tables. Sorta awkward because the room is small and its very quiet but hey I'd rather sit there than wait. 

The menu was very limited but they had quite a few good selections for their tofu soups. We ordered the spicy pork, kalbi and tofu soup with kimchi. The server brought out the banchan and again not a big variety and they didn't have fish cake boo! But it was alright they did provide a freshly fried mackerel? and it was actually really tasty. Shortly after dish after dish started appearing and we stuffed ourselves silly. Food was alright - not the best and not the worst. I thought the service however was outstanding. 

I'm still on my quest for good Korean food in the City. Nothing comes close to LA Korean food that I've found yet.
author: Julie F.

description:
09.27.11

No wait on a Tuesday!  Service was slow, but the servers are very nice and friendly.

A tofu soup and a bulgogi will run you almost $40.  Kind of crazy talk, no?
author: Jenny L.

description: Did not like it. None of my friends did. Tofu House(no relation) in Millbrae is better. I ordered the same thing as I do at Tofu House and My Tofu House let me down. The food was bland and the wait was too long.
author: Tina T.

description: I've been to tofu houses before and this place is good if you're having a craving. I had the tofu with both seafood and beef and both were pretty good.The bibimbap with beef didn't really stand out. I love side dishes and they were all alright. My favorite was the fried fish which was perfectly salted.
author: Jaclyn N.

description:
This place is one of my favorites in the Aves. The Yellow Croakers' that come with most meals rock! Those little crunchy super flavorful Minnie-fish in a bowl of their own amongst all the other little bowls full of really great stuff totally rock too. I really like the style of cooking here. All ingredients taste really fresh - always.

The wait staff are on top of it and fill your tea, water, check on you, ....very pleasant experience being served by these people; they clearly want to provide excellent service but are really cool about it, not intrusive hopping all round your table annoying you. They are  there when your cup is almost empty, there when your food hits your plate in the kitchen and out to your table with it, back in a bit for a check-up, straight-up great service.

Parking can be a bit of a drag in the area but it is worth it to be patient and just cruise around the block a few times and then you turn the corner, again, and there it is - your very own parking spot waiting for you,... Tofu House, here I come!
author: Daniel G.

description: Really good Korean restaurant. Very good food. A bit waiting though if you come late.
author: madeline m.

description: I had a wonderful dinner at My Tofu House. I came there after a long day of work with my friend. We came there on Saturday evening. There has plenty of tables. We were seated immediately. It filled up very fast. The food was delicious, service was also very good. We ordered tofu soup, kalbi and seafood pancake. The tofu soup came with a smoked croaker and an egg. It was amazing and really flavorful. I couldn't stop taking the tofu and soup, and I mixed it with my rice.  The meat was also very yummy but I expected them to give a little more quantity. It was presented on a sizzling pan, so it was and juicy. The seafood pancake was pan fried nicely and generously filled with seafood. It tasted really amazing. We had their banchan which was also great. Their kimchi was extra saucy and tasted great. It was my favorite of the night. I think the meal was perfect for two people. The prices are affordable. I didn't have many items, but based on this experience, I would definitely come back, and I am excited to try the rest of the menu. All the food tasted very good and delicious. I love there. We felt comfortable with everything.
author: Yu H.

description: Had a good experience overall.  Beat the long wait that came right after us.  Didn't wait long for food, and the bulgogi and tofu soup we're both satisfying.  A little pricey, but tofu houses usually are.
author: Chinito G.

description:
Decent Korean restaurant with decent food. Nothing is exceptional, but they do tofu soup right. The banchan wasn't as good as I remember it being and there didn't seem like there was many of them. Our kimchi had a metallic taste to it and were sliced very largly... odd.

I had the kimchi tofu soup and it was good. The kimchi just turns into cabbage in the soup because the flavors go into the soup. The gf had the dumpling tofu soup. Think packaged Ling Ling's in tofu soup. The spiciness levels were spot on for medium and mild.

I don't know if I want to come back to this place. It's not quite good, but it's not quite bad. I'll have to try other Korean Restaurants out first. My only other experience is Tofu VIllage on Irving, and I like that one better so far.
author: Timothy L.

description:
That night was those one night that I can go out at night and I came here.  I would't come here in a million years if my friend didn't drag me here.  It was kinda like a birthday dinner for her and she chose this place.   We got there at around 8pm and waited and waited for more than an hour then finally, they sat us down.  By that time, I was starving.  This place is very busy but there were only one or two waiters serving the front of the restaurant.  I think I got the original beef tofu soup, mild.  When it first came, i though the bowl was small and you only get one bowl of rice? That's nothing.  But I was really full after, so I was wrong about that.  Mild is not that spicy but you would feel it really spicy because it is hot, very hot.  The soup burnt my tongue and I felt awful the next morning. So take it slow and it will be much better.  

Pretty good food, might come back again, slow waiters, comfy.
author: Lily L.

description: So poor!!!! I really hate the service they served us today. We are visiting San Francisco, we don't know what to eat, so we wanted to eat at My Tofu House because we used to eat Irvine. But we didn't expect what the waiter did to us. We are costumer, he should talked to us in nice way, not by just throw the menu to us. We just walked out of the restaurant without say any thing. And we won't go, nor recommend any of my friends to go there again.
author: Rotana L.

description:
I LOVE the food from here, HATE the lines! There is always such a HUGE wait for this place because the food is soooooo good here! The free appetizers rock my world!! The service is pretty bad because they are so busy but it's totally understandable...

Come here if you are a fan of GOOD KOREAN FOOD!!! :)
author: Amiee H.

description:
Picked up beef and veggie bebimbap to go -- unfortunately, it's not cooked in the iron pot and thus doesn't have the crunchy rice.  Comes with a whole wrapped dried fish and a selection of kimchee banchan. Make sure to get the melon gum to cap it off!

While waiting for our lunch, the waiter served us barley tea. Quite hospitable.
author: Vanessa H.

description: I ordered tofu with kimchi soup which is standard, and sizzled pork with garlic in hot pot which is ok. Overall,not bad. Service is OK.
author: Obert C.

description: Fabulous!  The food is just fantastic.  My friend & I split the pancake and we still had enough leftover for another meal.  I cannot say enough good things.  Go.There.NOW.
author: Michele M.

description:
This place is down the street from my house so I come here once in awhile. I think it's a little overpriced so that's why I don't come more often. 

I normally get the seafood tofu soup or the beef bibimbap. Both are delicious. I love, love, love the korean side dishes and they give plenty of them. They also have no problem giving you seconds/thirds on them either. 

The menu is limited to mainly tofu soup and bibimbap. There's a small selection of meat, but this place IS called My Tofu House. If you want a wider selection of dishes, go elsewhere. The wait staff are all Korean, sometimes I have trouble asking for stuff but whatever, the food is good and they are nice. That's all the matters.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
After reading the good reviews on Yelp, I decided to venture out to the Richmond to try My Tofu House.  Though our meal was good, I don't think it tops doobu's, which is our current go-to soon doobu place.

The banchan is good, but with very limited variety.  The rice comes out in a hot stone pot, but after the waiter scoops out your bowls he pours tea into the pot.  This was unfortunate for me because I *love* eating the crunchy bits of rice that get stuck to the pot.

The tofu comes out SUPER hot, still bubbling and boiling.  This will get you sweating!

Service was quick and attentive.  And with great hair.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Really?

I must be picky...

I think the place is decent, at best.  The prices are way too high, and can't compare to anything that they serve is SJ or LA.  The tofu soup is okay, but that is all.  The meats are pretty nasty, and I am not a fan of overpriced, bad food. 

I wish that there was a larger Korean population in SF, so that they would have actual competition.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This place was truly a disappointment. It was very expensive for the quality.  What I ordered:

Seafood pancake -the pan was too hot and it was burnt on the bottom by the time it got to us.  It was also mushy inside and had chunks of bell pepper. Weird. 

Bulgogoi - pan wasn't hot enough. No sear at all and the food was just warm. The meat seemed simmered instead of broiled.  We put this on the seafood pancake's plate to warm it up.

I didn't want my leftovers and nobody else who tried it wanted it either.
author: M H.

description:
*sigh* soon dobu.

I've been eating at My Tofu House for about 5 years now, and I never get tired of the dobu soup.  My cousin and I ate here last night, and rather than ordering the usual combo or mushroom soup, the dumpling soup caught my eye.  I ordered my soup spicy (over the years I've built up my tolerance to the spiciness of Korean food...it takes a lot for me to break a sweat these days..) as usual.  The soup came with 4 dumplings (which were just potstickers..probably purchased at the market next door), rice sticks (I was expecting dduk bok ki but they were just like...little balls) and beef.  My cousin ordered the kimchi dobu soup which came with mushrooms and beef.

We were brought our tea and ban chan and chatted while we waited for our food.  I was soo happy when the soup came!  My Tofu House is like a party in my stomach.  Crack one egg, mix it in and its a little bowl of heaven.  The staff came by and refilled our cucumber and bean sprout ban chan, and our tea a few times.  mmm...I want dumpling soup again as I type this.

Like I said, I've been coming here for over 5 years now, and I've never had a bad experience or anything bad to say about this restaurant.    I've tried about everything on the menu...the kalbi, bulgoki (which I don't particularly care for), chicken (LOVE this), spicy pork, bi bim bap....everything.  I have yet to try the pancakes, I'll probably knock that down the next time I eat here.  I've watched the prices slowly go up and up...they're pretty sneaky about it, they just add .50 every so often so you don't even notice!

Lunch time specials are a great deal, especially for the meat...even though the portions are a little smaller, the prices are fairly cheaper.
author: Steph D.

description:
Craving Korean BBQ and Soondubu before your big night out on the town - but don't want the smokey - "hey I just had Korean BBQ" scent on your clothes and hair. Well, hell hell... do I have a little gem for you. 

Here's a Johnny Gill inspired review for you. 

Put on that Red Sauce. 
Slip me some spicy kim chee.
And some of that tofu soup
It sure tastes good to me. 

Slide me that sho chu
Raise your glass to toast
Cause baby when you get through
You'll have food comatose!

Tonight will be a special night
As long as we eat here
And I'm so proud to dine with you
I just wanna let you know...

MY MY MYYYY... MY MY MY MY! 

MY Tofu House hooked it up tonight. And it sure tastes right!


Ronny, Bobby, Ricky  and Mike... Sing with me!
author: Stephanie I.

description: The wait was a bit long especially if you are taking a kid with you.  It took us 40 min or longer to eat and it was 2pm already.  The two waiters were moving non stop but apparently need more hands! No doubt the good wad really good (we were also starving so everything taste good!) .  We checked the store next to it and there were only two tables of people there.  It was the wait.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I'm a San Francisco girl at heart, but I have to say that when I moved back here from LA I went through a dark time of BCD Tofu House withdrawals. Would I ever find soondubu love in San Francisco?

Four years later, I'm proud to say that I've moved on. To be honest, I don't think it's as good as BCD or anything else in LA's Ktown, but it's pretty darn good. Get #6 - the dumpling soondubu, and you'll be a very happy camper.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
There's something that needs to be said when your hot stoned bimbimbap is still sizzling and crackling and your soondooboo is still boiling rapidly upon serving: "Hot damn - that's the shit!"

Other additional spot hitters: barely tea + the infamously delicious sides (bean sprouts, daikon, kimchee - really good!, the fish, cucumbers)

Soondooboo ~ $10.50ish
Bimbimbab ~ $14.50ish

Mmmm...:) So freakin gooood.
author: Gail N.

description:
blatant discrimination.  sure we dont have koreans in our party, but that doesnt mean that it's ok to skip over our party.  we were like 2nd in line and at least 2 parties of the same size who were after us got seated first.   also this party of 2 who was seated after us got their side dishes to come before ours.  

as for the food, it is blander than most korean places.   it is less spicy, less sweet, and less salty - but its at the same price as the other korean places.   the only thing that i would have thought was good was the pickled cucumber.   otherwise everything else was not too memorable.

i would not come back here again.  i would rather go to arang for cheaper and more tasty korean food or just go to toyose for the atmosphere/soju/super spicy foods
author: Tina A.

description: I had the soon tobu on a really cold night so it hit the spot but for the price and quality of side, I'd try other places around Inner Richmond before I came back. Nothing special.
author: Linda L.

description:
This place is definitely one of my favorite Korean BBQ places in SF. They're usually packed during dinner time and the wait may take 30 mins+. My tip is to get there before 5:30 to get ahead of the crowd. They have a wait list inside and a small waiting room. This place is a bit different from other Korean BBQ places where they let you BBQ your own meat. My Tofu House cooks it for you.

Their Kalbi, Bulgoki, and tofu soup are great. Definitely well worth a try. The meat are nicely marinated and they're soft and tender. They have a wide selection of tofu soup so whatever floats your boat. You can could how special the soup is, which range from mild to very spicy. Their bibimbab is well made and delicious although the meat dishes comes with white rice cooked in a stone pot.
author: Steven B.

description:
The BEST SOON DOBU (Tofu Soup) restaurant in the entire city!

I've been coming here since college (4...5 yrs now?) and am surprised that I haven't written a review!  (Altho I probs don't need to...hellza reviews...)  The banchan is minimal in quantity but the kimchi, bean sprouts, and sweet cucumbers are goooood...(the cucumbers help cool down the spice from the soup!)

The tofu soups apparently have levels...who knew?  I always just say spicy...but my friend asked for extra extra spicy...and the waiter asked "what level?"  HAH he said he had lvl 4 and was in the bathroom all morning the next day...so my friend got 5...it was hades.  Recommend 1 or 2 :P it's SPICY ENOUGH TRUST.  

Affordable, too!  Our bill came out to $21 for 2 tofu soups!  Plenty for 3 people :)  

Seriously, tho...when they say it's spicy (the levels I mean), truuust theeem...
author: Kat C.

description:
I love, love, love the soft tofu soup here. Came here for Sunday lunch today with friends after a night out, and left with full, happy bellies.

I ordered the beef tofu soup, medium spicy (a little over $10). While some tofu soups have veggies in it, this one has mushroom and lots and lots of tofu. I enjoyed its simplicity, and the medium spicy was the perfect amount of spice balanced with flavor. I glanced over at my friends' mild spicy tofu soups, which looked like they lacked flavor.

I liked that one of the banchan were salted mackerel, which were a nice and tasty complement to our meals. The rice also comes fresh from a hot pot, which I liked.

Service was attentive and we didn't have any problems with a wait at around 12:30pm. Gratuity was included in the bill, and I ended up paying $13 for the beef tofu soup after tax and tip. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Anita C.

description:
Went here for dinner right when they opened and it was full within 15 minutes!  

Service was good (never had to wait long for a water or tea refill, and they were quick to get us menus)

I got the dolsot bibimbap with mushrooms and vegetables.  It was delicious!  The banchan dishes were great and they brought us more when we ate all the kimchi and cucumbers (SO good!)

I would definitely go back.
author: Cate M.

description:
If you like TOFU, you've found your heaven.  Can't go wrong with any of the tofu soups; I prefer spicy!!!!!

The pork bibimbap is top notch .... 

The service is sometimes not so good.  They need to hire an extra wait staff!
author: Sassy G.

description:
My Tofu House lived up to the Yelp hype and my ridiculously high soondubu standards. I ordered the regular seafood version (will have to go back to try the fish eggs).  Piquant in both seafood flavor and spiciness. The banchan assortment here was not bad, albeit pretty pedestrian as far as the Korean food I've had goes. However, I must show love for the fried fish banchan, that's a new one! And the fresh rice w/ chickpeas and peas...I love it!

We also shared a bowl of steaming hot bibimbop, which was excellent. And I've had some bad bibimbop before. The beef was  well marinated, accented with a refreshing assortment of veggies. 

Main quibbles about this place are not food related - first, the wait! I guess that's the price of good food. We also waited way too long for our food. Second, the service! The main waiter we had was just...strange...it was like he was on another planet and took forever to give us our banchan or water. Then the waitress who brought the bibimbop out didn't bring out the red sauce, which is key to the full bibimbop experience. Or maybe it's not. Contrary to my obvious obsession with Korean food, I am not Korean. Anyway, when she did bring it, she took the liberty of doing the mixing for us...except she mascerated it as if it were her mortal enemy!  We must have said, "Um, that's fine..thank you" at least 3 times before she stopped. Maybe she had too much kimchee that day.

Anyway, I am sooooo happy that I have found a very local place to get my soondubu fix!
author: Steph P.

description:
My favorite Korean place in SF because of the Fish Egg Tofu soup. It's really hard to find Fish Egg Tofu soup and this is the only one I can find in SF. They also serve it bubbling hot as it's supposed to be, so that I can crack the raw egg and cook it in there. For the Fish Egg Tofu Soup, they get 5 stars!

Another good thing about this place is that they have whole fried fish (one for each person) as part of the appetizers, along with kimchi and all the other good stuff. The bad part is that this place is quite expensive. Daeji Bulgogi, Kalbi, those meat dishes cost about $20 here whereas most every other Korean places will price it at about $12-14. However, they are really good and tasty. 

The only dish I would not recommend here is the Seafood pancake. It's not crispy enough and maybe even undercooked cause it is just too wet inside.

Service is really fast and also the waiters are very polite. And ever since they have that back room, I have never waited longer than 10 minutes to be seated, even on a Saturday night.
author: July N.

description:
I don't know what others were talking about, but maybe my taste buds are damaged. When I ask for spicy I want it REALLY SPICY!!! I even told the waiter really spicy "10" on a scale of 1-10. In addition to tofu I also had the bulgogi which was ok. The bulgogi would have been perfect had it not tasted a bit bland. All in all the food was good and had decent portions. 

We were seated promptly, but the service was slow. Good tofu, but not great tofu. It's hard to find a really good tofu place around here, especially in the East Bay. We ended up eating here before the Yelp elite event at RF80, so if I smelled a bit funky you know why (or perhaps I just always smell funky).
author: Steven T.

description:
I feel bad for strict Meat Eaters Of America (there must be some association or lobbying group). Because if you are aren't willing to swing both ways and sample vegetarian on occasion, you are missing out. Especially at My Tofu House.

The first thing I noticed when walking in was the line. It's Monday night, not that warm, middle of the holidays, and there is a line. Always a good sign.

Fortunately it didn't take long, and within 15min we were seated. My friend and I were of the same mindset - a clay pot boiling with soft tofu and seafood. His was spicy, mine was mild, both were boiling. Both looked awesome.

Following his lead, I cracked my egg into the pot and let it cook while we enjoyed the complementary complimentary kimchi side dishes. Soon it was time to dive it. Each tofu packed spoonful was divine. So light, so healthy, so perfect.

We were out the door for about $12 each, a steal considering the amount of food. Judging from the line, we are not the only ones to think so. Perhaps the last thing we need are members of MEOA adding to the wait. Their loss is definitely our gain.
author: Jason B.

description:
My Tofu House is a small Korean restaurant located on Geary. Most of their seating is inside booths that can either sit 4 or 6, so it is definitely a nice place to grab Korean food with your close family or friends. 

I've been to this restaurant for a few years now and they have always met my expectations. I usually order their Dumpling Tofu Soup and everything in that pot tastes so flavorful! Btw, if you're like me and you don't like to eat spicy, still go for the mild. The not spicy ones does not taste like anything, and mild is really not that spicy. They also have a decent selection of side dishes (2 fried fishes, anchovies?, bean sprouts, cucumber, kimchi...and maybe more, I don't remember). Their Galbi is also very delicious.

In general, service is very friendly. If you come during lunch on the weekday, you should be able to grab a table pretty easily. If you come at night, that's another story, especially if it's on a weekend!! I think the longest I've waited in line was probably about 30 minutes. But I think it's worth the wait!
author: Selina T.

description:
I LOVE MY TOFU HOUSE

It truly has become my tofu house. Everytime I come back home for breaks and hang out with friends, I always suggest this place. The servers here very attentive, cater to all your needs, and are easy on the eyes. ;]

You get a ton of yummy appetizers with anything you order. I usually get the #2, Original Soft Combination Tofu Soup, mild. I have tried medium (one step above mild) and all I can taste is the medium-level of spiciness! I finish off my meal with sucking the delicious soft tofu soup juices out of the shrimp heads, which I save for last.

I should apply to this place.
author: Esther A.

description: I'll have the say before sitting down to do this review that I was contemplating equating them BCD.  Which, is a huge complement.   Just go.....unless you have an extremely off day, you won't be dissapointed.
author: Dude D.

description: Just okay. Enjoyed the banchan and stone pot rice. The beef tofu soup medium spicy was pretty bland. The spicy pork bulgogi needed more marinade and sauce. Expected better from the reviews.
author: Pearl L.

description: The bim bim bop is delicious and the ramen tofu soup is amazballs. This is my go to place for Korean food in the city. There is usually a wait so don't come starving.
author: Joanne H.

description:
5 stars 
- tofu soup
- Bibimbab (BBQ beef with veggies)
- the condiment plates
- excellent service
- good food for the soul 

4 stars 
- i cant handle the spiciness!! 
- too much rice

The original plan for yesterday was to have lunch at Tofu Village on Irving because David and I didn't want to drive but they were close on Sunday. I didn't want to eat anywhere on Irving because i was craving for tofu soup so we ended going to My Tofu House instead. Thank goodness, Tofu Village was close because i left My Tofu House happy and satisfied.

My Tofu House probably has no more than a few items on their menu but you can't go wrong with ordering any of them. I ordered the Bibimbab (BBQ beef with veggies) and their tofu soups are hearty. All of the rice is steamed to perfect individually, which is a favorite and the soup comes boiling at the table. Be careful when deciding the level of spice for your soup; the "hot" is REALLY hot. 

Even though out meal came out to $25.00 even, we left a hefty tip because our waiter kept coming by to our table to refilled our tea and also provided second and third helpings of kimchi. i wish i requested cold water because by the end of my meal, i couldn't stop sniffing due to the spiciness of my food. 

thank you! :) :)
author: Carol Y.

description: The tofu soups and bulgoki is so good here. The wait can be long at times during dinner. The prices did go up a little. The side dishes are not bad too. They don't serve alcohol but they do have sodas. This place is always great for those cold winter days.
author: Jennie W.

description: BBQ short ribs are delicious! They said that it's best to come here for lunch cause the price is cheaper than dinner & it's about the same amount of food. Decor is kind of plain. But yeah.. Loved the short ribs. :D
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend.

I ordered the Combination Soft Tofu Stew with beef, clam, and shrimp. Either i didn't order it spicy enough but it tasted bland to me. Wasn't really satisfying at all. I actually forgot how their sides tasted like as well...
author: Darnell L.

description:
My absolute to-go spot for Korean food.  Perfect to have a meal here on a cold night.  Every time I crave hot soup on cold weathers, I always think of this place!

I'd probably say they have one of the best tofu soups in the city!  I loooove their soup!  My boyfriend and I come here often, but we usually come with friends as well.  I always recommend this place whenever friends of mine come to the city and want to try Korean food.  

I've been to other places as well.  Sure, their meats and appetizers are all the same, but it's the SOUP that needs to stand out.  This place definitely stands out to me.  I will never give up my loyalty to this restaurant on their tofu soup!
author: Nancy S.

description:
I went to this place last Tues. I'd say this place is fine.

We ordered Kimchi Soft Tofu, Sliced spicy pork and spicy beef, Vegetable Pancake. These dishes  were decent good. 

The service was slow, only 2 people working on lunch time. One was good but another was slow.  Don't get me wrong, i work as a  restaurant business as well, and i thought it wasn't fair for another person to do all the work.  It's just my idea.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: The  was really good!!! I was a little surprised with the prices at first but my family was very satisfied in the end. It was good solid Korean food.
author: Annie S.

description: Delicious. Great tofu soup and Kalbi. I look forward to the complimentary fried fish with each dish ordered. I've been here numerous times but can't bring myself to order anything other than their seafood tofu soup and Kalbi--they're so good!!
author: Debbie N.

description:
To start, I don't consider myself a Korean expert, but I love My Tofu House.  Honestly, I love every dish in this restaurant.  The tofu dishes have a lot favor with a few unique selections such as the ramen, wonton.  Besides that, the rice is served in the very traditional hot stone bowl.  After scooping all of the rice, they pour a little water into bowl, so it becomes a crispy fried rice soup.  Yummy. (sorry that description wasn't useful).

The other choices that they provide is the bibimbap plates.  The favor is very rich.  I had this in other places, and they just don't put enough taste.  Like other bibimbap plates, the rice becomes a crispy fried rice, after you scrape the bottom and mix everything.  I know this place is called "My Tofu House", but this is honestly my favorite plates in this restaurant.  

Ambiance.  This place can be busy.  However, I feel the price, taste and quality combination is well worth it.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
I am not a fan of rants, so consider this a mini elucidation: Being a Vegas local, I read a lot of reviews that claim that everything tastes better in California, including sundubu. So, while in San Francisco, I had to see what I was missing in the world of sundubu. I landed here. Yelp was persuasive, but so was the "100 Places to Eat in SF Before You Die" feature.

The interior is cute in a 70s modern way, and it is clean. The servers were incredibly nice Korean guys who were more than happy to make change for the meters out front, which made parking a breeze too!

The soft tofu soup, i.e. sundubu, was a tad expensive at $10 and change, but I told my hub, "Hey, we're in San Francisco," and he thought the bowls were bigger than our Vegas haunts. At first taste, the sundubu did not blow me away, so perhaps I should have gone for hot instead of medium. The tofu was crumbly, not chunky, which did not bother me because the taste was good. Where this creation did shine was in vegetable inclusion. There were a variety of green things, including a turnip that was a welcome surprise. Plus, they serve dolsot rice, which I don't think they do anywhere in Vegas, a minor bonus, but I don't have to have the crispy stuff to enjoy my tofu soup.

Another cool thing was the variety of soup. Some came with dumplings; others with ramen. The variety was notable.

I gobbled up some quality, fresh banchan. The spread was for the most part standard fare, but it included two, little whole fish. I think the waiter said they were croaker. This is a neutral event for me, however, because I do not eat little whole fish. My husband said they were salty. 

Overall, I enjoyed My Tofu. I wouldn't say it left me with a desire to move to San Francisco to get my fix, but I'm a fan!
author: Misti Y.

description: Great food, great prices. The service can be lacking sometimes, but with the prices as they are, I'm not complaining. The only thing is, once out of 10 times, soondubu can be meh... Not sure what explains this. But the freshly cooked rice and banchan are always solidly delicious.
author: C S.

description: cute little place to have Korean food. I first heard about this place from 7x7. The side dishes are so tasty and if you want more feel free to ask for a refill (it's free)
author: Connie M.

description:
Yummy deliciousness Korean style in a bowl and on a plate.
This is one of the better Korean joints in SF compared to many of those in Oakland.
Nice selection of food, especially the hot pot ...recommended. 
I've been 3 times - 2 times they really hit the mark - and once they lost it on service and a missing order.
author: Maki T.

description:
oh MY TOFU HOUSE.. how thee filled my empty tummy with so much yummy goodness! I promise the next time I visit you (yes, there will be for sure a next time) I won't accidentally walk into your neighboring korean restaurant (korean village) at first thinking its you... I swear I was sober, you just all looked the same and I just followed my nose and the huge neon sign that said "KOREAN BBQ".... sorry.

Anyways, I ordered a chicken stoneware bibimbab (basically a HUGE rice bowl with meat or w/e you order in a stoneware bowl thats about the size of your head), spicy.

me: could I get it spicy please?
waiter: oh, SPICY? *makes a shocked face* for some reason
me: um, well spicy.. but, not super spicy you know?
waiter: hmm.. mild?
me: like, above mild?
waiter: hah okay, I'll just give you some more on the side then *thinks this girl is crazy while walking away*

so first they brough out an assortment of appetizer dishes and tofu soups while we waited for our food. I LOVED that they did this! they were awesome and made the wait seem not that long. then our bibimbabs came and they were deeelicious! the spicyness was exactly what I asked for, and I definitely felt the heat on my tongue. I didn't even have to use the extra chili they gave me :) the waiter was very very nice, and two of them were kinda cute too! I left this place happy and VERY satisfied!

*note, they did kinda mess up our table at first though.. my friend got there first and put us on the wait list and for some reason all the people after us got seated before us.. but then we figured it might be because he went outside to take a call and they might've called him during that time. the waiters were very nice about it and seated us immediately after we brought it to their attention. hence, no star off!
author: Jennie L.

description:
Service: Dependable, efficient. Quick seating, did not have to wait at 6pm on a weekday.

Atmosphere: Cozy, booth seating, relatively quiet.

Food: 
Complimentary: kimchi appetizers (sesame sprouts, kimchi, pickled cucumbers, anchovies, fried fish), hot tea, brown rice porridge for dessert, melon gum.
Menu: Bubbling hot tofu soup in cast iron pots. Choice of mild, medium, hot, and extra hot/ spicy (medium worked for me-- same level as kimchi). Lots of tofu with moderate amount of meat.  Also has vegetarian option with zucchini, carrots, onions and tofu. Comes with 3 bowls of white sticky rice (for 2 people). Brown rice usually not available.

$$: about $10 - $15 for tofu soup. 

Parking: street- hit or miss.

Perfect food at the perpetually overcast inner Richmond!
author: Debora L.

description:
one of the best Korean restaurant in SF. make sure to get hot tofu.
Service is decent and they serve food rather quickly, or at least give you side dishes first.
Make sure to sit not too far from register counter so you can get constant service. if you sit too far back or front of restaurant sometime you have to wait really long to get tea or check.
author: Scott B.

description:
I've been here so many times it's almost crazy. It's a very nice place with a good amount of seating. You get a lot of privacy with conversations and such because you the seating is blocked off from each other. I often order soft tofu soup. Their Bi Bim Bap is good as well, but I really do find myself loving the soup. Its very filling and you can choose how spicy you want it. I usually alternate between mild and spicy depending on what I feel like having. 
The mushroom soup and the kimchi soup are great and they have a good selection of ban chan to have with your rice. You of course can also ask for more of any type of ban chan and they'll gladly provide you with more since I know there are several places that don't do that.
The soups are always boiling hot so I know my egg will be fully cooked within minutes of putting it in. The tea is great and the rice has a nice sweet taste sprinkled with garbanzo beans. 
I'm definitely coming back and this is one of the best Korean restaurants I've tried in San Francisco.
author: Veronica L.

description: The medium spice is just right.  There's about 8 variety of soups.  I had the dumpling soft tofu soup.  The banchan comes with fried fish and that is very tasty.  The bimbibap was good.  This place is a bit pricey, but well worth it.  They have weak barley tea.  The servers get you in and out in 60 sec. (just kidding).
author: Helen L.

description:
My Tofu House is pretty good, and the tofu soup is what it should be. They use nice silky soft tofu, the soup base is flavorful and not overly salty, the small dishes are ok (bonus for giving grilled fish) and its just about what it should be in terms of food quality. Also the bulgogi is a little heavy on the ginger btw. Having said all that, I think this spot, altho good, is a little over priced and the wait is longer then is should be for this type of food. Tofu house and some other spots in the south bay offers equal or better tofu soup but I guess My Tofu wins the tofu soup title for SF at least, which isn't saying much. 

Enjoy!
author: Byron C.

description:
Meh. In all fairness, I was so disgusted that I couldn't give the actual food a fair chance. I was really craving Korean tofu soup and found this on Yelp. I called in my order for pick-up. I went with everyone's reco of the original tofu soup and ordered it spicy.

When I went to pick up my food, the woman who was helping me asked me if everything was okay... she was upset that I didn't leave a tip! I've never left tip for pick-up before??

Anyway when I got home, I took out my food and there was a whole fish packed in. I guess this is one of their side dishes (not sure?!) but it was so funky and stinky! I was completely disgusted and nearly lost my appetite. My entire apartment stunk up because of that thing. SOOOO GROSSSSS.

I eventually ate the soup. It tasted just ok... I've had better. But an hour later, I had the worst stomach ache. I eat a lot of spicy food and the soup wasn't even very spicy so that wasn't it. Just a really bad experience overall. Definitely won't go back.
author: Ghazaleh K.

description:
This is the best place to go when its freezing outside.  Not sure what kind of tofu they use in their tofu stew, but its so soft and silky and comes in big chunks...YUM!

The beef tofu stew was less than 10 bucks and totally hit the spot.  

You get fried fish for appetizer too.
author: Cindy C.

description:
It's hard for me to rate Korean restaurants because I've been to soo many good ones. I'm giving The Tofu House a 4-star because as a visitor to SF, I can see myself coming here regularly if I do live in SF. However, is it the best Korean restaurant ever? No, I've probably had similar ones back in Cleveland where I currently live.

With that said..

What I ordered: Seafood Soft Tofu (mild)
I loved it. There were oysters, clam, and shrimp. If I had a complaint on it though, it's that there aren't enough oysters/clams/shrimp in it. But the flavors were very very good that I really can't complain.

Side Dishes: I came here alone but I still got a good amount of food. I'd like to think that their side dishes do not have enough variety but it is good. I enjoy that they give a fish as a side dish.

PROs: super friendly staff, clean restaurant, nice environment, reasonable price

CONs: none really.

If you live in the area, you should definitely check this place out!
author: Funglin W.

description:
Been here twice because my friend lives right near it and she likes it, but after 2 times ordering different meat dishes I give up.  The meat is crappy quality.  BBQ pork was  .. . I can't pinpoint why it wasn't so good but I wasn't into it.  Second time I had chicken bimbimbap or whatever it's called, it was small pieces of dark meat and grisly fatty weirdo chunks, I couldn't eat it.  There just wasn't much n the way of quality ingredients.  It may be cheap but $14 for a few pieces of "shit chicken" and bowl of white rice with a few leaves of spinach tossed in isn't cheap to me.  I could get something much better for $14.  

Guess if you only eat tofu you might like it.  I avoid soy like the plague so I won't be eating anything here again.  Service is ok though.
author: Muriel D.

description:
Hits the spot on a foggy San Francisco night - especially starving after a 45min wait at 8:30pm.

Despite the long wait time (or perhaps partially because of it), I couldn't be happier with My Tofu House.  The food comes quick and fresh, the banchan is DELICIOUS (albeit a little basic), and the tofu is incredibly soft and just melts in your mouth.  My only regret tofu-wise is not getting the kimchi soft tofu soup - I went with my standard mushroom tofu.  The kimchi with beef is definitely better.

What blew me away the most though was the seafood korean pancake.  It came on a hot plate that crisped the pancake to a perfect crunch, hot until the moment you devour.
