The plate is so hot that when I cut into the pancake, a tiny piece of octopus fell off the to side and seconds latter popped from the heat and flew into my cup of water.  Didn't touch that again, but the pancake was amazing.

Slightly on the pricey side and a little out of the way, I probably wouldn't come here every week but would happily come here once every month or two when I'm in the area.
author: Judy L.

description:
Lots have been said about this place all I know is that it is great and delicious .. 

Anytime I have a Korean craving and I dont want to cook my own meal My Tofu house is where I go ... ( Brothers if I feel like BBQ) 

The service is very quick .. the sides are amazing and flavorful and I love love love the spicy tofu soup with ramen .. great texture and flavor ... Sides are delightful and every dish I have had has not disappointed ... 

Idk this place just does it for me .. even better on cold days
author: Anthony S.

description:
My favorite spot in the City for spicy soup.

It's often quite chilly here in the City, especially in these summer months of fog. My parents actually stumbled in accidentally before I even got to try it out. They went again on that trip, with me this time, and I was sold. I've since been back several times, each time trying a different soft tofu soup.

The spice can be a bit much, so I usually go with medium. The banchan dishes are sufficient, and the waitstaff will bring you more of something when you run out. My faves are always the marinated bean sprouts and kimchee. And I've generally encountered full houses whether for lunch or dinner, so I know the turnover must be quite good.

My Tofu House is for me!
author: Randy M.

description:
Went there on a saturday night.  Soon Doo Boo's not bad but is it worth 10 dollars a bowl?  Hmm.  I'd rather go to Mom's Tofu House in South San Francisco.  Their Bahn Chan is better and the soup's just as good.  

Strategy:  Drop off someone to put your name on the list first while you circle for parking.  Then while you wait go to one of the local bars to have a drink.  They serve no alcohol. 

They don't take AMEX either.
author: Gina K.

description: Food was good. I got the kalbi. It was $23, ouch. The issue was the service! Our waiter gave us tea when we sat down but never refilled it. We had to ask twice for water and he would just mumble something and walk away. We got our water after about 25 minutes after the first time we asked and before we could ask for napkins and another menu he had left. It was a constant battle to get our waiters attention eventually we got up and got the boxes and napkins ourselves. And with all this frustration they don't serve alcohol or at least that's what our waiter claimed.
author: Cortney c.

description: 5 stars for food. Best Korean tofu in the city. But 0 stars for service. They try their best.  So I am giving them 3 stars. They need to hire more servers.This place is severely understaffed with only 2 waiters serving the entire restaurant. Anyone who eats Korean food knows that servers need to expect  constant refills on side dishes, water refills for spiciness, but totally absent here. You'll be lucky if you get to order. The 2 waiters that work there are seriously over worked, exploited almost. It's very depressing. So if you don't mind the slowest service ever, then come here.
author: Maria D.

description:
I'm surprised I never even bothered to write a review for this place.  My all time favorite Korean restaurant in SF.  Hands down the soon dooboo is the best here.  Get that and a meat, for two or three people and you have an awesome meal.  

Their panchan is the best.  I love their pickled cucumber more than any other place.  The wait is really bad during dinner time though :( 

If you want consistent, good quality Korean food, this is definitely my go-to recommendation.
author: Anna T.

description:
Maybe I'm not the biggest fan of Korean food. Maybe it's because I'm not a big fan of spicy foods. Or maybe I'm not the biggest fan of Kim Chi? My Tofu House is one of those restaurants that leaves me questioning, "Is it worth coming back?"

First off, Korean food is generally pricey. The portions are small, and the food is heavy in flavoring. My Tofu House has gotten a lot of hype about it's Kim Chi, but I personally thought the Kim Chi wasn't the best dish out of the three I ordered. My favorite was the Chicken and Veggie Bimbimbad (whatever that may be). The chicken had a good amount of seasoning, but the flavors weren't as overwhelming as the other dishes. I also tried the Seafood & Veggie pancake, but the pancake was way too oily for my taste. 

The booths are cute, and the place is ideal for big groups but I don't recommend going here for an intimate dinner. It's a little too busy and stuffy for me. The service was overall friendly and inviting, but the dishes don't really cut it for me.
author: Linda T.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm not Korean but I think this place is pretty good. With the foggy weather that's so prevalent in the area, My Tofu House is always a safe bet and you can't go wrong with piping hot and delicious soondubu ($11).

I love that the rice comes in a stone pot and they add the hot water to make rice soup for after the meal and while the ban chan isn't extensive, it's definitely passable and tasty.

While the soondubu is decently priced, I feel like everything else is overpriced. Meat is around $25 and a seafood pancake is over $20. Maybe it's because I have a hard time paying $20 for batter but COME ON NOW.

I've been rather lucky and haven't had to wait a lot but I've heard some horror stories so keep that in mind if you're dying for some soonduu.

p.s. Parking sucks but it's the Richmond so what else is new?
author: Amy L.

description:
It's not the best tofu soup I've had before, but probably the best I've had in SF so far.  I love the hot bubbly tofu soup, so I was really happy to find a good bowl to devour here.  I will definitely be returning here often to get my tofu soup on (which I crave fairly often and would get more often if the boyfriend wouldn't put his foot down about eating the same thing over and over again).

I don't remember much else about my experience there except the yummy soup and having to repeatedly wave down the waiter to get water and then finally getting up and stealing the pitcher of water myself.  Service could be improved, I guess.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
On a cold rainy day, I thought this place would be perfect. Walking into this place, and first things you see were the people. It was packed! The interior was really boring! Everything was mostly white. The wait was okay, but I didn't like how they didn't have anyone to greet you at the door.The wait was a boring 10 minutes with nothing to do but look at the take out menus in the front. They had 1 TV but that it was hard to see while sitting in the waiting area.

It was a nice and simple menu. I was about to order some Korean BBQ but, but my friend said that I should try their signature tofu dishes and get BBQ elsewhere. So I ordered the "Combination Soft Tofu" medium spiciness.The waiter was nice and friendly, checking back once in a while to see if everything was okay. I liked his circle glasses haha. The side orders came first, they were all okay but the zucchini had a great sour taste to it. They also gave us a fried fish which I thought was a great starter. My order came and I thought it would be a bigger bowl but it wasn't. I took a few sip. It was spicy but not too spicy. After some time, the taste got really plain and I didn't finish it. I wasn't satisfied with the meal, it got too boring. At the end, they gave us some melon gum with the bill. A few minutes later, I felt like I needed something else to eat afterward.
author: Hui L.

description:
I rarely eat Korean food - not that I have anything against it. It's just not something I typically crave. But for some reason, it sounded pretty good on this cold night and it had been a good few years (yes, I said years) since I've had tofu soup and Korean dishes. 

We ordered the seafood tofu soup and seafood pancake to split and I must say, the portions are more than enough for 2 people to split and with extras for leftovers! Both the seafood tofu soup and the seafood pancake were delicious! 

The soup was piping hot and the flavors were just right. We ordered it mild (for my sake and my inability to eat anything remotely spicy) but it did have a good zesty kick, which I really enjoyed! The amount of seafood in it was just enough, too! 

The seafood pancake, though, was the first prize winner in my book. It was delicious, piping hot, and crispy on the edges because of the hot plate. The amount of seafood in this pancake was also quite generous. I couldn't stop eating it. 

Service was prompt and our waters were constantly filled. I left happy, full, and my clothes stunk. Oh right...that's why I hardly eat Korean food.
author: Kristina K.

description: Thought this was a decent korean place. I liked having fish as a side dish. The seafood pancake was pretty good, probably better than a lot of other ones I've tried (and I like ordering this a lot). The bibimbap was just okay though. I thought the meat in this could be better. Overall, a decent experience but not the best I've had.
author: Liwei Y.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night and it was decently busy. Even so, the service was great. Five of us ate family style and we ordered the seafood tofu soup, seafood pancake, kalbi, and pork bibimbap. It was all delicious, especially the side dishes. I think the side dishes are my favorite part, and they even being you more if you ask. I'd definitely come back here.
author: Kelsey C.

description:
This is one of my fav restaurants in SF.  Great side dishes.  Yummy tofu soups.  Good meats. Speedy service.  Very consistent in terms of food, quality, and service.  One of my strong recommendations for good korean food in SF! 

I'm not sure about the hot water they pour into the rice pot though, and that your supposed to eat for desert? Also, try to avoid seating in the back room, as there is little ventilation back there.
author: Tramy V.

description:
Since I'm Korean, I'm extremely picky when it comes to Korean food.. but I have to admit, Tofu House is definitely one of my favorite soondubu places! 

My favorite is the Ramen Soondubu, but all of them are fairly good.. all for just $9.99 / pot. Their meat (bulgogi, spicy chicken, etc) are good, but nothing too special in my opinion. Highly recommend the soondubu! (Good for a cold day.. or a hang over cure on a weekend afternoon!) 

The waiters are also very nice and attentive.
author: Sarah C.

description: Mediocre. Nothing too special. It's good but not outstanding as the reviews may have suggested.
author: Carrie T.

description: The service here is terrible!! There was only 1 waiter serving the entire restaurant, our iced water took 15 minutes of nagging before it arrived and the waiter was extremely rude! Expecting a 15% gratuity for walking around with a stick up your ass with your nose in the air? Well you're not getting it mister!! The food was okay, but i lost my appetite after the bad service.
author: Jes D.

description:
I've only had Korean cuisine one other time, and it failed me miserably (read my review for Won Mi Korean BBQ). When a friend of mine asked me to try her favorite Korean place, immediately I began experiencing PTSD and was highly reluctant. However, being an Ethnic Restaurants Examiner, I had to find a new exotic place to review so I decided to face my fears and give Korea (North and South) another shot at impressing me.

Thank God (and I'm not religious) for My Tofu House! Seriously, this place brought back a love for trying new things that I thought was fading away. Upon arrival, I noticed all the articles that have been published about them. All of them seemed to have one thing in common: their undying love for MTH's Soft Tofu soup with Kimchi.

Done. The decision had been made for me.

I never expected this place to be as busy as it was, especially on a Monday night. I had to write my name down on a wait list for a table and ended up waiting 15-20 minutes. Most of the patrons were Asian, and I only noticed one table of non-Asian customers. This convinced me that this place is the real deal.

I ordered the soft tofu soup with beef (as opposed to pork, because the waitress recommended it), with medium spice. The portion was generous, as I couldn't finish all of it in one sitting because it is accompanied by rice. I'm so glad I ordered the medium spice because, being a spicy food lover, found this dish to have the perfect amount of spice. That to me means it is spicy enough to clear sinuses without leaving you teary-eyed and begging for water.

$11.00, one soft tofu soup and 3 cups of tea later, I was rubbing my belly and showing off my big smile of satisfaction. Inner Richmond, you've got a gem and I'll be damned if you let it go to waste!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
I was in the area doing some shopping & the bf called. He wanted dinner. I wanted to try My Tofu House. He was in SOMA. I got takeout. 
There was no wait, it was Monday around 6. My order took about 15 minutes. I ordered the tofu soup with dumplings - I'm a sucker for any kind of dumpling. For him I got the short ribs since he doesn't really like tofu. Both were great!!! I LOVED the tofu soup, mainly because it reminded me of the food I ate while living in northern China.

I'd go again :)
author: Sara P.

description:
3.5 stars for this place, but I'll round it up.

I went here with my family and uncle last week.  We ordered the dumpling tofu soup, bulgolgi, bi bim bap, and kalbi.  The dinner was close to a whompin $80!!!! =O  A little pricey if you ask me!

However, all of the entrees were delish!  The tofu soup was full of flavor and was pipin hot when it was brought out to us.  Although it was tasty, it didn't stick out for me. It tasted like other tofu soups that I coulda got for around $7-$8.  I also enjoyed the bulgolgi- the meat was tender and juicy, but was about $18..EEEK  The bibimbap was a little to spicy for my liking.  I wish the put the red sauce on the side so I could add any amount I want.  

Would i come back? hmmm i dunno, maybe just to order their tofu soup.
author: Kristen T.

description: We had a tasty and filling meal here. The BBQ chicken was quite good, and the combo pancake was nice. The side dishes were the highlight for me. Would definitely recommend it!
author: Julia M.

description: We come here waiting our dinner more than half hour and someone come later than us get them dinner first. We were try to talk them but there is a fat waiter wearing glasses argue with us. So ridiculousness.
author: shilong d.

description:
It's a nice place to go to for lunch, but I went there for dinner, and it was PACKED. 

I was with a friend and we waited for probably half an hour and got seated. That's not too bad, I mean, there were a lot of people. However, when we got seated, we waited for twenty minutes before a waiter took our order and waited forty minutes for our tofu soup to come out. The waitress had a bit of an attitude, probably because it was busy, when I asked about the status of our food. 
Aside from that, it's a fine place to go to. The tofu soup is delicious and it's nice for a cold, rainy day in San Francisco.

If you are going for dinner, be prepared for a wait. If you're lucky, you can bypass the wait.
author: Bianca W.

description: I don't care what anyone says. This business has consistently been my favorite. They have built a brand. Whenever I am in the mood for tofu soup, I think of this place. They are pretty good!
author: J C.

description:
A nice place to go to on a cold day. Their tofu soups leaves your tummy feeling nice and warm. I recommend their tofu soups, they are actually quite filling especially when you eat them with the rice that they cook in stone bowls.

Service is a little slow, but you do get free side dishes to help make the wait more tolerable.
author: Karen C.

description:
I'm shocked by the positive reviews because the combination tofu soup is terrible. It has absolutely no taste -- I kept eating it hoping I'd taste something, but it's just watery. What they pass as soonubu at this place is laughable.
The restaurant itself is nice and it's cool you get banchan even if you get take-out, but that's standard.
author: Sydney E.

description: My Tofu House serves homey Korean food with no bells and whistles. Their menu is simple, with bibimbaps, tofu soups, and meat platters. I'd recommend sticking with their tofu soups as it's their namesake. They start you off with a good variety of banchan, including three pieces of fried mackerel. We ordered the seafood bibimbap, BBQ chicken, and a tofu soup. I loved that the sides of rice came in a stone pot as well, since they pour hot tea to loosen the crispy rice, creating a delicious, smoky rice soup. Their BBQ chicken comes in a generous portion and the meat is cooked and seasoned well. The seafood bibimbap on the other hand had a strange sauce in it. I prefer the usual chili sauce, but they had already marinated the seafood in a sauce reminiscent of ketchup. Although the dish wasn't bad, that seafood ruined it for me. All in all, the meal was satisfying, however definitely on the pricey side.
author: Ashley T.

description: The food here is fantastic but the service sucks bad. I usually come here alone and am always ignored. My waiter once dropped my debit card in the garbage bin and I had to go fish out myself. And yet, I keep coming back for the food. I guess that says something.
author: Rachelle S.

description:
If you're a big fan of Korean food like I am, you will absolutely love the Zagat rated Korean restaurant, My Tofu House, located on Geary street in San Francisco. 

Their kalbi, served with an assortment of Korean side dishes, also known as banchan, (kimchi, sweet sardines, and other goodies...I can't seem to get around to anything else because I'm always busy inhaling the deliciously spicy pickled cabbage when visiting) is fun and messy to eat...so bring good company ;). 

Also try their soft tofu soup, but I must warn you...if you like spicy, I recommend asking for "hot" instead of "mild." Their tofu soup is surprisingly mild in flavor for a Korean restaurant. 

I've been a fan since my college years at SFSU, and I'm still lovin it. Definitely a must when in the area.
author: Jasmin W.

description:
I have been here twice only in the past few years and it made me miss LA because Tofu House there was so much more amazing. I went like 2 weeks ago and it totally changed my mind. We ordered the SPICY seafood combo tofu soup and the SPICY pork... Both mouth watering dishes and I love the unlimited side dishes they give you. I also love the rice its not from a rice cooker but from a stone pot... never had rice this good!

This is a short review but a great review... great serviced, they checked on me a few times, bought me tea when I needed it but didnt even ask for it. Re-filled my side dishes when it was out and free melon gum in end lol not very lasting flavor thou... good food, good service what else can you ask for!
author: Lynna N.

description: This place is way too overpriced. The bibimbap was not worth it and the kimchi tofu soup was ok. The quality of the food was not worth the price. I've been to other Korean restaurants that were cheaper and tasty.
author: Mimi H.

description: Yum! For the past few years, this has been my safe go-to place when I'm hungry and don't know what I want to eat. A light, refreshing tofu salad paired with some flavorful kalbi (which includes complimentary side dishes and rice) always makes a comforting and satisfying dinner for two (unless you and your companion are ravenous pigs!). The tofu soup offerings are pretty filling and delicious as well - perfect for those chilly winter months. On a recent night, my friend and I were feeling pretty adventurous and decided to try one of their bibimbaps. Unfortunately, we must have ordered the wrong one, as it was bland and disappointing. How sad! I felt my eyes well up with tears that night while I longingly gazed at a neighboring booth's plate of juicy kalbi. It was the worst night of my life and made me want to drive off of a cliff...and by "cliff", I really mean a sidewalk curb.
author: Suany W.

description:
I personally prefer my kimchee tofu stew from Todam's in Millbrae and their rice better...but this place is a lot closer to my work so it will do (even though they charge more then most other places for any stew)

One plus for this place is their banchan. They have a fried fish (I think it is mackarel) that everyone loves (I think its okay, too much bones) and their other side dishes are pretty good too. 

The stew is pretty good compared to other places that are NOT specifically only tofu houses. flavorful and comes with lots of ingredients. 

One thing I do not think is all that but other rave about is their seafood pancake. It is too battery and soggy. Not worth the $15 it cost (I am not sure is that exactly the price but it is way overpriced compared to other places)

But if you are in the inner richmond area this place does the job especially on the cold rainy days. VERY CROWDED all the time.
author: Annie L.

description: This place is nice and clean but the food is so-so.  I ordered the soft tofu soup with beef and I have to say- for a place that calls themselves tofu house, the tofu was pretty weak.
author: Erika S.

description:
The first time I went to a tofu house restaurant, I ordered a heaping pile of meat because I was afraid of tofu.  The second time I manned up and ordered a tofu bowl, and I've never looked back since.  

I had not yet found a tofu house restaurant in the city to call my own since my previous experiences were in Palo Alto, but last week for lunch I finally convinced the coworkers to try this place out, and guess what, they loved it!

I enjoy converting skeptics over to the good side of delicious food.  Service here is speedy and efficient, just how it should be.  The servings sizes are right on, and they refill your side dishes if you want more.  The soup was so piping hot throughout the entire meal, it was slightly painful yet perfect, because nobody likes cold soup (gazpacho excluded).  

I ordered medium spicy and to me it tasted completely mild, but my coworkers who also ordered medium said they wouldn't have gone hotter.  So if you're accustomed to the heat, go for the hot, but if the temperature is the only hot thing you want, go for mild or medium.  

I will come to My Tofu House whenever I'm craving my hot bowl of tofu and meat soup.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I tried really hard to keep defending this place. My family has been coming here for many years, but there are a few things that have irritated me about it recently. 

First, the service is kind of rude. Compared to the soon dubu place on irving in the sunset (with the nice old korean man), these servers are young and more abrasive. 

Second, the prices keep going up and up, and their portions don't continue to follow. In fact, I think they are giving less banchan with their meal than before and they are stingy with their rice. When I go with my parents we are a group of three, and they only give us one pot of the rice cooked in the cast iron. It isn't enough rice for three people and when my mom asked for more, they gave her old rice. Let me tell you, as a korean mom, she was NOT pleased. Also, wtf the prices for their meats are outrageous. no, no, no. 

but at least their soon dubu still tastes good.
author: Tim B.

description: This was my introduction to Korean food, and I was looking forward to it. We waited an hour to get seated, and there seemed to be a lot of locals. So, I thought this place must be great. However, I thought it was dreadful. The soup entree was scalding hot and had little flavor once it finally cooled down enough to taste it. I didn't think much of the sides that came with the entree, either. I also thought it was very expensive for what one gets. If this is an accurate example of Korean fare, then never again.
author: James S.

description: This place gets 3.5 stars. Service was pretty bad and slow, and there was no alcohol. The tofu soup was great, as was the banchan, but I guess I expected a larger menu and more attentive servers. I also wish the pajun were more traditional - it was very thick, which wasn't what I was expecting!
author: Ashley C.

description:
The food is 4 stars 
The service is 2 stars 

So.............3 stars it is. Their tofu soup is probably ranked pretty high up there. Love it when it comes still boiling. The side dishes are few here. Missing a lot of other stuff..............maybe it is because I am not Korean. hahahhaah I had the bibimbab. Chicken and vegetables with rice in an iron pot. Very good. 

Price is very reasonable for Korean food. I still don't get why Korean food is so expensive to begin with. But................this place is priced fair and like most Korean restaurants, it is very clean. 

Came here with Sandy L and a co worker for lunch and the bill came out to 38 dollars.  Sandy stuck me with the bill again!!!  She's good!!!
author: jason g.

description: My go to tofu soup restaurant in SF.  There are better places in the Bay Area, but I haven't found one better in SF.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
I'd give 3 stars for the price but the food is tasty.

We got the soft tofu soup with beef and it's so good I had to learn how to make it.  We also ordered the lunch short-rib plate, only to learn that they were not offering the lunch prices.  It was so expensive for the amount of meat you get.  Good food but lunch for two ended up being about $50 with tip.
author: Jeanne C.

description: I come here at least once every other week. I have never been disappointed with anything I've had from here. My favorite is definitely the dumpling tofu soup, I get it extra spicy.  It is amazing and with all the side dishes it is definitely enough food for a full lunch or dinner. The Korean pancakes and the Daeji Bulgogi are Also very good.  The service is pretty good, definitely prompt and I never feel rushed.  I love this place.
author: Stephen M.

description: The combo tofu soup did not disappoint! I am a big tofu soup fan but not every place makes it right. This place does it right. The broth, soft tofu, minced beef, and shrimp, everything is good. We will come back here! Oh and the fried fish appetizer was good too.
author: Cartman P.

description: First time at MTH. And as far as i remember - first time at a place with this type of format. Definitely an interesting experience. Had the #15 BBQ Chicken and Veggie dish in the hot stoneware container. The complimentary fish appetizer was cool, and the whole meal was more of an experience than just getting some food - looking forward to coming back.
author: Oleg H.

description:
We decided to come here on Sat night, because it was a really cold night, and I wanted something that would warm my taste buds! We got here an hour before it closed so it was late already. We were seated immediately and given hot tea. You don't get a lot of side dishes like typical Korean places here. The sides you get are: mung bean sprouts, cucumber, kim chee, pickled radish, anchovies, and 2 pieces of small fried fish. They do have other things on the menu other than tofu soups such as bibimbops, meat dishes, and seafood pancake. But when you come to a place called "My Tofu House" - I would safely assume that tofu soup is their specialty.

We ordered 2 soups: The combination and the original soup (both $10.05). We got one mild and one medium. You also get 2 raw eggs to crack in the soup! You also get rice in a stone bowl that the servers help scoop out for you. They then put hot water so you can have the "rice soup" at the end of the meal. The tofu soup was delicious. Lots of tofu and meat and full of flavor. My mild soup had barely any "spiciness" to it, but the medium soup looked very red and spicy (I did not try this). Overall, it was a very satisfying soup experience!
author: Betty S.

description:
For a place with over 950 reviews and 4 stars, I expected better. Alot better.

We came here for dinner and when we first walked in, we saw their rolling cart piled high with dirty dishes. Ewww! Not exactly the first thing you want greeting you when you walk in.

You don't often see cod roe soft tofu on the menu so I decided to try that. Maybe other folks like it but I just wasn't a fan. And sadly, the side dishes were just...sad. Not alot of variety and kind of boring. The clincher were the little fried croakers. They must've been leftover fish because it was lukewarm and soggy. Definitely not cooked to order.

Definitely won't be back.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
Yummmm.

I came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon and it was not crowded at all. My friends and I ordered the seafood bibimbop, combo pancake, mushroom tofu, and kalbi. Everything was really good, except the bibimbop was a little plain. So were the pancakes, unless you dip it in the sauce it comes with, then it's pretty bomb. Service was also really good.

Minus one star. Why must Korean food be so expensive?! :(
author: Tiffany T.

description: My friend brought me here once and the food is alright. I don't go here often, but I went here when it was crowded at night.
author: Serena Z.

description:
Mellow girls's night. Where to? Cheap dinner in the Richmond. Hmm. What kind of Asian food should we try? My Tofu House!

Not bad. Not bad at all. But not great. I wanted the dishes to be more flavorful and less spicy (if that makes sense). I liked our beef bibimbap much better than the traditional soft tofu with chicken over white rice. We got in at the best possible time (6:30) because right as we sat down the place all of a sudden became packed with people waiting. They're doing something right.

Service was a bit slow considering how many people were waiting but we were happy to enjoy a long, relaxing Korean meal. I'll be back for sure.

(Personally my favorite part of the evening was heading to a random candy store a couple blocks away on Clement and hearing "Hard For Me To Say I'm Sorry" by Chicago and the store owner humming along with glee.)
author: Meredith R.

description:
Sadly, this place was only ok. The two of us got the beef bibimbap and the spicy kimchi hot tofu soup. I can only speak for the bibimbap and it was really not that great. There was virtually no meat and it was actually pretty bland. The side dishes were few and far between, but what they brought out was pretty decent. The service was excellent and the prices weren't bad.

Next time I will get one of the hot tofu soups or one of the pancakes.
author: Lisa C.

description: Their Bi Bim Bap is decent but hella expensive - $15 and change for Bi Bim Bap?! Better be some kinda fancy fusion-y place with nice decor, all-organic ingredients, and beer on tap to get away with those prices... but it's not.
author: Chris K.

description:
Wow! Now that's what I call tofu soup! The side dishes were delicious and their kimchi was perfect.  We also ordered the hot stone bibimbap and kalbi- YUMMY!! 

Def our top Korean pick so far.  Will 100% come back!
author: Candace D.

description: This is my favorite Korean BBQ place in SF.  The meat is never fatty.  The soup is always spicy.  But the kimchi may be over marinated.  And they do not serve alcohol.  And the wait time may be very long.
author: Byron L.

description:
After a long day of fishing (well, it was only 3 hours, but still! fishing is a whole new level of patience), my friend brought me here for some good ol fashion Korean food. We entered and was seated 5 minutes later. We ordered a tofu soup, a barbecued chicken platter, and a bibimbap.

All I have to say is OMG, the bibimbap was super delicious! My favorite part is the crunchy rice on the side! It's so good! 

I also tried their tofu soup and it was really good as well! The Chicken platter was alright, but a little dry for my tastes. If I were to come back here again, I would definitely order the bibimbap BUT if it's a cold and rainy day, I would definitely order the tofu soup.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Best Korean food in SF, hands down.

I recommend going with a group of friends and ordering family style (order a bunch of dishes to share).  Get a soup, a bulgoki, two bibimbabs, and a pancake.  They bring you all the kimchi, bean sprouts, and broiled fish that you want.  If you're convincing enough, you can actually get them to put some real heat into the dishes!

They are a little hard to flag down for drinks, so maybe try asking for a pitcher for water or something.

Don't forget to sign your name on the waiting list hanging on the wall to the right (just past the waiting chairs)

Also, those eggs are for cracking into the soup immediately when served so that they cook in the soup.
author: Dmytro A.

description: the wait here can be long, esp on fridays.we had a group of 8 and waited 30 mins. but it's worth it! i love korean food, esp on cold days. the tofu soup here is pretty spicy but you choose to type of spiciness you want. it's perfect either just eating it like that or pouring it over your rice. we had the pancake here too which i love, but i still like the one at toyese more. we had their popular rice dish in the black clay pot and ther bbq short ribs.. the little dishes they serve you before the meal is pretty good as well.. my fav is the fish dish.. it's spicy and sweet.  i like the tea they serve here, but i don't know what type of tea it is.  overall if parking isn't a pain i would come here more often.
author: Belinda C.

description:
My Tofu House never disappoints.  I've come here numerous times... and I have always gotten delicious flavorful tofu soup.  It's not watery (unless you get mild) or bland.  The medium spicy flavoring is perfect for me.  Perfect redness and spice.  I always get the Dumpling Tofu soup, which comes with 4-5 pieces of dumplings, rice cake, and beef.  I add ramen to it also (free of charge).  It's the perfect blend for when I want tofu soup, yet I want ramen. $10.05 + tax/tip for tofu soup. 

This is my place to go in SF. =)
author: Diane L.

description:
We have eaten heremany times in the past, but I hadn't been in a couple of years.  The place still draws a crowd on weekends--come early.  There's no greeter, so go to the front and sign yourself in.  

In the past, the spicy tofu soup has always been quite good.  But today I am reviewing the beef and vegetable bibimbop.  The stoneware pot came out hot enough to burn a hole through the table and singe my eyebrows off! (like it should)  There was decent portions of rice, meat and veggies.  Note: the chef cracked an egg over it raw.  Some restaurants fry it first.  Just depends.  The spice and flavor was just average, but still a good meal!  Personally, I could use more seaweed.  The panchan was fresh and tastes homemade.  There should be a bigger selection in my opinion, however.  Still, they tasted better than most, which earned an extra star.  

Service is about average for a Korean place.  But no real complaints.  

The booths were designed for "self-bbq" from a previous restaurant.  I presume the current owners removed those grilling tables and replaced them with standard tables, which are much narrower.  The result was benches that were too far from the table.  Whoops.
author: Stephen F.

description:
I guess I'm used to the Korean restaurants in Hawaii, as I thought this place was a bit expensive.  The Bi-Bim-Bap was at least a few dollars more here than the prices back in Honolulu.  My friend and I ordered the spicy tofu soup (this was quite good) and the Bi-Bim-Bap that was served in the stone pot (not as good as the soup, but decent).  The food here is in no way bad, but I honestly think that for the price you'll pay, one could find the same if not better, elsewhere in SF.  

This place is not that big and around 1pm on a Sunday, it was pretty busy with folks waiting to get tables.  Also, it took a while for the waiters to come over to give us some tea and then later to get our bill - I had to call them over to let them know.  I understand it is busy, but I've been to busier places where I don't have to even ask.  

Glad to have tried this place to know how their food is like, but quite frankly if it wasn't for my friend who had never tried Korean food before, and also for the fact that this was on route to where we were heading afterwards, I probably would have not yelped this place and came here.  Overall experience with both food and service here in my opinion was 3 stars.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
Soon tubu... I love this stuff. And although I've been spoiled most of my life with it (Homemade.. SoCal area.. ABC Tofu House, etc..) this place fills my appetite for good tofu stew. Not only is their stew on par, but their bbq is delish as well. Kalbi, bulgogi, spicy bulgogi.. Very good and worth coming here for even if you don't want tofu.

Great variety of pan chan and although it was a busy Saturday night, our party of 5 was well treated in a timely manner.

Definitely coming back!
author: Tay R.

description:
What's the hype? It's just a typical Korean restaurant. Who are these guys who make up the 7x7 top 100 list? I've tried a few things on there and I BEG to differ...

I've had more side dishes at other places and better bibimbap. So I ordered the beef bibimbap and seafood tofu soup last night. My bibimbap didn't even come with Bulgogi... when the menu said bbq beef it really meant "bbq beef". It was beef pieces with bbq sauce not the korean bbq beef... Wth?! And honestly it was just whatever.. nothing special.
The tofu soup was also just like any other I've had. Everything on the menu was more on the pricey side. My bibimbap was around $15! Are you serious? Isn't it usually like $10. Their meat plates like Bulgogi was over $15 and its not even like they give you a large portion.
Basically, you can get better or a similar quality of Korean food from other restaurants for LESS.

Just like the hotdog from Absinthe, 7x7 you have let me down once again...
author: Karen C.

description:
If you want good food at a really affordable price....My Tofu House is one of them go-to places.

My friends and I ended up in this place accidentally. We were supposed to try the other Korean place next door, however it was closed. And it was truly a blessing in disguise! This place is Rockin'!!!

The place is quite small. The booths all situated by the wall, that for 7 people, one of us had to sit by the head of the table, which kind of blocks people from passing thru.

Okay....the unlimited mini plates of appetizers are great. there were so much variety... I liked the one that looked like baby fish... and their kimchi tastes good. we probably asked our server to refill everything 3x and he gladly did.

I tried the BBQ Pork and Vegetable Bibimbab. It was smoking hot of course..but i really liked it! the meat was actually very tasty. The only complain is that, they put too much rice, and not too much of the meat. One of my friends ordered a plate of BBQ Pork, so she just kept adding more to my plate.
The plate orders are enormous! It can really be good for 2 people. unless you're a really heavy carnivore.

One tip for Bibimbab orders. Make sure you cool your plate first.... i know i know....seeing it and trying it right away can be really exciting... but it can be too hot that it burns your tongue...and when it does, you miss out on the good flavorful stuff in the plate. So...adore it for maybe at least 5 minutes, mixing everything before taking your first bite.

The order of Kalbi is droolingly yummy!!! one order is probably enough for 2 people. or could be for 3, if there's another entree. It's really tasty!!! But you've gotta be ready to go down and dirty with the bones.
that's where all the flavor is at.

One of our friends ordered the Dumpling Soft Tofu. It's really good as well... Good thing she has a really small appetite so all of us took her leftovers. lol.

The service is great. We all didn't have cash so we all had to each give our server our cards for payments. So i'm glad they take split payments using cards. Some places don't.

***oh. i had a really bad experience with the bathroom. So that took the other star off my rating. They should probably inspect the bathroom to make sure it's clean enough for guests. one guest apparently left a USED pad open. i would hate to go into the gory details but it really did make me gag. that b*tch should perish for being so gross and unhygienic.
author: Monica H.

description:
My Tofu house is a great find especially on a cold night, nothing else warms a person up than a bowl of soup. I guess I'm biased since I love tofu, but all the other entrees are just as appetizing.

Likes: The food 
Dislikes: The wait while starving.
author: Calvin T.

description:
Had the spicy bulgogi and it was very marinated. The tofu dumpling soup is also pretty good, esp. with the fluffy rice.

I was a little bummed out that I was rationing out my rice with all the bulgogi that after a while, the waiter came by and poured tea into the large rice bowl where the rest of our rice was! I thought, "Nooooo! My rice!" I wish the waiter would ask if we would like the eat the rice before setting up to wash it for later. 

The seafood pancake reminds me an omelette with squid (violet seafood creature?) and shrimp. 

The wait was not long - you sign in yourself and the waiter calls you as he crosses off names. 

There are fresh white and red roses at the center of the place and flowers on the window panel out front too. It's cozy!
author: Jan S.

description:
BEST place to get tofu soup because they give you like a million side dishes to go with it.

This place is probably one of my favorite Korean restaurants to go to.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The food here is really good - I recommend the bibimbap in particular: hearty, eggy, spicy. 
I found the place and service to be a bit impersonal; not necessarily a bad thing.
I would definitely go back - in particular for a quick meal (rather than, say, a romantic evening.)
author: D Z.

description: Food was really good, would give it a 4 and a half!  Service was pretty average.  They need another server since it seems like a full house is the norm here.  If you aren't super needy it's passable, although it is a bit annoying to ask for some more tea and have to wait for the server 5-6 trips in and out of the kitchen before she refills your tea.  Paying was also an ordeal.  5 minutes to get the check, more than 8 minutes before I just walked the check up to the register.   I would go back for the food, but bring your patience as the place is very busy.
author: Hann A.

description: The tofu soup is here is perfect for a cold day in San Francisco. I usually always get the kimchi tofu soup. It's my absolute favorite. I've also tried the bibimbap which was also good and spicy. One thing I wished about this place is that they actually need to make their "spicy" level in the tofu soups spicy. There's no kick in it at all! It doesn't bother me too much though since I'm always coming back here.
author: Marilyn W.

description: Tasty on a cold chilly day.  I've only had the seafood soon tofu.
author: Suz L.

description:
We arrived early to avoid the crowd and were seated right away.  One of the nice things is that this restaurant is airy, roomy and clean, offering both booths and tables.

However, the food is pricey - $15 for dolsot bimbimbap and I've had better (didn't taste the marinated pork at all; ingredients besides rice were skimpy). The pancakes can be around $17 and the bulgogi dishes are more.

The banchan was just ok - 6 dishes, including 2 fried mackerel.  Nothing really stood out.

Service - the wait staff disappeared once the food arrived, only reappearing again with the bill.  A refill of tea would have been nice - along with at least the offer of hot water for rice porridge.

Not going to be rushing anytime to return.
author: M G.

description:
By many knowledgeable accounts, among the best Korean restaurants in the whole Bay Area.

The panchan (appetizers/side dishes) are so damned good I have to be careful not to over-indulge before my order comes out.

Consider the "mild" or "medium" option if you're ordering sundubu for the first time -- there'll be no lack of flavor with the former and fire aplenty with the latter.
author: Francisco G.

description:
mmmMMM... soon doobu!!! One of my favorite soup of all time especially when it's made right, and My Tofu House definitely makes it right. 

I came here for lunch on a weekday. No wait, and we were seated at the table with hot barley tea waiting for us. Two of us shared the kalbi and spicy tofu soup (extra spicy of course!). 2 minutes later, the ban chang came which consisted of an assortment of kimchis and 2 fried fishes. I loved their kimchi so much that I had to ask for a refill, and I finished them all by myself!!! (BTW kimchi is supposedly very very good for you b/c all the capsaicin from the chili powder cleanses your blood, de-clogges your arteries, increase metabolism, and even help you loose weight!!!) 

After a while, our rice came in a stone pot, followed by the scorching hot soup and a plate of kalbi. The soup was very rich in flavor and spicy, and probably one of the best I had around the area (there're pbb better ones around sunnyvale). Kalbi was pretty good too, and I'd say it's a good deal for only $9.50 during lunch. 

I'd definitely come back here again for lunch. Never been here for dinner, but judging from the menu, the dinner seem to be pretty costly. Also, I think the waiters were very attentive and polite. Definitely my favorite soon doobu place in the city!!!
author: tiannaaah J.

description:
I have no other Soon Tofu places in SF to compare this against but it definitely can hold its own with some of my favorite places in LA's Korea town.

Traditionally while waiting for your meal you will get a few small plates including kimchee and other things like a whole fish that has been deep fried. I am not usually a fan of eating things that look back at me but this is too delicious to refuse. They really bring a lot of this stuff around so keep in mind that you still have a giant entree on it's way (i didn't)

I ordered the Kimchee/Pork Tofu along with Pork Bulgogi to share with my friend. The soup was ideally spicy and had a lot of pork inside. It was pouring outside which is the best time to appreciate this sort of thing. The Bulgogi was in generous portion and was more than we could finish along with our bowls of soon tofu and rice.

The staff was first, very organized in dealing with the line that had formed to wait for a table. All of us knew that they were aware and working on getting us each a table. After that we never had to wait for anything. The staff was quick with tea as well as the individual courses of our meal.

This place is the first Soon Tofu place that I have seen without beer, which really did not bother me since I am not a huge fan of Korean beer. Sorry Hite fans
author: Eric G.

description:
Solid 4 stars.  Usually get the beef tofu soup, but this time got the mushroom tofu soup (#5).  

BOMB!!!!!!!!!

The banchan is the shit too.  They give all kine.  I really like the fish they give, both the little ones and the bigger fried one.  Its awesome.  And their Kalbi is one of the best ever.  

Bam!  Done Deal.  Eat here or die.
author: Sage S.

description:
My favorite Korean place to eat at! 

I love the little appetizer dishes they serve before every meal.  I love their Kimchi.  I have never had any other Kimchi anywhere else that was as good as the Kimchi at My Tofu House.  I can never have enough, I even ask the waitress to refill my Kimchi plate!  She was really nice about it and did it with a smile on her face! Damn, my mouth is watering writing about it...

I always get my usual Original Soft Tofu Soup with beef - medium spicy, and also the BBQ Beef on a sizzling hot plate (I forgot the name of it, its in Korean).  It's so damn good! I usually get my tofu soup with just half the tofu because I don't like it when the whole thing is full of tofu, it gets in the way.

The waiters there are always very polite and friendly (it could be a cultural thing).  They scoop the rice for you and everything.  At the end, you even get a piece of melon flavored gum! Yay!
author: Janny S.

description:
Now listed on 7x7's Big Eats Top 100 Things to Eat Before You Die, you MUST come here and try the food. Specifically, the Kimchi Tofu Soup is listed on the list as what to try. However, anything that you order on the menu wont disappoint you. All of the tofu soups are very flavorful (i've only had 2x spicy, spicy, and medium so dont quote me on mild). Whatever you choose to put inside, dumplings, seafood, or beef, there are healthy servings. This makes it a steal of a deal for about $10 a serving.

The sides that come out are very tasty. They are very fresh and aren't overly seasoned. The cucumber, raddish, bean sprouts, dried fish, fried fish, and kim chi can be a meal in itself. It adds to the overall experience and the cold sides are a good palate cleanser and can help cool down your mouth after taking a big helping of spicy tofu soup.

While a little expensive at ($14 or $17, sorry i dont remember) the combination seafood pancake is probably the best i've ever had. Its not flat, doughy, soggy, It has a good amount of seafood in it and the dipping sauce isnt too salty or sweet. I like how they serve it on a cast iron dish so it remains hot and crispy when served.

I have ordered bulgogi here before and it was excellent as well, i Just wouldnt do it again because it fills me up and i cant eat my soup completely. I would recommend it to be shared by a group since it is a pretty big serving.

Service here is good and fast. If you come at a prime time for dinner, be prepared to wait a little bit for a table. Parking here can be a challenge, but they do have some street parking on side streets as well.

My only gripe.... I wish the melon gum they give you with your check lasted more than 2 minutes. haha :)
author: James T.

description: On one of those cold summer SF evenings, we were satisfied by our hot tofu soup meals, but not blown away.  Overrated in my opinion but I'd probably try it again. Service was OK.
author: Henry Y.

description:
So this is my third time here and I find that the quantity and quality of the food at this restaurant seems to be lacking. 
The food didn't taste as great as before. 
The service with the "cute" waiters suck; they never refill tea and are not helpful and/or friendly.
Overall they are so so but not great anymore.
author: Carmen L.

description: I have been dying to come here because of the reviews and it was okay. My sister and I ordered the tofu soup and our friend ordered the bibimbap, and also the seafood pancake. The banchan they served were delish! I enjoyed the fish alot. The soups were great and the bibimbap was mediocre and I would've given this place 4 stars except the pancake- it was bland. We came on  Sunday before noon and there were two servers only and so sometimes we'd have to wait longer than usual to get waters and what not but they were really nice. I would come back because the place is clean and legit.
author: Vanessa P.

description: I don't understand the 4-5 star reviews that this place gets!?!?! The quality is lacking. The decor is appalling. The service is average at best. If you want good Korean, at least go to a place that is owned/operated by Koreans!!! And I'm not trying to be racist or anything...
author: Stephen Y.

description:
The weather was horrible yesterday. It was cold/windy and frankly, I was dressed pretty crappy. My friend and I wanted to eat at a nice place for dinner, but we were so lazy, we said screw it, and she suggested this joint.

I haven't had Korean in a while, and a nice bowl of shared tofu soup and bulgogi sounded amazing. We ventured out to the Richmond and the place was PACKED. It's perfect for 2 people, as we were seated after only 15 minutes (you write your name on a list). However, we were seated in what my friend calls the "reject" section, as there were only 3 tables in the back of the restaurant, which probably used to be the pantry. I didn't care. I was hungry. Plus, there was a button you could press if you needed service when the wait staff forgot about you. We didn't have an issue with service though. 

 Like typical Korean restaurants, they serve side dishes. Although I am used to having more side dishes, this place only had maybe 6 dishes. There was a plate with 2 little fish. My friend isn't a fan, so I decided to attack it. As I was eating it, she decided to tell me that the last time she was there, her boyfriend ate the fish and one of them was pregnant because there were eggs in there. I almost threw up when she told me that. Again, I was hungry so ignored it and continued eating. I must have punctured something because something from the fish squirted onto my hand. I literally "yelped," dropped my spoon onto the table from shock and shoved it to the corner of the table. GROSS. Nevertheless, the rest of the side dishes were standard

We ordered a huge plate of bulgogi with onions and mushrooms (beef was cooked perfectly), and a bowl of  tofu soup with spicy broth. I'm a spicy girl--the broth could have been spicier, but it was good regardless. The meal also came with rice served in a stone pot--and a nice surprise of garbanzo beans and peas. I never had rice served that way, and it was really good! Total bill was $30 just for the 2 of us, and I'll probably go back there again if I'm ever in the area/someone suggests it---but I'll definitely skip the fish the next time around. Overall good experience
author: Victoria B.

description:
I'm also loving their vegetable and mushroom bimbimbap.

This is still my go to tofu soup place in the city.
author: Kristine B.

description: The tofu & veggie bibimbap was good but we found it to be a bit pricey at $15, and it really needed more vegetables. I'd like to go back and try the highly-recommended tofu soup.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
I just had the seafood tofu soup and my fingers still smell like fishness. That's how you know. 

This is probably one of the best tofu soup places that I've been to in the bay so far. Definitely a new favorite spot for me because the service was great and the food was good. I am SO happy they did not put zucchini in their soup because I think that always makes the soup so bland.

The only thing I'd change next time I go is that I will be getting the very spicy instead of medium because medium felt very mild and I would've liked it to be spicier.
author: Maryneth K.

description:
Are your sinuses acting up? No need to pick up a $30 box of over the counter Claritin, just hop on the 38L Geary bus and get yo'self some spicy soon doo boo jigae ( soft tofu soup). That will clear your situation ALL up and set your straight!

Seriously though, MTH is the bomb. No, it may not quite measure up to the total experience of what you would find in Seoul, LA K-Town, or even 32nd St. in NYC ( as others have noted, ban chan/ side dish offerings are limited). However, they are great at the few menu items they do offer.  I usually get either the seafood soon doo boo jigae-which is delicious, stone pot bi bim bap ( they make a tofu one for your veggie friends) or the galbi (short ribs). They cook the galbi in back since this is not a barbecue restaurant, but what you lack in table experience you make up for in saved dry cleaning fees (i know you cheap asses be febreezin' it!) from trying to get the smell of korean beef out of your clothes.

To boot, the waitstaff is really sweet and hard working. This joint is pretty popular and there is usually always a line at dinner time, which speaks for how good the food is. You know business is good when your waiters have a constant stream of sweat down their faces from scrambling back and forth from the kitchen to the tables! Came there with a non-korean friend who was in pain from trying to eat the tofu bibimbap which came with too much hot sauce on it ( kochujang) and upon request the waitress kindly took it away and had a new non-spicy one made asap.

+ 1 star for the cutie pie waiter who asked us " are you ready to orders?" instead of " order". I love Engrish!
author: Lummi B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!

I got the Dumpling Tofu!! SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO GOOD!!! it has everything I want...i think it is very good for guys!

It has Tofu, beef, rice cake (sorta like noodles) and dumplings. 

The Kalbi is sorta expensive but it was pretty good...$21? for Kalbi and prob 9-10 pieces....

Dinner for 4...4 tofu's 1 kalbi came to be $20 each including tip....

Expensive but really good!
author: Brendan L.

description: It's your regular Korean restaurant wait staff - as in a few people frantically scurrying around. Tends to be busy and the food is pretty good. I would definitely stick to the soft tofu soups. Perfect for a foggy sf day.
author: Gee H.

description:
bff and i have been eating here since high school...the soon dubu is always pretty consistent...i normally order the combination, extra spicy please!  the portions aren't skimpy and it's always served piping hot to your table.

the bbq selection here has always been super sweet...as they probably have to cater to the non-korean crowd...but not my cup of tea.  i like the traditional kalbi, bulgogi, and dakgui...but why would you be coming here for meats in the first place right?  right. 

tonight we ordered soon dubu(tofu soup), dolsot bibimbop(rice in a stone bowl), bulgogi(marinated beef), and a seafood pancake.  i love how bff described the seafood pancake...they make it chicago style here.  hahaha.  it's thicker than traditional korean pancakes but still yummy...the dolsot bibimbop and the bulgogi were just a bit too sweet...

the rice is always great...served in a stone bowl with garbanzo beans and peas...and don't forget to eat the best part at the end when they mix the tea with the burnt parts!  

quick tip:  chew the melon gum for 30 seconds and spit it out...that's about how long the flavor will last.  

years ago, i would've easily given this place 5 stars...but the food just isn't the same anymore...but hey, you can't find better soon dubu anywhere else!
author: Jen W.

description:
went here at around 6 at night after going around the block a few times looking for parking. got seated right away conveniently in front of the tv! perfect! 

It was a little expensive but the service was great, the servers were attentive and very pleasant. They have big servings so I guess thats why it was a little bit more expensive..
author: Niko B.

description:
The seafood pancake is money. With the plentiful banchan included in the meal, you can easily fill up two people for about $20 bucks. 

Be warned that even if you come on a Wednesday evening, you still may have to wait for a table. We waited about 20 minutes last Wednesday, but it was so oh so worth it.
author: C P.

description:
My Tofu House never fails me. Quality is always consistentp whenever I go from twice a month to twice a year, still good with one exception--the hijacked price.

Always order the kalbi, delicious but it's now 12.37 for lunch! Crazy!! 

Tofu soup is perfect but spices can be a bit off; ordered the medium today and it was not spicy at all.

Side dishes are always yummy especially the fish, the salted mini fish, bean sprouts, and cucumbers.

Parking sucks in the inner Richmond, but no other tofu house can top this one in SF, yet. 

Service is nice, always the two same Korean guys.

Place is amazingly clean; bathroom is clean. A plus!
author: Judy L.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! I've been here a couple times before, but each and every time is a delicious journey.

The tofu soup is delicious, soft tofu swimming in savory broth, but I have to say that the bibimbap is what I get all the time, every time. It comes in a huge stone pot that's still sizzling when it's served. The rice turns crispy and everything is supremely delicious! Even though it's a pretty big serving, the bowl is so good that I must finish it all, even though my stomach is ready to burst at the end. So truly a mark of a great meal.

Love this place and I can't wait to come back again!
author: Sabrina C.

description: Really good Korean food. The seafood bibimbab is wonderful!!! Thank you My Tofu House for being a great foodie port in a storm.
author: Jen S.

description:
Oh so good. My mouth waters every time I start thinking about good Korean food.  Now that I think about it, that expression is kinda gross, but...it's true.

Anyway, went here on the 4th of July (I really do love America, I swear!!) and it was a full house.  We put our names on the clipboard (in lieu of a host - a system I liked), and got a table reasonably soon.  Even while we were waiting, the waiters were attentive and told us we'd be getting a table soon.

All 5 of us got a tofu soup (jjigae...not that I'm actually Korean), and were all just SO happy!  None of us were super hungry so it was the perfect light but filling and oh so satisfying dinner.  Nothing fancy schmancy, just a good solid meal.  The raw egg they let you crack yourself and the fried fish (anchovy?) were unique touches.

Also, my friends thought the waiters were cute, and well...it's true.
author: Yushan K.

description:
I heard this was the best soondubs in Norcal.
I ordered combination soondubu, which had beef, shrimp, and clams. It 
was great, but not amazingly delicious like I expected. I ordered mild, expecting it to be mildly spicy, but it did not seem to be spicy at all. The soup reminded me of lamyun.
The banchan is just alright.
I would have given it 4 stars because the waitresses were nice, but it is pretty pricey.
author: Iris Y.

description:
Tofu Soup...is tofu soup , nothing fancy to begin with. It's a pretty safe thing to eat, because I don't think you can make it taste bad. So that's what I ordered, since I'm not really a fan of Korean food, and thought it was just OK (yes...I've had tofu soup before, Bay Area, LA, SD and what not...even in HK) 

Honestly, I don't think this deserves to be on the 7x7 Big Eats Top 100 Things to at Before you Die list. It was, however, very freshly made and came sizzling HOT. 

The seafood+beef Korean "pancake" was too doughy and oily. 

Generous side dishes though, and good selection.

Long wait, mediocre service (mainly due to lack of staff on a busy Saturday night) and not-worth-it prices (oh wait, we're at a Korean restaurant.)
author: Grace C.

description:
My Tofu House has turned me off Korean food. 

No, not because the food itself is bad quality. It's just that there's hardly an ethnic restaurant in the City where I feel more foreign than here, even if I am visiting with a Korean. The waiting staff is somber and strict, and I never know if I can even speak English to them. Or maybe because I am just not a fan of fermented stuff, like all the endless kimchees that I am supposed to eat while waiting endlessly until the tofu soup actually gets to the cool enough temperature.

Let me dwell on this point. The food comes sizzling, in thick clay pots that keep the heat forever. And ever. Basically, if you are hungry, do not come to My Tofu House. Unless your tongue is made of asbestos. Yes, you will inhale all the delicious flavours, completely unable to partake, since the temperature of a soup is close to that of a smelting furnace.

And it is a good soup, I must say, once you are able to try it 30-40 minutes later. But the place is also somewhat overpriced - which really applies to every Korean restaurant I've been to. I do like the taste of a Korean BBQ, but paying 20-25 dollars for a few slabs of meat that you even have to cook yourself - sorry, not my idea of a money well-spent.

Perhaps I would have given My Tofu House an extra star, if it hadn't been for the sad fact that the place does not serve alcohol. That's right, no beer with your BBQ. To me, that was the last drop. Of nothing.
author: Evg R.

description:
I heard this place was very popular and the food was very good but I've had better korean food for the price. The place is very tiny and the waiters were very busy. 

When I went with my friends to eat, the waiter gave us 2 pots of rice. She began filling our bowls for us but then stopped half way, left, and never came back. She didn't even use up all the rice in the pots and took one of the pots away, so 3 of us were left with no rice and had to scrap the other pot for left over rice. 

The price is a little on the expensive side if you're going for dinner. It ranges about 15-20 dollars per person and not looking for a very full meal. The plates weren't that big for the price. The bibimbap bowls were small. 

Overall, the food was good but the service not so much.
author: Polly W.

description: First korean restaurant experience and i give it a thumbs up. Very simple menu which was good because I didn't know what most of the stuff was anyways so it kept it simple. I went in for the tofu soup w/ kimchi, the hubs got a steak dish which reminded me of carne asada - bulgogi maybe? Anyways, both were very tasty. The soup was spicy, but not too spicy to each. It was a long wait, so be prepared. We got there and ordered to go thinking that it would be quicker, but the wait for to go was a little over 30 minutes anyway so if you do that be sure and call ahead or just wait to eat there.
author: Audrey V.

description:
I like this place. They greet you when you walk in and then they seat you. If its not busy. The service is quick like lightning. They're moving a mile a minute to keep people happy. 

When you order food, they give these nice side dishes like Fried fish, some pickled side dishes, kimchi. Its good stuff. 

When you go there, you go there for a nice hot meal in a bowl. That's why you should consider a tofu bowl first before you think about getting anything else. Its darn good. Comes with an egg that you crack in there while they serve it to you piping hot. The rice is fantastic too. Actually has flavor and isn't bland and boring. 

For the price, its a deal. You will get full. You can also ask for more side dishes.
author: Chris L.

description:
I was hungry. So for a table of two, we ordered the combination soup, the pork/veggie rice plate, and a beef pancake.

The little condiments I've grown to love in Korean restaurants were very fresh and flavored well. 

First came the soup, I don't think I've developed a palate yet so it tasted okay. Nothing special, but overall, very happy with it.

The pork/rice bowl (i know there is a name for it but can't figure it out and too lazy to google) was alright. The dish was a little dry for my liking and the combination of the veggies didnt do it for me. I should have just been lame and ordered the spare ribs.

Last was the pancake. This is the reason I give The Tofu House 3 instead of 4 stars. It didn't taste good at all. It was a leek overkill and I just had one slice.

Overall, the meal was pretty expensive, yeah, I ordered three dishes for 2 people but the pancake was about 18 bucks and the price different between lunch/dinner is about 8 dollars. Damn. 

The staff was very friendly though and I had a good experience there. Next time, I'm just going to stick with the spare ribs.
author: Kevin L.

description: Cheese tofu is the best!!!!!!!!!!! This is my go-to soonduboo place! I'm drooling just thinking about it.
author: Jaclyn H.

description:
Great tofu soups at a reasonable price (well, it'd better be when there are plenty of other tofu places) and a good variety of side dishes! Though I had to pay in cash because its CC machine broke. The waiter only came around when I got his attention because I needed scissors to cut the huge pieces of kimchi, and to get me the check.

Since this is along the busy Geary St., it'll be hard to find parking, even paid street parking. I had to run out several times to insert coins (25 cents per 1/8 of an hour) for my parallel-parked car.

+ Delicious soups and side dishes
+ Reasonable price (~$10/soup)

- Inconvenient and expensive parking
- Difficult to get service
author: Brian H.

description:
This is by far my favorite Korean restaurant. Based on food alone I would give them a five; however, the service is spotty at best so I had to give them four stars.

Highlights:
-The banchan is not as plentiful as other Korean places BUT they do give you a whole small fried fish. The fish is so delicious!
-Soft tofu soup is what they are known for and they do it so well (I particularly like the fish roe I can add to any of the varieties).
-Stone pot of crispy rice. Be sure to ask them not to put tea in your pot. I prefer using some elbow grease to get that crackling rice stuck at the bottom.
-Bibimbap with spicy pork!
author: Chanthi L.

description: If I can give 0 star I will. I will never recommend to any new customer especially when they are busy. Horrible customer service. The waiter said he called our name 6 times when we did not even hear once, and when I ask about it, he give me an 'attitude'. I used to come here all the time, but no, I will never go there ever again
author: Bandaid C.

description: Good Korean food. Tofu soups are excellent. My husband wanted a beer with his food but I guess they don't serve alcohol. No big deal. Other than that, food was excellent.
author: Hanan K.

description:
Really good eats. At a price. I went there for lunch on a weekend with another person. Got a tofu soup, bibimbap and spare ribs. 

-Food was really good but I love korean food. The meat was cooked to perfection and the marinade was delicious! Tofu soup was great too. 
-Service was good too. Waiter and cook was pretty good looking. If I were gay, I would definitely try to holler at the korean chef. Side note, "Joh nuh boh noh jo?" means "Give me your number" in Korean, in case you want to get at him.
-But of course, as with all Korean restaurants, the waiters are partial to Korean speakers. Not a bad thing though. 
-Expensive food! Three items between two people came to around $35. 

Highly recommended. I'd go again!
author: Aron L.

description:
I haven't been here for few years, but the food is just as good! They serve small Korean appetizers with your meal. It's a small yet homey restaurant. 

Try their tofu soup. It's really good
author: Jenny G.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets in San Francisco!  

What more can I say...  My fave spot for tofu soup and bibimbap.
author: jane d.

description:
I kept on hearing good things about this place so I have had to pay a visit and see how awesome it is.

The experience was really meh.

The side-dishes are pretty standard and tasted bland. The kimchi was good, but not "authentic good." 

We also tried the kimchi rice in stone-bowl, some pork, some beef, and some chicken... but they were all not worth mentioning. 

Oh, the soup wasn't spicy enough even it was in the most spicy mode.
author: Chi T.

description:
I had lunch here on a Sunday afternoon. I came here for the soft tofu soup. I've only had that at Cherry Maki, and it was delicious.

My tummy was growling and ready to devour some hot boiling soft tofu soup. The menu was simple and I like it that way. I ordered quickly because I already knew what I wanted. Everything else on the menu looked good too. 

I didn't expect the side dishes because my friend said the menu stated there wasn't any on weekends. I was disappointed, but suddenly the server came by with white dishes. I was soooo happy. There was a lot too, and a whole fried fish. 

The also serve the rice by bringing over a whole clay pot then scooping it for us, which was very interesting. They don't do this at Cherry Maki. I didn't know peas and garbanzo beans were a Korean thing.

My mild soft tofu soup arrived all bubbly and hot. It didn't look as red as Cherry Maki's mild, but that didn't bother me. The soup was comforting, especially when I felt my allergies coming.  

The service was great. There were 2 guys working and they were attentive. They didn't mind that I was taking my time, I stayed there for about an hour. Nobody was waiting for seats, so it should have been alright. I wouldn't have changed anything. This is a restaurant I would love to revisit.
author: Winnie L.

description: Yummy tofu soup! Definitely will come to this place when I crave for some korean food! Their bibimbap's also good! :)
author: cadence p.

description:
Every Friday, like clockwork, I pack my bags and hop on BART to San Francisco -- not because the bf lives there, but because My Tofu House exists.

We eat My Tofu House every weekend, willingly (enthusiastically, even) braving annoying bus rides, inclement weather, and ridiculously long waits for the BEST food ever. The service is great, the side dishes are plenty, and the tofu is straight up divine. No other place, not even my beloved Koreatown restaurants, comes close to making us feel as happy, full and satisfied as this place does, and for so cheap! MMMMMmmmmmmm. I love you My Tofu House.
author: Julie D.

description:
There's nothing better than warm, spicy soup to coat your tummy on a cold, rainy night!  I've been here before, but I never ordered the main attraction: Tofu Soup (duh...).  So upon 7x7's advice on their 100 Must Eat list, we ordered the Original Tofu Soup with Chicken and Mushrooms as well as an order of Vegetable Bibimbop with grilled beef.  

Before ordering, keep in mind that small dishes (all of which are delish!) ie: Kimchee (One of the best I've tasted), Bean Sprouts, Pickled Cucumber, Two Small Fried Fishes and Spicy Radish (?). They all come while you wait for your order...so don't fill up on them!  In addition, ordering the Tofu Soup means that rice is served.  The rice comes in a hot clay pot.  They let the rice crisp on the clay pot and pour tea over so that the rice loosens for a yummy crispy rice delight!  My Favorite!  

So!  The Tofu Soup finally arrives.  My thoughts?  I totally could have done without the chicken and mushrooms, because it was THAT good.  It came out bubbling HOT and SPICY!  (Just how I like my....!)  The soup was savory but light..full of flavor.  Crack a raw egg in there and let it cook.  The tofu was the perfect "melt in your mouth" consistency.

The Bibimbop also came out in a hot clay pot and it was good...I'm afraid to say that I've had better, but I suppose it must have been because I had the Tofu Soup first, which overtook my senses.  The beef was shredded or thinly sliced (which I thought was interesting...) along with everything else.  I usually opt for an order of grilled Korean BBQ Beef cut up into an order of Bibimbop.  Oh Boy...that's good.  Try it.  It won't disappoint.   

Service was great, friendly and attentive.  Result? My Tofu House=Thumbs Up!!!!!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
would've gotten 5 cept their side dishes were lacking
ordered the spicy pork and the beef
the meats in my opinion were a little on the sweater side
came here after the niners lost the superbowl

place gets really packed
i think the service was fast but at the same time it was borderline kind of "eat and get out as fast as possible" type of service
pricy for the amount of food but most korean places are like that
author: Andi I.

description:
I have been to this place many times over the last 10+ years. The food is great.

Normally, I come as a group of 2-3 and order a Tofu and Bibimbab. Their small dishes are good. The BiBimbab smells good and taste excellent. We ordered non-spicy to protect our taste buds and the taste is good. Service is good as well. The wooden booth is comfortable. The best part of the meal was the crusty rice. Crunchy!!!

It's not expensive, but next time I would order just 2 main entrees and that should be good enough.
author: Allan W.

description:
The soondubu is good, but not great. I'm not sure if it was just the batch I got, but the tofu broke apart very easy and didn't taste very smooth at all. I got the kimchee soondubu and otherwise it tasted fine. The side dishes were excellent, I've always enjoyed places that included the fish.

Service was adequate, the wait wasn't long (just remember to sign the clipboard on the wall or other people will try to jump the line) during peak dinner time. Soda comes in a can here and you pour yourself a glass. And your meal comes with a stick of watermelon gum at the end.

But I came here hearing this was the best soondubu in SF, and I wasn't blown away. The search continues!
author: John Paul P.

description:
Yummy Yummy Yummy~

My mother and I decided to come and try this place out since my cousin recommended it.

I love that they have a variety of soft tofu soups, rather than just the original one. They offer: original, seafood, dumpling, mushroom, etc.

We ordered the dumpling soft tofu soup and a seafood bibimbap. My mom was telling me to get the Korean pizza too, but that's just too much food for us. Hahah, next time.

So we got our side dishes first: kimchee, cucumbers, radishes, little fishes, two grilled fishes, bean sprouts. Delicious. I really like their kimchee. 

Next came our soft tofu soup. Bubbling and steaming, we immediately cracked our egg into it and made "egg flowers." The way they serve our rice is nice. They bring out a whole stonepot of the rice, scoop it for you, and leave the "burnt rice" at the bottom for you to eat. But instead of just picking the "burnt rice", they pour tea into it (different way of eating it.) My mom was like, "NOOOOOO!" Hahahaha

Then we got our seafood bibimbap. Pretty good. Tastes like how a seafood bibimbap should taste.

We decided to order bbq pork to try and to bring home for my dad, but the waiter forgot to put the order in.. We waited pretty long, but oh well, it's okay. Things happen.

Overall, I will definitely come back for the soft tofu soups. They're around 10 bucks each, and it comes with rice and Korean side dishes. The bibimbaps, however, are way to expensive IMO. It's around $15 for it. Our total was $31 for two dishes after tax and tip.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
This is THE PLACE FOR SOON-DOO-BU. Good Korean food is hard to find in SF, especially tofu soup. The tofu was silky and soft in the perfect kim-chi spiced broth (get medium). The bulgogi is just as savory to accompany your boiling soup. The stone pot rice with garbanzo beans and peas is the ultimate with tofu. 

The side dishes could include more options but its really all about the soup.

On a cold rainy day its a perfect spot with the family.
author: Ash T.

description: We went here for lunch.  Wasn't too crowded, so I don't understand why there was a delay or that the server wasn't too attentive.  Loved that they offered a free fish appetizer for each of of us.  Panchan was good.  The dolsot bibimbap was okay.  Portions are big.  No real wow factor for me.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: Get any of the soft tofu soups and you won't be disappointed. I also ordered the short ribs, which were very tasty. The meat is kind of expensive if you go any time other than lunchtime on a weekday. The tofu soup meals are always a good deal though. This place also isn't shy with the banchan.
