They give you two whole salted fish along with all the other usual dishes. Would definitely come back again for the tofu soup. Aptly named restaurant, as that is their best and most popular deal.
author: Sannie L.

description:
I usually never see grilled chicken at many Korean restaurants...probably because I like bulgogi too much. I decided to give it a try at My Tofu House and it's pretty much amazingness on a plate. The portion was very generous--we ordered a soondubu and the grilled chicken plate to share between the two of us, and had to take most of the chicken home. 

It's a little far from me but I'd definitely make my way down here if I was craving some good krn food! It's still crowded at 9pm though, so note that you'll probably be waiting a little bit.
author: Stefi C.

description: Great Korean food - especially many varieties of Sun Doo Boo (spicy tofu soup). Best Korean food I have found in San Francisco, and inexpensive. Always a line for dinner.
author: Mark P.

description:
I eat here at least 3 times a month. 

I love the many small dishes that come out before the meal.  I'm not sure if the picked vegetables are to be eaten with the meal, but they are so good, they're almost gone before my meal even arrives at the table. My favorite is the fried fish, bean sprouts and kimchee.

I always order the Seafood Soft Tofu Soup (Spicy) and it's always very good. Cracking the egg in the boiling soup and stirring it around so my soup cools down almost always gives me anxiety. Everytime I start to stir, my mouth just salivates uncontrollably. 

The Lunch menu is the same as the Dinner menu, but Dinner is double in cost. I reccommend coming here for lunch to avoid having to pay $18 for a plate of Bulgoki (broiled beef). 

The wait can be rather lengthy between 6pmish-8pmish, but I assure you, it's well worth it.

My Tofu House was featured in the 7X7 100 Things to Try Before you die list. Though I can't remember which issue it was, I do know why they made that list. Their soup is definitely a "must try."
author: Lily N.

description: good food, fair prices, service was subpar, panchan was sparse
author: Justin I.

description:
I live in Santa Clara, which is NorCal's version of K-Town (An nyoung ha seh yo, biatch, what). So I've been spoiled with really awesome Korean food, specifically speaking, tofu soondubu (soft tofu soup), which I love. Love. LOVE!

Craving it again, we made the trek all the way out to My Tofu House.

And was sadly disappointed.

SADFACE.

This time, the tofu soup was extremely watery and the broth was not as tasty as it was the first time I was here. It was very underwhelming.

Lucky I was hungry, or else I wouldn't have finished so much!

I'll give them another chance...maybe it was a fluke?
author: T L.

description:
This place is like one of those Hole in the Wall finds, you would never excpect nor thing delicious korean food would come from here...  

I remember the very first time i was introduced to this place, i didn't expect much and had no idea it was a korean restaurant.  But when i went in there... i have been going there ever since.  I have recently went there again and this place never disappoints.  

we ordered the following:
- Seafood soft Tofu ****
- Kalbi, broiled short ribs *****

and gotta love the assortmant of mini dishes they give you before your meal.
author: Kenneth V.

description: Love their soup selection! Yummy seafood tofu soup and I love that they give you whole fried fish for banchan, and the "rice soup" at the end (pour hot water into the hot stone pot that was holding your rice). Probably one of my favorite korean restaurants.
author: Caroline D.

description:
Still on a high from the Walt Disney Museum Elite event, or maybe due to hunger making my stomach cave in, my companion decided that it was a good time to knock another restaurant off of our list of things to enjoy before our untimely demise...

#9 on 100 Things to Eat Before I Die in SF: Tofu soup with kimchi at My Tofu House.

Having come from a mildly disastrous sitting at To Hyang last night, I went into this venture a little further down Geary with no expectations - other than it could only go up from that experience.

A fairly short menu, with soup taking up the whole left side, we decided quickly.  The kimchee side dishes came out first and the best part was definitely the Yellow Croaker fish, which the server explained was similar to a kingfish.  SO GOOD.  Lots of little bones, but really well cooked with crispy skin still on.  A first for me, they also brought out raw eggs.  I didn't know it was raw, and thankfully I slowly cracked it. 

When the soup came out sizzling, I was excited.  I first plopped my raw egg in so that it could cook in the heat from the dish.  Let me tell you, by the time I got to that yolk, it was so perfectly stewed in the soup and the texture so good, that the next time I order it, I'm putting in 3 eggs.  

The tofu was nice and soft, the spiciness of the soup delicious without being overpowering, and the overall consistency: chunky.  Chock full of so many well-balanced elements that I couldn't finish what seemed like a little bowl at first.

The next time you feel like you're coming down with something, or your significant other is unavailable and you need a cuddly food to keep  you warm, forget pho and forget hot and sour soup...eat this and savor it.
author: Tamar D.

description:
Given that it was raining and I have a nasty little head cold, Korean food sounded perfect yesterday. Got to My Tofu House around 2:45 on a Sunday and there was a line of ~10 people in front of me.  Took about 30 minutes to be seated.

Once I sat down, they started bringing out the side dishes - pickled cucumber, radish, bean sprouts and a whole broiled fish. All of it was delicious.  I was by myself and felt like it was an absurd amount of food (absurd in a good way).  I definitely had to put some aside so I'd have room for the bibimbap.

I had the bibimbap with chicken and vegetables.  It was good, though slightly bland, and I was disappointed there wasn't siracha or another chili sauce on the table.  Definitely could have used a little more heat - I am a huge weenie when it comes to spicy foods, so you know it was mild.  Service was a little spotty, so by the time a waiter came by to check if I needed anything, I was already halfway through the meal.  I ended up eating it as is with no additional spicyness.

Total for bibimbap, a diet coke and tip was $20.  Not the greatest deal, but given the amount of side dishes, I felt it was fairly reasonable. If I had that same meal on a weekday, the cost would have been half that as part of their lunch special, so that might be a better bet.  

Overall, I'd go back if I'm in the nighborhood, but I don't know if I'd need to make a special trip.
author: Kent E.

description: This has been my goto place for soondubu. Not sure what was up this time. We were a party of five and the condiment offerings were so skimpy that we had to request 3 reloads. Luckily, the food was very good and tasty. Knocking it down one star for the lack of kimchi and the effort it took to get more.
author: Scott W.

description:
What happened?  I used to frequent MTH when I was a denizen of the Richmond and it was satisfying on a cold night.  I was going to say Winter but lets face it, night time is cold in the Richmond regardless of the season.  

My family wanted to have a nice value conscious dinner so we selected MTH remembering that it was solid back in the day.

The silky tofu soup we  fondly recall is no more.  The tofu was crumbly and didn't taste fresh.  The Kal bi was okay, but you can't really go wrong with fatty short ribs.  I am mourning my kimchee tofu soup.  I guess I have to look for a new place.
author: Monica L.

description:
one word.

MEH.

- Ban-chan (mini appetizers) were a total of 5 dishes, therefore I was terribly disappointed by the meager selection.
- For their signature dish, the Combination Tofu Soup needs some work.
- Kalbi was delicious but slightly greasier than other places.

+ nice, cozy atmosphere, perfect for lingering conversations over a hot cup of tea
+ service was on point AND they chased us down when we forgot our credit card.  

Kudos for the cool servers!
author: Lisa W.

description:
3.5 stars

After shopping and buying a bunch of stuff next door at First Korean Market, we decided to have a late lunch here.  There were 2 large parties and 5 smaller parties of 2-4.  We were seated pretty quickly and the menu was already on the table.  The tea and the waiter actually took another 15 minutes...maybe because the two large parties were just a bit much for a 2 person staff.

The tea must have been sweetened with brown sugar because that's what it tasted like.  What we ordered:

fried noodle soft tofu - tofu boiled w/ ramen and vegetable - spicy - $10.05 - piping hot and tasty. better if they had a little more ramen 

bulgoki - $18.04 - broiled thin sliced rib eye - good, finely sliced onion covered the iron platter cover with lots of beef mixed with sliced mushroom 

lots of side dishes, including small fried fish,  kimchee, radish, bean sprouts, cucumber and anchovies

menu is pretty limited like other tofu house...actually I think they have a little more selection such as seafood pancake.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I would say this is one of the better Korean restaurants if you're craving some good Korean food!

I came here with two of my friends for dinner on a weekday. It wasn't too crowded, we didn't have to wait in line. 

I ordered a bi bim bap while my friends just shared this beef dish and tofu soup in medium spicy. Appetizer dishes and side dishes comes with the meal I would assume? Kimchee wasn't too great, maybe I was never a fan of kimchee. But their pickled cucumbers are yummy.

We cracked an egg into the soup, I tried some, it was DELICIOUS. I'd recommend their soups. My bi bim bap just tasted like any regular bi bim bap at other Korean restaurants, except for DOUBLE the price.. tsk. And we had extra rice left too.

Definitely try their soup though. My friends really like the beef, also.
author: Tina C.

description:
ommggg this place is soooooo good! and indeed, you have to come here to get their tofu soup! on a cold winter day, it's the best remedy :) 

if you don't know what you want, get the combination tofu soup, which includes seafood and beef. i got extra spicy and it was delicious! they don't give you a lot of side dishes but i liked the kim chi and they give you a full plate of that! they also give you fish as side dish. the tofu soup is really good. i liked every bit of it. the egg at the end with the egg cooked just enough that the egg white turns white and the yolk is still a little raw. 

we came here on a wed night and still waited for over 30min but it's totally worth it.
author: Joyce B.

description: This serves really good soondubu and the fried herrings they serve with it are fantastic. Friendly servers and really cozy dining space. Reasonable prices and good food is a plus.
author: Shelly M.

description:
I ate here this morning with my friend.  We walked in around 11:30 and got seated immediately.  We were greeted by the server with a friendly smile.  I appreciate places where the workers can speak English or at least make an attempt instead of glaring at you.  

We both ended up ordering the dumpling soondubu because come on, who doesn't want dumplings in their soondubu.  This is the first place I saw with it.  AND it was WELL WORTH IT!  I ordered mine spicy and it came out in about 10-15 minutes.  The pot was boiling, the way I like it so that the egg can cook properly.  It was the perfect spicy and the tofu tasted great!  I hate places that have tofu that is too old and should have been thrown away but instead they threw it in your pot.  The meat was just alright.  I like that they gave fish for banchan which made the lack of other banchan forgivable.  However, the little banchan they had was good.  Normally, Korean restaurants are hit or miss with banchan but it was a hit here.  They also cook the rice in the hot pot which always tastes a tad bit better than the ones cooked in the large industrial sized rice cookers.  

Being used to home-made soondubu from my mom or BCD in LA, this is probably the closest to great soondubu you're going to get in San Francisco.  The service was nice - we didn't have to ask for them to refill our cups and they gave us both hot tea and cold water.  The price isn't bad either for the city - 10.50 for soondubu.  I'd definitely go back here when I'm hung over or need a good home cooked meal.
author: Anna C.

description:
I have slightly mixed feelings about this place.  I don't know if it is because of the hype that 7x7 has given it, but it's fell short of me becoming a fan of it.  I've been here a couple time and each time, the place has not left an impression on me, but I always find myself going back just because this is the only tofu soup restaurant I know of.

The tofu soup bowls are a tad more expensive than what I am used to.  Also, the side dishes are not my fave.  It's the usual mung beans, dried fish, kimchi, cucumbers... I ordered medium soup base, three other families ordering extra spicy, and I ended up getting one too :(  I had a hard time eating it and I ended up the next day with a sad sad stomach. 

Eh... I guess once I move back from SF, I'll have to settle for this for some tofu soup.  Anyone know of a better place that you can rcommend for me?? :)
author: Rosanne L.

description:
very packed but worth it.

I like their fried fish as part of their banchan.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
My Korean friends bitch about it all the time, my non-Korean friends whine about it as well, and on top of that, I totally agree with all of them - REALLY good Korean food in the Bay Area? Totally lacking. One of our only shortcomings though, phew.

But as far as tasty soondubu up here - it doesn't get any better than My Tofu House. When it's cold outside (and it usually is here in San Francisco), what's more ideal than getting into a cozy wooden booth with friends to thaw out with hot, cast iron pots filled with the still bubbling, delicious savory/spicy tofu soup and a heaping bowl of perfectly cooked, short grain rice? Tasty, relatively healthy, and filling. Totally hits the spot. :)

Arguably what would be more of a 3 star joint if My Tofu House were transplanted to Southern California, but up here - it's the best you'll find for tofu soup. The tofu soups range from a reasonable 10-12 dollars (with the usual free sides - kimchi, bean sprouts, pickled radish, fried fish, and a huge pot of rice), you pick your meat (pork, chicken or beef, and the spicy level varies from white/non-spicy to extra spicy. Medium spicy is just right for me, but the mild is pretty tasty as well for those of you who want just a liiiiittle bit of a kick. Whatever level you get, though, the broth will be piping hot and delicious. Trust.

Everything else is passable - the meat is expensive, the appetizers are okay but nothing to write home about (plus, back to the expensiveness - the pancake is priced randomly super high at $17.13 - wtf? Is that necessary?! It's just batter, dude). But you should know that already - what with the name of the place being called My Tofu House and all.

There's always a wait, though it fluctuates randomly. I remember coming here on a Wednesday night one time and having to wait almost an hour, but being able to walk right in on a Saturday evening. The service can be a little slow, but all the servers are always so nice that it's forgivable. Plus, we're desperate NorCalers and we take what we can get when it comes to Korean food, and I'm definitely not gonna mess with a gem like My Tofu House.

A solid four stars, she types up while wearing her NorCal hoodie.
author: Betty W.

description:
My all-time favorite Korean restaurant in San Francisco! It's the best Korean restaurant in the city HANDS down. I honestly need my soondobu from this place at least once a week. Since I've been out in Philly for the last year, all I can do is dream about it.

What makes this place so good is not the myriad of dishes they serve (quite the contrary!), but rather the tofu soup or soodobu as Koreans say. It's the best in town and extremely consistent - that is what makes this place the best - the consistency and of course, taste. They have made a name for themselves on this dish alone and then since they were getting famous, they decided to expand their offering of other typical Korean dishes (pa-jun, dol-sot-bab, kalbi/bulgogi). 

Please don't bother with the other dishes, just stick to the tofu stew!
author: Chihee K.

description:
After all the great reviews about this place, I was more than excited to come here when my date had a hankering for some bibimbap. I should explain that we've been together and in at least half of that time I've LOVED Korean Food; more specifically SoonDobu and he's only started enjoying Bibimbap about a month ago. In fact, I think this was probably his 5'th time eating it. So, our joint exploration of Korean eateries is fairly new and he is still getting his palette acclaimated. I am trying to make sure to keep those experiences positive so that he will continue to want to return. I digress...

We waited about 30 minutes to be seated and, I was pretty excited that there was a long wait - for me it's an indicator of a great meal ahead if that many people love it.

My date and I were led  with 2 other groups to the back room (some nether region between the bathroom and the main dining area, just outside the kitchen). No windows and the only way out was the one way in, which was a narrow doorway covered by a curtain leading to a narrow hallway, passing the kitchen on the way to the main eating area. An afterthought of sorts.

My date orders the Bibimbap and I ordered the mushroom tofu and excitedly said, "spicy!" when the server asked me how spicy. Panchan arrived shortly after and it was pretty good (so this, too, was a good sign!).

They serve us our main dishes, but my date doesn't get his kochujang (the "Korean Ketchup" as we call it) and because we're in the back room, it takes a while before the server comes back for us to ask him for it. By this time, we'd already started eating. I tried both dishes and they were equally bland. The beef in the Bibimbap did not have much flavor, and my soondobu was not as thick as I'd heard it reported and not really that spicy. I added the 2 fishheads from the panchan and let it sit in the stew a bit for some added flavor and the flavor improved to the point where I did not even mind the soupiness anymore.

When the server finally comes back around I ask him for some kochujang for my date and he apologizes and disappears. He comes back a couple more times without it and I ask him again. Again, he apologizes and finally brings us some - my date is more than halfway through his meal at this point.  His meal improves a bit, too after adding the kochujang, but we've been sitting in a tiny window-less room for a good 30 minutes by then and not really enjoying our experience at that point.

The server was nice enough when he was around, but I think the back room left us a bit neglected. The flavors of the dishes were good, but only after some doctoring and one of us couldn't even do that until the kochujang arrived.

After all the reviews I've read about this place, I just can't imagine that this was a typical experience and I think sitting in that back room contributed to my general unhappiness.

In short - maybe if I sat in the front area; maybe if my soup were not as watery and it was actually spicy; maybe if the kochujang came with the meal; maybe I would have had a better experience.

2 stars for the 2 servers that were nice when they were around and for actually refilling my water once.
author: Kariz M.

description:
This place must be crackin popular since I had to wait a good 30 minutes on a Monday night. They seat everyone based on the order in which you put your name down. Some might like this system, some may hate it. People that hate it probably envy the groups of 2 that get seated in the huge booths that can fit 6 people. I got put in one with a group of 4, they really are spacious.

Once we ordered, they brought out about 6 dishes of banchans plus a fish per person. Super plus that they include the fish as part of the side dishes. We ordered soondubu, seafood pancake, and bulgogi. 

 I'm used to socal Korean joints so I feel like I've tasted all the good stuff (in the US atleast). The seafood pancake was the clear winner of the night. Came out piping hot and crispy, it took about ten minutes before I could actually take a legit bite because of the temperature. But once I sunk my teeth into that bad boy, it was well worth the light-weight tongue burn I got from attempting to eat it right after it was served. Great balance between batter and the seafood/veggies.

Tofu soup was tofu soup. 

The bulgogi was definitely lacking, the meat was mushy tasting. Definitely not ordering this dish again.

For a Korean restaurant in San Francisco, not bad. Not bad.
author: Diana W.

description:
The perfect tofu soup would be with RAMEN and DUMPLINGS! and of course, extra spicy because i love the burn!!!! 

The soup is thick, not watery like other places i've tried. I love how they scoop the rice right in front of you out that that hot stone bowl... :)
author: Hanna K.

description:
Could have sworn this place was better when I was back in college! The bf and I had dinner here tonight. The server was super nice and quick on his feet but it took a while for any of the food to come out. We patiently waited while our eyes kept wandering over to the couple next to us who had already received their side dishes and rice. 

Items we ordered was the Original Tofu Soup, Kalbi, and Chicken Bibimbap. The tofu soup was average a little more watery than I remember. Kalbi was good. And the Bibimbap had a unique taste. We didn't love but we were hungry. 

The side dishes were not fermented long enough to get that little taste of vinegar. Somewhat dissapointed...

I recommend heading over to Mom's Tofu House in South San Francisco...much better!
author: Michelle Y.

description: YUMM!!!! MMy new favorite korean restaurant!
author: Lina S.

description:
I'm a regular here and the food is always consistent.  I need to have my spicy tofu soup fix and this is the only Korean restaurant that does it for me.  I came here when they first opened and they've gotten a lot busier since, which is a good thing for them but it's usually a long wait. I always try to beat the rush and go early.  

My dish: Assorted mushroom tofu soup- spicy
His dish: #1 with beef - extra spicy (9x spicy when he feels like it)
author: Anna C.

description:
I was a huge fan of this place, came here once a week... until they served me a half eaten fried fish for one of the side dishes

Maybe it was a mistake, maybe they recycle side dishes (that are not fully consumed), or maybe they do it to reduce the waiting list at dinner time
author: Ming S.

description:
good place.

their soon tofu was very nice cooked but nothing so spectacular about them either.
it's worth traveling up there and trying their soontofu if you're looking to have an authentic experience with korean food.
author: Sung C.

description:
This is the one place that I consider a pure tofu house in SF that I've been to, and I really liked it the times I came.  The menu style reminds me of when I visited friends in LA and they introduced me to the popular tofu house in Koreatown down there.  There is a place I went to in Cupertino Village I went to at that also reminds me, but unfortunately it also reminds me of something personal I rather forget, which is why I don't go there anywhere even when down there.)

Last time I came I even got bold and ordered the spiciest soup, and it was good.  For a long time I only ordered medium spicy fearing I couldn't handle the next level now that I got older, but found that I definitely can and enjoyed it. ;)

I tried coming last Saturday but there was still quite a line even around 9pm.  So I tried the Wooden Charcoal BBQ place a few doors over instead.  There's always next time for this place.
author: H K.

description:
Very fond memories of this place ... it was my first date with my boyfriend and I had always loved My Tofu House so when he recommended we grab dinner, I certainly didn't hesitate.

I think this place has the best bulgogi (sp?) in the city and the lunch prices are outstanding (the price almost doubles for dinner, but the portion size remains the same).  I love the unlimited side dishes and the tofu soup bowls are perfect for a cold day in San Francisco.  

The staff have always been very friendly and efficient and most patrons are there for the good food instead of the ambiance.

Parking sometimes can be a little painful, but just circle around a few times - it's worth it!
author: Whitney Q.

description:
BBQ Beef Bibimbap-  Very good.  Many delicious sides included a whole fried fish (herring?).  
Kim chi Tofu Soup- Another 7x7 Big Eat SF let down.  I don't know who is in charge of that list, but this stuff was just a step above mediocre.  Get a clue!  It wasn't bad and they weren't kidding around when I asked for it spicy, but definitely not one of THE BEST dishes in SF.  And it was about $9 a bowl.  I liked the Bibimbap better.  
I will be back for the Bibimbap.
author: Dan L.

description:
It was cold and windy one Thursday night. It was freezing and foggy. Depressing. I'm sure the Zodiac Killer would've loved it. 

My best friend and I drove by MTH and I screamed, "PULL OVER!" I had totally forgotten about this place. I had come here once and loved it. There was a line and we had to wait about 10 minutes. Shortly after, we were seated at our table and given complimentary hot tea and little Korean appetizers.

Kimchi tofu soup -  I ordered it "not spicy" & I'm pretty sure my waitress snickered. My friend can handle her spicy so she was pretty dissapointed that I ordered it not spicy - I know, I ruin everyone's day. 

The Bal Ki is delicious - it's meaty.  I was on a month-long trek of not eating red meat, but I had to give in to the Bal Ki -- it is phenomenal. I'm also one of those crazies who eat everything -- but the bone, so believe me - when I tell you that I ate that meat around the bone like it was no one's business. I'm a sav. 

The total came to about $30 - how sweet! Everything was delicious, the service was nice and the price was right. I just recommend going early so you can skip the line.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Droooool... I don't usually like soondubu, but I asked for mine spicy and it was freakin awesome. LOVE IT. My mouth was a little bit numb by the end but it was a good numbness. =)

I would have liked it if they gave us bigger portions of the side dishes we asked for refills on like other Korean restaurants do, so we don't have to ask repeatedly... the service is kind of forgetful as well, but they were busy, and asking twice will get the job done.

So delicious. I'd go back for sure.
author: Daphne L.

description:
This place is all hype. People rave about this restaurant as if it is the best Korean restaurant in the city. Well, it's not. 

This place is way overpriced. Ended up paying $60 for two people. We had a less than mediocre mushroom tofu soup. I could have asked for hot water with bland spices to have a comparable dish. We also had a Daeji Bulgogi (pork) and the Kalbi (short ribs). Although both dishes were pretty tasty, they were pretty small and expensive. Not worth the price.

Service was also terribly slow. I waited for a table for two for 15 minutes even though there were several tables open. The employees didn't bother to bus the tables and allow us to sit. During the meal, they didn't refill our water or side dishes. They barely noticed we were there until the check came.

Go eat somewhere else, this one is a let down.
author: Alexander C.

description:
Good tofu soup for cold, foggy nights.

However prices have gone up since I've been there and the ban cha selection has been culled down a bit.
author: e l.

description: Long line out the door on a cold night.  This is a very popular place on Geary.  I got a medium spicy assorted soft tofu soup, which wasn't spicy enough for me.  The soup was decent.  We wanted to order the vegetable pancake but they didn't have any pancakes that night.  The banchan is pretty limited - fish cake, daikon, kimchee, croaker, bean sprouts and pickled cucumbers. The croaker was pretty interesting.  I'm not sure why there is a long line here.  Overall, the food is good but it's not THAT good.   Service is decent also.  I wonder if this is related to my tofu house in san mateo.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Wow, the soft tofu soup is really amazing. I've been here a few times but I always order the soup because it is one of my favorite dishes in the city.

During the winter, or on rainy days, I often think about coming here for that scrumptious dish. The only problem, is that the inner richmond is not exactly easy to get to without a car..
author: Greg T.

description:
My favorite tofu place.  I used to come here for lunch once a week when I was still at USF.  Great tasty sides and really good flavorful tofu soup.  
Parking is kind of a pain but well worth it.
author: Erick L.

description:
Positives:
-It's good on a cold day.
-The Korean BBQ is really flavorful and the meat melts in your mouth.
- I like sampling all the little dishes before the meal.

Negatives:
-It's expensive. Over $10 for a soup with tofu and tiny, tiny pieces of beef? Ridiculous.
-I felt rushed... and I hate that feeling. Because it's so popular, there were tons of people waiting for our table, so we felt obligated to leave as soon as we finished our meal. Not cool.

The soup was good, but I could have made it at home.
author: Elyse H.

description:
I'm glad the bf suggested this place for dinner. I have been fighting a cold for over a week and what better way to clear up your sinuses than a bowl of uber hot tofu soup? Yup, sounds good, right?

He had the medium spicy kimchee and I had the mild assorted mushroom tofu soup. The spicy level is a little extreme here... his was a little too spicy and mine barely had any kick to it at all. Nonetheless, the soup itself was quite tasty.  We shared a plate of Kalbi and i loved it. the meat was super tender, I did not mistaken their kalbi for beef jerky like I normally do in most Korean restaurants in SF/Peninsula. Unfortunately, the menu is a little expensive compared to most Korean joints i've been to (3 plates and 2 sodas= $48), comes with a limited selection of side dishes and they do not carry jap chae!!!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
side dish was ok
combo tofu soup was good
everything else is pricy
author: Diane W.

description:
I ordered the kalbe (BBQ Short ribs), the ramen tofu soup and the combination tofu soup and we shared everything between the 3 of us.  The company was definitely enjoyable =) I don't get to hang out with them much but this is about the food...so no more side tracking...

Any ways.  The Kalbe (BBQ short ribs) were delicious! it was perfectly cooked, nice tender, juicy, and the perfect amount of fat.  The sauce was sweet and perfectly balanced.  Over all this dish is proabably one of the best plate of short ribs I've ever had.  

The ramen tofu soup was okay.  I think the ramen was rather soggy for my liking and the soup wasn't anything spectacular.  I'm not a big tofu soup fan so maybe that's why.  The tofu it self however was rather smooth and soft.  It was really hot and it was just perfect when you took a bite.  The satisfaction of eating tofu is definitely satisfied.

The other combination soup was pretty much the same thing.  It had beef and seafood,  I want to say they were kinda skimped on the seafood and the beef and the soup was just mainly tofu. which is good but i wish there was more of the other stuff.

The side dishes are good, kimchi was pretty good, not the best ever but not bad at all.  The fish was OFF THE HOOK. I had to ask for an extra one because that piece of fish was just so yummy.

The service was okay.  we beat the rush...but still they were kinda stingy when we asked for extra rice (which never came) and we had to ask multiple times for side dishes refills.

4 stars because it was a great experience but not perfect...
author: Zu W.

description: I'm a little surprised to find all the raving reviews, because the food had a lot of msg (then again, all Asian restaurants have a lot of msg). But the food was typical for a Korean joint, and in my perspective, it was a bit over priced for these items. I mean all items seem to round out to be about $18 per plate. But overall, the food was alright, and the service was okay...they never stopped by to check on us, we had to flag people down.
author: Minette C.

description:
Hungover and bleary-eyed, I stumbled into My Tofu House the morning after Halloween in dire need of nutrients and hot and spicy tofu soup!  My roommate and I were one of the few patrons at the restaurant, so the service was fast and I quickly had a hot, steaming claypot bowl of spicy beef tofu soup with ramen in front of me!  Just putting my face over the rising steam helped wake me up and feel better!

Adding the ramen to the tofu soup was money!!! 

After eating every bite of the soup, and washing it all down with a sharp 7-up, I felt immensely better! 

There's nothing quite like hot tofu soup to revitalize the body and fill you up with comforting goodness.  It'll get rid of your hangover and goes a long way in piecing together the dignity you probably lost the night before!
author: James C.

description:
I came here with high expectations due to all the reviews my co-workers told me, so I was pretty letdown when all I got was a mediocre bowl of tofu...I tried really hard not to be disappointed since it did take my friend and I a good 40 mins to get to the restaurant on public transit. 
We each ordered a bowl of tofu soup and a shared kalbi. Sure it satisfied the craving, but it wasn't as fantastic as I thought it was going to be, definitely not a place that is worth going to before you die (in my opinion). If you're really about to die and you want some amazing tofu, just come down to LA and you can find all the tofu restaurants you're dying little heart desires. 
Plus the prices were pretty steep for just tofu, $10+ for a bowl of tofu? It's around $7-8 in LA!
author: Michelle W.

description:
dol sot bibimbap was one of the best i've had.  side dishes, perfectly refreshing.  tofu soup itself...considering i don't even really like tofu that much, it was pretty stellar.  great flavor in the broth.  but the highlight here...

seafood pancake.  amazing.  best i've ever had.  this alone is worth the trip.

also, my korean friend approved.
author: Robert S.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! One of my favorite places to go with friends !! Very traditional korean food place and the food was delicious! We ordered the pancakes and soups and bibimbap ! My favorite was the soups it was delicious! Been here a lot ! I am glad they have so many reviews and are recognized!
author: Sophia W.

description: My tofu house seriously never disappoints. The food was exceptional as always.  love love everything!!!!! Soooooo delicious!!!!
author: Jiwoo L.

description: We went here during the weekend for a late lunch and two of us ordered the tofu soups from the menu for about $10.60 each.  We didn't realize it when we ordered but the soups came with all the traditional Korean small side dishes (vegetables, kimchi, and some fish) which ended up great.  The restaurant itself was fairly busy but the three waiters managed to be attentive enough and get our food to us within a reasonable amount of time.  Some of the other traditional Korean meals are not available on the weekends for the lunch portion/price but the larger/costlier dinner portions are.  I'll likely go back during the evening hours to try their other items as the soups we ordered for lunch were very flavorful.
author: Kent W.

description:
I'm drooling just thinking of the great food I've had here.  I love it here.  The only problem is that parking can be difficult.  But it's not the restaurant's fault, so I am not taking a star off for that!

Usually when I eat here, I get the MEDIUM SPICY seafood combination tofu soup (although I have tried ALL the tofu soup flavors!!  MY next favorite is the Kimchi tofu soup)  and we usually share spicy pork :D   

I love the tea they serve.  I always get to manage to drink a few cups every time I eat here  :)  The banchan are good too! They have fried fish, anchovies, kimchi, bean sprouts and daikon (i think!)... but my fave is their pickled cucumber!  PLUS you get MELON GUM at the end of each meal!    

The dinner is pricier than lunch like other korean restaurants....(I think for dinner the restaurants use gold pots and pans or something....that might be the reason why it's always more expensive for dinner...or maybe it's something involving Economics too, but I think my gold pots and pans theory  OBVIOUSLY makes more sense...).  Anyway, I digress.

The only thing I didn't like here is the Bibimbab.  But this is because I'm not really a big fan of crunchy rice and also, I think it's too pricey for what it is.  

But, despite the Bibimbap, I still love this place.  I feel at home here, so I'm still giving it 5 stars!  This is still my go-to Korean restaurant even though I live near Mom's Tofu House...  

But that's another yelp review for ya....
author: Erod S.

description:
Had to review this place because of the rude wait staff. He kept moving people around because he was trying to "free up" the other tables (although it wasn't too crowded and no line forming). I understand being a busy restaurant you gotta move fast and think smart, but he showed little respect for his customers and was incredibly impatient with an elderly Korean couple who came in with their daughter to have a nice Sunday lunch. I don't know about them, but he definitely ruined lunch for me. 
I would go to this place strictly for convenience alone. Banchan is sparse (they only give few items compared to other places I've eaten), food is average and prices don't challenge competition- $15 for dolsotbibimbap and $11 for soon tofu. I'll take my business elsewhere.
author: Christine Y.

description:
"If you miss the Korean food in Sunnyvale you might wanna give My Tofu House a try," said one of my co-workers upon hearing my sob story of not being able to find any decent Korean food in SF.

(see below links for support)
http://www.yelp.com/biz/chois-kitchen-santa-clara#hrid:QI2E64QGfIDStq-15oSSbA
http://www.yelp.com/biz/myung-dong-tofu-cabin-san-mateo#hrid:zxwTdUWqafYOCqnSWCnh4w
http://www.yelp.com/biz/jang-su-jang-santa-clara#hrid:Hhvx8FHln5Jg3sI2v2lesg

So I was intrigued, even though Inner Richmond isn't exactly easy to get to (nor is parking situation great).

But one night the three of us went and tried the same old galbi, pork soondobu  and bi bim bap.  The whole thing cost $60, which was definitely a 30% premium compared to their South Bay counterparts.  Guess they have to make enough margin to cover off the overhead.

The dishes were just OK, nothing mindblowing - there was a comparatively much less banchan selection, though they did give us fried mackarel; the tofu soup was a bit thin *and not spicy enough*; and there's extra for rice.  

The same coworker *in the same conversation* did put it so eloquently, "It's no South Bay, but it'll tide you over until the next time you make a trip down there."

word.
author: Ange L.

description:
The banchan here is pretty decent and the bulgogi VERY flavorful. But the main dish that this place is known for, in my opinion, was the worst dish I ate. 

I had the beef soondooboo, medium spicy. The broth was so flavorless. Like they seriously just dumped some soft tofu in hot water, little bit of red pepper flakes and some beef. So tasteless. I was very disappointed. VERY VERY disappointed.
author: Jen D.

description:
Worst. Bi bim bap. Ever.

1) Server was pouring water into our cup and let it overflow, spilling all over our table. But didn't come back to give us more napkins or help us wipe it up

2) They don't give you the red sauce to add to the bi bim bap on your own to adjust the flavor yourself, they add some in already but isn't enough for the entire dish, leaving a lot of rice leftover.

3) They blatantly lied to me and told me they added an egg into my bi bim bap already, when I clearly remember looking for it at the beginning, asking them, and still not finding it at all in my dish.

I will not be back.
author: tianyu c.

description: One of my fav korean spot in SF. Feels like a mom n pop shop but very clean. It's best for cold foggy nights in SF. The Tofu soup is creamy and spicy, just the way i like it. :)
author: Sandy L.

description:
If you're on a budget and looking for a place with great service, this restuarant is NOT what you are looking for.
Many many reasons why I would give this restaurant a rating of two stars. TWO stars because I was really hungry and devoured the bibimbab and tofu soup...and exited feeling bloated..but the other reasons as to why I would not consider coming back here:

1. It is wayyyyyyyy overpriced. the tofu soups all are priced around $10.68, the kimchi or seafood pancakes are priced around $18, the korean bbq bulgogi or galbi dinner plate cost around $20, and the bibimbab (rice mixed with hot paste and vegetables and your choice of either seafood, beef, pork, etc) cost around $15. They do give you a generous portion, but I know I can find better places that are not as costly, especially for their quality of service, which brings me to the next point.

2. Their service SUCKED. We ordered our food and we were given just a few side dishes. I don't know if it's because I'm from Los Angeles and have been to many quality korean restaurants, but this place did not even impress me with their side dishes. They gave a few slices of bland kimchi, some cucumbers, anchovie, radish kimchi, and bean sprouts. Usuallly I'd get about 5-10 more side dishes considering I was with three other people. We also ordered two tofu soups and three bibimbabs, and when our tofu soups were served, they forgot to give us RICE. I had to ask more than once for some rice. And to top it all off I found a piece of hair in my tofu soup!!!!!! BLEKKKKK. I took it out, pretended that I didn't see that because I was so hungry and tried to enjoy my dinnner that i had been looking forward to the whole day. The tofu soup was not too bad, I've definately tried better. They also give you fried fish with the tofu soup. It was a little soggy and almost burnt...............after eating a generous portion of the bibimbab and tofu soup, I needed ice water, so i asked for some ice water, and they forget my request  AGAINN. So I ask one more time and they finally served us some ice water after 15 minutes. We were almost finished with our food. 

The food was decent, service was bad, overall I just felt like I did not get my money's worth, I was stressed after paying the bill :( Never coming back here again. If you want to try some goood tofu soup, I suggest you take a visit to LA's BCD Tofu House, they have the best organic tofu soup and everything is fresh and amazingly good.
author: Tracey K.

description:
Tofu soup is normally one of my main hangover foods, but last night a hangover wasn't my reason for coming here. It was that time again for one of our "girl dinners", and I was surprised that I actually liked the tofu soup here!! 

After 3 tofu soups (kimchee, mushroom, and assorted), kalbi, bulgogi, and the seafood pancake... we left very satisfied. My favorite was the mushroom soup because they'e not lame and use only one kind of mushroom...I at least saw THREE!! :)
Their bulgogi was also really yummy, and shockingly my BFF even thought so. Her being Korean and all, they typically don't care for a whole lot of outside restaurant food since they cant get better...tastier food at home from their momma. SOOO JEALOUS. 

Since my momma will forever be Chinese...I guess I'll just have to come here!!
author: Kristen C.

description: One of the best places for tofu soup in SF. The wait can be pretty long, but definitely worth it.
author: Leslie C.

description:
My boyfriend (who is Korean) and I went to My Tofu House recently with a couple of friends. On the way there, he tried to teach me how to say "soon tobu" which ended up sounding like "soon to (use number two)" when I pronounced it. Yeah....I'm going to avoid trying to say anything in Korean by the way. I don't want to offend or gross anyone out.

My Tofu House is clean, but not too clean where the food wouldn't be good. A supreme upgrade of a hole in the wall restaurant. I heard the prices went up, but everything is still less than $20.

We got to MTH at around 6:45PM on a Saturday, so they sat us as soon as we got in. The staff was really nice. They didn't mind that our whole party hadn't arrived and were very cool that we pretty much just sat there talking for 15 minutes while waiting. After we sat down, the crowds started lining up at the door. (Perfect timing.)

We ordered:

Tofu Soup x3 (perfect for a cold night)

Kalbi (delicious)
  
Spicy Pork (definitely made my nose run)

We were all stuffed by the time we were done eating. I KIND OF (just kind of) wish that I didn't wear my new skinny jeans and wore my fat jeans instead. Haha, okay...who am I kidding? I don't have fat jeans!!! (I do. And next time I come back, I will definitely be wearing them...with a sweatshirt.)
author: Maureen B.

description:
I certainly hope that this isn't the best that SF has to offer in Korean food. Maybe I'm spoiled from decades of LA Korean food. But really SF? REALLY?!

The food here was pretty meh. For being a Tofu House, their soon doo bu was the weakest dish out of the three my friends and I ordered. That is a damn shame. The other two, which were the dol sut bi bim bap and the dae ji bul go gi (spicy pork) were ok. Spicy pork was on the verge of being way too sweet. 

Ban chan was ok. Not anything special. It was nice to have that typical grilled fish dish. 

Price for value and quantity? Don't even get me started. 

Safe to say, I won't be coming back here anytime soon. =P Hopefully there are more redemptive Korean places around the Bay area.
author: Beck P.

description:
oh spicy tofu soup, how much do I love thee? Um, very much. 

Tofu soup here is perfection. Sometimes there is a wait for a table, but its good. They prepare excellent tofu soup and also the bulgogi and kalbi are decent. You will be leave happy and full. =)
author: Jennifer T.

description: This place is definitely small and you need to make a reservation if you have a big group of people. We came here for a family dinner (about 10 of us) and we were in a separate room which was really nice. The food was good and we had a variety of different things but this place is a little on the expensive side. Anyways, satisfies my Korean food craving and that's all that matters!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I love korean tofu stew! ....but this place is only okay.. I was really excited when my friend suggested that tofu house for dinner but I was disappointed.  I ordered the mild mushroom tofu stew and it was really bland.  I know I know, I did ordered MILD but the mild mushroom tofu stew that I have had and fell in love with in Socal was so much better.  

The panchai was pretty standard so nothing to complain there.
author: Tina T.

description:
I love the spicy soft tofu soup at this restaurant. It's the perfect level of spiciness and the pot is sizzling hot when it comes out. I love to go here whenever it rains and is cold outside; however, it gets pricy. Each soup is around $14. I think it used to be only $10. However, I would still go back because I love their food. Each soup can be specialized to the level of spiciness that you prefer: non-spicy, mild, and spicy. In addition, they have very good seafood pancakes. They taste so good when dipped with the accompanying soy sauce. 

Note: the side dishes are great. They have very good picked cucumbers.
author: Anh W.

description:
7x7 list - http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

#9 - Tofu soup with kimchi  - nothing to rave about 

I didn't want to even come here but b/c my bf is OCD and wants to complete this darn list together, I had to sit through it. There was a wait for a table even! Obviously, these folks don't know what good soondubu SHOULD taste like. 

Spicy pork and vegetable bibimbap was not appealing either. I will not have a second thought for a revisit next time....hate wasting my calories for "meh" food.
author: Katie K.

description: Me and my friend had always wanted to try this place out since it was a four star rating on Yelp. We finally had a chance to tried it out tonite. I was so disappointed with the food. We order the seafood tofu soup, seafood rice bowl and the rib eye. The seafood soup was so tasteless, over stuff with just tofu barely any seafood in it except for two small shrimp. We pay $12 for that. Then came seafood rice bowl which also barely had any seafood in it. ($17) then came the rib eye. The rib eye came out cold and greasy ($23). And it taste so nasty being that it's cold. The waiter were so rude and it took them forever to bring us our bowls for our soup. Had to asked them twice before they finally came back with the bowls. This is the most disgusting Korean food I ever ate. As we start leaving the resturant my stomach hurts like hell. I barely made it to a bathroom. I felt like vomiting and didn't feel good at all. I think I had food poisoning. Their food is so nasty and they're over charging it. We ended up paying $57 for two of us excluding tips. The worst Korean restaurant I ever been to. If you don't want to end up having dirareah and vomiting please don't go there.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I have to agree with the other ppl who noticed that the tofu was crumbly and not in large silken chunks.  It really put a damper on my mood.  

I ordered the mushroom tofu in very extra spicy.  There were noticeably fewer mushrooms than last time.  In fact, it barely had any mushrooms at all.  And the mushrooms that it did have looked limp and sad.  It was crying in my soup.  Sad sad mushrooms.  This place has really declined.  I don't know if it's the recession, but the quality has gone down.  

I love tofu soup and I used to crave it, eat it and want it all the time.  But after this experience, I'm willing to wait until I have an opportunity to go to the south bay.  This place isn't worth it.  Not even the whole fried fish makes up for it.  And the kim chee was not as good.  The tiny fish was still tasty, but, if you can't even make decent kim chee, can you really depend on the rest of the Korean food?

I don't think so.
author: Christina C.

description:
2.50 stars.

Came here with a large group (10+), and they were fairly accommodating.  Since this is a tofu house, a lot of us ordered their tofu soup. I ordered the stone-pot rice. I heard from my friends who ordered the tofu soup say that it was not filling at all. They ended up going to grab a burger later. For me, the stone-pot rice did not have much flavor and taste to it. Further, I remembered the price to be high for the quality/taste and portion of the food. 

I would unlikely come back.
author: Sam W.

description:
I was pretty excited to munch at My Tofu House because I had heard such great things about the place, however I was quite disappointed.  There wasn't anything special about the interior,the place looked like any other typical restaurant: kind of bland.  

There is one thing I have to make clear:  I LOVE KOREAN FOOD PERIOD, especially the mini appetizer dishes.  However,  I was pretty disappointed when the dishes were brought out because they were just mediocre, eh.  The insipid tofu soup was also disappointing.  I could have gone to the one on Taraval and gotten it for free!  The Kalbi beef, what more can I say.  For $19.99 it tasted like something my lil sister could make.  It was greasy and lacked vigor.  The texture did not taste at all like "bbq" it was as if they boiled it and slapped on some flavor.  ICK. 

Over all,  I give it a medium on the spectrum.  Don't get me wrong I still ate the whole thing, but it wasn't what I had expected because I guess I had expected too much.
author: tammy c.

description: i love all their tofu soups here!! i love the one with dumplings, the seafood one, the original one etc! all are good! i also love their biimbap...they have generous portions of meat or seafood, veggies in their hot stoneware. its always so yummy here, i cannot wait to go back! =)
author: Stella J.

description:
I haven't tried too many Korean places in the city other than Shin Toe Bul Yi and The Spot, but I have to say (although I don't have much to compare from) My Tofu House serves up really good authentic Korean food.

The scene:

There was a group of 7 of us and we got there before the dinner rush so we were able to get a table right away.

Like every other Korean restaurant, there were a ton of appetizers - kimchi, pickled radishes, anchovies, and pickled zucchini. And, they give refills! We each got a small fried fish which was so good! I think it was fried with some kind of a black bean batter.

The food:

Each person got a soup and the total came to $13 per person.

Tofu and Kimchi Soup - We are all fanatics of the 77 Big Eat SF 100 Things You Must Try Before You Die list, so a majority of us ordered the spicy tofu and kimchi soup. When ordering the dish, you pick the level of heat and what kind of meat you want in it. I chose spicy with beef. The soup contained a few thin slices of beef, soft tofu, kimchi and tons of chili flakes. The sizzling hot soup is served in a clay pot with a raw egg in which you crack open and cook in the broth. They also give you a side of short grain rice to put in your soup. The bowl of soup itself looks small, but once you add in the rice and egg, you'll be loosening your belt.

I thought it was good, but I didn't see why this particular soup was on the 77 list. To me, the soup tasted exactly like the free soup you get at Shin Toe Bul Yi on Taraval. The only thing that stood out of the meal was the fried fish. Yum, I'd come back just for that.
author: Sam L.

description: So, there's lotsa Korean to choose from in the CIty, but you sure as hell cannot go wrong here. Clean, fast and almost always busy when I want to eat there, but it is sooooo worth it. There're Korean places that are good for specifics, but these guys cover about 75% of it or more. Order any of the soft tofu pots and you'll be well presented with some of the best warm -your-soul food. DO NOT FORGET the pancakes (best I've tried yet out of the dozen or so places I've ordered one). Get some extra croaker and settle in for 60 minutes of face stuffing bliss.
author: Tristan C.

description: Wow! I've heard a lot about their tofu soup so I finally gave it a try. They serve it to you boiling hot so don't forget to throw in the egg they give you. I ordered the spicy original tofu soup which definitely quite tasty. It was so good, I couldn't even finish it. It's perfect if you're looking for a warm meal on a cold night. They also bring you a ton of extras like fish, kim chee, and some sprouts before you get your soup. My only complaint was that they didn't put enough mushrooms in it. Otherwise, I can definitely see why this place is so popular. Just don't go to the wrong place because we saw the sign but we accidentally dropped into another Korean place a few doors down!
author: Amy J.

description:
I've had the hugest craving for spicy seafood tofu soup.  Decided to give Tofu House a try.  We arrived around 6:30p on a Sat. night and there was already six parties ahead of us.  Sign in on the clipboard and browse the market next door while you wait.

By the time we were seated, I couldn't control myself and ordered the spicy tofu soup, bulgogi, and seafood pancake.  The pancake was pricey at $17.50 and I was expecting a huge flour/egg omlette filled with tons of seafood.  Instead it was more like an appetizer -- small, chewy, flour-like, circle with tiny shrimp and half-bite-size pieces of squid.  Such a let down.  Bulgogi was sliced super thin.  Tofu soup was okay, but not as flavorful or spicy as other places I've tried.  Side dishes were pretty good.  Kim chi was awesome and the whole fish was yummy.

Maybe I was expecting too much, but I didn't think the food was that spectacular.  Service was good though and the restaurant is nice compared to other tofu restaurants -- date worthy.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Tofu soup is good, except mild has no kick at all this time; maybe I ordered the medium last time when I was here or I have built up my spicy tolerance? Either way, guess I will have to up it to medium next time......
Oh, love their side dishes, especially the fried fish; it was a treat that they serve you a whole fish :) When the server set it on our table, we were looking at each other like, wait, did we order that?
Tried their beef and vegetable bi bim bap, it was a bit bland.  Well I agreed they are called "My TOFU House" for a reason. Oh, minus prob.  1/2 stars for something that has raw garlic in it and left my mouth feeling thirsty all night.
author: Prascilla L.

description: Caught up with my friend for some Korean last night.... Her impending Korean tour had her in the mood for some spicy Korean tofu stew. She had the medium spicy stew (combo) and I shared a seafood pancake with her. Ample food portions, nice service, and you get a stick of Korean fruity gum at th end. Tip: come at 6:30pm or earlier to avoid the line.
author: Patricia M.

description:
I love the restaurant hours for this place. When my friends and I decide to eat Korean BBQ or Tofu, it's always at a late time, somewhere passed 9pm. Usually most restaurants close at the time but not this one. It closes at 9:30 or 10PM. First off, I love the side dishes, they give you FRIED FISH (YUM!) and fish in some SAUCE (YUM!) and lots more. The cucumber is also delicious too. I finish this first all the time and find myself ordering many cucumber side dishes. The tofu is delicious. I get the spiciest because I love my tongue burning. If it's not spicy, then it's not good. That's my motto. The seafood tofu is good!! As for the meat, I wasn't too impressed with it. It was good. I admit it but it wasn't out of this world. 

Service is good but sometimes you have to wait awhile to get seated or receive service because it's always busy during dinner time or so. Overall, this is a great place to go if you live in SF.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
It was almost closing time when I squeezed my way through the door of this restaurant, so I ordered everything to-go. Quick, efficient, and the waitress was very nice (she offered me tea while I sat at a table and waited for my food). I didn't particularly feel like eating something super spicy that night, and all I really wanted were those delicious Korean side dishes. 

- Original soft tofu soup w/chicken and mushrooms, not spicy: Your choice of meat (beef, pork, or chicken) and choice of spiciness (spicy, medium, mild, not spicy). It also comes with a bowl of rice. I've tasted tofu soups that are not spicy from other Korean restaurants and this one was a disappointment. No flavor at all, very bland. I wish they gave some more vegetables besides mushrooms. 

Side Dishes included:
 - Pickled cucumber topped with sesame seeds: This one was pretty bland, only a hint of vinegar. 
- Chili-pickled daikon: This saved my soup and gave my soup the flavor it was lacking.
- Kim chi: bland, I seriously only tasted the chili. 
- Bean sprouts: flavorless, but it was a good non-spicy side dish.

I was disappointed that I only got 4 side dishes in my to-go order, as opposed to other restaurants that provide me with at least 6-8 dishes. Everything was bland, although I ordered non-spicy for my soup, they should have some chicken flavor to it at the least. 

Tracy's Tip of the Day: Don't go to restaurants during closing time = reject leftovers! 

P.S. They have little grills and numerous dishes like bimbimbab, BBQ dishes, and Korean pancakes too (maybe these would have been better?)!
author: Tracy T.

description: tofu soup! i love cracking my own egg into the hot steaming soup. they also have great service. love their side dishes here.
author: Kristina L.

description: I felt the service here was very poor.  Some people here had a bad attitude and were being rude to customers.  There may be other people who work there that are nice but I felt that the customer service just wasn't there.
author: Aron L.

description: The beef tofu soup is good but can use more kimchi and spices to thicken the soup
author: Cliff T.

description: My Tofu House offers a variety of soon doo boo (spicy tofu soup).  The soup is rather light, not in flavor, but traditional SDB should be a lot thicker.  There's just something to be said about spooning out really thick and spicy SDB that I really enjoy on a cold and foggy SF night.  Don't get me wrong, it's definitely the best place tofu soup if you looking to stay in the city and don't want to drive out to the East Bay or the South Bay.  It's the best restaurant that serves SDB in SF.
author: Wendy S.

description:
My Tofu House is wonderful.

Their tofu soup, seafood pancake, and bibimbap are delicious and reasonably priced!  I also love all the little kimchi side dishes that you get.

It's in my regular cheap eats dinner rotation!
author: Carol L.

description:
I found my go-to soondubu spot in the City.  Love the panchan (mostly for the fried fish), the kimchi is "ok";  I've had better elsewhere.  But I love the #1 special - extra spicy with pork - it's delicious.  Lots of tofu, and meat; just the way I like it.  It really hits home on nights like these - cold, dreary and dismal.  Nothing like MTH to keep me warm.  Been there twice in the past month - that's how much I like it.  First time was at 7:30 - long line.  Second time at 7:00 - no line, but by 7:20, there were people hovering.  

(Helps that one of the waiters is handsome and very nice, too.)
author: Christie X.

description:
Likes: the tofu soup (perfect for a cold day), the side dishes, bibimbap (remove the top layer of red sauce if you cannot take spicy.  i didn't do that)

Dislikes: waiting for tables
author: Karen M.

description:
I love Korean food...love all the yummy side dishes that they kick in for you when you sit down...yum.  My Tofu House doesn't give you as much as other korean restaurants but they give you actual whole fried fish, which is soo yummy. the mini fishes are sweet & candied. really delicious. 

I had the ramen noodle tofu soup spicy $8.95 - it actually was spicy as promised! yay! ate it with rice that comes with the meal..and it is a FULL meal! doesn't look like much at first...but you'd be surprised once you hit halfway thru your bowl! 

The ramen was nice & chewy, not soft & gooey. tofu was delicious..and i would so go back...like right now. 

definitely go check out My Tofu House if you haven't had a chance to.
author: Lulu C.

description:
this place is mostly wooden booths with old style  overhead venting 
hoods. there's a flatscreen in the middle of the eatery

ordered the seafood tofu  soup, spicy (9.91) which came boiling hot. 6 banchan including  a fried mackeral  accompanied a whole stonepot of boiled rice.  the tofu soup had 3 oytsers, 3 clams, 3 shrimps a raw egg. 

there's a lunch special (8.99-10.00)  avaialble bibimbap(14.52) seems pricey but there was value in the tofu soup i had. they give pretty of  food.

the service seem wooden  but adequate. ample refills of  banchan available. the server seem slow but steady.

note: parking is bad here. no doubt sf makes $$ from parking fines from
the people who misjudge their time here,
definitely a place to repeat.

dessert: melon gum.
author: Victor G.

description: The tofu soup is delicious here!  We also enjoyed the bulgoki and it was tasty and tender. The bibimbap was ok.
author: Winnie L.

description:
this is my and every-other-person-and-their-mother's go-to soon dubu place in the city. even though the prices continue to inch higher and higher, it's worth it for the rich, flavorful, consistent quality of soon dubu. i've tried once and again to replicate the recipe at home and it never works. they work some kind of magic here that a chinese girl trying to cook korean food can never do.

my favorites here are the mushroom and the original--why venture too far from something that works, right? i've also tried the kalbi (tasty and thick), chicken (good), and also the bibimbap (good). looking forward to try the tofu salad one day--have always been curious about it--and re-try the pancakes (i guess they weren't as memorable as other places).
author: Andrey C.

description: One of the best tofu places in the city. The service is usually pretty good, but they're always in a hurry so catch the servers when they're running by. I love their pickled cucumbers, I probably go through 3 bowls on my own. I've had almost every tofu soup and they're all good. The Kalbi is good as well, but the price seems to go up every time I come. The last time I went I tried the seafood pancake and it was one of the best I've had. It comes on a cast iron plate and is super crispy when you bite into it.
author: Adelina W.

description:
What to order:  The soondubu (tofu soup)... duh!
Price:  Good.  Normal for soondubu. Less than $10
Portions: Normal.  Is it just me or do they skimp on the tofu?  Doesn't it only cost about $1 for an entire package of tofu?  Why skimp on it?  They give you A LOT of rice though.  Maybe because I was by myself but I literally had 3 bowls of rice.... It's cooked in a huge stone pot- the best way to cook rice!
Flavor: It was a bit bland... 
Banchan:  The kimchi was very good here.  Mmmm...
Parking:  Street parking.  Not horrible but definitely not plentiful
Service:  Good!  Very on top of it
Overall:  Not bad!  I will be sure to return since I'm in the area quite frequently.  I just wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Justine L.

description:
Bleh. I was fooled by all the positive Yelp reviews and finally came here to try their food last night.  I left disappointed. 

I ordered the assorted mushroom tofu soup spicy. First, all I could taste was spice and nothing else. It seemed like they put peppers together with hot water but forgot to add anything else. Secondly, they charge $10 for that tiny bowl! 

We also ordered the bbq chicken and vegetable bibimbap. Nothing special. I've had better in other places in SF. Overall, the food was mediocre, expensive, and the menu is incredibly limited. The only redeeming factor in my opinion is the good customer service.
author: Cee J.

description:
my friend suggested korean bbq so we came here and it wasn't really about the bbq. more about the tofu, which i shoulda noticed from the name. went in and the place was very charming with orchids all around and clean and service was good. they also have very spacious booths which ii really liked. 

the food is a little more expensive than what im used to from socal korean tofu houses. portions were decent. we got the spiciest tofu and pork bibimbab. the tofu was good and i especially liked that they put dumplings into the soup. but the bibimbab was ok. it couldve used alot more flavoring. it was only good when I ate the rice with a piece of the pork and unfortunately there wasntt that much pork in the dish either. 

its a cute date spot .. pricey tho
author: Lee H.

description: Quite mediocre experience considering the hype and wait. Seafood pancake was way too doughy and needed more crispiness. Spicy Kimchi tofu soup lacked depth in flavors and was very one note. Bibimbop was good, great flavors and crispy rice on the bottom was the business. I think this is good but not anything better than your typical Korean Mom and Pop restaurant.
author: Ed L.

description: Thank mister SOON for being a great waiter! He had good manners!  I had dinner here with my girls because we were feeling for some KOREAN FOOD. The portions are perfect. The appetizers were delicious. We ordered the BULGOGI and BIBIMBOP. Both delicious! The place is clean and friendly.  I recommend this place for anyone looking for KOREAN food in the inner RICHMOND! :}!!!!!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Big disappointment. I would've given 2stars but I added one more for the accessibility for people in the city.
First, the beef tofu soup (like $10.50 or something) had more mushrooms than beef (not that there were THAT many mushrooms either), might as well have called it mushroom tofu soup with supplementary beef. Liked idea of rice served in the hot dol-sot, but didn't add that much taste to the rice itself. Soup also came with grilled yellow mackerel(? not sure) fish and side dishes were okay. Oh yeah and the service wan't that nice either. Made me wonder why this place has such a high average rating. 
If you ask me, the food is WAYYY overrated AND overpriced for the quality. I'd rather go to Jang Su Jang or Cheon Joo Young-Yang Dolsot in San Jose. Or I'll just go to Toust in Berkeley - basically same deal without the fancy dolsot rice thing, but at a much more justifiable price.
Sorry guys, but I've seen better.
author: Soo Jung R.

description:
My roommate and I went to My Tofu House last week because 1. it was a cold day in the middle of June and 2. our friend said it was comparable or even BETTER than BCD in L.A. Say whaaat?!

We both ordered the mandoo soondubu, medium spicy, which came with several large mandoos (dumplings) and pieces of dduk (rice cake). We both thought the broth was bland and not nearly spicy enough. Possibly the most flavorful part of the stew was the mandoo filling. As we were leaving, I got the dry-thirsty mouthfeel usually associated with the cheap pho I like to eat when I have a hangover (MSG..?) BUT I can see how that would also make this a great place to eat after a night of mayhem.

You'll be disappointed if you go expecting L.A.-level soondubu (like us.) However, keep your head straight and remember that you're in SF, and it'll taste alright. Possibly even amazing when feeling sick (re: hungover).
author: Leah C.

description:
Great place for korean tofu soups, otherwise a very limited menu.  Service seen to be short handed most of time, 1-2 waiters working hard and efficient to keep things moving.  Usually a 20 minute wait.  
The funny thing here is if you look at their business license hanging in the area you wait at, It saids My Fofu House.
author: Delon N.

description:
definitely did not live up to its hype. People seem to go crazy over how "amazing" this place is. They must not have been to enough korean places. with long wait times and high prices, I thought to myself "this place better be good"

my gf got the tofu soup and i got beef bibimbap. Tofu soup was ok, nothing impressive but it wasnt bad. Bibimbap sucked bibimBALLS. 

ok im going a little overboard, the bibimbap wasnt terrible, but I ordered beef bibimbap and i got what looked like 99% rice and 1% beef. Im serious the meat was almost nonexistent. They shouldnt even be allowed to call it beef bibimbap. I just felt a bit robbed when I left the restaurant. 

The sides are also nothing to rave about. small selection and I've had better sides at a 10$ AYCE korean bbq.
author: Dustin D.

description: Omg its was the best meal i have for the day when i visit san fran!!! Their tofu soup just made my night!!! Also their bibimbap is way too good than any other place i have eaten!!! Love to come back again!!!
author: Cindy L.

description:
I had dinner at this restaurant tonight. It's my 4th time going to this restaurant. I have to say that although this is on the pricier side for Korean food, this restaurant gets 5 stars for being consistently, clean, friendly, great tasting, and gives me my home-cooked fix.

The waiters and waitresses although, they do not talk much, are very acutely aware of their surroundings and have consistently provided a high level of service to me, the times I've gone.

I really enjoy their 'pan-chan' or side dishes. You can really taste their high quality ingredients.

This is also one of the few places that gives you a raw egg to cook in your tofu soup. A+ for that!

My Tofu house is my favorite place for getting a home cooked meal on Geary...... IF I can find parking that is......
author: Jj H.

description:
I ate here tonight for the first time after read the reviews on Yelp. The highlight was the whole fried fish that came as one of the small plates. Absolutely delicious. The kimchi and the other dishes were good, though I've been to other places that were slightly better. 

For dinner I ordered the beef tofu soup with medium spiciness. I was honestly disappointed after reading the reviews, because I thought it was fairly bland. I normally love tofu, but this really didn't taste like much of anything. It wasn't terrible, but at the same time I probably wouldn't go back unless it was to try the bibimbap.

My other complaint is the water glasses. They're tiny, and the waitstaff wasn't very good about refilling them either. Also, serving the hot tea in plastic cups? I'm not a hippy or anything, but I'm not an idiot either. There's no way I was going to drink boiling water out of plastic cup. If these problems were fixed then I'd probably give it an extra star.
author: Alex K.

description:
The chilly weather and word of good soondubu led us to this spot in the Inner Richmond. I was hoping for some soju to get a buzz goin but no alcohol offered here.

Panchan was limited but pretty good. They give you a couple fried fish here as panchan, which I rarely see so I definitely appreciate it. Radish kimchi was my favorite as usual (it's hard to screw it up), while the bean sprouts and anchovies were good, but the cabbage kimchi wasn't the best.

I went for the beef soondubu, medium spicy and liked how it was pretty brothy. Sometimes there's too much tofu and I don't get all the sips of broth that I want. The broth was a deep red color, with good heat for medium, and I noticed it tasted faintly like the style at SGD and Coco Bang. I'm guessing there are different tasting gochucaru flakes? Here, the broth was more balanced though, with enough complexity to satisfy me. 

The quantity of small beef slices was sufficient, a good portion of button mushrooms, and they give you an egg to crack into the soup. My favorite way to eat the egg is to let it poach so I can eat the yolk runny. I also notice that once you mix the egg whites up into the broth, the flavor of the soup tends to diminish dramatically. If you're one to complain about the soondubu not being spicy enough, try it before and after you crack the egg. Big difference.

My favorite soondubu is still, you guessed it, Pyung Chang in Oakland. But in SF, this is my favorite soondubu so far.
author: Derrick V.

description: This is one of my favorite korean restaurants - whenever I have the tofu soup craving, this is the place to go!  Love the tofu soup (very flavorful and hearty), the meat (hmm.. marinaded just the way i like it), and the side dishes (you just can't get enough of it).  The servers are nice too.
author: sandy h.

description: Great Korean food, they give many small dishes. I love their tofu soup but there not much of other choices. It's easy to get bored if you been to this place several times. Overall it's still a good place.
author: Suabot J.

description:
My Tofu House is in a little spot in what seems to be a random section of the Richmond. I've been there twice, and can confirm that yes, their tofu soup is wonderful. I get the medium Kimchee, though for any other tofu soups there, I'll get spicy (obviously, the kimchee has extra hotness to it).

The thought of the soft, spicy tofu in soup is practically making me drool. The beef bibimbap, which we got on our first visit, was only okay. I can't say there was anything remarkable about it, but maybe that's because I was distracted by the tofu soup. So the second time, we got the combination tofu soup and the kimchee tofu soup. They did not disappoint.

I will say, I still don't know if i can get with the rice that they serve....mainly, the garbanzo beans/chickpeas. I still think it's just a weird texture combination. Either way, make sure that they make you rice toast soup! They'll pour tea into the hot stone rice pot, which will lift the crusty, toasty rice off of the surface. Let it sit and thicken just a bit and you'll get rice toast soup. One of my favorite things from my childhood and a great way to finish your meal.

One thing that drives me crazy: twice I've been seated near the entryway and it a little difficult to get tea refills (I said I like spicy, but I didn't mention that I'm weak). They'll start working their way toward you, but that pitcher always seems to run out before they get to my cup. And by the time they try again, everyone else has emptied their cups...so it's the same thing all over again. Grr. So I end up having to ask for a refill a couple of times each visit.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This place is VERY popular on a Friday night.
The epicurious madames I was hanging out with that night, know their food, so I felt I was in good hands for a decent meal. 
When you first walk in, the establishment proudly posts their 100% score card from the San Francisco Health Board. They have every reason to, because the place is spotless and so are the bathrooms. 
We sat down soon enough into a large, cozy booth. 
I don't eat Korean food often, mostly because I don't know what to order, but I was happy Friday night. I enjoyed it a lot especially with all the different kim chi dishes. My favorites were the mung bean sprouts and the cucumbers.
The Richmond can get cold so having a big thick bowl of a STILL BOILING bowl, pretty much would cure any cold.
The tofu is slippery and yummy  and so is the broth. It is definitely on the top ten soup list.
author: J A.

description: Out of all the times i came to Tofu House, I always order the beef bibimbap. And all those times, i NEVER finish it no matter how hungry i am. They give large portions, and i'm an average eater. Their food is always scalding hot. And that might be another reason why i never finish my order. I tried their seafood tofu soup one time and that also, was really hot. My tongue always gets burnt so i can't taste the food =/ Their side dishes are pretty good. They're cold so i could taste that perfectly fine haha. I love how they always serve a fried fish for every person. Overall, price is worth it since they give large portions. Perfect for a cold day because the food will warm you up :)
author: Angela H.

description: Loved the soft tofu soup and accessories. Great meal for the money.
author: FromScratch M.

description: Good Korean food and I used to live two blocks away.  I didn't frequent this place though, not sure why.  I think I associated this place with a lot of waiting.  And I hate waiting for food, especially if I've eaten it before.  I've had the tofu soup (pretty good) but I would definitely skip the mushroom soup.  The dumpling soup and kalbi are my favorites here.
