author: Erika C.

description: We ordered pancake and seafood tofu soup. It tasted great. The one thing I like about this restaurant is that their food doesn't taste too salty and is just about right. What I dun like is that when I first step inside, I felt the restaurant smell weird. idk if it's the wood or something. Anyway, I got used to it after I'm in there awhile. Moreover, they don't have refill of their side dish. $1 to $1.50 if u need a refill. I probably will come here again if I go to SF, but I experienced a better restaurant than this. Overall, it's pretty good.
author: Yuan Yi Z.

description:
Korean tofu soup, where have you been all my life???

After visiting My Tofu House I decided that my life has been lacking Korean cuisine.  My first experience with Korean tofu soup was definitely a good one - I ordered the kimchi tofu soup (mild, I believe) and left feeling warm and toasty, very content and just full enough.  This dinner cost only $10 and the many small dishes that they give you were delicious; I'm always down for salted/picked veggies.
author: Krystle S.

description:
This is one stingy Korean restaurant, My Tofu House provides the least amount of appetizers I've ever seen.  The funny part is that they only give out 1 fried fish for 2 people no matter how many entree you order.  How can do 2 people eat or share a tiny piece of fried fish??

The main tofu soup, however, actually delivers.  The no.2 tofu soup contains beef, shrimp, and clam.  The soup tastes rich and full of flavor and it's best enjoyed from medium or spicy, because I think the extra spicy kills the original flavor of the soup. Combined with the scrumptious stone pot rice, this one hits home for me.

Bottom Line, despite of the super stingy, tiny appetizers, I will still give this place a 3 stars just because the soup is that good.
author: Wei H.

description:
I want to write something witty and engaging, but the horrendous meal I had here sapped my ability to write prose of any substance or quality.  It took us an hour to get seated.  During which time a group behind us was seated before us.  I think it's because two of us were white.  That pissed me off.

The waiter kept skipping over my friend and girlfriend's orders.  This too pissed me off.  I ordered the seafood tofu soup.  It was bad.  This also pissed me off.  

I left hungry.  That really pissed me off.  Won't be back.
author: Chris I.

description:
Love this place.  So I grew up in SoCal and was on the sdb train at the beginning.  I would eat it every week on the weekends when I was in LA, and to this day I love it and never get sick of it (In-n-Out's the only other place that I've had such a love for and never get sick of...but that's another review).  

When I moved up to San Francisco back in 2001, I was genuinely worried that I would never again have good sdb...and for a few years I was right, but then I discovered My Tofu House and have been satisfied since.  

True, it's not quite LA, but it's pretty darn close actually.  

If you're bringing friends, try their kalbi too...I dunno how they do it, but it's awesome.  The only downside: it takes away from the flavor of the sdb because it's so flavorful...so depending on my mood, I usually refrain from the kalbi, but if I bring friends, I'll usually order it.  This place has gotten so popular that I've been ordering out and taking it home to eat...and it's still great.  They give you all the ban-chan (side dishes), and it's well packaged.

The service is great...they always recognize me when I come (whether to dine-in or to order out), and they even remember what I order most of the time.
author: Allen H.

description:
I've been here for more than 10 times! Can you even believe it? Walk in and sign your name on the waiting list if it is on a busy night. They will seat you based on the customer arrival order. Fairness~ 

The spicy tofu stew is what kept me going back! The service was awesome, especially when the ajima was there... she welcomes and goodbyes me in and out. The servers are attentive and prompt on the services. It is fairly a small restaurant with ~8-10 tables, and I enjoy the simple décor. 

The first time I came here was back in my high school days with the entire badminton team (~20 people); they were very patience with us picky little girls. Several times when I came here with my friends years later, I continued to receive great dining experiences. Dined with my parents here twice in the year of 2008 and they gave it good compliment also. Based on all my visits to my tofu house, I was never disappointed and will definitely come back again when I have a chance. Not a lot of variety to choose, but if you crave for something specific and traditional, this is the place to go for! 

Pros: Friendly Service, Cleanliness

Cons: Parking, Limited Variety
author: Lisa R.

description:
With 169 reviews before me, I will be brief.

This is one of my new favorite Korean restaurants in the Bay Area.  I live next to the cluster of great Korean restaurants in Temescal, but My Tofu House is still good enough to justify making the trip to the Inner Richmond.  As far as tofu hot pots are concerned, my neighborhood favorite Pyung Chang Tofu House can go toe-to-toe with My Tofu House's any day.  But things like bbq are better at My Tofu House.  And who really wants to eat just tofu?
author: Ben A.

description:
I used to think I could eat spicy foods.  But now I'm not sure if it's because I'm getting older and my taste buds are more sensitive or because I eat Korean food more often that I realize I didn't really know what spicy was.  Red coloring on meat or in soup won't deter me from trying it, but I prefer not to sweat when I eat and it's hard to enjoy food when my mouth is numb.

I'd never had soon dubu as a main dish, but the ones I had tried were always really hot.  At My Tofu House, you get the choice of not spicy, mild, medium, or spicy.  Since we weren't sharing, I went conservative and got the mild for myself.  That was the perfect spice level for me and underneath the heat was a delicious meaty broth (not vegetarian apparently).  I'm no Korean food expert, but I can eat soup for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, and that's one I know I'll be craving.  Next time, I might even order no spice... blasphemous, I know!  

We had about a 20 minute wait, but totally scored across the street since we got a Boudin bread bowl for free from a worker w/ a cart full of them.  The banchan were refillable and my fave was the small whole fish (not sure what it was, but I ate the head and tail - it was so flavorful and had a good amount of meat).  Oh and how can I forget about the service?  All of the workers were young, polite, good-looking men *yummy*.
author: Mimi L.

description: Some of the best things about living in San Francisco are the people, the cool all year-round temperature, and My Tofu House! Tofu soup is the ultimate comfort food for me. Whenever I'm coming down with a cold or needing to vent to my girlfriend about my horrendous boss, i can always count on the tofu soup here to calm me down.  I only get the soup here and it's always good and consistent. The seafood soup and the dumpling soup are my favorites.The service is fast and prompt. I really have no complaints here. i guess my rating speaks for itself
author: Serena V.

description:
I'm a big eater and the portions here will make any up and coming sumo wrestlers proud.  Seriously great food that's inexpensive. I love their BBQ dishes but the tofu is awesome. What makes the meal even better is that you get a ton of solid side dishes that feel like they are a meal itself. I always think of it as two meals. Damn my mouth is watering just writing this. 

The only thing that keeps them from getting 5 stars is the service. The people here are nice but it's 3 people running around helping everyone. There can be a line so I always come early. Lastly it's just street parking which is always available though you might have to walk a few blocks. 

Solid food, big portions for a low price. That's my kind of place.
author: Dan T.

description:
I love My Tofu House. Really, love hardly describes the lust I feel for the deliciousness supplied.  

The only flaw with My Tofu House is that other people know about it causing the line to occasionally be "really fucking long."  Don't let such a line discourage you.  Eat my friends, taste the panchan, be merry!
author: jack p.

description:
Good place for Korean tofu soup on a cold winter day!  

Pros:
- the soup is quite tasty (my favorite is the mushroom one)
- comes with yummy stone pot rice on the side - I like to wait for the rice to get crispy on the edges and scoop it up to dip in the soup - yum!
- delicious side dishes (panchan)
- also available is a pretty good stone pot bibimbab

Cons:
- tofu is good, but not quite as silky-smooth as I've had at some other places
- wait can be long sometimes
- don't expect responsive service after you've received your food (like seconds on the panchan or more tea/water)
author: Fontane L.

description: Been going here since i went to college around the area. The food is good and service is nice and friendly. Its especially crowded at night.
author: Anthony V.

description:
If you get here early with no wait, it's worth it.  I came for the Tofu soup that everyone was raving about; b/c I had a cold and needed some good soup.  The promise of hot soup with hearty dumplings and beef was appealing and all those extras on the side was another bonus.  They give you a small fried fish (tasty, but small and you're picking thru it to get the meat), with sardines (ewww, yucky for me), classic marinated bean sprouts, pickled cucumbers, spicy pickled radishes, and kim chee.  All good, with lots of hot rice and fast service for the food.  

It did take about 15 minutes to get the check though, they seem understaffed.  I don't think I'd wait for a table, and they were busy with a line to the door right at 7:00 PM; I came at 6:10 PM.  Worth a try without a line, the soup was wonderful.  Cost was about $20 for 2 Tofu soups and sides.

My husband said he had heart burn afterwards, b/c his soup was spicy and he drank too much tea - so he was up all night going to the toilet.  :P
author: Audra E.

description:
not the best, but better than other Korean sundubu restaurants in San Fran...  people there are always smiling, and keep coming to ask I am OK with the extra spicy hot mixed sundubu jjigae... 

I am getting hunger for it now...
author: Julie K.

description: Great soups with reasonable price!! Meat dishes are not as good as some other Korean restaurants, but acceptable!! Services are good.
author: lee c.

description: I like the gay guy in the glasses with no lenses.  I'm not sure if he is gay, but I think so.  He always gives me snarky glances while I slurp my soft tofu soup.  Joking aside, probably the best Soondubu (soft tofu) soup I've had.  The waiters are all very hard working and charismatic.  Love the experience.  They're always packed, but always seem to serve everyone real fast.  And the staff are all sexy as hell.  Especially that girl with the cute ponytail.  I think they should all wear the same glasses like that guy.
author: Porkfeat P.

description:
I saw a long line inside that continues into the sidewalk outside with people trying to have dinner here at 6:30pm.  Great recommendations from friends and good reviews on Yelp, so I thought to myself that this place MUST be good, so we decided to go after work on Friday night, with reservations off course.  

I had the Assorted Mushrooms Sundubu, mild... I don't like my food too spicy.  The soup was still boiling when the waiter placed the bowl  in front of me so I quickly cracked an egg in it, waited a few minutes before tasting my very first Sundubu.  YUMMY!  The portion was huge and there was enough variety of mushrooms and tofu at every spoonful.  There was two sets of side condiments at our table of 6 -- small plates of kimchee, salted fish and assorted pickled veggies.  I wasn't into the kimchee, but I liked the pan fried fish.  We also ordered BBQ beef and two pots of rice.  I'm embarrassed to say that I practically had a pot all to myself ... yes, I love rice... rice is my friend.  I can eat rice with just about anything ;-)!

I really wanted to give My Tofu House 4-STARS, but they serve NO ALCOHOL and the women's bathroom is horrible... so horrible that I will never use their bathroom when I come back here... if I ever come back.  

After dinner, we headed to Trader Joe's for some Lambic beer to meet our alcohol quota for the night :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
This place hits the spot. I'm loving it. Prices are decent, great portions and service. I love how they give me 3 helpings of Kim Chee, FOR FREE! AHHHHHHHHHH!

I ordered the #3 combonation tofu. It has everything you want, shrimp, tofu, meat and more meat. Go ahead a live a little and get the Spicy Tofu. It hits the spot. I will be back!

My new obsession.
author: David L.

description: A little on the pricier side. Nice environment inside. Would recommend the seafood pot in particular.
author: Gianni C.

description:
Soon tofu is the best remedy for the cold weather blues.  And by far, My Tofu House has the best remedy I've experienced in San Francisco yet.  I tend to favor the mushroom soon tofu and dumpling soon tofu, spicy level HIGH, please.  I am a big fan of the peanut-shaped tteokbokki (rice cakes) that you find in the dumpling soon tofu.  I also love the huge stone pot of rice they bring to each table.  The rice isn't just plain white rice, they have green peas and chickpeas mixed in too.  And I make sure to tell the waiter to refrain from pouring tea into the pot because I like to eat the crispy rice at the bottom.  The banchan selection here is very generous as well (you get a whole fish!).

Since the restaurant's name includes the word tofu in it, you know their tofu should be good.  And they definitely do not disappoint in this aspect at all.  I've tried their BBQ before and have stuck to their tofu since.
author: Diane L.

description:
Food is still 5 stars.  Including  with all the [panchan].  but insist on not taking the back room, if offered.

seriously the room must of been the kimchee store room.  no windows, no tv, no nothing.  the only view you get are the restrooms...  boo.  disappointed that they would actually serve customers in here.  bad business call...
author: Isaac L.

description: I've been here twice for dinner, and the BBQ and Tofu soup are delicious.  The banchan and rice are also good.  The servers aren't very attentive after your food arrives.  They take your order quickly, bring you your food as soon as it's ready, scoop rice into bowls for you......and then they disappear until it's time for your check.  I finished the entire meal before being able to flag a server down to refill my tea.  I understand that they get really busy at dinner (long wait list), so if it's too much trouble to check on people's drinks while they are eating, the restaurant owners should consider putting tea pots on each table, so that we can refill our own glasses!
author: Barbara T.

description:
It was a lazy  and overcast sunday.
We just finished a multiple netflix blitz, and one of the roomies has been fighting a cold. Joy swelled from within my belly at the mention of soondubu. We arrived right before the early dinnertime rush(5:45ish)I really enjoyed the tofu and vegetable with shrimp and my roomie raved about the fried noodle with veggies and tofu. I'm just a fan of all the little banchan dishes. Good food, not great. But overall a fun place and a really good value. The perfect meal for a foggy day. . . .
author: Kia B.

description:
The assortment of kim chee they offer is only the beginning. BBQ dishes are good but there is a reason this is "my tofu house." Focus on the entrees served in bowls.

-  Seafood chigae is great! Full of spice & vegetables and shellfish are always great in any kind of soup.
- Bi bim bop is very good. The smell and texture is amazing and I always look forward to the crunchy brown crust of rice at the bottom of the bowl.
- They also cook white rice in stone fire pots. You will get that heavenly crunchy rice at the bottom of that too, but let your server know of your intentions; they pour water in it quickly to cool it down.

Servers here are great! They are consistently understaffed but still courteous and friendly. The line however does wind out the door and reservations are not accepted.
author: Adam W.

description:
Contrary to popular belief by certain Koreans on this site (you know who euge are), it's not un-asian to dislike spicy food. 
Not a fan here.  And that's OK at My Tofu House, cuz you can get their tofu soups "white" - hey that's not a racial remark.
And though it's marked spicy on the menu, they CAN and WILL make your bi bim bap non-spicy. With only a small giggle when they serve you.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Friday night dinner at My Tofu House.  When we left, the line was to the door!  They don't take reservations but there is a sign in list - don't forget to put your name on the list.

The complementary dishes are awesome.  I love how they poor hot tea into the clay pot if you want to eat the roasted rice.

Waiters were very busy but polite.

2 pieces of gum came with our check in the end.
author: Sandra L.

description:
OK, I don't really understand Korean food, so I'm not really qualified to review this place.  I do, however, understand what I like, and I do not like this place.  It was spicy and weird.  Both adjectives are normally fine for restaurants.  But add to that strange service (overattentive at times, ghost town most of the time) and a general lack of understanding of what I'm supposed to eat and how, and you get me, not very full but with a mouth so full of spices that I couldn't really eat anything else.

I kind of like feeling like I'm being crammed into some strange focus group about Korean restaurants, but they didn't hand me an envelope with three fifty-dollar bills afterwards, and I don't think my going there helped improve any products.
author: John S.

description:
I like simple, kind of bland tasting food. Thai and Indian food? Not for me. Too much spices, sauces...ick. So, tofu is always a good option and I haven't found a better place that specializes in it than My Tofu House. 

I've only been here a couple of times, but I already know that my favorite dish is the one with tofu, dumplings and itty bitty clumps of rice noodle. I don't eat spicy food either (I'm boring, huh?), so I ordered mine "not spicy"; I can't even stomach "mild." W-E-A-K, I know.  

I didn't really like the free appetizers, because I'm not into pickled vegetables, but I did eat some of the broiled fish, which was pretty good, bean sprouts, and some anchovies. I didn't have to wait too long for my boiling pot of tofu and the waiter scooped rice into our bowls for us, so they get +1 star for that.

Overall, the main course was delicious. The dumplings weren't soggy (my main concern) and the soup was very sweet (just enough flavor, not too overwhelming). I don't know what kind of rice they use, but I love it. It's kind of sticky and goes perfectly with the soup and tofu. 

I got full pretty quickly, but I tried to stuff myself, because the dumplings were so good (and I wasn't sure I had the option to doggy bag it). I love dumplings (as I write more reviews, this will become very apparent). 

My only gripe about this place is that some of the waiters (not the waitress, she was very attentive) looked pissed off (I was afraid to ask for more water!). They didn't acknowledge us when we came in (there wasn't a line, just me and my boyfriend). They could have at least said, "wait a minute" or something; we were left standing around wondering if we were supposed to seat ourselves. 

...But other than that, I'll definitely return again!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Craving soon doobu?  This place hits the spot.

Little bit pricier than soon doobu houses in say LA (ah, of course the comparison always comes up).  But they also provide bahn chahn.  The selection of b(p)han chahn we had was not incredibly diverse or particularly tasty -- fried mackerel, radish kimchee, cabbage kimchee, anchovies, cucumber, grated radish.  BUT, our server was efficient, helpful and asked if we wanted our bhan chan refilled.  Oooooo, I almost forgot, I like that the rice was cooked with peas and garbanzo beans!  Yummeee!  And they give you barley tea, which they'll also refill.  

Anyway, the actual soft tofu stew was pretty frickin good.  I had the dumpling, rice cake and tofu stew.  And ate ALL of it.  

They stuck our party of 3 in the back windowless room.  But, hey, no wait?  I'm OK with it.  The clientele was pretty diverse, Korean, Chinese, uh, European-American, etc.  So word's gotten around, I see.

One final note, our server was SUPER nice and holy cow HELLA CUTE!  I said to Amy C., "Shee-aht, our server is sooo cute."  To which she replied, "I didn't see him."  To which, I smacked, well a light smack, her with my chopsticks and was like, "Well LOOK!"  She agreed, he was hot.. and she said, "young."  And that's a problem because...?
author: Natasha S.

description:
Ok I get it: the south bay has way better soondubu than the city.
Duluth, GA has better soondubu than the city.. probably a lot of places have better soondubu than SF but where to go IN SF. I haven't found a better soondubu restaurant than my tofu house. The mushroom soondubu is my favorite. Pair it with the daeji bulgogi (spicy bbq pork) and you are good to go.
author: Doro P.

description:
The best compliment I can give My Tofu House is that several of my Korean friends have taken me here.  Some say its better than most for being a bit more authentic -- serving dishes more like you might actually get at a restaurant in Korea.

I have eaten Bi Bim Bap all over the city, and My Tofu House's version is one of my favorites.  I love that they go to the trouble to make it and other dishes using the hot stone bowls.  If you have never had Korean food made in the hot-stone bowl style, you really should try it, especially on a cold day.  The heat will stay with you for hours.

Another true test of a Korean restaurant is the quality of complimentary side dishes they give you with meals - kim chee, rice, etc.  The side dishes were better than average, fresh and skillfully prepared.  I'm picky about my rice, amazing how many restaurants get rice wrong, or just use overly cheap rice - but My Tofu House's rice was some of the best I've had in the city.  I want to go back here just for this rice!

The only con I'd give My Tofu House is the prices seem a little higher compared to other eateries in this class, but then again, you get what you pay for, and here the quality is a cut above, so there you go.  But it's still a good deal: $25-30 for dinner for 2, and it's hard to find many quality dinners for much less than that in the city these days.

Tip:  They have a Weekday Lunch Special where much of menu is 1/2 price before 4 pm.
author: Jack H.

description:
I don't know if they advertise no MSG, but it tastes like it has a ton in it. Bay Area ppl, you REALLY don't know what good soon-doo-bu tastes like b/c you're stuck in area with terrible Korean food.  Everything is either too sweet or too bland.  BLECH.  

This place is just a-ight.  I like the fact that they give you a lot of banchan (side dishes) and fish, but the prices are ridiculous for an order of kalbi.  It's a monopoly and makes me want to open up my own Tofu House and call it "My Tofu House Without Crazy Amounts of MSG and Affordable Kalbi."
author: S K.

description:
Welcome to Cooking Mama's Tofu House new for the Wii!

Wave that WiiMote up and Down for the spiciness of your Kimchee.
Ah...your dinner may be quite simple, but Cooking Mama made it so it should be all good in the Richmond Hood (it being next to a Jack/Crack)  Unlike most of the other Korean restaurants I have been into, this place is surprisingly bright and VERY COOKING MAMA like, intermediate levels.  

The restaurant from the outside looks very unassuming until you get to the window and you see a Yelp logo!  Awesome.  We waited about 10 minutes and the restaurant was pretty crowded, but those Korean restaurants work pretty fast.  

Cooking Mama, Level 1:
Small Korean Vbles.  Nice normal selection, but I did miss the no bean curd.  

Level 2: 
Broiled, thinly sliced beef
Portion size was good for $15, meat was tender and thinly sliced as advertised

Level 3: 
Ramen and vegetable tofu soup
For some reason this had clams?  No clams listed on this dish, but I guess they thought we looked like we liked eating clams.  The soup had an electic taste and deserved most of the stars on this review.  

All in all, Cooking Mama passed her test and the dinner met expectations!  Gold Star!
author: patrick o.

description:
I love love love you My Tofu House! It's one of those places I get giddy about when I know I'm going to eat there. No, it doesn't have a huge screen display playing endless Korean Pop songs, and no its not located inside a garage, and no it doesn't boast a variety of flavoured Soju. So what's so special about this ordinary sit down korean family restaurant? 
THE FOOD!
When I crave good old Soondobu soup, and Haemul Pajeon (Seafood pancake) this is my go to place. I have tried all the tofu soups on the menu, but personally I enjoy the spicy Kimchi with Beef Tofu soup the most. Some of my friends say Arang has better soup, but I think this place is still the best. I am a bit conflicted to say which has better seafood pancake, this place or Toyose. They're both very delicious, and they don't skimp on the seafood (Yes Coco Bang-- i'm pointing this at you).
They're also generous with their Banchan or small dishes. There is this fried fish that they serve as a small dish along with kimchi and namul which I love so much! I swear, I think I can eat only that fish with rice and not eat anything else.
I would also recommend the Kalbi. Juicy- sweet- tender- Perfection! They got this one right.

I'd give you 5 stars if you had flavored Soju, but I still love you oh- so- much, My Tofu House!

PS: Come during lunch time! The prices are almost half of what they are during dinner. I don't know why this is..
author: Libby K.

description:
The food was over-priced and the portion was small.  I'm really want to give  this place 0 star because 2 out of four people got sick after eating here.  

we ordered bbq chicken Bibimbab, bbq pork Bibimbab and (2) bbq beef Bibimbab.
author: L C.

description: Very good food liked the seafood soft tofu
author: Jack L.

description:
I knew it was only a matter of time before I was put into an awkward/weird dining experience at an Asian restaurant in SF. My coworkers and I waited a good 15-20 minutes for a table. Thinking that we were going to get some kind of special seating, the waitress started leading us into a strange hallway near the bathrooms. We were then seated directly next door to the men's bathroom in the weirdest stark white, windowless room. Think of it as a party room, but in a closet. We would have requested another seating arrangement if we weren't so desperately hungry for food. At the time, the menu looked pretty appetizing. Lots of tofu and meaty type things covered in grease and spices. I ordered the tofu soup and my coworkers ordered Korean BBQ. Our food came with a million and one side dishes. Everything was pickled or salted.

I have to admit, it was all pretty tasty. Unfortunately, it's not really the kind of food that you could eat for an entire meal. After about 3 bites, I realized my tofu soup was nothing more than a brick of tofu cooked in spice water. My coworker ordered a red hot meat dish that looked like it had been marinating in chili for days.

The food was decent but this review is more about the service than food. As if having lunch and conversation in a supply closet wasn't awkward enough, the waitress came over and poured tea into our rice and left 20 glasses of water on our table. I just don't really know what to think about that.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Korean food is by far one of my favorite types of cuisine. So I was so happy to go here for dinner the other night. 

We go there and the place was packed and the waiter said something to us in Korean with an unpleasant look in his face. We came in behind a Korean family, so maybe he thought we were together? Anyway, we had to put our name on the wait list. The wait wasn't too bad since we were only second on the list. We were showed to our seat by the gentlemen with the sour looking face. He seemed like he didn't want to deal with us. We got seated in a booth, it was very cozy. 

We got our menus and tea as we looked through the menu. With the place packed, surprisingly it didn't take us too long to get our orders taken. As we looked through it the menu the waiter with the sour look on his face ignored us when we gave him eye contact to let him know we were ready. He walked pass out table and a girl took our order instead.  She was very nice. We decided to choose a dish from each category. We got the kimchi soft tofu soup, seafood pancake, kal bi and the beef and veggie bibim bap. 

First the small dishes came out. We snacked on it as we waited for our meals. The kal bi was cooked perfectly, it was tender and not rubbery and tasted great. I really enjoyed the soup, it felt good to have warm soup on a cold SF day. The bibim bap was perfect, especially because I requested no carrots and they remembered to leave it out. The pancake was so-so, I have had better elsewhere. It was so thick and oily, no real taste. 

All in all the food was very good packed with flavor and spiciness. It was a nice meal aside from the unpleasant looks from the male server.
author: C L.

description:
came here last week with a couple friends...it was nine o clock and they were they only place worth going to that was open. We got seated in the back room of the restaurant... man they were so packed at 9 pm. WHY DON'T PEOPLE EAT EARLIER DAMMIT! I hate the back room, its always hot and steamy in there. GROSS 

So, we got our menu's and I told my friend to get extra spicy, and told him to step it up and be a man. and i guess our waiter heard us. So when it came time for me to order i told him that i was extra spicy...and he told me hey why don't you get 3x extra spicy... BE A MAN! hahaha i started cracking up because it was so funny! I can't believe he pulled it around on me! Any ways... i went for the 3x extra spicy, and i was kind of disappointed how it wasn't that spicy. It had loads of MSG though that for sure.. i was thirsty till the next morning, but it was good though. Oh one thing... don't order the ramen tofu... it's a no go! the soup gets all soaked up in the ramen, and then the ramen gets all soggy. IT'S A RED LIGHT FOLKS! 

We also ordered the seafood pancake, bbq chicken, and kalbi! Kind of expensive for the amout you get, but none the less its still a green light! 

O yeah i forgot one thing, even though we were seated in the back room, service was still good. Cups were always filled with water, and the waiter would always come check up on us if we need more chan-pan, napkins etc...!

ONE TIP FOR MY TOFU HOUSE COOKS... ease off the MSG please!
author: Brian P.

description: This place gets a lot of business even on weekdays. They don't have a lot of seating inside and is quite small. I believe there is only one big room for large parties, which is seated near the restrooms. Order any entree on the menu and it comes with 5-6 small side dishes and two large ones. My favorite side dish is the fried fish, they make it so crispy and the meat inside is so juicy. The entree i ordered is the second one from the top left and made it spicy. I love spicy foods! Also they bring you a huge pot of rice in a clay pot! I would definitely come here more often. The tofu soups are around $12 each, but comes with a variety of dishes to go with it.
author: Helen C.

description: The sizzling meat selections are a little pricey, so we ordered the tofu soup bowl instead, which is around $11.  They are good, but not exceptional.  Service is ok, again nothing remarkable.  I will come back here, but it's not at the top of my list.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I've been searching for a go-to Korean Tofu place in SF, so I was excited to try My Tofu House.  I think 3 stars is appropriate for MTH, as nothing really stood out in particular.  

For dinner, we ordered an original tofu soup, and a seafood tofu soup.  I enjoyed my original, and I wouldn't recommend the seafood (which is what the bf ordered, in one of his adventurous moments).  Don't get me wrong - I LOVE seafood and could probably eat a dozen raw oysters as a meal, but the seafood tofu soup was way too fishy-tasting to eat.

Though they offered a lot of side-dishes, I found the Kimchee to be on the bland side, and it tasted a little off.  The bean sprouts and cucumber sides were good, though.  

Total dinner for two came out to $25, so it's a pretty good deal.  Just wasn't the best...
author: Kira K.

description:
As a billion other Yelpers have stated, a bowl of hot tofu on a cold SF night is gold!  We ordered some fried fish (dunno the kind) and it was crispy and flavorful!   I was excited to see pancakes on the menu, but I found my seafood pancake to be overcooked and pretty bland.  The side dishes were fine, but I've been to other places with more variety.  We sat in the back room of the restaurant which, if you're claustrophobic or have some government secrets to discuss over dinner, you probably should wait for a regular table.  Service is fine, but the waiters here are not exactly patient - so no questions like "so, what exactly is bibimbap?"

Overall, 3.5 stars and a great pick for a cold night, but you should go early to avoid the crowds.
author: Tim L.

description:
It's korean, its good price, and most important, it tastes good!  A friend and I came here and we both split an order of tofu dumpling soup (medium) and a galbi.  you ever get into that situation where both are really full, and who knew?  that you could kill so much food.  ESPECIALLY since you were gonna order an extra plate or soup before!  

Yes, this was what we experienced as we devoured our delicoius tofu soup over the rice.  The galbi, in my opinion, was a bit on the fatty side, meaning the cut had a good amount of faty connected which on the bright side, makes it that much tastier.  But what i like about the Galbi is that they aren't all burnt up and the seasoning for it is just right.  

Definitely will be coming back here sometime soon.
author: Vincent K.

description: Good Kalbi and soup was also good, the prices are tad too high, $12 for a tofu soup with strips of pork more like $10. Banchan was OK not as good as Han IL Kwan.
author: N A.

description: My Tofu House is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the Richmond District. You'll find us here at least twice a month. The soft tofu soup is absolutely delicious and I love the banchan as well. Although you may not get the gigantically huge variety of banchan served at other restaurants, the stuff you get here is really good. The servers are always attentive and friendly and the stick of melon gum they give you with your check is just an awesome touch. 5 stars across the board!
author: Kristy R.

description:
The best sundubu around. The sides are great -- the kimchi could be better, more sour, but it's still pretty darn good. I'm a huge fan of their mushroom sundubu -- it tastes better than the regular beef/pork, for sure. On cold Richmond days, sundubu definitely hits the spot.

The prices for the sundubu are dirt cheap -- the kalbi and dolsot bibimbop are pricey for the serving size, but that's not why you go to My Tofu House.

Service is excellent, the wait when it's busy is maybe 15-20 minutes, and the atmosphere is nil. Go for the food -- oh, and booths are small, so any more than four isn't really worth it.
author: Perci N.

description: I am still glad that a Korean restaurant has English speaking people in it! I am not complaining but it is just nice to have people UNDERSTAND you..I came here on a Monday afternoon around lunchtime. Surprisingly there were a lot of people eating in this restaurant, but less people then there is at night.  Anyways I got the seafood bi bim bap like always and the seafood pancake. The bi bim bap is good like always but I kind of choked on a piece of rice because it just went straight down my throat and I was coughing like CRAZY! The pan cake is not that great. Don't waste your money! Well I didn't really like it and it cost me about $17 what a waste! They don't give you as much condiments here as the other places. And the waiter didn't refill our drinks that much and I was growing super thirsty and he finally refilled it when I asked for the check!
author: Janet Z.

description:
My first attempt in going to My Tofu House was stopped by the long wait. It was 7:30 on a Wednesday night, which I assume is a prime dining time for San Franciscans.

So, my friend and I decided to try being patrons at My Tofu House again this past Wednesday at approximately 6:30, an hour earlier than the previous week. Luckily, this time My Tofu House was "bare" (not so many customers), so we were able to sit down and dine here.

I had heard a lot about My Tofu House from Yelp reviews, but was never really drawn into the hype over it. To me, I find that I cannot follow hype over a place since then it'll set my standards too high for any one restaurant, which may ruin my impression of the place if my standards are not met.

Upon first impression: service seemed decent. The servers were pretty persistent in trying to get our order in as soon as possible, which I found irritating since I was having trouble deciding what I wanted to eat. Chige or Bibimpap? Chige or Bibimpap....decisions, decisions. The menu was limited, like Doobu, but I suppose that's why the place is called "My Tofu House"; the specialty is...chige really. That's fine.

Ah, I was happy when my friend said that we would share our dishes, so I didn't have to make the incredibly difficult decision of chige vs. bibimpap. We ordered one of each....#2 chige and seafood bibimpap. The food came out quickly and both were sizzling (literally) upon receiving the dishes. Taste-wise; good, not great, not bad. My friend was so cute about the bibimpap since he hadn't tried it before....we both agreed it was good, especially with the bits of squid mixed in.

The atmosphere/ambience of My Tofu House--lighting was a little bright, so I assume they want the customers to enjoy and eat quickly...so they can usher in more customers. Not really a place to stick around and chat awhile unless you want to be a jerk to the people waiting....by the time we left the restaurant (around 7:30/8pm), there was a huge line of people waiting for tables. We made a good decision to go earlier in the evening! 

(But, now that I mention this, everyone will want to go eat at My Tofu House at 6/6:30pm from now on and the restaurant will become crowded earlier...)

Summary: The place was okay, not mind-blowing. Might go back in the future, depending on what my friends want to do.
author: Helene K.

description:
sure it tastes good but i just think it's too expensive.

we had the short ribs and dumpling stew.  the short ribs were delicious, but $21?  too much for the amount.  and the dumpling soup was good, but there were only three dumplings and spicy was NOT spicy.  after sodas (no beer and no byob), we still paid $40 after tax and tip with no alcohol....and i was still hungry.
author: Christy C.

description:
this probably is as good as it gets when one craves "soon-doo-boo jji-geh" (tofu soup) in the city....get it "white"..get it mild...get it medium...get it spicy...or anywhere inbetween....it's good and done right....

it's served piping boiling hot...that's the way it should be served....so be prepared to duck your face and open up a napkin to shield your clothes....to avoid getting your nice white blouse splattered with soup.....but..hurry up..and crack open that egg and drop it in while it's still boiling...learn to crack an egg with one hand...so you can use the other hand to hold up your napkin shield.....*sounds like mission impossible*..hehehe....

i knocked off one star for the serve yourself need...feel free to grab your own water pitcher....or grab extra napkins or chopsticks....don't even bother asking...
author: Hen A.

description: This place used to be really good, but now it's only mediocre. Why two stars? The price does not match the quality and quantity of the food. They are waaayyyy overpriced and are meager. Their tofu soups and entrees are at least $3 more than other tofu places and they give a lot less meat. The bibimbap is so not worth it...they give you a ton of rice and cannot even see any meat. Nowadays there are so many other choices that taste way better and are cheaper...no need to come here wait in line and spend extra money. Not worth it.
author: M L.

description: Just like mom used to make! The name says it all. When I'm in need of some Korean comfort I snuggle up to some My Tofu House. I usually get the seafood , but the Fish Roe is also good. The fried fish is also a nice treat, but the rest of the banchan is just average.
author: Steve K.

description:
YUM! that's all i have to say.
Waiting was never really a problem for me sicne me and my friends come in around late lunch time. Food and service is excellent. Parking is a hassle though.
author: Tracy A.

description: Mmm, it was my first time having Korean Tofu soup.  I didn't know what to expect but after walking from the California Academy of Sciences and really wanting a hot bowl of soup to warm me up, this place delivered.  The flavors were different than I am used to since I usually eat at Thai and Japanese places but we wanted to try something new and I am glad I did.  It would have been nice if the waiter had given us some sort of explanation on how to assemble the soup, since it came with all these garnishes and we weren't sure what to do.  However we figured it out, except for the raw egg part, and really like the little fish, and the kim chi was great.
author: Christiana G.

description:
Cheap eats to satisfy your Korean fix.  But get there by 5:30 or prepare to wait...and wait...
Mushroom tofu soup, Seafood tofu soup with Bulgogi are a great combo for 2.  Rice comes steamed in mortar bowl.  Nothing I can say bad about this place.  Service is always fast and the spice level is perfect.  I take friends from out of town here and they always want to come back when they're back in town.
author: ken o.

description:
This place is poppin 24/7 and for good reason. Very reliable Korean food. The banchan is good, though the last time I came here we didn't get any pickled daikon. The tofu chigae is very flavorful and all the main dishes like bulgogi and galbi are juicy and tender. The menu is pretty simple, so it won't take you 15 hours to decide what to order (and your stomach won't resort to eating your fat deposits).

However, they need to start playing K-pop like other Korean eateries I've frequented. It really gets me horny for some bulgogi and soju, minus the soju since I would probably barf that up (due to my uncooperative Asian genes).
author: Alvin T.

description:
Awesome tofu soup.

The kalbi is tasty. Spicy pork is perfect. Chicken is tender. 

Really busy at night, so get there early.

I love the little dishes. The only thing missing is the fishcake dish.
author: Mai H.

description: This place is yummy.  I definitely would recommend at least trying the tofu since the tofu is sooooo soft and tasty.  The tofu was about 10 bucks and we also ordered the bulgogi which was under 10 bucks I believe.  I wasn't too impress with the bulgogi since it came in lil bits of meat (it was as though they were leftovers).  The good thing is that they didn't overcook the meat like most restaurants.  There were also a few side dishes that came along with this meal (~6) which made the dining experience not as fun.  BUT, this place does give out more rice (for a group of 2 at the very least).  I'm disappointed that I live so far away from this place (500 so miles away), but if I had it my way, I would come back again!
author: Janey Y.

description:
The weather has been gorgeous this spring and I (again) feel like a walking succubus of death. I have the flu AGAIN. (Cough, sniffle, snort, sneeze.) After 5 pitiful days indoors, a wise, nurturing soul dragged me out to My Tofu House for a bowl of hot aromatic soup. mmmmm.

The specialty here is the spicy tofu soup SoonDubu. There's an entire section on Tofu Soup variations.  You can have it with clams, kimchee, veggies, fish eggs.. the possibilities are endless. The service was pleasant but perfunctory.  The soup was great. What a remedy. My congestion was gone. I could totally breathe afterwards. Next time I'm getting it spicier.
author: Sirima S.

description:
I use to come here with my ex-gf. We had this thing where I would leave momentarily while she flirted with the waiter.  This eventually got us free food.  It was a fun game but now I'm a big boy and shit like this won't fly with me nowadays... but I digress.

There's nothing more satisfying than kimchi soft tofu soup on a cold evening.  I really wanted to order the version with ramyun but we all know you can't have ramyun for dinner.  Its bad for you!

Party: 4
Order:
Tofu Salad
Kimchi sundubu with beef
Original sundubu
Veggie sundubu
Kalbi
Rice
Seafood Pancake

It was all good with the exception of the Seafood pancake which was soft and limpy.  Read my review of Choi's Kitchen in Santa Clara.  My friends didnt care much for the tofu salad but I thought it was good.  I felt their Kalbi was a bit too sweet for me but everyone else seemed to enjoy it.  I wished I had soju to go with this meal but its too early in the week for soju =P 

You should try this awesome combo of a spicy burn from the soup and cool burn from the soju.  CRAZY GOOD!!!!

I heard something amusing while I was eating. Someone at another table mention how the kimchi sundubu tasted nasty because it was sour and salty.  Uh, no shit.  You don't use fresh kimchi for this dish. As far as I'm concerned the older the kimchi the better.
author: Sun T.

description:
My Tofu House is crazy.  Or maybe I'm a white girl from the burbs.  Either way, I am amazed every time I go in there.

Obviously, this review will say  nothing that's not listed on here already.  There's the little starter plates (tapas!?!?!)... my favorite is the cucumber, the bean sprouts, the something cold and crunchy with spicy sauce, the little baby fish and the big fish with all the bones.

And there's the soup!  Any degree of spiciness, combined with any veggie/fish/meat preference.  I love the mushroom soup the best. And the tofu is so silky fresh!  I really like the egg that you can drop in there to make it just a little more hearty.

And, END SCENE to Allison G.'s most ignorant review to date. (What just happened here?.... Was that for real?)
author: Allison G.

description:
it's MY tofu house , not yours! haha that was stupid.
had some bugolgi, and soon dubu. i'm probably spelling this all wrong but whatever, it's expected of me i'm not korean. 
it was decently priced, and it was decent. Ordered my soon dubu medium spicy and I think it could've been spicier. My date couldn't hang with the spicy stuff so he had to wussy it out. Oh well. =( 

The tea is dam good here. I'm addicted to it.
author: Susy C.

description:
I came here with a few friends awhile ago. Every time I've come, there has always been a slight wait. The service is a bit slow, but the food makes up for it.

We all ordered four different kinds of tofu soup, it was by far, one of the best tofu soups I've had in SF. I've ordered the kalbi and bulgogi before, and though they were tasty, the price was a bit high for decent korean BBQ. Although I definitely think that Korean food is already a bit overpriced. 

The atmosphere almost feels like a cafeteria. I would definitely return, but I'm never feening for it.
author: stacy c.

description:
I am a big stickler for the health inspection ratings and when I saw the 99 grade on the wall, for the whole world to see, I breathed a sigh of relief.  

The menu consists mainly of main courses.  There will be no appetizers on this menu.  

It is all about the tofu.  I've been here twice.  The first encounter, I ordered a bubbling HOT tofu soup.  YUMMY.  I cannot begin to express the joy the spicy concoction provided to me.  I ordered the mushroom tofu and it was wonderfully delicious.  Plus, it came with all sorts of wonderful little side dishes (mostly fish and pickles, including the pickled, spicy cabbage that we all know and love...kimchi).    I don't remember the price, but it was stunningly low for dinner.  Plus, I left unbearably full.

This most recent outing yielded favorable results, but forced me to detract a star (there was a hair in my boyfriend's Dak Gui).  Plus, we went for a weekend lunch and still had to pay the dinner rate (1 Dak Gui, 1 Korean BBQ Beef Bibimbob, 1 soda), which cost about $31, NOT INCLUDING TIP.  My BBQ Beef bibimbob  was good, but not as great as the tofu soup that I ordered during my first dining experience.  The service was pretty slow, although VERY polite to non-Koreans.  I have no complaints about the friendliness of staff.  All in all, my boyfriend's Dak Gui was quite delicious, other than the hair, I was pleased.

So, all in all, I would say a good 3 star experience.  I would go back there for the speciality...TOFU.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
For soon doobu (Korean tofu soup), my gold standard is the Tofu House (technically the SGD Tofu House) on El Camino in Santa Clara, and I'll be frank: My Tofu House isn't as good.  Something about the flavor, the freshness of the ingredients, or the preparation method just isn't quite as enjoyable as I've had it elsewhere.  

Having said that, My Tofu House is a pretty damned good substitute.  They use the same formula that works so well for SGD and they follow it pretty closely.  The menu is pretty simple, just offering soon doobu, good bibim bap and yummy BBQ meats, and you get a number of kimchi dishes as appetizers before the meal.  You can choose original, kimchi, vegetarian, or seafood (be prepared, for better or for worse, for seafood with eyes), and you're given rice out of the stone pot in the standard metallic bowls, and eggs to cook in your soup.  After the meal (which I never finish and stretch into left-overs the next day), you're given the requisite melon gum to cleanse your palate and sent on your merry way.  

It's a pretty familiar routine to me, and though this place doesn't have the best soon doobu I've ever had, it's certainly the best I've had in San Francisco.  It'll definitely tide me over until unlikely circumstance takes me back down to Santa Clara again, and it's still good enough to get soon doobu newcomers hooked on the stuff.  It's not THAT hard-- the stuff is crack in a crockpot.
author: Mike O.

description:
I used to be only okay with the idea of going to eat Korean Tofu.  This place converted me.  I first tried the tofu soup while in LA at BCD Tofu House.  I left there not thinking much of it.  I gave it another chance at My Tofu House and was stunned afterwards.  Everything tasted so good and I was so full that I had to take baby steps back to my car.  Ever since then, I crave Korean Tofu.

I'm actually heading down to LA so I'll be trying BCD again.  I hope it doesn't disappoint but I doubt it.  I probably didn't enjoy it the last time because I didn't know how to appreciate the flavors.  My Tofu House will always be the one that converted me though.  I ask for at least two more plates of kim chi when I'm there.  Tonight will be no exception.  MY TOFU HOUSE, I'LL BE THERE SOON!
author: Chris C.

description:
If you're fixin for some spicy tofu, this is the place to go.   I always find it a good place to go on a foggy cold night in the city.   The spiciness of the tofu soup really warms ya up.  And don't forget the order of Bulgogi.     The service left something to be desired for though.  We had to say "ice" 4 times to the server before she could understand.  

If there is a line, remember to sign in on the clipboard which is usually hanging on the right hand side.    Parking will require a couple of loops, but it's not too too hard to find.
author: Herb C.

description: I went here with Joyce B (below!) and thought it was pretty good as well. I'd have to say though... I'm not AS convinced as her that it was worth the wait and the price. I paid around 15 dollars for a bowl of bibimbap but don't think it was quite worth it. Joyce's soup was good, but I think they should have given her a little more for the price she paid. Service was good although they seemed to be short on servers. It seemed the same two guys were running around serving the entire restaurant and the wait was around half an hour to be seated. Overall, the place is GOOD but not...great in my opinion.
author: Angela H.

description:
This place is really good and worth the trip out to the Avenues for us Mission/SOMA types.  I went there today for lunch with my friend Yan and we both loved it.

We had the kimchee soft tofu pork soup with comes to the table at a rolling boil in a clay pot to which you can add a raw egg which was brought out with the seven gratis pickled side dishes.  The tofu was silky and the broth and pork delicious.

We also had the seafood bi bim bap which was outstanding.  Served in a larger stone pot with the nicely crusty rice pressed into the base and sides and filled with mussels, squid, etc and topped with an egg poached by the heat of the dish.  Beautiful presentation and really delicious.  It could serve two people for lunch on its own but even with addition of the tofu soup a really interesting and filling lunch only set us back $23.

Our server was very attentive and helpful.  When asked for a refill on one of the free sides it appeared right away.  

The room is nothing special but is clean and comfortable.  And they didn't hesitate to put the two of us in a private booth for four - some restaurants won't do that even when there's room.

While I wish there were a similar Korean tofu restaurant close to where I live and work I'll glady travel out to Geary and 10th Ave again for this tasty and beautifully presented food.
author: Jon R.

description:
Service was good and food came fast
Great food, though not 5-star worthy. 

The tofu soup was great and the veggie pancake was good (but not great). Definitely a nice place to come if you're feeling under the weather or on a cold and cloudy day in the city.
author: Ben K.

description:
Had the mild spicy tofu soup. It wasn't very spicy so I will go spicier next time but overall pretty good. Lots of appetizer dishes including 2 whole fish to pick at! 

Beware you'll definitely come out smelling like the restaurant.
author: Anna D.

description:
$10 soondubu at dinner.  probably the closest u can get to good southbay soondubu in sf.  panchan includes fried mackerel.  stone pot rice.
went for medium combination--has all the right elements, not the most concentrated though
for the area though, this is the go-to.
author: Rob C.

description:
I don't know Korean food at all. The few times I have had it my friend prepared and served it, so... today that friend took me to My Tofu House. I ordered what he ordered which was the soup with mushroom and tofu and some meat. It was perfectly spicy and since it was a freezing cold day out it hit the spot.

They bring out kimchi, fish, and pickled stuff out first which were all good, but I didn't try the little fishes, they reminded me too much of my tetras. They bring out the soup which is literally bubbling hot. And a bowl of white rice that is crispy brown on the edges. Later they pour hot tea in the bowl and the crispy bits can be scraped off. 

So yummy comfort food. On a side note, the tea they pour in the plastic water glasses is scalding hot. I took a mouth full and as my taste buds  were being seared, I had to spit it out before more damage was done. That got a good laugh out of my friend. Classy, having to spit tea out during lunch. At least I was done with my meal.
author: Amanda L.

description: Can't say I'm an expert on Korean food by any means but if you're in the area and have the urge this place is definitely worth it.  For what it's worth, I was shown this place by a Korean friend of mine, so there you go.  Try the bibimbab.  The wait staff works with no-bullshit efficiency and although you may wait a bit to get a seat, the food comes fast, hot, and tasty as f***!!!
author: Bryan B.

description:
Yay..  Korean foods is good.  I actually am not a big fan of the soft tofu soup that this place specializes in, but that's in no means a bad thing, cuz they have plenty of other things for me to eat.  My brother and his girlfriend love the tofu stews, so we end up going there a lot.  I usually get the bi bim bap or the kalbi, and it's tasty goodness.  The panchan they serve is plentiful and tasty, and they've started giving us two little fishes too, so that's nice.  They also serve a sweet-ish barley tea along with dinner which I really like.

Oh, and you know it's a real korean place when they give you the melon gum at the end of the meal.  I love that stuff.  INTENSE FLAVOR for about five seconds.. and then... nothing.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
I've only went here once, but one time is all you need to make you go back for more!!!  Too bad I don't live in the city, I think I would be going here like once a week.  LOL. 

This place is really petite, but it was hella crackin' when I went there.  I guess SF loves Korean food.  I think what attracted me the most is its name... "My Tofu House"--how cute!!!!!!!  I guess the word "house" made it feel more personable and welcoming?  haha I'm just rambling!

Okay, so straight to it.  You should definitely try the Kalbi (bbq broiled short ribs) and the tofu salad.  Oh, sooo good!  The Kalbi just sizzles on a hot plate just waiting for it to be served, now doesn't that just sound sexy to you??  Hahaha.  

Anyways, My Tofu House is one of the best place to grub on some Korean food =)
author: MaryGrace V.

description:
best soon tofu i've ever had.  the restaurant is quite small and the place does get packed in the evening.  one downside though: this place is PRICEY!!!

FOOD:  awesome, got the original, mild, should've gotten spicy.  the side dishes were very good, however, it took forever to come out.  we waited like 15 minutes before the tofu came first, THEN the side dishes.  i'm used to munching on side dishes first.  the fish was bombbb. also ordered a plate of kalbi after smelling the aroma from another party.  although it was VERY good, i was disappointed that it was not sizzling when brought to us, which brings me to my next point, the service.

SERVICE:  this place has like 2 waiters total, one for the back section and one for the front section.  the waiters are also responsible to bus the tables, seat guests, AND take orders and deliver food.  our food did take a while, but it was worth it.  and i don't blame the waiters, they were very friendly, the place is just tremendously understaffed.  

all in all though, i would go back to this place despite the price and their slow service simply because the food is so good.
author: Alex W.

description:
Nothing to fear here--the City of San Francisco gave them a perfect 100 points on their last health and food safety inspection!!

It also helps that their soondubu and dolsotbibimbap are quite tasty.
author: Richie K.

description:
well watdya know, i walk in and i see this beautiful red YELP AWARD! i knew this place had to be good if they had the yelp award! My party of 3 arrived at 9:30 pm, and there was still a 15 minute wait, we were very disappointed when they didn't let us sit in one of those cute booths that everyone else was at, but instead we were seated in a tiny back room with one other party (really, the room was too small to have a fun conversation without the other party peering over every 5 minutes) MINUS STAR!

Afterwards we ordered the combination tofu soon (beef and seafood), fried noodle tofu soon (had ramen in it), and bbq'd ribs (ack! the price raped us..$17) i enjoyed the soup but we ordered medium....should've been spicy. you never know with these places, some are too spicy and this just wasn't spicy at all. 

and the side dishes...they didn't give us as many side dishes as we would've liked...no jap chae or pickled radish (they had one but they usually have another one...ok ok well I don't know i'm not korean i just observe!) 

I think I'll have to go again...and next time I'd like to sit in a booth!
author: Janelle H.

description:
Deeee-licious!

I'm a big fan of spicy tofu soup.  I didn't know My Tofu House is actually a Korean restaurant.  For some reason I kept thinking it's like a tofu-theme restaurant like... japanese tofu-ya....

Anyhow, I had Korean tofu soup cravings one day and I relay the message to the bf.  The bf brought me to My Tofu House.  

Oh bubbly-hot tofu soup...  The bf ordered the kim-chee tofu soup with medium spicy.  Dood, if he can only take medium spicy, imma have to go with the mild.  And the mild was just spicy enough for my taste, and my tongue.  

They also give you rice in a stone container, I believe they actually cooked the rice in it.  mMMm.  And the condiments... so many condiments... I LOVE CONDIMENTS!  

And last but not least, check out First Korean Market next door to get some condiments to go!  And... don't forget the melon bar!
author: Gigi T.

description:
I love this place, but it's getting quite expensive.  I know I should consider that it does comes with all these lil side things, but $10.50 for a tofu soup????   :(

Maybe they know that I'll still be going...but it'll be less frequent.
author: Theary K.

description:
With a single grunt of "table", we were seated. and our place settings quite literally tossed on the table. We were scared...

When we ordered, the waitress didn't seem like she caught what we ordered and when i changed my mind from medium to spicy by saying, "you know, i think i'll go with spicy", she repeated "okay, i think i'll go with spicy" as if it was a menu option. We were scared...

We sat there for like 10 minutes without any pun-chaon. We were scared...

But finally the food comes. The tofu soup was delicious - warm, hearty, and just as I ordered, spicy. It's possibly one of the most perfect comfort foods in the city.

If only they could get the service aspect down, they would get 5 stars hands down.
author: Bernie L.

description:
This was my second time coming here and first time was OK.... We waited forever to get a table so I scarfed it down.

Second time... not too long of a wait, the place didn't look too busy... but took forever to order and to get any kind of service.

Freakin $19 for kal-bi!!! you can get a 6oz steak for $10!!!!!!! Add a couple dollars more and you can get a better Korean BBQ BUFFET!!! 

Ridiculous
author: Jamie K.

description:
My boyfriend and I always come here after a hard day snowboarding on the slopes. We were initially recommended to My Tofu House by a Korean friend, as she said it reminds her of her mom's cooking. We became a fan after the first visit as well.

Their tofu soup is to-die-for. Bibimbap, kalbi, bulgogi, even the ban-chan... yumm... Can't wait 'til the next ski season!
author: Lois W.

description: My favorite Korean place yet, love the bim bibibbab, or however you spell it.
author: Y S.

description: I throughly love it here.  I get the tofu soup with assorted mushrooms.  They crack an egg into the boiling soup and it cooks there!  I like the thrill of this!  I'm sort of a picky eater so I only eat a couple of the small dishes, the cucumber and the sprouts. The barley tea is mild and always hot.  It is surprisingly more filling than you'd think.  If you can made people try this place, you can hook them and then they'll come back...sort of like a tofu soup cult.  Yes, it's real.
author: Julia D.

description: Sure, it's just soon tofu, but this is one of the best places in the city to get it and eat it.  Every time I'm here, they try to seat everyone as quickly as possible and bring out the food as quickly as possible.  That includes tea, water, soon tofu, extra rice, and those 10-something side dishes.  Everything is delicious, even the little fried anchovies.  They must think I'm royalty or something.  Well, I'm not surprised, I did wear a Princess T-shirt, just kidding.  When they are swamped, they are so apologetic.  I'm like, "It's okay, I only wish I'm the princess that the shirt says."  Aside from the soon tofu, they also have lunch specials on kalbi and bulgogi for $8-9.  Geez, at those prices, I eat 2 orders at a time.
author: Ally W.

description:
The Tofu Soups are quite tasty! I really enjoy eating the Dumpling Tofu Soup ordered EXTRA SPICY. It makes my nose run. 

The chicken served on a sizzling clay dish is really tasty as well. There are onions layered under the chicken which gather up the chicken juices and caramelize with the clay dish and is oh-so-good.

Gets crowded really fast at dinner time. Really fast service. Good food. Of course they serve many little Korean appetizers.

The reason for the 4-star review.. the price. The chicken is good but not $17 good. Are we in fact paying our way through the many little Korean appetizers which we thought were on the house?? And accidentally ordered more of (the pickled cucumbers are good!)?
author: Christine C.

description:
OH man, I am all about the panchan here!
My Wednesday nights for awhile during winter consisted of swimming for 40 minutes at Rossi Pool and then jetting it down Geary in time to eat at My Tofu before it closed.
Speedy service that isn't in your face, good tea, and the term "spicy"... actually meaning "spicy" are what keep me coming back!
author: alexis g.

description:
I've been hurtin' from the Yelp plague so all I crave now is soup to ease the sinuses and bad cough.  When I have a craving for soup, this is one of the first spots to pop into my head.  Fast, convenient, tasty, and inexpensive.  If I want something besides soup, there's also the normal barbecue meat options (kalbi, bulgogi, chicken, etc.).   Love the salty, sweet little fishies in the panchan also.  And don't forget to eat the burnt rice soaked in water in the stoneware at the end of the meal.  A nice refreshing treat to end the meal.   

One star off for the illegal Yelp plaque review they have in front.  j/k

DSKO favs: dumpling and mushroom tofu soup
author: Dik Shun K.

description: This is the best Korean place I've ever been to! I should add that it's the first authentic Korean place I've been too. The kimchi and the other small dishes they bring at the beginning was probable my favorite part. For my meal I ordered the seafood soup and it was perfect! I'd recommend going to this place on the hungry side because they serve you a lot of food, but the wait can be rather long so plan accordingly!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Whenever I go to Korean BBQ, I always get bulgogi. So I went in and ordered this, and it was the best beef seasoning I've ever had. Sweet but also salty and the meat was tender, oh so TENDER. The rice was also excellently cooked. The tea was very good as well.

The 4 stars above are mainly for the bulgogi. The kimchi assortment, is okay I think. I like their radish kimchi and potato, but I wasn't in love with the other side dishes. (they gave me the bean sprouts, regular nappa cabbage kimchi, a grilled fish, seasoned potato, radish kimchi) and maybe something else I've forgotten. 

My friends had bibimbop and tofu soup. I didn't taste too much of them but the bibimbop seemed pretty standard and tasty. The tofu soup was nice and the tofu fresh tasting.

The major con is the wait. I'm not sure if you can phone in a reservation, but it's best you do that because we were waiting over 30 minutes for dinner. The list was about 10+ people. Err, and as Korean places go it was along the same price lines.
author: Shizuka L.

description:
The Spicy Pork is perfect along with Kim Chi Tofu Soup.


Those are the only two food that I enjoy the most in this restaurant
author: Wid S.

description:
today, I ordered the tofu lunch special; it had bit of beef, clams, whole shrimps, and ton's of tofu. It comes to you in a bubbling pot!
like outrageously boiling. I would not want to deliver it or touch. 
Comes with one egg, and an assortment of fresh kim chee delights.
so, you break open the egg into the boiling pot and the pot says Thank You
 and calms down. Let it sit for a few minutes. Begin to devour the assorted kim: the 1/2 inch cubes of daikon? , in red chili is always my  fav; the bean sprouts are ok, the fried whole fish is transcendantal--- pick it apart with your chopsticks, the meat is sweet n' salty. Amazing.  
If you are a gourmet , pick out the fish cheek !  a tiny nugget of sweetness.
 And there is the requisite  nappa cabbage kim chee, also deelicious. and you get a bowl of sweet n' sticky korean rice dotted with cooked peas. yummy. $9.50 and you can have seconds on the kim chee. Order up Holmes.
don't tell anybody, this place is clean and low key.
customer service: excellent.
author: Bert K.

description:
Service was good. 5/5

Tofu soup was sad. It's the thick soondubu that has little liquid and lots of broken up silky tofu, but somehow still lacking depth of flavor. 2/5

The famed seafood pancake? Eh, it's very thick and doughy, which takes away from the seafood. It came served on a hot cast iron plate that kept the pancake hot throughout, which I guess would have been nice had the pancake actually tasted good. 2/5

I will never return of my own volition. Where do I find good Korean in SF? Must I continue driving to South Bay?!

*Update* Dae Jang Geum Tofu House in Daly City is very good. Go there instead.
author: B B.

description:
The food was ok. I had better Korean food elsewhere and was expecting really excellent food considering the reviews.  It did not leave any strong impression. 

The service is prompt but the side dishes are small and they do not always refill it unless we request.
author: Michelle N.

description: Food is solid but, man, the service is horrid due to a grossly high customer to waiter ratio.  And they yell at you if you lean against the small wall. Have you considered a Plexiglas divider?
author: Yum Y.

description: Their sundofu tastes like Mrs. Grass noodle soup.  Meh.  I'm all for trying to be creative, but it's just that tofu stew isn't quite right tasting like that.  That being said, it's not that bad and would warrant three stars, except there's usually a ridiculously long wait here, even at 9 PM.  Which I wouldn't mind if the food was worth it.  Go to any of the other Korean restaurants on Geary. (Or Balboa.)
author: David A.

description: The silky tofu is nice.  I like the seafood pancake a lot.  Very crispy outside with plenty of seafood (mostly squid) inside :)
author: Lin L.

description: I'm probably the only person who eats soup in blazing hot weather and loves every moment of it! This place has the best tofu soup in the city. I usually get ramen w/ carrot because I love noodles, but would also recommend beef or kimchi. Sadly I've become allergic to shrimp but I'm sure seafood is epic, too. Negative for me is the price...my boyfriend and I paid over $60 for lunch (two soondubu and one kalbi) !!
author: Phuc N.

description:
My Korean roommate took me here for the soup hot pot with tofu and oysters in a spicy sauce. I've been to quite a few spots with him, and this dish remains hands down my favorite I've tried. In fact, I'm craving it so much I've been trying to juggle my schedule all week to get there. I may have to drive across town tomorrow just to pick some up for lunch. Especially recommended if you're feeling under the weather...nothing more soothing than something brothy and spicy for what ails ya.

Only reason I'm not giving it five stars is I've tried my roommate's mother's home cooking and this is still a ways off from completely authentic.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
I came here hoping to find the best Korean food since I've heard so much about it.  Well, I came out a bit disappointed.  It was about 11:45 or noon when I ate here on a Wednesday.  Only one other party was there when we arrived.  Service was extremely slow and not very friendly anyway.  They gave us tea and left us hanging for awhile.  Plus I sort of got used to other restaurants giving jap chae as a side dish, but we didn't get it here.  Minus one star. 

One thing I love about these places is the stone bowl of rice, and I eat my rice crispy off the sides.  Well the waiter didn't ask about that and he dumped all the tea in the bowl.  Minus another star.  Of course not many people may like the crispy rice on the edge of the hot bowl, but it's bad he didn't ask.  (5/14 - I have been corrected on this - they usually do not ask if you want tea in the rice bowl.  It's the custom to pour it in.  However, I'm not giving the star back) The food itself was ok.  Not great and a little less flavor than I'd hoped.  Which is probably a good thing - less sodium.  Mild soup means no spice whatsoever.  

So I really don't know why people talk about this place so much.  I couldn't see anything that stood out over other Korean restaurants I've eaten at.
author: Stacey C.

description:
What do you think when your co-worker first answers the question "Have you been there before?" with the response: "I've only been there twice and as far as I remember it was pretty good." and then later says "It's, "OK", it's not my favorite though."  You think, 1.) "I'm going to lower my expectations, this place won't be any good." and 2.) "Why aren't we going to her favorite place?"

My Tofu House, contrary to my expectations, was excellent!  My co-worker did us the honors of ordering everything in Korean.  We ordered kalbi, two tofu soups and a seafood pancake.  They really know how to pile on the traditional side dishes here!  My favorites were the kimchi and the small dried fish.

Overall, the food was great.  A table of 5 of us got out for $20 each--well fed, content and a little more knowledgeable about Korean culture.  I definitely would frequent this restaurant if I lived in the Richmond.  Instead, I'll just have to visit every so often to get my Korean food fix.

P.S. I really was supposed to dock a star (on behalf of my Korean co-worker) for not having shik hae (the malted rice drink)--but everything else was so good I couldn't do it.
author: Christopher W.

description:
There aren't many places that I would stand in a long line (that at times can move very slow) - but My Tofu House is definitely one of them!  Especially on cool evenings in San Francisco (which is a majority of the time in SF and a super majority in the Inner Richmond).  You can't go wrong with the tofu soup or the dol sot bibimbap.  Our favorites are the dumpling tofu soup and the seafood dolsot bibimbap.

When ordering the level of spicy in the soft tofu, recommend the medium (spicy but not too spicy).  If you get spicy, you will feel it. =)  And the cool thing is they can make it super mild for little kids to enjoy too.

We frequent this place because of their tasty foods and also their really friendly service.  Everytime we go there they are so nice and make sure to check up on you even though they are all running around.

From our experience going here for years, can't go wrong eating at My Tofu House.
author: RICOLE P.

description:
I stick to the stews here. Not that the other dishes are bad, but you gotta go with the house specialty. I'd say it's definetly better than the other Korean restaurants on Geary, but not as good as some of the places on El Camino in Sunnyvale/Santa Clara. 

I'm tempted to give only 3 stars because 4 out of 5 times I come here, I usually have to bus the table, pour my own water, and ask for tea multiple times.
author: Shinn Z.

description:
This is almost too clean for a little asian place like this. It felt very empty even though every table was filled, not sure what i think about that.

The food was good, good portions as well. I got the original tofu w/ chicken. the tofu was YUM :). got a bimbimbap, that was pretty good too. i know my korean friends always give me a hard time about ordering it, but i do it anyways =P

The banchan was decent as well. not a huge variety, but enough.

I will be back. (i've also started noticing those "yelp" stickers on store windows)
author: cat k.

description:
I don't know how many times we wanted to go here but gave up after looking at the line... but finally we went for it since the line looked "short." It turned out to be about 30 minutes or so, but damn was it worth every second.

Best tofu in San Francisco... perhaps the best I've ever had. Oh so good. As soon as I took my first bite I knew I would be craving this again at some point in the near future.
author: Jon N.

description: The best soondubu place in San Francisco.
author: Chas J.

description:
this is probably the only place i'll go to for korean tofu soup in the city. all the other places have watered down broth! =[

the flavor is good and its the right amount of spice for medium spicy (which is what i always get!). they still can't hold a candle next to my favorite spot in santa clara but hey... this one's much closer! that is until i found MOM'S TOFU HOUSE. teehee (they're better)

the employees there are pretty nice though and the price is just like any other tofu house would be. so yea... if you're in the city on a cold day, this place would definitely be a wise stop to make.
author: amelia g.

description: This place is my go-to restaurant when I'm feeling under the weather.  It's always really warm inside even when it's freezing cold outside.  The small dishes are so good, especially the grilled fish.  I usually get the tofu soup with mushrooms, medium spicy.  After eating this, I always feel much better.  =)
author: Jen Y.

description:
I ended up here for some roommate bonding on a Wed. eve.  My Tofu House is a relatively small, casual and bustling place where the focus is on the food.  For those who don't eat Korean food often, be prepared for deep-fried teeny fish appetizers and do-it-yourself egg drop soup.  The BBQ pork and onions was one of the best I've ever had, with lean pork and just the right mix of sweet and sour.  And the original with beef - a bubbling clay pot filled with very fresh tofu, minced beef and soupy goodness - was super filling, tasty and non-greasy.

Couple My Tofu House with a foray to an Irish bar on Geary, like Abbey Tavern, and you have the making of a great guys night out.
author: Kevin G.

description: Haven't been to this restaurant in a while, but decided to stop in last night.  Tofu soup is good, but at $11.50 for such a small bowl, the price is higher than most.
author: J Y.

description: I'm absolutely in love with My Tofu House. Despite the fact that you walk out smelling like your dinner, it's DEFINITELY worth it. The tofu soup is amazing, as well as the bulgogi, kolgi, and beef bibimbap.
