The side dishes which consists of a fried fish, pickled cucumbers, daikon pickles, kimchi, anchovies, and bean sprout salad really do curb your appetite while waiting for the delicious entrees. The restaurant is packed for a reason, the food is THAT good. It may be pricey, but you get what you pay for which is impeccably flavored Korean food.
author: Mirabella C.

description:
The regulars:
- Tofu Soup (All good)
- Kalbi
- BiBimBap
- BanChan

Wait could get a little long so be prepared. There's nothing in the immediate area to wander off to either, unless you want to check out the Jack in the Box or the bars.

Definitely worth the wait.
Make sure to bring a date.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
Love the kalbi-super soft and juicy.

I am not Korean but I'm asian and I love this place.  My Korean friends love it too.

I usually get take out kalbi plate lunch from here (comes with rice, soup, and a grip of Korean veggies).  The kalbi just melts in your mouth and everything here has the perfect amount of Korean seasoning, nothing is over sour or over garlicy or over done at all.  Dinner or lunch special for 2-4 comes with a pile of food, and is a great deal.  BBQ chicken, soft bulgogi(korean style grilled beef), Jap chae (korean fried clear noodles), sang sae jun (pan fried fish), pae jun(pan fried green onion/beef pancake), veggies, lettuce wraps are all delicious. I must say that i like Brother's jap chae even better. (place right up the street)

they do the "cook your own" bbq if you want as well.  I love korean yakiniku.

Nice clean place with clean workers and cooks who are the real deal Koreans.  Staff is quick and friendly. Prices are reasonable, you get a good amount of food for your money, and the taste is delicioso.

If you crave korean food my tofu house is a good bet for lunch or dinner.
author: Mark K.

description: Overpriced, got a beef bibimbap. I've been getting this at every Korean restaurant I've been to. By far this place is the worst, and overpriced. My beef bibimbap had grounded up pieces of beef.  For $14 I expect wholesome portion, not grounded up chucks of beef scraps. Will not return. (2 stars is for a decent service)
author: Tuan B.

description:
This past weekend marked my ninth consecutive week of having lunch/dinner here... and the food has been consistently terrific every time.

The tofu soup bowls and beef bi bim bops are the best. For tofu bowls, I usually order the kimchi with beef. You basically scoop up the goods and spread it over rice. Delicious. Bi bim bops are basically assorted meat and vegetable ingredients served within a hot stone pot. You let it sit for a few minutes so the rice becomes crispy. Then you add the hot sauce, stir it around, and chow down. 

Only area of improvement I might suggest is the alcohol... This place has no booze. It'd be nice to have a glass of cold beer during my meal. I'm considering taking a page out of elementary school and conceal a bottle of beer within a paper bag next time I go there. Bottom's up.

Seriously though... This place rocks. I'll be there next weekend for sure.
author: Chris M.

description:
DEFINITELY WORTH THE WAIT!  The tofu soup is amazing.  It's thick and spicy and soooo good.

We always get their seafood tofu soup and fish egg tofu soup!  SOOO GOOD!  I would assume all their tofu soup would be good, it's just a matter of what you want in it.  

I also like their ban chan.  I love their kimchi because it's not too sour.  Their little anchovies and the fried fish are also quite good.  

I've also tried their bulgogi, kalbi, and dolsot bibimbap. It's good,  but for that, I like to go to Han Il Kwan.

 Go to My Tofu House for the tofu soup.
author: LiveToEat F.

description:
I have recently tried this place after a long time of wanting to. The first time I went here it was busy since it was a Friday night.  It was about 8:30pm and the place was packed! we had to wait in line for about 25mins.  Boy i was hungry while waiting! we ordered kal bi, bul go gi, spicy tofu soup and the seafood pancake.  The food was okay it didnt really make me happy,  I guess because there were a lot of customers.  The seafood pancake was not a hit, it was like a deep dish pizza with seafood.  I would not recommend to get this but it is very big. 

I came here again for lunch because I love korean food! we ordered kal bi,bul go gi and spicy tofu soup.  I guess since it was not as busy as dinner time, the food tasted extra good! the kal bi had a lot of flavor and the spicy tofu soup was excellent. tofu was soft and spicy! my best dish would have to be the kal bi, will always order it.  Although, I wish they had better side dishes. they can always improve on it.
author: Ann L.

description:
My favorite Tofu House!! I come here so often I can't keep count.

First time? Try the Original Soft Tofu with your choice of beef or pork and mushrooms. Select your degree of spicyness (i prefer spicy to get the full flavor). Right when it comes, it'll still be boiling so pop the raw egg in there quick and stir! It makes your soup so much better.

With your order, you'll also get the small plate appetizers and rice. In the end, they'll pour hot tea into the rice bowl after they scooped it out. Let it soak for a bit and scoop some out to try. I think that's the best part of the rice. I had it in my childhood years and I liked it.
author: Nancy N.

description:
My Tofu House is the perfect place for dinner on a rainy, cold night in SF. I came here last night for dinner and ordered my favorite, #1, original soft tofu soup with beef. Piping hot soup filled with tofu, bits of beef, and mushrooms are served in a hot stone bowl. You can order it in any degree of spiciness. I always get medium. Along with your soup, you also get an array of veggie dishes. Tonight, it came with chilled sesame cucumbers, two crispy sardine fishes, kimchee, chilled bean sprouts, marinated tiny sardines, and marinated potatoes. On top of that, you also get a hot stone pot of rice. For all this food, it came out to only $10 a person! (excluding tip)

My friend had the bim bim bop and that looked delicious too! I had the grilled meats before too and it's good! Order anything here and you can't go wrong.
author: Denise L.

description:
Even though the wait is long, it's worth it once you sit down. Their banchun is different from other places. I like the fish they bring out. The spicy pork is to die for (a little expensive, but it's worth it). Their pancakes are pretty good too. I haven't tried the soup yet since I've been obsessed about the grilled meat. 

Overall, the wait and food is worth it.
author: Nam T.

description:
The stoneware Beef Bi Bim Bop ( did i spell that correctly?) is my favorite here. Served in a stoneware bowl that gets fired in the oven, then the rice is placed in the bowl so it gets nice and toasted on the edges, giving the dish a nice nutty and crisp texture.  Accompanied with a raw egg that cooks itself in the steaming rice, and all those great pickled veggies... kimchi's, spinach, cucumbers, radishes, bean sprouts, and those small salted fishes that seem to just compliment each other.  I don't know what type of tea was served but it had a roasted rice-nutty flavor, also complimentary to the flavors in the entire meal.

You definitely leave feeling satisfied, it always has that  "hits the spot!" appeal.  Come dinnertime the place fills up quick, sometimes folks are lined up against the wall waiting for a table to open, that pretty much speaks for itself, you know it's going to be good.

The melon gum accompanies the check, has a short lived flavor, but a good one while it lasts.
author: B H.

description:
My favorite tofu soup restaurant, the spicy is spicy! I can eat really spicy food and this soup can make my nose run! My favorite is the dumpling tofu soup, haven't found this anywhere else. The dumpling and rice cake is a little sweet which is a good combo with the spicy soup. 
The meats are equally as good. I always see the sizzling plate of kalbi (short ribs) come by, but I've never had them yet, maybe next time.
Only drawback is during peak hours you'll have to wait at least 15-20 min.
author: Flavia H.

description:
All I been hearing is that "My Tofu House" is great, they have the best soup and blah blah blah.....well it was blah.
Went on a Sunday afternoon so there were not wait, thank God otherwise I would of given them 1 star. I order the seafood soup which was very mediocre, the shrimp in it,3, were freezer burn shrimp (it's not hard to tell freezer burn shrimp). The soup came with clams (VERY chewy), and oyster and a bunch of soft tofu.
The truth was it didn't taste bad but it didn't taste great either, it tasted like the free soup you get at most Korean restaurant. Nothing out of the ordinary and for people to wait 30 to 40 minutes to eat on a busy night, it's absurd
I only had their soup so I can't say how good their other dishes are but if their soup is what they are claim for fame....I seriously doubt I will come back here again.
author: Andres K.

description:
I went here from a friend's recommendation and I'm glad I did. This spot is delicious. I find myself eating a ton of Korean food since I've been dating a lot of Korean chicks. I think it's because I remind them of the Super Human, Kim Jong-il. Take a look at my pic and decide for yourself. 

My biggest gripe about it is that parking is a real pain. They don't have a parking lot so you'll have to park somewhere in the surrounding neighborhood. There's a Jack-in-the-box next door and if you park there, they'll tow your car. 

All the stuff here is good though. Tofu soup, bibimbap and all the other standardish Korean dishes.
author: Trung V.

description:
I have nothing but love for MTF.  I like coming here on weekend afternoons when it's marginally empty and quiet.  I order the kim chee soondiboo, medium, and my friends and I split the Karbee.  Heavenly.  I always want to try the bimbimbap but I just love the soondiboo too much.

I am loathe to drive anywhere in the City and I very rarely ever go past Divisidero for any reason whatsoever.  But I'll hop into my car to head over to MTF in a heartbeat.  

Also?  You can always stop next door at First Korean Market for all your yummy korean needs.  Their homemade kimchee is bomb.
author: Courtney N.

description:
On a cold SF night, this hits the spot to warm you up. It's such a simple meal- hot tofu soup. Be careful when you order the amount of spice for the soup. Spicy is.... burning red hot kimchi spicy.  :-P 

The rice that goes with the soup is cooked in a hot iron bowl. I'm not sure what else they add to the rice but it gives it a different addicting  flavor than the usual rice you get from a chinese restaurant.

A great addition with the soup are the BBQ short ribs.
author: Bert T.

description:
While the name says tofu, I come here for the soup and Korean BBQ.  Either is a meal by itself, but they taste too good for me to want to choose.

Just don't come here for the ambiance.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Being Korean and having had recently moved from Palo Alto where I ate at Tofu House at least once a week, I was really excited when my friend said she found SF's version of Tofu House -- My Tofu House.  We went here for lunch the other day, and it wasn't very good at all.

My friend claimed that it was an off day.  Both of our dishes (mushroom soondubu and kimchi soondubu) tasted like spicy water.  And the spicy isn't very spicy.  

The panchan was still very good, though.  (And my friend ate the fish eyeball on a dare -- I bought lunch).  

Also, I prefer Palo Alto Tofu House's rice, which has beans.  This was plain white rice with a couple of peas and chickpeas on top.  But they do serve the rice in individual pots so that you can add water to the pot and then eat the rice-water porridge at the end of the meal.  Yum.
author: S J.

description:
One of the few really good Korean restaurants in SF. I've been here at least 10 times, and always leave feeling stuffed! 

They are known for their soon doo boo (although they have other menu items). They bring your rice out in a hot stone pot, and after putting the rice in individual bowls, they put hot tea in the stone pot so you can eat/drink it to cleanse your palette after the spicy soon doo boo. This is pretty traditional that not a lot of restaurants do here.

Slightly pricey, but still love it!
author: Jane M.

description:
I had dinner here today with my bf and it was delicious!!! This was our first time at Tofu House and it was such a delight.  We ordered the original tofu soup with beef (mild) and bulgogi. I think this is the best bulgogi I've had yet!  It was marinated just right, not too sweet or salty.  

I am leaving a star out because they didn't have the tofu side dish which i love.

I would definately go back.
author: Lily T.

description:
This truly feels like my house.  Like my very own... tofu... house.

My lovely girlfriend took me here, and now its one of my fav Korean places of all time.

The menu is small, but they know how to make everything on it well.  The combination tofu soup is a classic favorite.  The bulgolgi is some of the best I have eaten.

The prices: reasonable, cheaper for lunch though.

The ambiance: SO CLEAN, and very well ventilated (Korean Restaurateurs have a deep resepect for ventilation)  This is one of the few places in the city that has scored a 100% on the health department tests.

I recommend  this place to anyone and everyone.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Over - Priced and Over - Hyped.

Over $10 for a SMALL bowl of tofu... Ridiculous. And the tofu does not have flavor or taste.

I would not come back to this restaurant to say the least. There much more better restaurants out there that will be better and cheaper.

Let's face it, tofu ain't expensive..

The service is ok. Everything is acceptable and mediocre. But nothing to rave about.
author: U L.

description: they did not give us the yellow crocker fish as side dish. The other side dish were horrible. I thought it would be like tofu house in LA but it was not!!! and mor pricey too
author: R. K.

description: I came here for dinner with my +1. We ordered the beef tofu soup and beef bibimbap, but the staff got the order wrong, so we ended up with the chicken tofu soup instead. The best part of the bibimbap was the layer of nicely toasted rice from the hot stone pot. Other than that, I felt that there wasn't much meat or vegetable toppings in the bibimbap, in comparison to a place in Inner Sunset where I usually go for bibimbap. They also do not serve alcohol here, and it seemed like more of a family-friendly place - in fact, there were several toddlers in the booths around us, one who was crying incessantly and would just not have it, so the overall ambiance was not that great. I think we were just unlucky with that, but for next time, I'll just stick to my usual Korean spot in Inner Sunset.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Wow, I was so happy to have found this place!  It's awesome!  The panchan is really good (they even give you a small whole fish).  Also, they actually have vegetarian options here- which can be rare at Korean spots.  They have several different kinds of stone pot bi-bim-bap, which is awesome in my book.  We had the seafood tofu soup, which was quite tasty.  I like also how the rice comes with a small bit of veggies on top.  

I felt bad for the servers, because the restaurant was packed, and there were only 2 people working.  But they were pretty efficient, and also very nice.  

They have HD TV screens on the wall, and this is always a plus for the boys.

Update:  I went here again, and ordered the bbq chicken bi bim bap.  It was not very good.  Also, the large table of Koreans next to us got a fried fish with their panchan and we didn't.  What a bummer for us.
author: Sarah F.

description: Mmm bibimbap! No, it's not that 90's song by Hanson. It's rice, egg and all those yummy ingredients sizzling in a hot stoneware bowl. I love the crispy rice bits that form at the bottom. They do it well at My Tofu House.
author: Joel A.

description: I always love to come here & get the soft tofu soup! Any if them are very good! Everything is very good! I would love to come here for lovely comfortable Korean food! Service was good. It was very busy & they tried their best to refill tea as much as they can. I would come here in lunch hours for better service. Not that crowded.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Attention Korean BBQ lovers, it's all about tofu soups here!

What I love:
1. Soondubu jigae (seafood, meat, or combo) w/ personalized hotness of mild, medium, or hot. If you're super bold... extra spicy! The best that I've had in SF so far...
2. Flat screen TV that shows major football games (e.g. the Red Sox and the Patriots!)

Lessons I've learned:
1. Write your name upon entry on the clipboard near the waiting area
2. Race anyone on the street heading toward that direction
3. It's strictly tofu and spicy soups here.
author: Jen L.

description:
This was my first time eating at My Tofu House. A friend had suggested going for dinner after a long day walking around in windy and chilly SF. I was definitely looking forward to wolfing down some sizzling/boiling food to warm myself up. 

First off, we had a VERY difficult time finding parking. It was a late Saturday evening and we were circling the area for what seemed like an eternity, looking for parking. No dice. Meanwhile, I was impatiently salivating at the promise of being served hot delicious morsels of food. Finally we found a spot a few blocks away a good 20 mins or more later. We ran towards the restaurant to get out of the cold wind.

When we got there, the very narrow hallway in front of the door was  jam packed with many bodies waiting to be seated. I pushed through to get to the waiting list only to have this chick rudely swoop in to grab the pen just as I was reaching for it. She pens her name down and I follow suit  - there are at least 8 names on the list before us. I attempted to find a tiny niche to stand and wait, only to be told to move back by an employee, to give patrons more privacy as the waiting area immediately spilled into the diner's booths/tables. I will count their concern for diners as a plus. An hour later we are finally called to be seated and I immediately inform the server that we had already decided our order.

Hot tea is brought out in "clear" plastic short tumblers that looks suspiciously too light to be tea. I take and sip and yes, it tastes like hot water, not tea. But hey, at least it was free. Our order is taken and my friend and I order the same thing - the #3 seafood tofu, mine mild and hers spicy (fyi, there are 4 levels: not spicy, mild, medium, spicy). I can't tolerate spice well and since I was at what appeared to be an authentic Korean restaurant I decided to play it safe. The side dishes come out soon after we order and I have to admit that they were the highlight of the meal. The kimchi was perfect, quite spicy but in a deliciously tolerable way. I love anything pickled and salted so the anchovies, bean sprouts, cucumbers, radish and salted/fried fish were all good. Our tofu dishes come out still sizzling hot and I'm staring in anticipation as they're put down. I crack the egg over and start looking for the oysters only to realize they put in the wrong order because there's beef in it. Ugh. Disappointing. But I decided to keep eating anyway. I dig in and the tofu soup is NOT spicy at ALL, neither is it as flavorful as I had expected. I try my friend's spicy dish to compare and found barely any heat to it. Disappointing again. There was barely any meat, mostly tofu and I had expected more for the price of $10.05, but then again I guess it's SF. Meanwhile, rice topped with green peas and chick peas is brought out in a stone pot and scooped out for us. Hot water was then poured over the rice stuck to the bottom so we could enjoy the slightly burned rice. 

To sum up, service was prompt but they messed up on our 2 simple orders. I can let that slide since it was obviously a busy night, but then again, I figure it's not the first busy night they've had. Food was way overpriced and I saw that the meat dishes were priced in the almost $20 zone which deterred me, but thankfully I just wanted something soupy. Maybe the restaurant had an off night, because I really can't see why this is the top rated Korean restaurant on Yelp, and in San Francisco no less. This can't be the best it has to offer. I'm no Korean food expert and I can't comment on the other dishes, but the tofu should be the easiest thing to get right and be cooked well. The 2 other Korean tofu places I've been to - Lee's Tofu in Fremont and BCD Tofu House in LA were far better IMO as far as flavor/taste. I would only ever come back to eat again if there's absolutely no wait and few people dining inside.
author: KFish L.

description: good tasting food for decent price. it can be a little cheaper but still good. I got really full off of a tofu soup and various sides with rice. so that is definitely a plus. service is ok, seems under-staffed.
author: Norman W.

description:
Solid, decent tofu soup and bibimbap; safe banchan, nothing exciting.  I went here a few times but I got bored of it.  

My Tofu House gets three stars (from a base of three) because I would go there if I'm in the neighborhood.  If Brother's wasn't down the street, it would be my default for tofu soup and bibimbap.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
My Tofu House is my favorite Korean restaurant for hot tofu soup in the bay area.  The menu is simple with a few choices of soup, BBQ meats and typical dishes.
Their soups are always hot with a perfect blend of tofu, veggies and meats(optional).  Great flavor.
The BBQ dishes here are also delicious.  In fact, better than at most restaurants.
They also give you a wide variety of panchan and are happy to give you refills.
The service has always been good and the place is clean and not smokey.
author: Boba P.

description: All I can say is yummo! One is prone to overeating there. Reasonably priced, tasty food that comes in those cute little stone pots that make you feel you're eating something primitive.  Compared to Korean BBQ places, the smell permeating your clothing afterwards is milder and just a comforting little reminder of that warm tofu soup when you step out into the cold & foggy SF night . . .
author: Peg S.

description: I had the tofu kimchi soup.  I'm not a super big fan of kimchi but it was on the 2010 big eats list so i had it.  The sides are great, some sprouts, fish, zucchini.  It is a great value for the amount of food you get.  It's more 3.5 stars.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Great service, awesome tofu!  The tofu literally melts in your mouth.  The only complaint was that the tofu soup stays so hot for so long in the clay pots.  I'm so eager to eat, but my tongue keeps getting burned.  
If you order "mild" spice, you won't taste much at all.  I recommend ordering moderate or spicy.
author: Gregg F.

description:
I came here with my parents and sisters to get some lunch.
We were deciding on the two Korean restaurants that were right next to each other but we decided to go to My Tofu House cause the other restaurant didn't seem to have any customers in there, LOL.

Anyways, we went into My Tofu House and were greeted by a waiter and we were immediately seated. He gave us menus and my parents were debating on what to get. 

We got 2 tofu soups and a bibimbap. 
The wait wasn't too long but we snacked on the side dishes, LOL.
Our food got here and it was DELICIOUS!
I love love love this place!

The prices are not very high but it's not cheap either. Reasonable for a Korean restaurant. :)
Will definitely come here again with friends! ^^;
author: Victoria D.

description: Love this place.  So far every time I've come here, I find myself ordering the soft tofu soup.  It is too good to pass up!  I'll one day try a different dish..  The sides are really cool and you can even get seconds on them if your really hungry.  I tried kimchi here for the first time and those tiny fish too.  They remind me of a beef-jerky consistency.  The waiters are really good there.  The food gets an 'A' from me. (I don't know much about Korean food but I think its really good)
author: Jesse C.

description:
Authentic.  Filling.  Best cure when sick!

After my third day of coughing, achy body pains, and sore throat, I knew my last hope was the spiciest, eye glass fogging,  soon tofu soup that I could find in SF.

I found that even the spiciest soup on the menu didn't burn off my tongue per the capsaicin spectrum, but it sure did in temperature!  Nothing screams authentic Korean like a clay pot of soup that's still boiling as it reaches your drooling mouth - except for maybe the abundant side dishes of kimchi, mini anchovies, pickled cucumbers, and salted fish - heads still intact!

The service was mediocre as it's generally busy there (especially on cold evenings) and a bit understaffed, but when the server did come around, they made sure to be friendly.

The menu consists of different varieties of soon tofu soups (all $9.91) and bibimbap ($17!!) and some korean bbq options as well.  The silky soon tofu and the boiling soup definitely worked wonders for my cough, but I probably wouldn't venture in any other meals here besides the namesake dish.

Know Before You Go:
1. Parking in this area can get rough later in the night
2. Order to go!  The portions seem larger than when you eat in and they neatly pack all the side dishes for you as well!
3. Order the soon tofu - best bang for your  buck.
4. FYI - soon tofu is extremely silky tofu - melts in your mouth.
author: Jane L.

description:
Since I usually have to wait anywhere from 30 to 45 minutes with a bunch of non-Asian looking folks, I'm gonna assume the word is out that this is THE PLACE for spicy soft tofu soup.  Whenever I come here, I also make sure to place a to go order so that I can have hot soupy goodness for days.  Sure, it stinks up my refrigerator something chronic.  But that's the price I guess I'll have to pay for not having a separate kimchee fridge like Mom.

Don't be fooled.  This place is not a full-blown Korean restaurant.  Check out the name "My Tofu House" not "My Panchan House."  If you're looking for panchan there are plenty of other restaurants that'll give you all those pickled, fishy, acorn jelly goodness.  Just not here.

Hungry.  Must get up and eat.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
My mom drove up with me when I moved from LA last month.  We looked all over for Korean food and found this great place!  (...enough with the life story, I get it)

The food:  great.  really, really good.  And my mom, the best cook of Korean food...EVER...really liked it too.  I had the soon tofu EXTRA SPICY and that was the shiznet!  Nothing like food that makes you sweat like a pig!

The service was friendly, the atmosphere casual.  I docked 1 star because parking's a b*&%ch in the area.  Welcome to San Francisco!
author: Susan L.

description:
Went here for lunch today looking for a tofu soup.  Theirs hit the spot.  We ordered the mixed mushroom variety and it showed in a stone bowl, boiling like a mini volcano caldera.  We cracked an egg in there there and it promptly disappeared to cook away under the surface.  We ordered it "spicy", and it was fine for me, but Y. would have preferred more fire.  There was plenty of soft tofu and oyster, enoki, and button mushrooms.  Delicious!

We also ordered a baked tofu and mushroom bibimbap.  This was a rice dish with nice blocks of baked tofu and plenty of mushrooms along with some egg, seaweed, and other vegetables, again served in a hot stone dish.  I thought this dish was excellent, and would definitely get it again.  

The meal also came with an assortment of small dishes like kimchi, bean sprouts in sesame oil, some little marinated dried fish, some bigger baked fish, etc.  They were nice to poke around at, but the main dishes were the main attraction.

We've been to a couple other tofu soup places in the city, and this is definitely among the top.  There is a place in Japantown that might have had them beat on flavor, but we agreed that we wouldn't go back after seeing multiple cockroaches on our last visit.  So, for now, My Tofu House is my tofu house...
author: Stu M.

description:
A few of my co-workers raved and recommended this place for dinner so I was excited to go here. I was disappointed though, having such high expectations and all.

I went with a friend on a Wednesday and it was busy but we were seated immediately when the whole party was there. For side dishes, they gave us a fried fish each that were really big, kim chi, sprouts, cucumbers, and the potato-like dish. These dishes were decent but I was disappointed that the cucumbers didn't have more flavor to them. Also, where as the tofu cakes?!?!

I got the beef tofu soup and it came with a huge pot of rice. My friend got the bibimbap so the rice was all mine. Pretty unnecessary if I may say. The soup was alright as well. I've had better.

This restaurant is located on Geary therefore parking is terrible. Apparently, don't park in the Taco Bell parking lot that's right next door.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The KimChi was not as good as I expected...a little tastless.  In all seriousness, I like my food a little spicy/salty/sweet when I eat at an asian restaurant.  Make sense?

Not that it is the end of the world, but they also do not serve alcohol at all!  I was looking forward to a nice beer with my spicy dish after a long day at work.  I won't be returning, but rather trying one of the other hundreds of great small asian restaurants in our lovely city.
author: Lulu B.

description:
I am a mild-soup guy, but I decided to be adventurous and got the medium-spicy soup. Boy, am I a wuss! I got that sweat mustache and everything. Despite that, the meal was great. I love all the little dishes you get with your meal. And get the Kalbi, I inhale that stuff.

Hmm.. are you supposed to eat the rice that 's left in the stone bowl after the waiter pours the water in it? I love that stuff, but for some reason, I don't know if the waiter is pouring water in the bowl to cool it down or not. I'm a self-conscious eater.
author: Hue L.

description:
I haven't been to too many Korean restaurants, don't know much about the cuisine either.  But I do know however, that I love My Tofu House!  I love the side dishes, especially the picked cucumbers and the plate of fish.  I always get the original soft tofu with beef.  Yumm. They offer mild, medium, and spicy- my pick.  Spicy isn't bad at all so don't be scared!  Tip: If you do order the tofu soup, I suggest from personal experience not to wear white or anything expensive because sometimes the soup sizzles far enough on it. Not good if you are sitting across from your date, with a blotchy red stain on your blouse. 

Be prepared to wait in line on weekends and friday nights.  The teeny weeny waiting area is horrid and awkward. Talk about being claustrophobic.
author: Mimi S.

description: Growing up in Los Angeles I was spoiled with delicious Korean food. Ever since i've moved up to San Francisco i'd get cravings now and then for some good Korean food. I think this is the only place that can satisfy my hunger for it. I'm always iffy about going to korean restaurants in the city because it's seriously not that good. I'm always left disappointed because there's always something missing. But then my friend introduced me to this place. This is probably the only restaurant in SF that i found that's remotely close to the food i grew up with. Whenever i miss home and need comfort food, i go here.
author: Suzan L.

description:
There's a reason for 298 reviews and 4 stars.
Shared last night...
One Bibimbap
One Kalbi
I'm a big eater and we still took home leftovers
It tasted too good to leave on the table.
Its not too often we eat all of the banchan.
Maybe that's why we took the Kalbi and Bibimbap home.
The kimchi and banchan were too good to leave on the table too!
author: Barry A.

description:
I've had better in other cities, but this definitely hits the spot comparatively in SF for soodoobu.  The banchan here are not bad... especially the gakkdukki (kimchi radish cubes) and kongnamul (bean sprouts) --one time I was here, however, the fish I got was half eaten or something happened to it's other side (very much a turn off) --we asked for a replacement and were given one, however.  The bibimbap is good with a nice crusty bottom and good helpings of content.  I think the pajon isn't that worth it ($17 something).  If you have the tofu soup, spiciness is key for taste quality.  I always get spicy... the medium isn't that bad, but the taste really comes out with more chili. :]   

This place is a must try if you are in search of boiling hot soup, rice, and unlimited side dishes that does fit the bill.  If you're not in search of soup, I'm sure the bulgogi or other dishes are fine, but I think the main attractions of soondoobu and bibimbap are definitely the more popular and tastier choices offered.  Prices are fair, but are OK for the quality and taste!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
The tofu is quite good, a tiny bit pricey since I am used to so Cal k-town prcies, but the best tofu I have found around town so far.
Definitely the place to go if u r craving some authentic tofu and yummy pan-jangs.
author: Jenny W.

description:
This place is awesome. I'm not a big fan of soft tofu, but this place definitely changed my mind. 
They give you a lot of food for your money.
author: Svet V.

description:
This is my first venture into eating Korean food.  My count currently rests at 3.  
1.  Tofu House
2.  Brother's (I was too drunk to remember)
3.  OZ 

My strumpet and I have a very complex system for picking out restaurants.  To be broken down from its science, it is basically I pick one, she picks the next and this goes back n forth.  Now this is just the layman's terms for it...it is quite more complicated than it sounds.  So we went to Tofu House , which was her pick and we went to also celebrate a fellow strumpet's new job.  Up to this point, all I knew of Korean food was kimchee and those cute little ribs b/c of an old roommate.  I ordered the Tofu Soup and because my buds cannot handle spiciness, I ordered the lowest level of hotness, much to the dismay of our waiter and friend.  The waiter exclaimed that the soup would literally be clear and like water...I told him my order was not a flub..I meant exactly what I said.  We also ordered some kalbi and my friend had a bibimbap bowl.  To highlight my ignorance, my girlfriend told me to drop my egg in the boiling mini cauldron.  I simply picked up the whole egg and dropped it in.  Everybody's jaws dropped, inches away from their own bubbling hot soup.  It had to be rescued and cracked in.  While I played it off to the best of my ability, I was quite ashamed.

The tofu soup was nothing spectacular.  It is similar to a tofu soup my mother makes except with more condiments.  The rice came in a cool clay pot, but tasted like.......normal rice.  The kalbi meat was pretty good but those damn rib like things are so small.  I hate sucking meat off bones.  The art of sucking is one I have not mastered and have no intention of.  The tofu house is not a place I'll go again.  It was not worthy of the heaps of phrase dropped upon it.  However, I am a guy and tofu is simply not my forte.
author: Brian V.

description:
Restaurant was cute, the service was mediocre, and the prices were a little more on the pricey side. 

But, the food felt more authentic than most of the Korean I've had in the area. The kalbe was delicious & the Tofu pot (original w/ pork) was great as well - got it 'medium' spicy... probably should've gone hotter :)

The appetizers were good - I really liked their bean sprouts & the pickled cucumber. 

Will definitely be back - great for a casual meal with friends
author: linda t.

description:
Meh. Way overpriced for soondubu. Is that how you spell it? oh, whatever. 

In socal, you can get something better for a few bucks less. The one here is pretty good (for the bay area) but definitely not the best I've ever had. I would probably come here if someone requested soondubu but not on my own accord. Sadly, they don't give you that much meat, either for being overpriced. So, then, I get more meat for cheaper in socal. How am I supposed to eat soondubu anywhere else? 

Nevertheless, for people in the bay who are addicted to this, get your fix here if anything.
author: Joyce D.

description: With a solid four star rating, I was expecting the restaurant to be a bit better. We came here for a late Saturday night dinner. The ambiance was in-line with your usual korean bbq joint. Service was friendly, albeit a bit slow. We had the dumpling tofu soup and the kimchee dumpling soup. I actually wasn't too impressed with either. The banchan was limited and not the freshest, though I did enjoy the fried fish. The place was almost completely full when we got there at about 9:15, so obviously people seem to like it, but I think I'll hold out for something else.
author: Nora G.

description: I ordered the combination tofu soup and it came with 6 side dishes.  The place looked really clean and no smokiness like other BBQ places.  The tofu soup came in this small bowl and it was pretty good.  It had some tiny clams and tiny beef cubes and 2 small shrimps(one of which looked really disgusting, brownish in color and all beat up and falling apart).  The soup was medium spicy and relatively tasty with the rice.  I think next time I would go with the full spicy level since I didn't think it was spicy enough.  The total came to $10.25 so I tipped $3 since the server was pretty friendly, although I had to get up to get the check myself.  It was not cheap for lunch, however if you are in the mood for spicy tofu, I think it is still a good place to go.
author: Jim J.

description: Do your body a favor and go here to eat.  Friends and I ate here last night, and I ordered the Mushroom Tofu # 5.  It was so awesomely healthy alongside with the sidedishes of kimchee, pickled cucumbers, fish and bean sprouts, plus barley tea/water.  Yum!  I finished it all and was pleasantly full, but at the same time, I felt like I nourished my body with good nutrients it definitely needed.
author: Maile N.

description: I am SO glad my friend recommended this place to me! Everything is yummy here, and they've got a huge variety of food with huge servings. They start you off with Korean appetizers - bean sprouts, fried fish, preserved fish, kimchee, veggies, you name it - they got it.The tofu bibimbab is dee-lish, as is everything else they've got there. It's a little pricey, but well worth it! The friend who introduced me to it craves Korean food every week, thanks in part to My Tofu House. lol
author: Monica M.

description: It was a cold August evening (why!??), and I was at the de Young looking at Chihuly's glass exhibit (amazing). I needed something to warm me up. Around 6:30p my friends and I got a table w/in minutes. I went with the dumpling soon tofu, kalbi and bulgogi. Now their medium soon tofu, is SPICY so if u're a newbie go a level below. Kalbi was awesome, lots of meat and sweet and easy to chew. The bulgogi... I've had better. Prices were reasonable and service was friendly and attentive. I am coming back for sure!
author: Thomas L.

description: We arrived a little before 7pm on a Saturday for my belated birthday dinner, there was a little wait about 5-10min. I know we ordered the dumpling tofu soup, and I think we also ordered original, both mild. Next time I'll order medium, since the mild soup wasn't spicy at all, I expected it to be a little spicier. We also ordered beef spareribs and some other beef item, which I can't remember what the names were, but they were the 2 pictures on the top right, on the 3rd page? I think. The beef was good, but we were so stuffed that we still had leftovers. Each tofu soup were about $9 something, and beef were about $20 each. About $20/person after tax & tip, I'd go again.
author: Kylie L.

description: My Tofu House serves great Korean tofu soup. Easily the best I've come across in San Francisco, the soup is tasty, hot, spiced to how you like and served at a reasonable price. The downside is that meat dishes are rather costly and there are no combo orders. Be ready to wait, there's usually a line and they're understaffed. Worth it, though!
author: Barrett I.

description:
The soup here is great. I forgot what i ordered last time, but if you mix it wtih the rice, it's awesome. But the soup is about all that's great. But don't get me wrong, it's good enough for a meal all on it's own. You just take the stuff out of the soup and eat it with the rice and then drink the soup. 

The meat on the other hand is nothing spectacular. I'd rather go to brother's for that. Same with the sides.
author: Karen C.

description:
For some reason, I was craving for dobu soup last night.

So, my boyfriend and I headed out for dinner to My Tofu House.  This is my first time here since about four years ago (yeah, I know.. what's wrong with me?!), and I have to admit, their prices have gone way up from back then. We ordered the combo dobu soup spicy $9.91 and kalbi which was around $19. They don't give as many side dishes as Brother's, but their side dish of fried fish is YUMMY.  I love their rice as well because it comes in a stone pot and they have peas mixed in the rice.  Our dobu soup came to our table still sizzling hot (literally, the soup was bubbly hotness). The kalbi tasted great, but not something I would order if you were to go on a first date because you will be getting your hands dirty. Order the spicy pork instead, it'll be cleaner to eat.

Although their prices seemed to have increased over the years, their portions seemed to have taken a plunge toward the opposite direction.  I wasn't quite as full as I remembered being last time I came here. 

I will definitely be coming back soon. Hopefully I can make it before lunch is over 11a-4p because their meat costs almost half the price than during dinner time!
author: Helen Z.

description:
Freakin' delicious.

Ok, maybe the only Korean tofu place that I've been to but my taste buds know what's up. 

Perfect for a cold, foggy, SF day; I get the crave when the clouds roll in.

Get the one with dumplings! Absolutely fabulous. I went mild because I'm a wimp but both that and the medium give a pleasant burn in my mouth.
author: Salina Z.

description: Great unassuming place. Service was attentive and the food very good. Basic menu, but that's what I liked about it. The dumping soft tofu soup was top notch, that even my Korean sister-in-law would approve. The kimchi dishes were adequate but the rice coming in a stone pot was unexpected. Well done!! We also ordered the seafood pancake, was not bad, and still fairly tasty. I would definitely come back and try more of the tofu soups....they're all a meal in itself.
author: Jack D.

description:
I was a little disappointed. by brother and bf raved about this place like no other. The little dishes at the beginning of the meal was nice, though a whole fish was a little much for 2 people. 

the food sounded delicious on the menu, but it was a little too salty and not what i expected at all. 

The booths are a cute idea, but for a big group and during dinner time, its a tight squeeze. I dont think i'll be coming back
author: Jane N.

description: This is my go to place for Korean food. SF in general is lacking and My Tofu House is a welcome relief. Anyone that can enjoy spicy food should try their soup!
author: M K.

description:
Went here with my girlfriend for dinner on sunday. The Tofu soup is awesome! I'm a meat eater so I ordered kal bi for me. I know I know it's a tofu house. I don't care. I'm Korean and I love Kal Bi. Both were really good. The Kal Bi isn't the best but still really good but that's to be expected you go there for the soup. But I was also craving Pa Jun (Korean pan cake with seafoood and veges). Normally this is an apetizer or something you eat with the meal. It was 17 bucks on the menu so we assume it's going to be amazing. Thus why I knocked one star off. I've had so much better Pa Jun. It was soo thick and cooked on one of the ceramice plates which made it crsipy which is a good thing but it was wierdly doughy in the middle. I've had such better Pa Jun than this at half the price. I couldn't believe I paid that much for it.

Word to the wise get anything else but that there. The rest of the food is great.
author: Hyung L.

description: This restaurant doesn't have the capacity to handle parties of 6 or more. The waiter screamed at my wife for standing too close to the table next to her. It's their fault that their tables are right next to the line of people waiting in the first place. I do not recommend this restaurant.
author: Brian L.

description:
* Food:
o Presentation: Ok. (3/5)
o Temperature: Hot! (5/5)
o Quality: No. (1/5)
o Dishes ordered: Kimchi tofu soup.
o Tastiest dish: None. (1/5)

* Server:
o Attentive: Yes! (4/5)
o Knowledgeable: Ok. (3/5)
o Friendliness: Ok. (3/5)

* Restaurant:
o Atmosphere: Lots of people! The restaurant was well-lit. (4/5)
o Cleanliness: The restaurant looked organized and clean. (5/5)
o Cost vs. value: Decent! (3/5)

* Will I revisit restaurant? Yes, I will revisit as there are many reviews on yelp. Maybe it was a bad day for them? As of now, I still prefer Tofu House in San Bruno, CA.
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description: OMG! My Tofu House has the best tofu soup! I love this place. Everyone is very nice, speedy and very clean. Thank you for the experience.
author: Mozelle L.

description: Their fish egg soft tofu was ridiculous good...large amount of fish eggs in boiling tofu.
author: ray l.

description: YUMMY! hot day, cold day, warm day, whatever! there's always room in my tummy for my tofu house. I'm not a big fan of  thepancake though. The wait is usually pretty long since the restaurant is so small. I put my name down and walk next door to the convenient store and shop for snacks (yea, i know , such a fatty). I love korean food! kal bi + tofu soup!
author: Wendy L.

description:
I had the #1 Original Tofu Soup w/ beef - medium spicy.  I don't know if it's because I am Chinese and I look Chinese (and sometimes mistaken for Korean), but my medium was definitely spicy.  Mike ordered the Ramen Tofu Soup and he ordered his "spicy", but my medium looked just like his spicy.  Our companions ordered medium too, but theirs looked mild.  To make sure you don't get the "gringo" treatment, be sure to emphasize the "spicy" if you really want spicy.  

The ramen tofu soup was good, pretty much as described.  The "beef" in my #1 wasn't that great, I'd probably choose a different meat next time.  It was a little bit tough, and there wasn't that much of it.  The broth and tofu are the real highlight of the tofu soup.  

As all the reviewers have said here the panchan is lacking, but they do at least ask you if you want more of any dish.  I think the service is just fine, nothing mind blowing, but adequate.
author: Joann C.

description: On a cold rainy night...after furniture shopping all day in the city...and still no sofabed purchased...this place made the day all better!  MMMM....tofu soup hit the spot.  However, the service sucked.  I MUST have those little dishes refilled and the server never stopped by to check on our table!  They weren't busy that neither so there should be no excuse!  Other than that, nothing really stood out to me.  What I thought was pretty cool was that they give you a small fried fish as one of the mini dishes.  I've eaten at a lot of Korean restaurants before and that's the first I've seen of it.
author: Cindy B.

description:
This place does cook some great tofu soups, but I don't believe it's worthy of the SF Top 100 Eats (specifically, the kimchee tofu soup). I've tried their kimchee, mushroom, combo, and seafood (on separate occasions). For the most part it can be super good, but there were occasions when it was just mediocre. 

I went there just a couple of days ago and noticed that they raised their prices. Ten bucks for tofu soup is definitely a bit pricier than the regular tofu joints. Heads up: the wait staff gets easily overwhelmed by the crowd. My friend had to remind our waiter three times just for the to-go box--the bill came without reminders though.
author: Carrie W.

description: I've had ALOT of Korean food and this place is just eh! The bi bom bop was not alot and not all that, I had better in a lot of places. They do their short ribs right, that was good! Tofu soup was good but I've had similar at other Korean places. I think it was just eh. I don't think I would come back since there are so many better Korean places in SF.
author: Karen T.

description:
3.5 stars
We like this place because it offers great Tofu Soup..  Great place for cheap but very tasty korean dishes..  
Unfortunately the do not serve beer..  : (
author: Rose C R.

description:
Thank the lord you don't have to pay extra for those little side dishes! If they happen to be out of those little cucumber cubes, the chances are high that I was there before you and ate them all. Fresh, crisp, good, and free "refills" - yay!

The boyfriend always gets Tofu soup with Dumplings, spicy since he's Thai and that's what Thai people do, and I always get spicy chicken. It isn't on the menu but the chef is always nice enough to make it for us (: I'm not a BIG fan of pork and I'm grateful that they'll make something special! Of course, the waiters always try to tell me that they don't make spicy chicken but the line "Really? The cook made it for us last time and it was so good!" always seems to work. They know me by now, though, so I don't have to use that line too often.

My only complaint is that my little Latina/Japanese tongue can't handle all that damn spice so my nose is constantly running. I eat the chicken which is spicy, then try to cool it down with the cucumbers and rice but then my hashii (chopsticks) are spiced up which makes everything I poke spicy too...Boo! Here come the sniffles...

The help is quick to refill tea but it can take an eternity to get a cold glass of h2o. I always bring a bottled water in my purse and pour when they're not looking. If they leave the pitcher out, I usually walk up and pour water myself. Problem solved. I think they hate it when I do that but damnit, what the hell does a girl gotta do to get some freaking water!? Cry? Cuz I'll do it.

That little stick of melon gum is great at the end of a spicy meal too. I love the Tofu House!
author: La De Da C.

description:
The food and service are both good! We came on a busy Friday late afternoon / night for dinner, and although the waiter already looks overworked, he was still efficient in seating us and getting tea. 

The tofu soup was good, as claimed by the name of the restaurant. The galbi  (bbq beef slices) were also  very tasty, as was the fried fish on the house. The seafood pancake was okay...it was a  bit overcooked, but still not bad. We did run out of rice, and they took quite a while to get more for us, but it's understandable. 

Come for the tofu soups, indeed! They have Not Spicy to  Extremely Spicy  options for most of the soups, so it'll work for everyone. =)

Oh, parking's a pain. So have patience.
author: April Z.

description: My Tofu House is Great!!! It's my favorite restaurant!!! The spicy seafood tofu soup is so so good and the spicy BBQ Pork is just delicious.  The service is good however they can get very busy and sometimes it is hard to get the waiter's attention.  The sides including fried fish, cucumbers and kimchi are the best.  The hot stone rice is delicious and has this great texture--way better than just regular steamed rice.  I totally recommend this place however if you are really really hungry, the wait might be a while on Fridays and weekends.  Remember to write your name on the wait list.
author: qulu C.

description:
I'd happily run the gauntlet of grim, hungry people lining the narrow corridor that is MTH's entranceway, put my name on the list, wait for anywhere from 20-40 minutes, depending on the time of evening -- for those steaming iron bowls of bubbling spicy red rich soon dobu chigaee, flecked with kimchee and various meats and seafood -- hot enough to cook your raw egg and scald your tongue for weeks, because you can't really wait for it to cool down, it's too damn delicious.

panchan (not as varied as brothers?) helps to stave off the hunger while you're waiting for your stew and i love that one small fried whole fish whose meat comes off so neatly in one smooth peel - but only if you're delicate and careful ... 

it's rainy and misty this afternoon and though i've been through 2 cake tastings and lunch today, i'm *really* craving tofu soup-stew right. this. very. moment.
author: Claudine C.

description:
This is one of those family-run asian restaurants in the Richmond. The decor is a bit odd. It's pretty obvious that the place has changed ownership - there are unused ventilation ducts weaving through the dining room. Otherwise it looks like they just stripped down and reused the decor from the previous shop since it was vaguely asian looking.

The service was total crap - they were ill-equipped to handle the persistent line of diners streaming in. Tables weren't bussed promptly, water/tea glasses weren't refilled, the check took a long time to get to our table.

The food was My Tofu House's only redeeming quality. The tofu was the perfect texture in the tofu soup and could be dressed with an array of condiments and options. The meat dishes my dining partners got were very tasty too except for the chicken. Drink options were... non-existent. There is water, tea, and 3 sodas to choose from. This is a great deal IF YOU GO FOR LUNCH. Many of the lunch prices are half that of the of dinner prices. There were a handful of dinner items that topped $20 - I wouldn't regard that as a deal especially considering the shabby decor and poor service.

I get the impression that this is another example of one those fun hole-in-the wall places that has crippled under the pressure of "being discovered."
author: Kevan M.

description:
This might be the best place to get tofu soup in the bay area.  The soup is very rich in flavor compare to other places.  My favorite one is the Dumpling Tofu Soup which has 4-5 dumplings (yums!) and has cute little rice cakes in it.  It also comes with rice served in a stone pot.  

I havent really tried anything else but the Tofu Soup is definitely the best.

The side dishes are also good.  They serve a whole small fish!
author: Jannifer H.

description:
For take-out, I'm giving it a 3.5.  We ordered two seafood tofu pots to go and it was not bang for the buck like dine-in was.  

The two take-out pots missed: two eggs, two pan fried fish, and extra rice, but were the same price at $21.50.  

This place is still worth it for dining in.
author: Mrs F.

description:
Mm I just ate here tonight. It was delicious as always. This is one of my regular spots for Korean food where I don't want to come out smelling like Korean food. The whole smelling like dinner an hour after I finished dinner doesn't sit well with me. This place minimizes that feeling. 

The tofu soup is delicious, which it better be since the tofu is the restaurant's namesake. They let you pick the degree of spiciness and the meat.  Plus they give you a fried fish, possibly mackerel of some sort?, as one of the panchan dishes. Yum! The bulgogi is also good. 

Prices are typical prices for a Korean restaurant, about $10 for the tofu soup and $17 for the bulgogi. I think it's pretty easy to find parking, but then again I usually eat here way past normal dinner time, which is also why I like this place. I think it's open until 10. I'm just happy whenever I find restaurants open past 9. Good service most of the time, but I have had times when I've come at normal dinner times, and service was lacking since the restaurant was busy.
author: Jessie C.

description: The food is awesome! I came here with my old college friends and we had a great time...They didn't know what to order but I told them everything was good..They were not disappointed with what they order everything was delicious from the apps to the soup and the grilled fish was really taste....coming back for more!
author: Christian P.

description: The wait was not bad.  The price is reasonable.  Order the combination tofu soup and it comes with  a variety of kim chi, fish, cucumbers, etc.  For the soup they are all the same price, you can choose how spicy you want your soup to be.  If you come here on weekdays, the lunch special would be more worth it.
author: Lee C.

description: Side dishes were great and the bibimbap rocked. The only downside was that the tofu soup was a bit bland (at least to me). I was expecting more of a kimchee jjigae taste.
author: Albert C.

description:
Damn good tofu chige! This is the real thing.
Atmosphere is a little too much like a cafeteria.
author: Peter O.

description:
I go here too much because this is the place nobody hates. You know how that is. A group gets together, argues over where to eat, goes to the least offensive place. Democracy at its best. Nobody is please. But I digress ...

There's less selection at Tofu House than at other Korean places, but the few dishes they have are all winners. I like spicy food, but spicy soup has never been my thing, so I miss out on the dish upon which Tofu House makes its namesake - though a non-spicy Tofu soup is still good. Prices are higher than I like, but acceptable. Parking is a pain.
author: Karl K.

description:
My Korean friend from Seattle was definitely not impressed.  But we picked the spot because it looked so busy inside.  The only choices are tofu soups and meats.  Nothing more, except some of those Korean appetizer things.

I went there again because it is a good place for a white girl that knows nothing about ordering Asian food.  Again, the food was not great.  The soup is not thick enough, and the meats are rubbery and dry while being coated in oils.

Next time I will probably find somewhere new.
author: Julie R.

description:
The drive is far and the wait is long but I keep coming back because each time the food arrives, all is forgiven.

The menu is short and without an alcohol section but they are good at what they do make, which are the tofu soups.  Even if you're not too spice-tolerant you should still get a medium because otherwise your soup is not reaching its full potential, and an under-achieving tofu soup is a sad tofu soup.
author: Andrew P.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a long while.  I used to come here when it was a Shabu Shabu Hot Pot a number of years ago so I wanted to see what My Tofu House did to the spot.  It's a lot brighter than it used to be.  

Food wise, It's okay.  I'm actually used to getting more sides though.  A lot of the other Korean restaurants seem to give more than here.  Not sure if I have just been lucky to try some of these other places that give more.  I personally am not sure what the "industry standard" is for the Dinner Starter Giveaways???  

So we had the Combination Tofu Soup and the Kalbi.  Both were pretty good.  I think the one thing that really captured my attention was how tender the Kalbi was.  This may be the most tender Kalbi I have had in my life.  I think that may be a sign of good cooking but I think I still prefer to have my Kalbi "seared" and have a little crisp to it..   

Service was kinda slow.  I think they must have been understaffed.  But I think they did the best they could considering it was pretty crowded on a Thursday evening.
author: Mark W.

description:
I love this place. It's very clean, affordable, and delicious. I always get the  mild seafood soft tofu soup, and it's always perfect. For about ten dollars, you get delicious spicy tofu soup filled with tofu, clams, shrimp, and if you choose an egg. You also get endless side dishes that include pickled cucumbers, kimchi, and an interesting looking fish. The bul gol gi and kalbi are really good too, but I usually only get them if I'm eating here around lunch time, as they are half the dinner price (8 dollars instead of 16).

However, I can only give them the 4 stars because you always leave smelling like kim chi (so shower and wear dirty clothes). I also ordered take out the other day, and my soup wasn't very spicy and almost bland. 

The restaurant is very clean. The waiters are all very nice though many of them do not speak English very well. Eat in, don't order out.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I've found my go-to Korean restaurant in the Bay Area! Can't say there's much variety, but what they lack in menu quantity, they make up for in food quality. The kal-bi is juicy and succulent and I've never been disappointed by the soft tofu either. They're the only place I've seen that serves my beloved fish egg soft tofu.

What I especially love are the appetizers that they serve, which extend the standard Korean fare (kimchi, pickled cucumber, bean sprouts) with deep-fried mackerel! So awesome.

Really, my only complaint is the price, but that's not really even a valid complaint in SF because other Korean restaurants routinely charge over $20 for kal-bi (my reference dish) so My Tofu House is actually quite a steal, relatively speaking.
author: Horace K.

description:
Gahhh -- every time I think of soon dubu, I always think about My Tofu House in San Francisco - right in my own neighborhood! The soon dubu (tofu stews) are so incredibly good here. The broth is rich and flavorful, and the silken tofu is the perfect consistency. And I LOVE the stone pot rice. The rice that gets crisp on the bottom of the stone pot really makes me reminisce on my childhood. If you want, you can also ask your server to put hot water in the pot so you can stir it up and eat the remaining rice that way, too. It's pretty good. 

I remember last summer, I took a road trip with a bunch of friends down to LA and couldn't wait to try the soon dubu in Koreatown. My friend's Korean friend recommended a place there, which I believe was a mini-chain, and the tofu really didn't seem soft and silky. The broth also wasn't as good as My Tofu House's. Needless to say, I was really sad and was crying inside for My Tofu House in SF. :( 

I'm not really sure why some Yelpers are complaining that the portions here are small - I think that the servings for bulgogi and soon dubu are pretty normal for a Korean restaurant. I always leave full and have leftover soon dubu, which is sad because it's never as good at home as it is in that stone pot in the restaurant.. I like the way the restaurant and the tables are set up. It's very clean and modern-ish. 

Although this restaurant looks like a hole in the wall from the outside, it's actually quite deep when you walk in, and if you come on almost any night around peak dining hours, there will be a bit of a wait. The service overall is pretty good, though. Yes, it is true that the banchan selection is not huge, but what they do give I enjoy. My Tofu House's soon dubu is now one of my biggest food cravings, and I'm not even Korean!
author: Yvonne W.

description:
My favorite tofu restaurant in San Francisco! Really can't ask for much more when it comes to My Tofu House. The food is great and the customer service is great! The guys who work there are always very nice. He spilled water on my table a few weeks ago...but I didn't feel upset AT ALL!!! Their years of great service just overshadow any horrible thing they accidentally do once in a while. 

I would give it five stars, but just a few things don't work out for me. One little stupid thing is that I don't like peas in my rice. The other thing is that I like the kimchee at my favorite tofu place in San Diego much more. But that's about it! If peas and kimchee don't bother you at all...this place is perfect for you!

Parking is only difficult at night. You can easily find metered spots right outside the restaurant on weekday mornings/afternoon.
author: Allan M.

description:
After leaving another Korean restaurant because they didn't have any tables, my boyfriend and I decided to check out My Tofu House.

Much to our surprise the restaurant was Zagat rated, which explained the line of people waiting for a table. It didn't take too long to get seated and was worth the wait. 

We had the soft tofu soup - hot. I don't normally eat a lot of tofu, but the soup was delicious and very flavorful (and it's their specialty). And we also ordered the bibimbap, which was typical and tasty.

 My boyfriend was kicking himself for not ordering the broiled short ribs everyone else was eating. So that might be worth checking out as well.
author: Sarah G.

description:
So far my favorite tofu house in SF

...even then, it doesn't hold a candle to LA's BCD cafe. Really, all Korean food in SF doesn't come close to the cuisine in Los Angeles.
author: Cherry P.

description:
It's still one of my fav restaurant in the city... but I do think they need to have something new in their menu. 
I know, they specialize in the tofu-soup-thingy, but a little more variations will be appreciated... I think I have tried almost everything in the menu and I want to try sth new!!!!!!!!!!
author: Doris H.

description: As far as Korean places go, this is a steady place.  Its really nice how they give you decent portion sizes.  The free mackerel was a nice touch for starters.  Food was very warming and seemed to hit the right spot.  Soft tofu soup, ribs, and seafood pancake, were all good.  Service was a bit slow though, I understand the place was busy and the staff couldn't have been as attentive but it would have been nice if they came by often enough to refill our hot tea occasionally without our reminding them each time.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
delicious bibimbap and ribs!
and tofu of course
author: Siri W.

description:
This was my first time at My Tofu House.  I was unsure what to expect of the place, but my brother and his wife have been here countless times and have attested to the tastiness of the food.  This was enough to get me to put this place down on my "must try" list.  

After me and my friend found parking a few blocks away, we were excited by the smell of barbecued meat cooked on charcoal wafting through the air.  We get closer and realize the smell was not from my tofu house, BUT rather, the Korean place a few doors down!!! It's oK, something tells me we weren't the first people to think that too. ADMIT IT!!!

Anyhow, we put our names down and was expected to wait 10-15 minutes; there were two other groups ahead of us.  The waiter finally comes and tells the people ahead of us that there was tables open in the back, but they opted to wait an extra 10 minutes to sit in the front.  The waiter arrives at my name to give us the tables in the back room.  We took it thinking nothing of it.  As we pass the kitchen and arrive next to the bathroom door next to a room that mostly resembled a closet.  It was kind of dim and plain... So, if you don't want to eat in a closet next to the bathroom, then wait a little longer to sit in the front. Fortunately for us, a few minutes later the waiter asked to move us to the front of the restaurant because of a bigger group requiring that room.  

The bulgogi was good; not the best, but good.  However, I really enjoyed the sides that came with the meal.  Overall, I think I'd come here again.
author: Darren L.

description:
I really love their Kim Chi soup!!! Their food is good except I wish the customers could cook their meat like other Korean restaurants let you do. The first time I came here, my friends and I introduced me to Korean food for the first time. Their BBQ chicken and their BBQ spareribs were delicious! The second time, I took my friend here and he enjoyed the food and liked the kim chi soup as well but he wanted to cook the meat like I had mentioned above. 

I would definitely come back here...the food was a little pricey though for something that is prepared for you. The wait staff could've given my friend and I more tea or water to drink. He wasn't very attentive to us...maybe because they were already closed and my friend and I were still there?
author: V M.

description:
I moved to SF from LA and I've come to terms that this city lacks good Korean food, since LA has oodles of Korean BBQ joints near down town at such amazing prices. 

With that said, My Tofu House is a great supplement for such cravings of Soon Du Boo, Bulgogi, and Bibimbap. The weather's getting colder now that fall is in full blown... you've got to run down there to get some tofu soup. Those side dishes are really tasty. I always look forward to that fried mackerel they give you. Fill up on the sides, then stuff my extended left belly with the real main course. 

Soon Du Boo is good, the grill meats is mediocre, and my beloved Bibimbap for some reason is messing that crunchy later of sizzling rice at the bottom and thus I've got to deduct some points. I know I'm being critical, but that crispy rice is what sets it apart. Afterall, why would they throw the rice in that sizzling stoneware! 

Prices are decent, but the wait is so long sometimes! I'm been there about 8 times and on a Sunday when I'm hungry, waiting in line for an hour just gets me punching walls. (alright, more like ordering an extra meal) but what the hell. Girl's gotta eat!

3 3/4 stars
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
The wait was a little long, but I guess that's a good sign, isn't it?

Service was friendly and quick.

We ordered tofu soup and bulgogi, and inhaled every bit of it.

Parking is somewhat of a shore on a weekend night, but well worth it.
author: mj m.

description:
Came here with friends several times. Its a small, homey restaurant with really good food! Good environment for large and small groups. 

The few times I came here I didn't have to wait very long. Parking around the area is not so bad, but it is located next to a ghetto Jack-in-the-Box (the chain itself is not bad just the location). Anyhow, the selection of food and prices here are comparable to all the Korean places I have been to in San Francisco. They are known for their tofu soups though, so I recommending getting at least one of these. The bbq is also very good, but not anything exceptional. 

What I love most about this place is their little side dishes that come before the meal, you can keep asking them to refill them but I advise against doing it repeatedly unless you're leaving a big tip. You don't even have to order much food because these little dishes are so delicious and will probably fill you up. There is even a dish with a whole fried fish!
author: Jay L.

description:
I always come here to get my soondubu fix. If I go anywhere else, I'm usually sorely disappointed. The food is always great. You get a bunch of GOOD sides. I love the cucumber! 

The service is good. Not kiss your a$$ good, but get stuff done good, which is all I really want anyway. They're usually quiet with us because we're quiet people, but it seems when they have time, they're chummier. The only thing is, when it's busy, it takes a little longer to get the check, but I don't care, because everything else is always perfect.
author: M W.

description: It is incredibly hard to find good vegetarian Korean food.  This place has many options and they can make the sundubu without anchovy broth.  What I was also impressed by is that they made sure we were strict vegetarians and not just pescatarians.  It is definitely a popular place but worth the wait if you have a hankering for some tasty and wholesome Korean food.  Their service is fast and the food was delicious.  I had both the "Baked Tofu and Vegetable Bipimbap" (looooooove the crispy rice along the edges) and the "Vegetable Soft Tofu soup" (perfectly spiced and warmed me through-and-through).  Their Ban-chan wasn't universally amazing but still pretty good.
author: Kaman C.

description:
I've been twice and both times were last year, but it was definitely good! The few times i tried to come after, it was too late and they were already closing. I've gotta be sure to get there earlier, haha.

We got seated quickly; not too many customers around. I love the side dishes they bring you! Oh man, I could get full on just those. Both fish sides were lovely. I don't remember if they did or not...probably not, but the potato salad would be a good addition.

Good soup, good tofu, good bulgogi! I like how they bring out the giant stone pot of rice and serve it to you there and afterwards, you have a nice hot rice tea/water drink to top it off!

Certainly not a fun decor though. Really bland. Something interesting though is that all the workers in the front were male! At least both times I was there. I've never seen that before. Usually all the Korean restaurants I've been to have been staffed by the older Korean women. Not saying it's better or worse, just an interesting notice! Street parking sucks sometimes, but then again, it's Geary.
author: Tinothy M.

description:
Great service.

Awesome Kalbi, tender, well marinated, perfectly grilled.

Seafood pancake was incredible. 

Tofu stew, superb. 

Win.
author: Derrick L.

description:
I come to My Tofu House when I want to reminisce about my BCD tofu house days in LA.

The food is always good whenever I come.  I always get the standard tofu soup, medium spicy (because any hotter, you can't even the food, the spiciness and temperature of the food compound each other) with the kalbi.  I also love all the side dishes that come with it.  It's nice to know that when you clean them off, you can ask for more.  When they're done scooping our your rice, make sure they add water to the iron pot so that you can get the watery rice at the very end.

Service is actually pretty good, the wait staff's English is not so good, so it may come off as rude, but from my experiences, they always get you what you ask for, so no problems there for me.  Like some people mentioned, the wait on weekends can be long so week nights are better.  It also looks like they close relatively early so get in before about 9:30pm.

The only thing about this place is that it can be a bit expensive for tofu.  At BCD, there's a tofu/kalbi combo for less than $20.00 but My Tofu House doesn't offer a combo so it nears the $30.00 for both.

I always leave this place STUFFED...I'm craving it now.  Might just have to go tonight and then go again 3 days later when I'm in LA enjoying BCD.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Every since I had  soft tofu soup for the first time this summer (in a strip mall neighborhood in Portland) I had been craving it. And when I found the scores of glowing reviews for My Tofu House on Yelp! I was very, very excited.  

The free appetizers were really good, although I was afraid of the chewy little fish, but my husband ate them all.  And my tofu soup was all it was cracked up to be-I got the seafood version. I got it medium, and I think I might try it spicier next time...it was pretty mild for medium.  

We sat in the odd little bare room in the back, and at first I thought the lack of stimuli would drive me mad.  But after the food arrived I thought no more of it.
author: Linda J.

description:
The soup that I ordered here was "Kimchi Chige."  Compared to the "Kimchi Chige" that I have had in Boston, New York City, San Francisco, and Seoul, My Tofu House's version was by far the blandest that I have had.  

The soup was extremely light in taste as I could tell that they held off on the chili paste, one of the main ingredients in Korean food.

Revised 8.19.07
I must say that my first experience here was not great.  However, my send and third times have been awesome.  Now whenever I want some comfort/ soul food, I come to "My Tofu House."  For some reason my first experience here was quite "bland" but I guess that was an exception.  

It's "Kimchi Chigae" is tremendously tasty and the side dishes that they serve are also very fresh and scrumptious.  "My Tofu House" is a good house!
author: Alan T.

description:
The wait wasn't so bad but you have to put your name on a clipboard.  

Banchan:  You've got the cucumbers, bean sprouts, kimchee, anchovies, daikon and something else i think.  The place is busy so you got to flag them down if you want refills on the banchan.

I got the "Original Tofu Medium Spicy" soup.  I thought it was fairly hot compared to the tofu soup I normally get at "Korea House" in Santa Clara.

Overall, it was pretty good.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Since I don't have a car in SF and public transportation to the Richmond is A PAIN IN THE ASS to get too from where i live... I haven't had Korean food in a LOOOOONG time. 

so... i made my own.

People shouldn't be allowed to cook when they're piss drunk. 

I'm not sure how i didn't burn my apt building down, but I tried my best to cook soon du bu. In my sheer drunkenness, i thought i was the Top Chef or something and threw in anything into my red soup that seemed good. Let's just say... fish balls, ramen, and broccoli does not make a good soon du bu. 

Thank god for places like My Tofu House. 
It reminded me of a few things:
1. NO more drunken cooking
2. Compared to My Tofu House's soon du but, how did I eat that crap I made??
3. I'll leave cooking soon du bu for My Tofu House
4. Melon gum is so anti-climatic!
5. Metal bowls are hot.... but a metal spoon w/ HOT soon du bu will leave 3rd degree burns on your tongue. 

Great spicy seafood tofu soup. Loved the kimchi and side dishes. Kalbi was good, but not fabulous.
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
How yummy! I was here for the first time last night and had their bbq beef/veggie stonepot bimbimbop (or whatever it's called--what a mouthful) and it was super delicious. I tried a friend's tofu and it was silken beyond belief. The kimchee little dishes also flow to your table like water. 

But.....isn't Asian food supposed to be really cheap? My bowl was $14, which I'd say is pretty pricey for what it is. That's about double what I've paid for in the past.

All in all though, I left a satisfied customer.
author: serena l.

description:
LOVE IT!

This was my first kimchi experience, and I was quite happy.

I was a bit worried, cause it was a litle empty here...but I totally take back my doubts. This place...delicious!

Also on the menu, aside from kimchi, was soju...and man was that some knock ya down stuff. I mean, sure it's fine while you're sitting down. But get up...BAM!

Definitely check this place out. The staff here is uber friendly and sweet. And if you're like my friend Martin, it will be spicy regardless of if they say it is or not. It's....yeah...magical. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Korean food at it's best.

I have been to this whitey-friendly joint several times and it is always a pleasing experience. I've had the Seafood Soft Tofu soup and it is so delicious. I never thought I'd be woman enough to crack a raw egg into soup, but the bowl is boiling when the waiter brings it, so the egg cooks completely. The spare rib Bulgoki is also a really good choice.

Gotta have the kimchee to start the meal too, these marinated delicables are served free with your meal. You can't beat it!
author: Shannon B.

description:
