Hella good.  The first time I had this type of Korean food was in LA at BCD Tofu House, which sets the bar really high.  I've gotta say that My Tofu House is just as good.  Granted, I'm not Korean (I'm a Vietnamese Jew) so I haven't eaten enough Korean food to really distinguish where the best stuff is, but my Korean girlfriend loves My Tofu House (though I think she prefers BCD) and there's no way you're gonna find better tofu stew in the city.  The bbq offerings are good (not the best bbq but still pretty good) and compliment the stew nicely.  

Both times we've been were on Sunday mornings, before the after-church rush, so there was no line, but I'd definitely be willing to wait at least 30 mins for a meal this satisfying.
author: Joseph N.

description:
soup and meat... and salad.

seriously, get the salad. it's $3.94 and big.

soon do bu here is the speciality. if i were you i'd leave the kalbi and the bru gol gi alone and just focus on the soup.  at just under $10.00 you'll get plenty of food and variety considering you'll have plenty of pan chan (side dishes) and rice to go with your soup.

if  soup isn't your game, the rock bowl fried rice type deal dish is the way to go. bip in bap. ask for some red sauce and mix the heck out of it, you'll thank me afterwards.
author: Ameer N.

description:
If I could choose the taste in my mouth at the moment of my death, it would be the soft tofu soup from My Tofu House. I'm confident that they could just sell soup and still make a killing. What I'm trying to get across is that their soup is made of all things worth looking forward to in life. 

If that wasn't enough, their bbq is on fire. Both the kalbi and pork bulgogi are perfectly prepared and served steaming on a hot iron plate. Tastes great and opens your pores. While they don't serve a large variety of sides like other Korean places, the sides they do serve are plentiful and flavorful. The fried fish is particularly delightful. The only downside is that the dining area isn't particularly special (it's downright dull) and the way the booths are set up isn't very comfortable. The benches are set too far away from the tables and you end up having to lean forward way to much for comfort. But the staff is very nice and attentive and deliver prompt and friendly service.
author: Raymond P.

description:
I love this place so much my friends and I have made it our 'once-a-month-girls-nice-out' dinner venue. Yes we seriously come here once a month to satisfy our Korean spicy tofu cravings. I would come here more often but obviously all the salt, spice, and msg does a body no good.

I usually get the same thing every time: dumpling soft tofu, medium spicy. However, when i'm really hungry it's the chicken bibimbop. The bibimbop comes in such a huge bowl but i finish it every time. I even try to scrape every last piece of rice off the bowl because it's so good.

I'm not Korean and I have no idea if this is what good Korean food is but I love this place.
author: Terry D.

description:
This place starts out with some good apps, (free of course) 
Fried fish (mackarel maybe?)
Pickled Cucumbers
Sweet (i think) smelt
kimchee
radish kimchee
Sprouted bean beans

I ordered the soft tofu soup, medium spiciness. It wasnt very spicy, but it was very good. Service was ok, but you have to ask for water and it was warm. Also, if you ask for egg they put it in for you. If you don't, they bring it for you to crack yourself (much better).

I'm not sure I'd go back with all the other Korean restaurants in the city. However, There were some other things to try on the menu, so maybe I'm not giving it justice.
author: Jake R.

description:
I think this place is super amazing.

I went with some friends for the first time last week and ordered what they are known for: The Soft Tofu Soup. I got the original with medium spice. It was perfect for me and I loved cracking my own egg and watching it cook in the bowl of sizzling soup!

We also ordered the Daeji Bulgoki (broiled spciy pork) which, honestly, was some of the best pork i have EVER had...in my life (and I'm really being that dramatic! it was that good y'all).

What I particularly enjoyed was seeing that this place is where all the Koreans go. The place was packed with a line out the door the night that we were there. We got there just before the rush. I also enjoyed swooning over the cute Korean boys serving us! SO CUTE.

I'll definitely be back.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Tofu House's menu is really small with only Tofu soup, Bibimbabs, and three little dishes of Korean bbq and stuff. This place gets really busy sometimes and the place is kind of small.  The waiters do not pay attention to you at all... some don't even speak english..  Denny's has better service.  

If it was a really really really really cold day, then this place would probably be a good place to go.  Their food is steaming hot!  It took awhile for it to cool down.  Me and my gf had the Tofu soup thing with beef I think.  It was alright, but as I dig around some more it was almost all Tofu.  THere was hardly anything else in there.  I wish they more beef or something else in there. 

 I got the BBq Bibimbab and me, not being really familiar with Korean food, I thought the Korean BBQ was gonna be like actually BBQ meat, but it wasn't.  The Korean BBQ was small meat with lots of spicy stuff. I don't really like spicy stuff and the stuff I liked because I guess I'm not used to it.  When all the little stuff came with the Bibimbab like the egg, the fish, small sardines, and other stuff, I wasn't so thrilled.  

Overall, I thought the service was bad, the soup was too much tofu, I wasn't used to the Bibimbab, and yeah..
author: Gino B.

description:
Great at what they offer, and they always refill your panchan plates.  

3.5 rounded off.  Would have been a 4.5 but there was a hair in my tofu soup...only took 1 point off and not more because at least it was not a pubic hair.

Still, I think I'll take some time to forget before I go back again.
author: Mia G.

description:
Came here sometime a week ago with my brother, Edgar G. I have come here once in the past with Jenny K and another friend. I left feeling quite satisfied and thought about returning in the future. I was craving Korean food, so I came here with Edgar G. We ordered the seafood and vegetable bibimbop and I believe the short ribs or something like that. The food came promptly but for some reason the food didn't seem too appealing this time. Whatever the case, the bill was nearly $40 between the two of us. But I suppose Korean food is just that expensive? I don't know, I don't eat it enough to know whether this is the standard between two people. Oh well. I wasn't too happy. 

Don't get me wrong, you may like the food from here. You also get a couple of side dishes like kimchee, sardines, pickled radish, bean sprouts, etc and rice. Anyway, My Tofu House, I don't plan on coming back for a looooooooooong time.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
I like coming here for lunch. Their barbecue dishes are only $8 or $9, but double that during dinner :[ It's also way less busy during lunch, so the service is better. I just went for dinner a couple of hours ago, when it was pretty packed. The waiter forgot to pour the tea into the pot of rice. But I had soup (9 kinds, all $9.91 during both lunch and dinner), so I wasn't exactly anticipating eating more liquidy rice. 

Their levels of spice did not quite match my expectations. I ordered my soup in spicy (the highest level, above "medium," "mild," and "not spicy"), but it turned out to be tolerably spicy. I expected spice that would make me sweat and cry, but alas, the temperature of the soup was what got to me. 

That they kept offering to replenish our side dishes. :D But they only have small servings of galchi, kimchi, radish kimchi, and bean sprouts. Pretty standard banchan. 

It's located next to a Korean market, so you could pop by to get a refreshing beverage after all that spicy Korean food. =D
author: Anna Y.

description:
I go about once a month. College student, not much money. This place is a bit expensive for teenagers. I go before dinner time, where they charge more for certain portions of the menu. Where it'd be 9 dollars at lunch but 17 at dinner. 

But good food, always steaming hot, or sizzling. I like the Dumpling Soft Tofu or any of the bbq meats. 

Plus at the end of the meal you get melon flavored gum! Runs out of flavor fast though.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Interesting that the servers are all guys.  Good service and good food.  I love the many small dishes that come out before the meal.  I had the Fried Noodle Soft Tofu (Tofu boiled w/ ramen and vegetable) and Korean pancake with seafood, vegetable and beef or pork.  It was nice that you can crack a fresh egg yourself in your soup.  The pancake was nice and crisp but slightly too thick for my taste.  Looking forward to trying other stuff next visit.
author: she q.

description: Foods are ok, price appears to be on the higher side.
author: Michelle K.

description: Funky name for a good authentic korean place. Tofu stew equivalent to LA K-town. Probably the best one in the Bay area.
author: Duke T.

description: Most fellow yelpers are right about the tofu soups and kalbi short ribs being excellent. The soup is served in a clay bowl, so it stays boiling hot for a long time (I like my soups hot). The egg that comes with side dishes is meant for the soup. I had seen a lot of ppl wondering what to do with the egg. You need to crack the egg and put it in the boiling soup.  Kalbi ribs are perhaps the tastiest in San Francisco. They lie on a bed of sautéed, sizzling onion platter, so they smell so good when brought out to you. The side dishes are also wonderful. As far as I know, it is the only place in the Bay Area that gives out small yellow croaker fish as a side dish - free of charge. They don't take reservation, and the line can get pretty long during meal time. Service is speedy.
author: Mary L.

description: I love this place.  The bbq pork rib plate is especially good.  I especially coming here at lunch because the lunch special prices are unbeatable in this area for (good) Korean food.  I do wish they would get a liquor license as it would be great to have a cold beer when eating here!
author: Storm C.

description:
-i came w/ 6 friends on a Wednesday night at 8 pm. We had to wait until 9 to get seated. They even seated 5 parties that came after us first. They claimed that they were waiting for a bigger table to be done, so we could sit there (but two of the tables that they gave to parties of 3 and 4 were exactly the same size). Also, I don't mind sitting a little closely to my friends if at least I get to EAT.
-pancakes for $17?! Not worth it. It's not that good.. not as chewy and tasty as other places
-why do all their tofu dishes cost $10.09 (and all the bibimbops are one price and all the pancakes are a same diff. price)? Very interesting concept, when a vegetarian dish is the same price as a seafood dish...
-very limited number of side dishes, but they were decent
-I thought the dumplings and rice cakes in the tofu soup were the best part of the meal; the seafood one was okay.
-i like that there are varying levels of spiciness for the tofus
Overall, this place has good food, but there's not much that makes it stand out from other korean tofu places.
author: Jessica W.

description: This is the best place for spicy tofu soup. No one else makes it like they do. The broth is favored just right.Other places make spicy tofu soup too but they never get the favor and coloring right. When I want spicy, I want it to look spicy too. Not clear broth, tofu, and a few chilli peppers.  All you need is a bowl of rice and an order of the tofu soup. I usually try not to finish a entire bowl of rice when I go out to eat (save room for all the other good stuff) but for this tofu soup, I don't care to eat anything else. They don't have very many items on the menu but they don't need to. The soup is a must try or don't bother going here bc the wait is really long for a table.
author: Kim D.

description: let's say I have never tasted great Korean soup until I went to this place. Also the bulgogi had a satisfying amount which is pretty rare at most Korean restaurant in san francisco. Side dishes are to die for with the dumpling tofu soup i order. Definately coming back.
author: Diane D.

description:
the service was great when i went, i arrived early ten minutes and sat by myself waiting for my friend..the waiter did not seem to mind and was friendly.

once we were ready to order he was prompt, and always came back to refill our drinks, help us with the food (e.g. soup and rice filling)..it was not necessary but definitely appreciated.

the food was good, it wasn't as hot as i'd hope but maybe that was buying into the hype on my part. 

i would definitely recommend.
author: Whitne Y.

description:
This place always have great Kimuchi.

I assume they make own home made Kimuchi.
Even though I am not big fun of the Kimuchi, Somehow I always  over eat this place Kimuchi.

I know Kimuchi come with side dishes!!!

I almost go there for Kimchi and good looking Korean waiter.
Also often Korean male customer eat there is very good looking.

Is that something got to do with Korean Tofu or what??
author: Faith I.

description: My husband and I like to come here when we are craving Korean food. It's our staple for Korean tofu soup. Unless we find a better place with similar prices, we'll be going to My Tofu House for a long time.
author: Shirley D.

description: This place is so close to my house, I am amazed that I didn't come here before!? I ordered the kimchee tofu soup with pork which was delicious! The tofu was soft yet meaty and gave the soup a rich texture. And the many side dishes were just as great! The extra kimchee allowed me to make the soup spicier if I wanted. The pickled cucumber and picked bean sprouts had the sweet and sour taste that I love. And the pickled fried tiny fish was so chewy and flavorful, I just dumped it all over my rice and ate the whole thing! Everything was tasty, the staff was friendly, and the decor was simple. I highly recommend going here if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Had the much reviewed soon do boo and it lived up to expectations. Ordered it mild and it had plenty of flavor without being overwhelmed by the spiciness. Wasn't overly impressed with the little side dishes. There are other korean spots around the inner richmond with tastier and greater variety of side dishes. I also didn't understand the pouring of hot water into the rice bowl. It just makes the crispy rice soggy. Then what?

Could have used a few more servers too. Plenty long wait for a table and service after being seated.

Come for the food. But be prepared to be patient.
author: Randy K.

description:
I love this place. The only downside is the wait at times. It's funny how there are always a bunch of people waiting in the narrow strip at the entrance, looking over with jealousy at those with drops of soup on their chins and noses running from the hot food. Ok, it's only funny when I'm not the hungry one. Just kidding, I'm not a bitch.. To avoid the long wait during the main dinner hours, someone always goes in first to sign in on the clipboard while another person looks for parking. Don't be the sucker that parks first.  

The menu may be limited with the main sections of tofu soup, bibimbap, and meat, but it does it for me. I usually overdo it by ordering too much meat and not enough soup. With 3 people, the little bowl of tofu soup is dunzo quickly while the leftover meat is plentiful. I once ordered the least spicy tofu soup (level 1) for my family and it came out  a cloudy white color. Go a notch higher..it's not going to be spicy. The spicy pork is my favorite. It's so tender and flavorful on a bed of caramelized onions. The price of the meats start at $17. A bit on the steeper end, but eh, Korean food in general is a bit pricey and plus Tofu House's dishes are flavorful and with fairly generous portions. 

The service is good. The servers have this sense of urgency/rush as though they downed 5 cans of red bull while in the kitchen. They quickly take your order, refill your tea, and give you change from the bill. They try to get you your food quickly and get you out to accommodate the others waiting. It makes me anxious sometimes, but whatever, they're fast.
author: Regina L.

description: Good bulgogi (okay price) and seafood pancake (high price!), but outstanding tofu soup. Prices generally are reasonable for good Korean food, but I feel that they are definitely pushing the tofu soups which are half the price of anything else on the menu. Nonetheless, I like this place the best of all of the Korean restaurants in the city. It is pretty tasty. Warnings: the menu is short and sweet and there is no BS. You are going to eat tofu soup, pancake, or bulgogi, period. You will have a few side dishes that you can get refilled but nothing too fancy. You will sit at a plastic-y looking table with paper tablecloths and disposable chopsticks and eat a filling, spicy meal. The service is prompt when you make a request and that's it, period. No charming chit chat, no cutesy ethic dining experience, no personal touch. Just eat and be satisfied.
author: p v.

description: Amazing. I'm at work, so this will have to be short. Great side dishes, the best tofu soup ever, and a long line to prove that it (is!) worth the wait!
author: Michelle G.

description: I go here once a week now. Great veggie options including all tofu, or tofu and mushrooms, or tofu, mushrooms and veggies... you get the idea. Sometimes a short wait, but definitely worth it. The waiters easy on the eye (bonus!), and very helpful in explaining the menu options.
author: Douglas T.

description:
Went to try this place out earlier.  We got there about 6:30 and waited for about 30 mins for a table.  It was worth the wait.

My bf and I ordered our own soft tofu soup and decided to share a dish of spare ribs.  All three dishes were really good.  I was also surprised that the fried fish as part of the banchan (small side dishes that you usually get with Korean food) was really good and fairly large portion.  We were pretty stuffed and still have leftovers to take home.

I'd definitely go back if I happen to be in the area and was able to quickly find parking.
author: tina c.

description:
Ordered the combination tofu soup w/ chicken (mild) ~$10. I should've asked for medium because mild isn't even spicy at all. We were given condiment dishes, a stone pot of rice and tea. We had a party of 3 and yet we were only given 1 pot of rice. This customer only had a party of 1 and she had a pot of rice all to herself! Hm...

Also tried the seafood pancake ~$17. It's not worth it! The soy sauce dipping sauce they give you is realllyyy salty. I suggest pairing the pancake with the red pepper sauce; you can treat it like pizza!

Our waiter checked to see if everything was okay. (That was nice of him.) BUT he was making rounds of refilling tea and didn't even refill ours (we didn't flag him down or anything but it would've been better if he offerred!) Needless to say, our little cups of tea weren't refilled until we asked for our check.
author: Jay Z.

description: I happened to be in the area, i didn't know much about this place. And what a great find. I love this place. I was with my mom and she is very picky with her food. Even she liked it.
author: Alvina C.

description:
My Tofu House makes me happy.

The steaming bowls of various soups that come out in the stone bowls are filling, hot, and delicious.  You have your choice of making it as spicy or not spicy as you like.  Great comfort food.  I really like all the little appetizer dishes that come with it - the kimchee, the turnups, etc but especially the little fishes that are sweet and tart and vinegary.  My favorite.   They have a limited menu but it works in their favor since those dishes are so well done.

4 1/2 stars!
-----
8/10/06 - I visited again last week... this time the soup did not taste as good.  It was a bit bland, even with the spices.  I ordered my usual.  Not sure if it was a fluke, but it's been awhile since i last ate there.  Have to take away the 4.5 stars from above.  It's hoving just below a 4 right now.  Don't disappoint me, My Tofu House!
author: Animal K.

description:
Came here for dinner last night with five friends, and even though the wait was a bit long at around 30 minutes, it was well worth it. With six people, we ordered five dishes which proved to be more than enough and at less than $12/person, who can complain? 

Great food, reasonable prices, and oh... how i wish they would open one up in the Millbrae area...!
author: Naomi F.

description:
I love Korean food! Love love love it to death.

But unfortunately the Korean food I love to death is in LA.  Then comes the next question...If I have Korean food in the city where would I go?  

DEFINITELY MY TOFU HOUSE.  With its simple menu, ability to make me think I'm eating healthy, and the piping spicy goodness, I call My Tofu House my Sunday staple.  

Some quick advise: If you're standing in line...Don't forget to sign up on the clipboard on the wall.  Oh and WEAR dark clothes because the piping hot Soondubu always manages to splash little orange spices on my white clothes.  I don't mind...I always come back!
author: Christine W.

description:
Really delicious food. I'm no fan of tofu in most of its iterations (my ex and I used to joke that you slept on a tofu and ate futon because that's what it usually tastes like), but this was absolutely great.

We had soup with the soft tofu (house speciality) which was excellent and just enough heat to add some kick without burning your mouth off. We also had a bibimbap which was also delicious. 

Cheap and delicious...can't beat that.
author: Mike F.

description:
Judging from the accolades  hanging from the wall, you'd think you were in for something special.  There's a wait sometimes. Somebody obviously really likes this place.

It's not the atmosphere--which is somewhere in the Wal-mart school of interior design. It's not the food--we're fortunate to have many good Korean places right in the same neighborhood. 

Maybe they've got somebody great at PR to get them all those best-ofs hanging on the wall? 

Maybe I'm just not drinking the right kool-aid. Seems like a reasonable, serviceable type of place if you're in the neighborhood and in the mood for this type of thing.
author: Trevor S.

description:
Service was very fast. Once we ordered it felt like a less than 5 minute wait before it all came out piping hot!. The food was also very good, their mild is very mild while their medium is a little less than most medium. Just watch out, from what i could see it tends to get crowded (wait time may be anywhere from 10-15+ minutes.

Good if you're craving korean in inner richmond.
author: Dan N.

description:
YUM YUM YUM. Last night was ended with a full tummy and a smile.

This place really satisfied me. The bulgogi was yum (kinda expensive though for 17.97 I think) and the tofu soup is delish! We got the #1 tofu soup with beef, mild. I love the soup, it tastes so clean, fresh, and tasty!! Luckily we got there at a good time.. BEFORE the crowd came. Apparently this place gets pretty packed and there is usually a wait.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
If I feel too lazy to go to the tofu house on El Camino in San Bruno then I go here for the tofu soup and korean bbq meat.  Soup is good, meat is avg to good.

Its better at the other place, but the chicks seem to hang out here I guess.  =)  I don't like having to wait in the line and all the people in close quarters and being watched by line people but what can you do?

I like how to servers here scoop the rice in front of you here.

I can't go into detail about food here much cus its typical fare.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
we came here on a rainyyy friday afternoon for some lunch, and there was only one other group waiting...but we didn't see the sign in thing...so we waited longerr X__X its okk, we got good parking right outside.
the wait is a lil BLAh
but we were sat down and the dude was nice. busy hours and only two ppl working.crazy!
we ordered a combination tofu soup medium and the pork dish thing. that and rice and the side dishes made 2 people a gooood full. didnt smell toooo bbq-y when we left which is goood, and the tofu soup wass pretty good. bubbly and satisfying for a cold day!
would come again for the soup!
author: Christine M.

description:
i've dined at the tofu house on Friday, last week for lunch. My dining experience here was horrible. The food itself was okay for me. and i've been to this place many times before. but the service i received from that male server was terribly bad. First of all, I've have to order my coke twice to quench my thirst while they were not even busy, and it took them 20 mins to finally got my soft drink!!! Secondly, i was asked to shut off my iphone volume while i was playing after-meal game while there were no people were sitting around my table, so i saw no point to ridicule me on that. i am not sure if that is their korean culture that your not supposed to have any noises at all, that is like asking me not to talk and keep quiet like i was in a freaking library!!! This is America, man!!! i am a paying customer and i am not doing any thing obsenced!!!  i've felt greatly humiliated by that stupid male server for doing that to me. Because i didn't feel like i was treating right as a paying customer, so i've decided to not give them any tip for the service. The worst thing, is that they charged me a tip by overriding my signature on my credit card receipt. Now i have to call my bank to deny that falsifying charge.......stupid and illegal move!!! if u want a tip, treat your customers right.....What i want to say to u, Owners of tofu house, u underestimate what i can do as a customer to hurt your 
business such as writing tons of bad reviews on here and many more!!!  now u piss me off totally!!! watch out!! It is definitely not worth it to mess with me over a few dollars of tip that u eagerly falsified on my bill.  people, if u want to have korean food, go to Japan town. they have better service and honesty there. Now, i will never spend a cent at tofu house again, along with my family and friends.......!
author: Larry W.

description: Thank you very much for all of the reviews here. The tofu soup is excellent!!!!!!!!!!!! only 10$ with side dishes. good service. will go back for sure.
author: Suvida N.

description: I ordered seafood bi bim bap that was ok but not great either. The amount of the seafood was tiny compared to other restaurant bowls. I was a little disappointed. The tofu soup was bland. It's not that I have to have it again. I felt like I was sitting in my dad's hospital cafeteria. Same atmosphere! Maybe I had the wrong dish but I can't figure out why the line is always long. I won't go back.
author: MS K.

description:
Of all the Korean restaurants in San Francisco, hell, of all the Korean restaurants in my neighborhood, I was surprised I had never tried My Tofu House before in the almost 3 years I've lived in the Inner Richmond. Mainly because it's right across the street from my house.

I am half-Korean, so Kfood is like comfort food for me. The good thing about it is is it's a pretty consistant, usually the only quality variation is price. Lots of the main meat dishes are served family-style, so the portions can be both HUGE and expensive. MTH has half orders of all their meats, which we were delighted to see because it was both cheaper and we would have room to order some delicious hot tofu soup we love as well.

We got the Kalbi, or marinated grilled short ribs, and the spicy warming kim-chee soft tofu soup. The smells reminded me of my mother's kitchen when I was growing up. Mmmm... We devoured it all with perfect hot sticky rice, cold kim-chee and pickled seasame cucumbers and bean sprouts done perfectly. I was sososo satisfied by the meal, and so was my boyfriend, who is completely new to Korean cuisine but is starting to love it.

Also, my dachshund puppy is thrilled with us because we saved all the little marrow-rich short rib bones for him to knaw on. Happy puppy!

I think it would be beneficial to all 3 of us if we went there again! This is the type of place I'd bring my mom to.
author: Rosie B.

description: I'm a big fan of the tofu soup and find it the perfect antidote to my neighborhood's cold, foggy weather.  I try to come on weeknights on the early side when it's not too busy, and that strategy seems to work well.  Service is no-nonsense, but totally fine.
author: A W.

description: I like this place a lot especially on cold days. Love the Kim Chi Chi Gae and the Bul golgi. Really can't go wrong and the many side dishes I love. The only inconsistency is the Kim Chi side dish. It's either way too young to serve or just right. a hit and miss, if you will... The service is always great there and always love getting my seat across the way from the big screen.
author: graham c.

description: I am a FAN of this restaurant, especially for its tofu soups!! YUMMMM! Prefer to go for dinner but always needs to wait and can barely stay longer because servers tend to push you out in a way.That is why I take off one star. It is a better idea to go for lunch is you happen to work close by or don't mind driving or taking public transit to go there.
author: Lianna D.

description:
The place is a bit on the small size, since the restaurant is more of a semi wide hallway upon walking in, but who really cares? I would highly suggest getting there before 7 pm dinner rush on fri and wkends, and albeit, I did wait as long as about 40 min before, it was definitely worth it! 
The tofu soup is one of the best that I've ever tried. I always go for spicy, since it adds a kick, and the bowl they serve you is more than enough. Especially with the little side dishes and the bowl or two of rice to go with it. The staff serves you in a very team dedicated and efficient effort. I've never gone and received bad or poor service, even at their busiest times and that wins me over, hands down. I think my longest run going there was 7 wkends in a row. Only con is that the prices are a bit steep, especially for the meats when it is super thinly sliced. Oh, and I noticed that a lot of Asian restaurants, including this, serve ice water in little juice sized cups. I wish they'd upgrade to a regular 8oz glass soon. Eating spice food was hot tea isn't ideal for me. I think there was a time or two, I've had to ask for the pitcher of water, instead of running over to me for re-fills.
author: kim p.

description: I didn't get tofu here, but I might next time.  I got some kind of beef and veggie bibimbap and it was delicious.  Definitely enough to take home and eat later.  Service was great, but it was also between lunch and dinner and the place was nearly deserted.  The side dishes were all good.  I would definitely come back here.
author: k h.

description: This place is delicious! The kimchi soup rocks. Its best to go with someone else because you get a ton of food. I've been a few times and it never fails to rock my world!
author: Tim A.

description: If you like Korean food, try the Bibimbap or the Soft Tofu Soup.
author: Matthew B.

description: I don't know where else I could get lunch for 2 people under $15 and be stuffed. Parking sucks, but it's well worth it!
author: Heidi T.

description: I wasn't craving korean food but my friend was so we went anyway. didn't like or dislike it, it just taste like korean food. =( maybe i'll try again when i'm in the mood for korean..
author: Tiff W.

description: 666 Reviews?  Let's change that, shall we?  I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place.  I've been coming here for years!  Bomb ass soon doo boo, and bomb ass bulgogi.  I love this place.  I came here often when I lived a few blocks away.  I still venture out to this place whenever I've craving bomb ass korean food.
author: Casey F.

description: Great tofu soup and all the fixin's.  Very affordable.  Easily accessible location.  Friendly attentive service and employees all seem very supportive of each other and genuinely happy here.  Booths and tables and tv if you want to watch games.
author: Dizzy L.

description:
I stumbled in one night while looking for a new place to eat and was thorougly impressed.  I am now a fan of tofu stew.  Looking forward to my next tofu stew fix.  

I hear there's a place on Taraval that's even better.
author: Jon P.

description:
It is my Tofu House! For a while, I had to go there every week for a dose of spicy sundubu. 

I also recommend a visit if you are getting a cold - or just getting over one!
author: Michelle C.

description:
How can anyone complain that $12 is too much to pay for a meal this generous and tasty? I had lunch here a couple of days ago and wasn't hungry again until the next morning. 

First came an array of appetizers: spicy cabbage kim chee, some kind of pickled turnip-like vegetable in a hot tomato sauce, pickled bean sprouts, cucumbers in rice vinegar, something else I couldn't identify, a little dish of tiny salty dried fish in oil, and a small metal bowl of chicken broth with bits of meat and cubes of soft tofu bobbing in it. I could make a meal out of this stuff alone. 

And then came the bibimbap, spicy and sizzling and served up in a hot stone bowl like it should be. The rice at the bottom turned into a crispy crust just the way it oughtta. I couldn't finish the whole order, and believe me, I tried.

I haven't tried the tofu stew yet, but if the bowls I saw being served up at other tables were any indication, that won't leave me hungry either. Need to go back and test this theory.


Updated 3/18 to note two things:
1. I have now tried the soondubu and DAMN, it's amazing. The ultimate spicy comfort food. I could eat it twice a week. In fact, this week I just might.
2. The menu changed in the last month or two. Boo: prices went up a little bit. YAY: more varieties of soondubu!
author: Fawn F.

description:
K says: Probably our favorite place to get soon doobu chige (spicy tofu stew). Very tasty, reasonably priced. This is a no frills sort of restaurant - they don't even have a liquor license! But we still enjoy getting good korean food here, and it is a nice alternative to Brothers if you don't feel like smelling like BBQ after eating.

J says: I love the soon doobu here, reminds me of the kind I used to get in K-town in New York.  The bibimbap is not bad either.  I hear there are better tofu places down south (sunnyvale) but in the city, this is the only place I know.  I saw another tofu house with a "coming soon" sign in Japantown recently, hopefully that one will be good since parking will be easier.
author: Jen Ken H.

description:
A good meal for the cold SF evenings. Tofu soup is tasty as are the little appetizer dishes, plus if you want more little foods they are more than happy to provide. However, this is only if you can catch the waiter's attention. They really do need to add some more staff to the place. Sometimes, part of the wait for a table is the fact that the guy just hasn't found the time to clear the dirty tables or bring people their checks/change.

Additionally, the last time I was there, the health inspection form was posted, 100/100, not too shabby. Although, I did see some grossness that night, however this was from another customer. This woman pulled a Walgreens bag from her purse and packed her leftovers in it. No box or container for the food, just dropped it in the shopping bag. A different approach to packing leftovers, although going back to the lack of wait staff, maybe she figured it'd just be faster to bring her own doggy bag.
author: n m.

description:
Soup person?  Good.  
There are many other places for me to go for other types of Korean food if I don' make it myself.  This place is great for all the Tofu soups -
author: Jubei K.

description:
Tofu house serves very authentic Korean cuisine. It's a little bit pricey for my blood, but I just can't resist a good pot off Kimchi soup and spicy pork.

My only warning is that you will have a very difficult time finding parking. Especially during the weekend. If you're gutsy you can always park in the Jack in the Box parking lot next door at the risk of being towed.

Parking aside, this restaraunt is the perfect place to take a group of friends out to eat. It has a very friendly (albeit plain) atmosphere.
author: Stephan K.

description:
I love tofu and when I was told by a fellow Korean this was the best place yet, I had to disagree. The service was outstanding, no doubt about that. One thing I was expecting was a lot of different dishes of random pickled veggies etc. that I was used to getting at Todam Tofu House in San Bruno. When we got the dishes there was only about seven compared to the fifteen or so at Todam. Also the amount of rice that you got was very small compared to the nice large dish you received at Todam.
I think I will stick with Todam Tofu House in San Bruno because it is also two dollars cheaper than what I had paid here.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
Hmm was a very tough choice here in giving either 3 or 4 stars but I think they did enough things right to where I would return voluntarily.

Honestly, banchan was lackluster. The first serving of kaktugi was BITTER. They need to brine that a bit longer methinks or pick up some younger daikon. Mehlchi was soaked in sesame oil and there wasn't that much variety. But they give plates of broiled yellow croaker and that's always a winner.

Soon dubu was solid. My socks were not knocked off, but they are in general on pretty tight. I got the seafood one and unfortunately they overcooked the oysters. Shrimp was pretty close too. But the broth was fairly rich and had decent body. I got the spicy but it barely stung the tongue. Do they think me a pansy lady-boy? 

I enjoyed their rice though that comes out in a stone pot and you can self-serve instead of having to wait for them to get you another container. Yay!

Conclusion: I wouldn't call MY tofu house, but it's a house and they serve tofu. Good enough.
author: Daniel K.

description:
This is by far the best Korean in SF. My fiance and I are HUGE fans of the soft tofu soup .. the BBQ short ribs will have you curling your toes under the table :-)

lots of Deeeelicious FREE sides which they refill over and over again..

I would have given them 5 stars, but they don't serve beer (or soju, or any boozy bev.).. a nice cold Korean beer mmmm
author: Colleen G.

description:
I love the little plates!!! You just can't get enough Kim chee... The food here is pretty good. Order an entree and enjoy endless little plates. The meats are tasty and the tofu soups are to die for...

Come by yourself or with a large group and share multiple dishes. My only beef with Korean restaurants is why do they give you hot metal spoons for sizzling hot soups??? I guess it toughens the lips and tounge... If the spiciness does not get to you, you will sear the oral passages...

A must try!!! OH!!!  Watch out for the little bones in the free fish... The little tiny ones can getr stuck in the back molars... Nothing like sucking on one a few hours after your meal...
author: robert C.

description:
I love this place! 
It serves the best tofu soup in the city. Recently they raised the price, but
it's still worth it.
Once you are seated, you get a bunch of small dishes. My favorite is this 
deep fried fish which tastes so good.
Tofu soup is served boiling hot. Ahhh, I'm now craving for it again!
Another must item is their Galbee. It's so juicy and tender.
It's over $20 and you may think it's rather expensive, but you really have to try it.
You are never disappointed here.
The only negative thing about this place is that they do not serve alcohol.
Their Galbee and tofu soup go so well with ice cold beer!!
author: Daniel A.

description: i think its great that we get free tea and a lot of side dishes.. the service is not good though.  the food was good but waaay too spicy for me.  maybe i can tell them to not make it spicy next time?  i don't know.... but i wont come back.
author: R F.

description: Meaty kalbi cuts and succulent bulgogi is what has me coming back to this place.  You get the typical side dishes and the service is decent.   The rice is hot and well textured.  The seafood tofu is full-bodied and abundant with the good stuff. Overall, the quality of this place is pretty good compared to others in the city.
author: MTBer I.

description: I LOVEEEE tofu house whenever I have the cravings for korean food. My boyfriend and I always get a tofu stew with some kind of bbq dish...and the meal really hits the spot on a chilly day in sf. I like it better in the afternoon, when there's no line and the prices are marked down a bit.
author: Hubert H.

description: Boy the tofu soup is good. Great Korean food all around. The service is good, very down to earth. They are friendly, easy going, and very easy to work with. Terrific restaurant all around.
author: Alex L.

description:
This is one of my favorite tofu houses in the bay area.  I don't eat Mushrooms and its one of the few places that don't have mushrooms in the tofu soupbase.  

I love the fried fish they bring out, and they have always been glad to bring me more.  

I always order extra spicy cause they get alot of American (and yes I mean white) people in so their ratings are on the American standard so if you like spicey food, go with hot or extra hot.  Medium to us spicy food lovers is like mild to normal people.

They have a dumpling soft tofu which has gyoza AND mochi in it.  AND I LOVE MOCHI!! Its reasonable pricing.

And to the person who complained and gave it 2 stars because of the plan decorations and not being greeted....... WOW you need to think less of yourself.  Its not a 5 star restaurant or even remotely fine dining.  You go there for the food not the ambiance.  There BBQ is fine, but don't go there for that, the tofu is where its at.  If you didn't order it spicy enough thats your own fault, you probably would have asked for the power or the paste they use to spice it up so you can finish.  I always come away satisfied and sleepy.  And I've also had soft tofu in Korea and Japan and each place is different and their levels of spicy are arbitrary.  If I paid 20 bucks for the little bowl, i'd be upset, but for the price its just right.
author: M. S.

description: Probably the best soondubu I have had in SF.  I would recommend the dumpling soondubu since it was delicious (but then again the others were just as good) as well as indulging yourself in all the side dishes.  The venue is a decent size and the staff was very attentive to me which was definitely a plus.
author: Richard L.

description: I've never had to wait very long of all the times I came here. But the service is just so-so. We had the backroom for my friend's birthday, and they totally just ignored us after taking our order. Nobody came in to refill our water or tea, or to check on us. My friend had to leave the room and flag a waiter down. The bbq meats are always too dry, and quite expensive. The bibimbap is good, but not better than other places. The only thing worth coming for is the tofu soup.
author: Christina X.

description:
Competent tofu house and perfect for thawing out from the cold.
Make mine a combo.
author: Charles C.

description:
When it's foggy and cold and my bones are chilled, this is the place I run to. I love the bi bim bap. The crispy rice at the bottom of the sizzling stone bowl is heaven. Plus, you get refills on the banchan (little sides). 
As others have noted, make sure you sign up on the clipboard at the end of the entrance walkway - otherwise you'll never get a seat. 
The Korean grocer next door is a great place to shop for hard to find items while you wait.
author: laila p.

description:
I'm going to rank this as a fiver until I find something to knock it off of my list for favorite tofu house in town. 
The atmosphere is friendly and the restaurant is comfortable and clean with booths big enough to sleep in. The menu is quite typical, but the flavors of the hot soups we ordered were delicate enough to have a range of colors, but hearty enough to seriously satisfy. 
The tea that came with the meal was soft and yummy as was the gum at the end.

Yey for Tofu House!
author: Anjel O.

description:
You know, I really need to stop eating kimchi, or learn how to tolerate spicy food so the kimchi doesn't taste like burning.  Oh, but the burning is SO GOOD. 

I know how crowded it gets here on weekends, but being Tuesday night, my friend and I were seated immediately.  Not only that, we even switched from one of the the booths (dude, we were like sliding off the seats!) to another table in the back.  Yeah, we're difficult, it's true.  Between the two of us we split a kimchi tofu soup with beef and mushsrooms and a pork bibimbap, and with the entrees and the side dishes it was more than enough food.  The tofu soup was soooooooo good over the rice, it's pretty much Asian comfort food for me.  That was my first time trying the bibimbap and that's one of my new favorite dishes, especially the burnt rice on the bottom.  Num...  The whole dinner was only $25, not including tip.  

The best part is that I was able to satisfy my hankering for Korean food without feeling all sluggish and greasy from eating an obscene amount of bulgogi or galbi.  Mmmm...that does sound good though.

My only complaint was they brought us our food and just sorta left us.  They didn't check how our food was or even to refill the tea.  I could understand if it was a busy night, but it wasn't that hectic tonight.  That's really my only gripe, though.  Overall, I enjoyed my dinner and will definitely head back there when I crave me some Korean food.
author: Kelly C.

description:
After enjoying my first bowl of soondobu in Honolulu a few months back, I had to find it in SF. And I found a fantastic one at My Tofu House. What is soondobu, you ask? Why it's only a soft tofu soup served in a cast iron bowl. And it's so freakin' good. Not at all what you would expect when someone says tofu soup (I don't even really care for tofu). It has the consistency of a soft boiled egg (ironic because you also crack a raw one directly into the soup), swimming in a hot, spicy broth. Yum! The banchan served before the meal is pretty standard, but good. And the entrees themselves are equally tasty.

The restaurant itself is nothing special. Which is inconsequential when your face is buried in the food. 

Oh, and maybe most telling, I was the only white boy in the joint. Take that for what it's worth.
author: Billy L.

description:
I used to love this place.  I hadn't been for a while, and when I finally made it a point to go back last month it was a pretty disappointing dinner.  

It was a Friday night so the wait was about 45 mins.  The food smelled pretty good while we were waiting...just as I remembered.  I was pretty excited.  But when it came time to eat, the soondobu and bibimbap weren't that good.  

The soondobu wasn't spicy at all (and we asked for very spicy), and the bibimbap just tasted like sesame oil.  It was weirdly bland food.  Maybe it was an off night.  I'll have to come back here another time to give them another shot....but probably not anytime soon =(
author: chewy c.

description:
This restaurant can provide searing, delicious spiciness if you ask for it - "spicy" means spicy, not some wimpy tease of spiciness.

About half of the times that I've come here, the banchan was really authentic (i.e. pungent and potentially weird/scary-looking to non-Koreans). The other times, it was boring and okay. The waitstaff scanned the table every time they came to check on us and quickly refilled the empty banchan plates after asking us so perfunctorily that they really only asked as an informative courtesy, because it seems to be this restaurant 's policy to never let the customers go without a full assortment of banchan on the table. Some might think that this service is spookily attentive, but I am impressed.

The stews come out piping hot, and surprisingly quickly too. They look small but they are satisfying.

I also appreciate the very pretty female Korean waitstaff. ^_^
author: Steve K.

description:
Don't fight. It's MY tofu house, biatches! Back off. 

I LOVE LOVE LOVE MY tofu house. Never been disappointed. Consistently delicious and the rice clay pot is so freaking cute. The bean sprouts are awesome. The kalbi is the best in the city. Can't go wrong with the steamed tofu kimchi beef. I would totally hump this place if it were socially acceptable. But since we're like 2 years away from that, I just eat here every week. I love it.
author: anocha s.

description:
So many reviews makes me wonder if mine really matters but I'll give my two cents anyway.

I always get the seafood tofu soup super spicy cuz' it's only good if my mouth is on fire and nose is running.  Great under the weather food.  I love how the rice comes in stoneware.  The banchan is good.  Bibimbap not so great cuz' it was bland.  

BUT here are my gripes.  There is really a lack of choices.  Everything is overpriced.  And service is slow and lacking.  Our waiter forgot to pour tea into our stone rice bowl.  Actually he forgot to serve us tea at all. If he wasn't such a tall drink of water =-) I'd give this place 2 stars.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
3.5 stars.  The small dishes that precede the main course (bean sprouts, kimchee, fried fish, pickled cucumber, etc.) were wonderful.  They helped fill you up as the chicken tofu soup, although very tasty, has very little mushrooms, a handful of miniscule diced chicken pieces and the soft tofu is like water.  You have to fill up on rice and everything else.  Lunch is definitely a better deal as it is almost half the price with the same food and no line.  

Only one waiter there for almost 10 tables and he did a great job making sure tea cups were refilled and the food came out in time, etc.
author: Eleanor C.

description: The main plus for me was the affordable tofu dishes. A friend recommended the restaurant next door, "Wooden Charcoal," but the prices were outrageous and we left  immediately to this place. We beat the dinner line and were seated quickly with plenty of space (party of two on a six-person table). Great service. The Seafood Tofu and side dishes were good, but nothing uniquely special. Korean style always intrigues me; One male server had an afro and the other had an old man comb-over do'.
author: Agent G.

description: I don't typically eat Korean food, but this place hits the spot if you're craving a pot of hot tofu. I'd give this place 4 stars if it weren't for FiDi pricing. $17 seafood pancake, $20 bulgogi, seemed a little steep. I recommend adding ramen to tofu soup for $1.
author: B Y.

description:
I ate soft tofu soup several times and it became our favorite one.
Its taste is so good and its side dishes were tasty, too.
I ate soft tofu soup at many other restaurants, but I like it the best.
My wife likes it because it is not only tasty but also it does not have her headache. She is senstive to MSG. It looks this restaurant dose not use MSG.
author: Jung P.

description: Pricey, just a little bit, but worth it. I don't come here that often since it's usually pretty packed during the weekend. But it's definitely very yummy. Love their tofu soups and their meat dishes are pretty well portioned. Lots of side dishes with pretty good service a lot of the time. Frequent tea refills. o_O" Hahaha. But yes, worth the wait and worth the price. Lots of other dishes too, but who wouldn't want tofu when they come here? It's delicious.
author: Susan Y.

description: After a very very long day of driving and moving my sister into her new apartment, Korean tofu was exactly what I needed and I found it at My Tofu House. Thanks Wendy for picking tofu over buffet. Smart choice. Our tofu (and cal bi) came pretty quickly. The servers are extremely nice, but a little inattentive. I guess this might have to do with the fact that we were in a small room in the back of the restaurant (so I guess I'll forgive them this one time). The tofu soup did not disappoint, but I don't know if it was really worth the wait. Had it not been so chilly outside, I might  have walked to another restaurant nearby. I would stick to the tofu soup here, I wasn't a fan of the cal bi or the bbq pork. It was just kinda meh.
author: Rennie C.

description:
better korean than any korean spots around the 'burbs. (well.. not much in the 'burbs anyways!)

vegetable bibimbap is my BFF... i can totally have that everytime, everyday, forevereverever! 

ohhyababbiiiiiiiii. and the sides is YUMMMSIEZ! meow
please come with ME here.. pweaseee! anyone? lol
author: Marc K.

description:
I am sampling different spicy tofu soup from different Korean restaurants in the Bay Area. It's up there as one of the best.

The place is certainly busy, a good 10-15 minutes wait on a cold Sunday night. Quick turnover.

Not crazy about the small plates of kimchi served prior to the meal. Seems like the pickled vegetable have more salt added to the brine. There's a salty kick and after taste to it. -- not my preference... I am sure other prefer this.
author: Clement P.

description:
Their soondubu is awesome! One of the best soondubu I've ever had! 
I'm a semi-veg ( I eat fish&seafood, but no animals), so don't know about meat stuff they have, but thier veg/seafood bibimbaps are pretty awesome too!

I love this place.  I think Koreans should keep running thier own food business....What's the point to open fake Japanese restaurants in the city?  Korean food is already yummy, so stop going for fake Japanese food!  They should serve your own good stuff more.

Anyways, their soondubu is wonderful.  If you are a tofu lover, you must try it!
author: moshi m.

description: good prices, good food, there will be a wait but it is worth it.  The free dishes are very good and you can ask for refills if needed...
author: jason c.

description: A necessary stop every time I visit SF.  The spicy pork is phenomenal, and you really can't go wrong with the original hot tofu pot if you're feeling soupy.  All the sides are outstanding, but I always request extra of the pickled radish and kimchee.  There's usually a small wait, but well worth it!
author: Natalia G.

description:
Sometimes I dream of soondubu on a cold, winter day. But sometimes I dream of it on a nice sunny mid-60s afternoon in SF. I'll take $10 soondubu any day, rather than expensive K-town in NYC!

I played it safe with medium original chicken soondubu (white meat over beef b/c of heart burn issues!). My cousin got spicy and his soup was bloody as hell red. I'm courageous, but not THAT courageous! He was beggin' for mercy by the end of his meal.

I might add that the $10 bulgogi was a hit. Deliciously marinated, and deliciously cheap. Sh*t. This plate would be double the price in NYC... that's it... I'm moving to SF. 

Anyways... definitely satisfied with my meal, although all the tables around me were filled with dirty plates and patrons who left hours before! Clean yo' tables tofu house!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Started working through the 7x7 Big Eat's list again and just moved near this place so wanted to check it out. I love tofu soup and was really excited to check out their version of it. The inside of this place is actually pretty nice compared to the other Korean bbq joints in town with spacious booths. We were lucky enough to snag a booth and settled in. I ordered the tofu soup, the kalbi and the seafood pancake. The tofu soup was soooo good but BEWARE even the mild is SPICY. I made the mistake of ordering medium, my mouth was on fire for the rest of the night. Holy moly. The kalbi was quite good and the seafood pancake was nothing to write home about but I want to come back and try their tofu soup with fish egg. Mmmmmmm.
author: Cathy T.

description:
if you're going to come here, come for the tofu soup only!   it's really tasty and they have all kinds of different kinds.

as for the kalbi and bibimbap - stay away!!  the kalbi has always been to gristly and the bibimbap meat has a very very strong unusual flavor - way too sweet with lots of ginger.

the free sides are ok, they don't give you too many.  if you want good korean food, go to han il kwan on balboa instead!
author: Josie M.

description: I used to live 2 blocks from this place and it the was to go to spot on a cold SF day.   Of all the tofu joints ive tried I would say its the best in the bay area, even close to some LA spots.  I usually get the spicy beef soup, it really filling with rice and side dishes.  The prices are reasonable and the wait staff is friendly.
author: Mike K.

description: I'm still a fan, but I'm sad, too. Today was the first time I came to eat with only one other person. Instead of all the usual assortment of side dishes, they came out with...5, including the fish. I miss my side dishes. :(  Soup was good and today was the first time I actually finished the entire thing. (Probably because there weren't many side dishes for me to fill up on.)
author: ML N.

description:
They have the best korean kimchi soup in San Francisco. I've tried many different korean restaurant. and im going to say My Tofu House is the best. and the price is very reasonable. friendly service. 
but they dont take reservation. so if you wanna go, i say go between 6:30 and 7:00. cuz usually the place is packed and u'll have to wait for like 30 minutes. besides that, i definitely recommend this place.
author: Choco M.

description:
I love the soup!
It's so healthy and tasty. 
It is worth the wait. It's always really busy.
author: sarah m.

description:
Honestly, I don't "get" Korean Tofu soup.  No matter where I go I always end up enjoying the bibimbabs at Korean restaurants or envying anyone else who order them.

I ordered a mild mushroom soup, and thought it was good, but not something I want to keep paying 10 bucks for.  Perhaps as a Chinese guy, these soups are just too hot for me to savor and enjoy.  

Perhaps I'm just not Korean enough.  =*(
author: M K.

description: One of the best korean restaurants I've been. They add fish as one of the small dishes you get and that's pretty dang awesome. BEST BI BIM BOP I've ever had, made wonderfully delicious by the stone cast pot that cooks the rice to just the right crispyness. The sauces in it are amazing too. My boyfriend loves tofu so he ordered their soon dubu and he seemed to like it. My korean friend and his parents highly approve of this place too and I trust his tastebuds somewhat. I don't get the whole tea in the stone cast rice pot to eat after your meal but it's cool, it's like a second meal. The service could have been better but whenever I come here there's always only 2 poor guys working the entire joint. I like that they serve barley tea, which goes well with the meal.
author: Justine C.

description: Seriously.. this is not the taste of real Korean spicy tofu soup. I can taste the MSG
author: Mike H.

description: To me, these are below average Korean food: the seafood pancake is tasteless and the spicy pork and the soup dishes are not favorable--i've had better.
author: Candy T.

description: Love their variety ^ - ^ Where else can you get fish egg tofu soup, or ramen and vegetable tofu soup? I tried their dumpling and rice cake soondubu. It was tasty! Plus their side dishes come with a small fried fish for each person (we had 4 people). Price-wise, the tofu soups are $1-$2 pricier than at other joints. Am planning my return :)
author: sonia c.

description: Ok, decent place. Not over the top amazing but not particularly bad either. Ordered the pork bibimbap which was pretty tasty and was preceded by a nice selection of kim chi and, uniquely enough, a fried fish (trout I think). The fish itself was alright; it tasted kind of cold and not all that flavorful...also really bony so watch out when eating it. The bibimbap was alright; it was a little too heavy for me on the hot sauce and could have used some more meat but it was still decent. This place would have been 4 stars but considering my main course dish was close to $16 before tip and tax, I felt like the meal could have been better.
author: Luis M.

description: Good affordable food. Love the soft tofu and comes with a lot of mini appetizers!
author: Amy C.

description: Loved my tofu kimchee soup along with a side order of kalbi (naturally).  You get fewer side dishes than at other korean restaurants, but the whole sardine (?) was yummy.  I like the ambiance inside - clean interior and you don't come out smelling (too) bad.  I'd been looking for a default tofu soup place in SF, and I think I found one.
author: Melinda C.

description:
i came here on a cold rainy day with some of my girlfriends last week...

their soon dooboo is bomb. or mine was  ahaha =)
i got the combination extra spicy and it was delish~~~~ 

the server was nice and came back several times to ask if we wanted more side dishes and whatnot although he seemed pretty busy being the only one working =)

my friend said they raised their prices but i thought it was fine for what i got. good food and good company =) what more could i want
author: esther k.

description: Everything was pretty bland except for the fried fish banchan, I ordered the combination # 2 and I just found it lacking in flavor.  I was not happy to pay $10 for this entree. If it had been priced at $8 I would have probably given the place 3 stars. I also was not happy about being crammed into a booth with no air circulation so as I was eating I felt like I was going to faint. Meh.
author: Connie L.

description: This is by far my favorite Korean restaurant!  Their tofu stew/pot with ramen noodle is something everyone should try.  Heck, this stuff is soooo good it might as well be banned in all 50 states (j/k)!  I live in San Jose but am willing to make my journey to SF to eat this stuff....and that's gotta say a lot since the price of gas is enough to buy a round-trip ticket to Korea (ok...so I exaggerated just a little).
author: T. T.

description:
I came here once last year and it was not very good.
Then I came here again last month, and for some reason, the tofu soup was alot better. Did they change management or something?

In a city where good Korean food is lacking, this is one of the better options. But then again, I was spoiled living in Los Angeles where excellent Korean food was abundant. 
 
The bi bim bop was GOOD.
The tofu soup broth was pretty flavorful.
The bbq meat was just okay. A little fatty and too greasy for my liking.
author: Jean T.

description: Soondubu jigae is one of those great Korean comfort foods for the cold winter.  The soft, silky tofu is contrasted by the spicy broth.  As much as the selection of sides disappointed a little bit, this was high quality soondubu jigae that I've had.  It comes pretty close to my mother's home cooking, but hey nothing will ever come close to my mother's home cooking (besides my grandma's).  Overall, very reasonably priced for the Bay Area.  I wish I lived closer.
author: Koh K.

description: Food is great.  The BBQ has better flavor and is more tender then just about anyother korean bbq place in the city (especially Brothers).  The only problem is that the wait is usually long and they dont take reservations, and they dont serve alcohol (if they were byob, I would have given then five stars).
author: Jason M.

description: I used to LOVE this place but my latest visit here just wasn't as satisfactory it used to be. Maybe I didn't go at the right time or I wasn't really hungry when I did. The tofu soup was as good as ever but comparable to other Korean restaurants. I didn't touch the side dishes because they tasted bland. I may not be coming back :(
author: Regina L.

description: This place is great when I'm in the mood for something soupy and spicy.  The bbq is just alright, so I would recommend sticking with the soups.  Their little dishes are good too.  Even their white rice is good - but they give way too much and I always end up wasting most of it.
author: Eric C.

description: Came here on vacation and came upon this on a search engine. It was very packed upon arrival and when we finally had a seat, we were presented with normal fair Korean Food. It wasn't anything to brag about and although that might be the case, it wasn't horrible either. It's possible this is the best they have in San Fran.
author: Betty M.

description:
*burp* 

mmm, fish eggs and clams.

That's when you know you had a very good meal.... when you can still taste it while burping.  I can still taste the food because some of the essence is slightly regurgitated back the cardiac sphincter of my overly stuffed stomach.  The tofu soup with eggs and clam ("number seven" on the menu) is served hella hot in a hella hot stone/clay bowl.  You can opt to have it white (not sah-pye-cee), yellow (mild), orange-red (medium), and red (hella sah-pye-cee).  

I went here with Cindy and Bernadette tonight because we miss each other so much and we needed to catch up on boys and life.  The place was packed but we were seated within 15 minutes, so I was very pleased.  Granted this was the place which Cindy lost her Chinky card, Berna and I gave her a little shit for it... so she ordered her combo tofu soup yellow to appease us a little bit.  Bernadette got the OG tofu soup red.

There was a couple sitting across from me who kept smiling at me.  WOW!  This is probably what Ed feels like whenever his fans recognize him in public.  Could this girl possibly recognize me from my pictures on Yelp?  So I waved a little bit and smiled back...  But she didn't acknowledge me.... but kept smiling... and then laughing.   oh.  
TIP:  do not sit directly underneath the plasma tv while America's Funniest Videos are on.  
blah... I am feeling crunchy for waving and smiling back at a person who did not reciprocate the same feelings.  watch me retreat back to my shell of eternal despair....

(It's okay, grace, it's okay.... you are about to experience some bombass food.)  

The waiters performed efficiently and quickly... First they laid out the different pickled munchies--the cucumber, bean sprouts, kimchee, some other cubed stuff, the small anchovies, and broiled fish--then gave us some of that bombass tea that tastes like boiled corn water.  That held us over for a little while waiting for our soups and spicy marinated pork.  When our server came back with our rice, Cindy straight up busted "you're cute" while giving him a dreamy look.

dreamy look... meaning she was ripping his white shirt off with her eyes to expose his skinny Korean boh-day!!!

Berna and I were a bit shocked at this ballsy performance, so we were just quiet and at the edge of our seats.  The server blushed and said something... I forget, but Cindy tried to play that shit off by saying "Oh I didn't realize you actually spoke English".  He maintained his professionalism as he evenly portioned our steamed rice, which is also cooked in a stone clay pot and topped with garbanzo and green beans, in our individual metal bowls.  He promptly refilled our tea as well.

We broke raw eggs in our soup, which added more thickness and body to our soups, which were EXCELLENT.  

Our daeji bulgogi finally arrived in a sizzling plate, on top of onions.  Mmmm caramelized onions soaked in bulgogi marinade!   The pork was not drenched in sauce and grease (unlike the ones at Sorabol), which I really appreciated.

Our bill came out to be about $54, including tip... so not bad, right!?
($54 divided by 3 equals $18 each!)

The menu is straightforward:  various tofu soups, bulgogi, bibimbap, and drinks.  I heard the wait here is usually long so get here early and put your name on the list to secure seating.  If the wait is that long, try to ward off temptation from buying curly fries from Jack In The Box next door... You will get the tasty burps from being THAT full at My Tofu House.

*burp*
author: Grace M.

description: Not a bad place but on the pricier side for what your getting.  Portions were not overly small or large but thought I would be more.  Service was fast and attentive.
author: Johnson W.

description:
on any given sunday night, especially the chilly ones that have now come to sf, i love to go to this place for a bowl of tofu soup that always manages to hit the spot and comes with a healthy sampling of korean appetizers. 

the only down-side is that there's always half-an-hour wait worth of people who have the same idea so either go early (at around 5ish?) or be prepared to wait (but it's totally worth it!).
author: wendy q.

description:
The perfect place to go when you have a head cold.  This place will open you right up but beware of the spice.  I never go more than MEDIUM to prevent curling up into a ball later. 

The joint:  Small joint with a back room.  It's clean and cozy.  This place is pretty much packed Thursday-Sat nights for dinner.  They do not take reservations so you should try to go early or for lunch.  

The food:  Hot, spicy and fulfilling. The tofu soup is the bes that I've had.  My favorite is the seafood soup.  It's got oysters, clams, shrimp and topped off a raw egg.  Sweet flavors of the sea with a kick of spice.  At about $10 a hot steaming bowl of tofu, you can't go wrong with the other tofu soups either.  I've had the mushroom and the kimchi soup as well.  It's all very good.  They also offer hot plates of korean bbq pork, beef and chicken.  It's not the best in the city and kinda expensive.  They have rice dishes as well like bibimbab but I ALWAYS get the tofu soup and from time to time we splurg for the kalbi.  This very limited menu all comes with a variety of small dishes (kimchi, bean sprouts, spinach, spicy dikon, tiny fish and fried fish (yummy but LOTS of bones) amongst other things).  The meal will also come with a stone container with rice.  They scoop out the rice for you and fill the stone container with tea so that you can have the burnt rice later.  So, good!  Only down side, you won't find any seafood pancakes or other korean dishes here.       

The service:  Young korean waiters and waitresses who pretty much ignore you if it's busy.
author: Marie L.

description: When I have mad cravings for Korean food, I have cravings for this. Soon toobu is hot and spicy. Panchan is limited but tasty. Service can be slow at times, but it's ok by me. Rice in a stone bowl and I love the peas. I feel a craving coming on now...I may have to go here for dinner over the weekend...mmmmm....
author: Caroline C.

description:
it was okay.  my party of 5 waited only 5 minutes for a table (at 7pm on a friday night) but 20 minutes later like 50 people showed up so this place can get really packed and the wait is just ridiculous.  the place is really small so it was uncomfortable watching ppl waiting for a table to give me that "bitch eat a little faster" look... 

i ordered the rice cake and dumping soup in mild.. and the tiny little portion (for $10) came in super spicy and hot as f*ck.  i can tell despite it all that it has some real potential of greatness in it though... the sides it came with was unimpressive and not very tasty.  

overall, kinda overpriced for okay korean food... if i come back... its only because i've forgotten i already ate here...
author: Tina L.

description:
Mi tofu casa es tu tofu casa....The waiters and waitresses here are friendly and eager to serve, and they get creative, unlike some other places...cough Oyaji cough.   They turned their storage/break room into more seating for customers.  It's plain as hell in that back room and not as pleasant as the booths, but shorter waits for impatient people like me.  Be prepared to wait if you come at peak times, however the line moves quickly.

I went with a friend of mine, and we ended up sharing my personal favorite, the boiling original spicy soft tofu soup with chicken, and some steaming hot bibimbop.  Bibimbop is basically hot rice mixed with vegetables and meat of your choice; we got it with beef.  With all this we were also given sides including cucumbers, bean sprouts, a fish, baby sardines, and of course kimchi.  The soup is super hot and will burn your tongue.  Munch on the sides and let your soup cool down.  The rice at the bottom of the Bibimbop is slightly burnt for that crispy taste.    They bring out the food super fast.  And they check up quite often making sure you have enough water, tea, kimchi, sardines and anything else you might need.  The tofu soup was excellent; the bibimbop and ribs are good but not spectacular.  Also when they say spicy, they mean business.  The sides are better than most other Korean places.  All this for two people for 30 bucks including tip.  And bring a jacket because its freezing cold when you walk out.  If you're still hungry or seeking dessert, there is a jack in the box next door.
author: Summit S.

description:
had dinner here last night... best korean joint in the city! their side dishes are yummy. this is where i tried my first korean "pancake," and it was good.

the only thing that sucks about this place is that they are a bit slow with service. they are understaffed, but given the economy, it's understandable.
author: Marisol T.

description: Some people consider fried chicken as soul food, others macaroni and cheese, still others pb&j sandwiches... tofu soup at Tofu House is my soul food. It always manages to creep into my heart and draw a smiley face on it =) I love their mini side dishes that they serve up before the main course, kind of like Korean tapas. YUM!
author: Melissa Y.

description: I live across the street, (don't stalk me now.. JK!) so I come here when I crave Korean but don't feel like driving. I love there Bi Bim Bob here. It's filled with beef and really filling. Their bulgogi, grilled beef and kalbi, beef short rib are also something to order.
author: Juliane N.

description: GREAT place for a weekday lunch since their meats are 1/2 off plus hardly have to wait!  Seafood Tofu soup is just great- esp if you order SPICY!  Last time I ordered mild, regretted it- didnt taste as flavorful!  Bim Bi Bop's are great too!   Their pancake is $18!  I think I've had better at Toyose's!
author: Tessa M.

description: One of the better experiences I've had! I ordered the dimpling tofu soup and it was just incredible. The soup was delicious and I really live the Korean side dishes. Highly recommend this place and will bring my friends for sure!
author: Alexander M.

description: OK...so you know you're going into a good restaurant if there's a long line...that's a given, but you never really know until you actually sit down, order, and actually eat the food. The great thing about it is that the long line justified the quality and taste of the food. I ordered the fish eggs tofu soup, which was quite delicious. I ordered it medium spice, although it really was only mild-tasting. Either My Tofu House has a different definition of spice levels or I've already burned out most of my taste buds. The side dishes were also excellent: anchovies, cucumbers, bean sprouts, and fried mackeral! If you're looking for some great tofu soup on a cold day in the Richmond district, this is the place to be at! Highly recommended!
author: Stanley C.

description: I've been here a couple times now and the food here is pretty good.  My tofu was piping hot!!!  We came late at night and they still welcomed us.  They didn't push us to leave which was cool.  I don't think there are many Korean tofu options in the city, but this is one my friends always take me to.
author: Tom C.

description:
I love My Tofu House. It's a great Korean restaurant. I usually go with a bunch of friends and if you make a reservation for a big group (usually there is about 10 of us), you can get the room in the back. 

The side dishes are good and the soups are great on cold San Francisco days. The service is pretty good too. I haven't had a bad experience there yet.
author: Michelle K.

description:
general consensus is right. this is the best soon dooboo joint in sf. i actually really like it. damn great hangover medicine. 

first time i went, i was with a buddy.

buddy: hey wtf they gots no soju or beer.

me: shut the f*6% up. a korean joint with no booze? what the f&6* kind of people would eat soon dooboo without the soj?

looks around, sees more straight arrow folks, most glaring at me for the f bombs in the middle of the day.

buddy : hey lets eat our shit and get the f&ck out before they lynch us.
author: Euge L.

description: Of the few Korean places I've been to in the city this is by far my favorite.  The kimchi is awesome and pretty much bottomless, as are the other little side dishes they bring to your table.  The noodle soups are served boiling hot and you get to crack your own egg into the bowl and watch it cook.  Hell of delicious.
author: Victoria G.

description: ok.. the Tofu soup.. is freaking good.. Trust me Im a korean.. but if you go in a little more east from this place.. there is a place called HAn Il Kwan.. ok.. that place is freaking cheaper and better.. but this place is wonderful too.. lol
author: Sean P.

description: The sizzling soft tofu soups here are great, I've tried the vegetable & tofu, the combination with clams shrimp and beef, but my favorite is the BBQ pork with kimchi. You also get the spread of condiments to adorn your soup as you wish (fried fish, eggs, kimchi, etc.). I haven't tried the Bipimbap yet, but plan to soon. Last night we actually drank the tea they pour into the rice stone pot; it's really good and is apparently good for digestion.
author: Alex D.

description: I had their seafood tofu soup and i thought it tasted okay. They must have added too much MSG or something that made me have stomach ache all night long. Service was attentive.  Place looks  little run down.
author: Kristy K.

description: OMG.....where do I begin.  I LOVE....LOVE....LOVE....this place.  My all time favorite is the tofu dumpling soup and the seafood pancake.  The tofu dumpling soup is a must order.  I can have the whole thing all by myself.  I've been to many different places and by far this place bets all.  It can get really crowded, but it's worth the wait.  You have to try it.  YUMMY....
author: Wendy H.

description: OK, I've made my feelings about tofu (kryptonite!) quite clear so what am I doing patronizing a place called My Tofu House? Eating beef! Pretty good beef too. Mmmm....bulkogi, a big sizzling platter of tender well-seasoned beef plus a great assortment of Korean mezes including a whole small fried fish, On another visit I had the Bi Bim Bap which I didn't enjoy as much. Actually my second visit cost them a star. The first time I went there the service was very friendly and attentive. The second time I went the restaurant wasn't as crowded or as busy as the first but the service was much worse, I felt like they were avoiding me. I will go back, however, I do like their beef.
author: Philip G.

description:
i came here when it first opened
and have come back several times since then..

the food is pretty consistent..
and i love how a grilled fish comes out as one of the sides :)
i also love how you crack in your egg when you steaming piping hot stew comes out..
