soon doobo... how i love thee
author: monica c.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night an hour before closing and had a short 5 min wait. This place is very spacious and even had a huge flat screen TV with Sportscenter while I waited. The tables are very spacious which I liked. 

The only Korean food I have eaten is in Koreatown in Los Angeles so I have high standards. We ordered the spare ribs and the pork tofu soup. Both were very good and would do well in Koreatown. Not the best but definitely good. The only downside is the price. Korean food is usually expensive but this is a bit on the high side and that's why I couldn't give it 5 stars. Will be back in the future though.
author: Eddie L.

description: Being Korean, I know the difference between good and bad korean food. I have been coming to my tofu house for over 4 years. I was introduced by my parents when they decided to have dinner. i always get the same thing: the kimchee soonduboo with mushrooms and fish egg. SO GOOD. The side dishes are great, love the fried fish and cucumbers. The kimchi sidedish is not that great, usually bitter and probably not riped enough. Other than that, the soup is good for cold, and rainy days. Almost everytime I come here, I have to wait, haha. Which means its a busy place, and great business. The servers are very attentive to customers' needs. They also accept credit card, which is a plus. I know probably most think its a little over priced, but you pay for what you eat. If you want cheap food, go somewhere else. I think its pretty reasonable. Plus korean food is pricey in general, and its because the dishes require a lot of ingredients and time. They also give you refills on the side dishes with no additional charge. Oh and I love their kalbi, it comes on a sizzling platter with lots and lots of onions!
author: Colette P.

description:
maybe its just cause its busy Im not sure...but they seem to have cut down in portions, they are not as attentive as before...

other than that the food is still good..but just seems less than usual.

I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and come back again to see if they can redeem themselves.. -___-
author: phillip w.

description: I had the dumpling soon dobu and it was yummy. It also had bits of rice cake in it. You can order your tofu stew with your choice of spiciness. I believe I ordered it mild. The meal came with ban chan (those little side dishes) of course, along with a fried fish! Not very many Korean places serve this fried fish. I've only had it at one other Korean place in Japantown. I like the fried fish. My friends also liked their meals, one of them ordered the bibimbap and it looked and smelled good.
author: Helena H.

description:
It is possible to have soondooboo that is pretty good outside of LA.  As in BCD Tofu House in LA, My Tofu House gives each patron a whole fried chamjogi fish.  The sidedishes are plentiful, but mediocre over all.  

The soondooboo, however, is very very good.  Even though I ordered the kimchi beef soondooboo medium spicy and received the kimchi mushroom soondooboo medium spicy, I did not mind at all.  The spiciness of the soup was perfect: not too hot, and it hit the spot just right.  Moreover, the ratio of soup to tofu and other solids was perfect for someone who likes soup but doesn't want the soup to be barren.  The tofu itself was very silky and fresh.  Overall, I think the soondooboo itself is better than at BCD Tofu House in LA, but because the sidedishes were lacking a tad, I give My Tofu House 4 stars, instead of 5.
author: Helen K.

description: For SF standards(I've been constantly let down by the K-food in SF), the best Tofu Stew you can get.  I used to order take out a couple times a week for a while...  I would've given the tofu house 5 stars except they raised their prices.  It just doesn't taste the same...  Always get the spicy pork with your tofu stew.
author: Mike K.

description: That place is one of best rating in the San Francisco, The food is very good, i love their tofu soup, come with a lot of side dishes for free, but if you go dinner, usually take more than 30 mins to wait. Good Korea restaurant. About $12-20 person for dinner
author: Tim T.

description: Soon doo boo is my favorite Korean food, and this place confirms that for me each time.  Line gets pretty long during peak dinner times, so we've learned to go a little early (6ish) or during lunch to beat the rush.  Consistently good service.  Nice spread of pan chan (little appetizer plates).  Hits the spot on cooler SF days.
author: Squeaks L.

description: Ooooooooh yeah.....cold, foggy day in the Inner Richmond (which is almost always)??  Go to My Tofu House for sure!!!  Tofu soups around $10 (favorite = dumpling tofu).  Bulgogi around $15 (it's a big portion)...Kalbi is around $17 I think.   And bim bim baps cost about $12ish....So, it's reasonably priced for Korean food....and definitely worth it for some good food that warms the soul.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: Just didn't think it was all that good.  The service was slow although friendly, and the atmosphere was pretty quiet, but something seemed to be missing.  I did really enjoy the barley tea and subsequently went and bought a whole bunch of it. So I thank them for that.
author: Sven S.

description:
Best Tofu Soup Ever!

Ok, if I wrote this review a few months ago, I would've given it 5 stars. This is by no means a knock on their food, just an overall viewpoint. 

First off the food. There are numerous Korean restaurants in San Fran, but this is my favorite. With "Tofu" in it's name, this place sure knows how to make their signature item perfect. The tofu is so silky smooth, and the ingrediants compliments it to the tee. The soup is served on a boiling iron bowl, so it stays nice and warm throughout the dinner. The BBQ items are great too, you must try the ribs.

The Korean numerous side dishes "were" awesome, they have now reduced the number of side items for each table. BOO! It used to be 10+ items on the table, now it's half that. 

The price is decent. The soup was $8.45 and ribs were $15(or so). But now the prices have gone up. Another Boo! It's inflation I suppose.

Overall I still recommend this joint. It's by no means romantic, so it's more of a casual place to bring a date.
author: George H.

description: This place has the best ventilation yet. I love Brothers, but every time we walk out of there, we smell like BBQ kim chi. Anyways, food is good, not a huge menu, but isn't it always bulgogi, and bee bim bob. Good quick service....
author: L K.

description: I didn't think this restaurant was all that.  Service was slow, it took a long time for the food to come,  and the food choices were very limited.  I had the combination seafood tofu pot, the tasted was decent but not so much to make it stand out from other Korean restaurants.  The beef short ribs were pretty good though i must say.  They appetizer they offered were far less selection than the one i tried in Milpitas.  The other place gave at least 10 plates of different appetizers for us to try!   I would try other Korean places to compare before I'd come back for a second time.
author: Tadaa T.

description: Their soups are the ultimate warm you up on a cold night meals. You are served your soup in a cast iron bowl while the soup is still rapidly boiling, perfect for cracking the provided egg into. Along with this you are served a bowl of rice, and assorted kimchi items (cucumber, bean sprouts, cabbage, etc.) Because the soup was so hot we ate the rice with it which was sooo good!! this was the most amazing meal, great flavors and very filling. I ordered the kimchi tofu soup with beef and was so pleasantly surprised by it, I can't wait to go again!
author: Barbara C.

description: I LOVE MY tofu house.  The servers are friendly and quick, and if you crave any more panchan, they will supply you more!  Everything on the menu is delicious! Watch out for the long wait during prime dinner hour, but let me assure you, the food is well worth it.  Only gripe, not open on Saturday afternoons.
author: Ali C.

description: I've tried many many tofu places in LA and ATL but I still love this place the BEST. I always get the seafood tofu - very spicy. This place is also very clean and has great service. Just make sure not to go on a Saturday afternoon b/c their closed and also try to beat the rush hour and go at 6pm.
author: Deb C.

description: Home sick from work with a cold, I decided I needed hot, spicy, filling soup. Cue My Tofu House with a bubbling stonewear bowl of soft tufu stew and I was in heaven. My sinuses feel cleared and I am feeling comfy enough for more restorative sleep.
author: Caitlin S.

description: Yummmy!  I had the bbq chicken and seafood soon doobu - mild!  I can't take food that is too spicy.  I'm sure my dinner companion would have found it hilarious if I had ordered spicy and spent the whole dinner sweating.  I thought the service was pretty good for an Asian restaurant.  We hardly had to wait to be seated and the waiter (who was pretty cute, btw) was apologetic for even making us wait the one minute.  They didn't mind that we sat around for 2+ hours just chatting after we ate.  I wouldn't have minded if they kicked us out since we were taking up a table and it's not like it's a coffee shop where you're supposed to hang around.  You go, you eat, you pay, you leave.  But we were there so long, they practically closed the lights on us!
author: Kris L.

description:
was slightly disappointed by their kim chee tofu soup. it was ok, but nothing to write home about. i ordered the medium spicy but it was more like mild. i had to throw in extra kim chee (from the side dishes) just to give it more spice, which didn't work all that well  :(

also got the seafood pancake, which was good but expensive.

all in all, it was ok. i'd go back if i was hungry and passing by, but wouldn't make a special trip just to go.

oh, and they don't serve beer (or any alcohol). no Hite, no OB - NO BEER!! how could that be??
author: Jill L.

description: This place is clean, almost too clean, like bleach clean... the tofu soup is good.. we ordered the slightly spicy which was not spicy at all.... next time we'll go straight for spicy.... how can a Korean restaurant go wrong with making tofu soup?... price is cheap...
author: Jay S.

description: Decided to check out this place for dinner.  The line was to the door when I arrived, but moved pretty quickly - there were 7 parties ahead of us in line.  Tried the Original Tofu Soup (with beef) which came out boiling hot.  I am a spice wuss, so started with a mild spice and this wasn't enough.  It was $10 for soup, and $14 for the other entrees at dinner, which seemed expensive.  Waiter was very friendly.  You get lots of semi-unpalletable side dishes, most of which have eyes to look at you while you try to eat them.  Only real complaint was being the only non-asian people in the restaurant and being seated, alone, in a tiny back room.  Were they embarrassed by my presence?
author: Michael C.

description: We were newbies to Korean food, having been exposed just to a few dishes like the BBQ and Bulgogi.  Our future Daughter-In-Law knows we are big time foodies, and highly recommended this place.  Big lines when we got there, always a good sign.  We were seated in an odd little room at the back of the house, but that was just fine with us.  We had to convince the waiter not to tone down the food for us - I think we were successful.  Delicious Bibimbab, whole fish, soft tofu soup, seafood pancake. Terrific flavors. Great meal.Wish they'd open one up in Seattle...I don't think we have anything quite like it up here.
author: B W.

description: Jon M. is such a decadent man that he drank 1/2 a magnum of Vouve Cliqout at Baker Beach yesterday.  Then we went to My Tofu House with Chloe.  We were seated promptly, but from that point forward the service was kind of touch and go.  Our waiter was exceptionally good looking, though...and Jon's eyes kept wandering toward the girl assembling the panchan...so I guess waiting around wasn't the worst thing ever...  My seafood dolsot bibimbap was very good, except for the lack of gochujang  which we started to feel like pests for asking for despite the 2oz. to share among the 3 of us.  The panchan were awesome, though, and the feeling was young, hip, and  unassuming.  I guess the minus 2 stars is just for eratic service and lack of gochujang ( I like mine in a squeeze bottle, thank you very much).
author: Joanna R.

description: This place is great! I think I must been Korean in my past life! I just can't get enough of Korean food. My favorite is the tofu stew with beef and all the tasty side dish that comes with the meal! I also like the fact that the rice comes cooked in a stone pot! Kinda like the Chinese clay pot rice! Also try the Tofu House on El Camino, they serve mixed grain rice that's also very tasty and great for the digestive track! :)
author: Annie L.

description:
this is not my favorite place for Korean food. 
 the soup is good, but the beef ribeye is not charbroil so it did not satisfy my taste buds. 
very limited dishes to choose from.
author: Bei K.

description: Outstanding food. Especially for the low price. They do serve meat and it's very different from most places I've ever eaten at in SF.
author: Victoria B.

description: I always order their #9 (tofu soup with vegetables & noodles) and it is dee-licious!  All of their sides are good and their staff over all is cheerful and kind.  The only negative is that when there is a wait the line forms along the two seater booths and those waiting will hang their arms along the wall on the side of the booth and just hover over you and your food.  It makes for a very uncomfortable meal and as if it couldn't get worse those hovering will even cough and sneeze (w/o covering their mouth) over your food!  Yuck!  I wish the restaurant would install a taller partition- I would then have no hesitation eating here.
author: K W.

description: My husband & I dined at The Tofu House on Saturday night and it was delicious.  We landed at the Tofu House after a day in the City.  Thanks you, Yelp!  We ordered the Spicy Tofu and the bi-bam-bap.  The staff there were very nice.  We'll definitely be returning to The Tofu House very soon!
author: Amy H.

description: the food here was ok. my friend took me there last week and I ordered the bi bim bop and she ordered the seafood tofu soup. I wasn't really pleased with the bi bim bop but her tofu soup she ordered was so good! The tofu was frseh and just melted in your mouth. I think I would go here just for the tofu soup and the appetizers.. i haven't yet to try the korean spareribs... but maybe next time.
author: leanna w.

description: I love this place! It's the only place in the SF Bay Area that I'll go to for some tofu soup. I haven't tried anything else that's on the menu (BBQ meats, etc). The soup is really flavorful and it comes with rice that's been cooked in a clay pot. The waiters scoop the rice for you too, because otherwise I think we'd all burn ourselves on the clay pot. Every meal comes with sides dishes and those are delicious too! My favorites are the fish, the little fish and cucumbers. I usually ask for seconds on those...YUM!
author: Maryann T.

description: 4.5....So yummy....I like it best out of all the other soondubu places in the city so far. Haven't tried their other dishes yet so I'll let cha know how that goes....this place gets really packed around dinnertime though so call ahead and ask how busy they are if you care about that sort of thing. They need more types/amt of panchan...that would totally hit the spot....but once again, lovin the main attraction here~
author: Kelley N.

description: I was introduced to My Tofu House by my Korean friend, and have been a few times since. When the San Francisco evenings turn chilly, or simply if you are in the mood for tofu soup you will not be disappointed with a evening stay at My Tofu House. Stick to the many Tofu soup selections or the Bibimbap. The only negatives are that it can get crowded, and the service is a bit slow, but food taste overrides any negatives.
author: Gregory C.

description: Many options for soondoobu jigae (sp?).  Soondoobu with fish roe, with pork, with other things, and I'm sure it is all good.  I got mushroom soondoobu jigae.  They had great panchan and gave us some fried whole fishes too.  It was good.
author: Carrie P.

description:
I don't like irrationally negative reviews on Yelp, but I am compelled to speak my opinion about this place.

The TOFU SOUP - 
The soon-dubu (tofu) soups are fine here.  I think that when you go to a tofu soup place the palate is easily pleased with the appearance of the stone pot and scalding, pipping hot red soup.  Yes, this is what you get here, and if this is all you want, this is what you'll get.  

That being said, I feel that despite the reataurant's name sake, the soup should be better than it is.  I mean, yes, it is tofu soup, and yes it tastes fine and pretty OK.  But it doesn't really make me pause and say, "yeah, this is great tofu soup."

The OTHER FOOD - This is where I was more disappointed.  The other dishes are very lackluster and just seem to be something to be ordered for the sake of ordering, especially the grilled items (but why would I come here for these, right?).  The kimchee here is not very good either.

Ambiance is pretty good, and is kept reasonably clean.  Service is fine also, nothing special here.  In closing, I think this place is a bit overrated.  You will get tofu soup that is a notch above decent.  I would go here only if you have a serious hankering for tofu soup.

Food: 2
Value: 2
Service: 3
Ambience: 3

Overall: 2.5
author: Michael L.

description: Great soondubu and bbq!! We had the combination soondubu and the medium spiciness was just great - not too much, not too little, but as expected, medium. You'd be surprised how often you ask for medium and its too mild, or even hot, and its as if they just dumped in a bunch of sauce with no consideration for balance. The spicy bbq park was really good too - the meat was tender and spiciness was just right. This is a great place for lunch, as they have special prices for the bbq; dinner looked quite a bit more expensive. I would definitely come back because the quality is good, service is fast, and prices are very reasonable.
author: David C.

description:
have been here twice, and the first time the soup tasted sort of bland, and the second time me and all my friends had stomach problems that had us clutching our butts while we raced to get home.

the waiter was really nice though and patient. and the banchan was good.
author: Ellen L.

description: What what? Tofu house rocks.! Whenever me and my gurl didnt feel like cooking. We'll come straight to here. Only thing i hate is looking for street parking but then again..tats all over SF. I really enjor the tofu soup here. They dont make it that spicy but is good enough for us. Definitely a regular joint for us.
author: Ernie P.

description: The waiters here are nice. The food is great, but if you don't like temperature and spicy hot food, then Korean food is not for you. The place is bright and family-friendly, and there are Korean themes throughout the restaurant. Parking is sometimes a pain, but the wait is worth it. I took my ex-lover here. Too bad things did not work out between us.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description:
Came for: Soon Du Bu; in search for some legit K-food
Will come back for: ...

Umm...  really?  Some of the reviews make me wonder if I ate at another place.  But I must caveat my review that I'm picky about my Korean food, especially as  my taste buds have been spoiled by LA Korean food.
On a cold rainy SF day, I went with a friend who eagerly anticipated I would like this place.  The wait was long and the place was all the hustle and bustle, so I waited with eagerness and wonderment.
But My Tofu House did not meet my two measuring criteria for Korean food places:
1) Ban Chan (i.e. side dishes, or some refer to it as appetizers) -- it was just ok; not anything impressive.  If anything, the kimchi should be good, but it was meh.
2) Seasoning -- I totally had a MSG reaction to the soup!!  It tasted fine going down, but it left me with a bad headache and thirst that only monosodium glutamate can.  And not to mention it tasted strangely like ramen soup base to me.
And to top it off, it was rather pricey!?!?  So clearly, low repeat value in my humble opinion.
author: Carol K.

description: This has become one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Bulgoki, tofu soup, it's allllll good.
author: Sandra S.

description: Not very much good Korean food in SF.  LA is where its at.  With that said, My Tofu House does a decent job.  It is not as bomb as LA, but it definitely can satisfy the craving for the time being.  Most other tofu places in SF are just straight up gross.
author: Bert N.

description: I would give MY Tofu House a perfect five star rating were it not for the many shrimp tentacles particles floating in my combination soon doobu. By the time I finished my bowl of perfectly spiced, steaming hot tofu soup, I had collected a generous pile of shrimp tentacle shards. Aside from that minor detail, this is the best tofu house I have been to in NorCal. Love the accompaniments including whole fried fish, raw egg to drop into the soup, and scattered green peas and garbanzo beans in the white rice.
author: Jess H.

description:
the seafood tofu chige spicy. oh god. i was sweating, but damn, it was good. damn it was good. good god.

and the server girl was cute too ;]

i want her so bad.
author: Ben T.

description: The best part of my meal was the burnt crusty rice on the bottom of my bi bim bop.The sucker was huge. It was brought to the table in a huge , sizzling cast iron bowl. If you never had that crispy rice on the bottom you are in for a treat. The tofu soup was good but certainly not the best I've had. Another treat was the steamed rice was also brought in a cast iron bowl and scooped at out table. The soup , ban chan and steamed rice was plenty for two. The waiter was really nice and friendly and pretty cute too.
author: Sophia C.

description: a great alternative to brothers!  Its just as good, cheaper, and you don't leave smelling like grill.
author: Dawn P.

description: yum yum, but super long wait.  Ask for the soondooboo spicey cuz it tastes bland w/o the spice
author: Janet L.

description: This is a small place... so get here early.  Not recomended for large groups... you may have to wait a while.  I like going here becuase i get to eat all those little dishes they put out.  They even include fried makeral with the lil dishes.   We normally order one of the tofu soups and a bbq meat dish.  It hits the spot.
author: Sheenie L.

description: 5 stars for the spicy tofu soup with dumplings! I cannot think of a better food for a cold SF evening. It comes both boiling hot and spicy hot, and stays that way thanks to the stone bowl. The tofu is wonderfully silken, and the dumplings are savory goodness. Oh, and I mustn't forget the BBQ beef and vegetable bibimbap which was great. However the line of people waiting is annoyingly close to many of the tables, so much so that I got a saliva shower from one particularly talkative lady. Yuck, I had to go home and shower in hand sanitizer.
author: Will A.

description: Came here after being sick for several days, and the veggie soft tofu soup was just what I needed - a big bowl of comfort!
author: Beth T.

description:
Our initial destination, Bubble Zone, is now "temporarily out of business", so my friend and I walked over to Geary St. to find dinner. Once we saw the yelp label on the restaurant door, we HAD to enter.
Not knowing that their specialty was the soft tofu soup, we ordered a tofu salad and bi bim bop to share (there are definitely vegetarian options here!). The tofu salad wasn't too good. The tofu was firm and tasted a little strange, and the salad under it was any regular old salad. 
When the bi bim bop came along, I had the honor of mixing the oozing yolk with the steamy rice and veggies, which was pretty much pure joy. The bi bim bop was sizzling and mildly spicy, which is perfect for my taste buds (: Later I enjoyed the crispy rice that formed at the bottom of the bi bim bop bowl.
I always enjoy the condiments/side dishes(?) that are served at Korean restaurants (: Neither of us had ever been served a whole fried fish before though (not to say that was bad. the fish tasted fine). We were also served strangely delicious hot tea. I wonder what it was. Friendly waiters frequently came by to refill our cups.
For two small girls, the salad and bi bim bop were perfectly filling and not too harsh on our wallets (keep in mind we're students). We had enough space left in our tummy for a refreshing dessert from tutti melon.
Neither of the things we ordered were amazing. I'm hoping that next time I go, their soft tofu soup will change my mind.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
What do you expect of a typical tofu house?... what you get is MY tofu house. 

There is nothing too special about this place.  But if you are in the area and you want korean food, this will definitely fill that void, and most importantly, on a budget.

Other Notes:
Parking is somewhat difficult but absolutely do-able for this location.
Service was good and swift.
author: Michael C.

description: So delicious. I crave Korean food and last night, My Tofu House hit the spot. But, FYI, if you ask for extra spicy, it REALLY is extra spicy! I am a weakling and stuck with the medium, which was really the perfect amount, though I could've used a tad bit more spiciness, so I dipped my spoon in the extra spicy.  The pancakes are kinda "bleh" compared to the outstanding soups and bbq...delicious!
author: Natalie S.

description: great place with tons of options for vegetarians and meat eaters. I waited no more than 10 mins for a table for dinner. I ordered a tofu salad and turned out it was huge. My friend ordered a meat dish that came out shearing on a cast iron plate. The service was great and people frequently came to our table asking if we needed anything. The price is very reasonable and affordable.
author: julia n.

description: This is my favorite korean resturants!  I love this place, the food is great and I'm constantly craving it.  The service is usually fast, it does get busy though so I usually avoid it if it's later in the evening on a friday or saturday as there is usually a long wait to get a table.  My favorite dish is the tofu and dumpling soup.
author: Amanda P.

description: I like this place.  Very clean, pleasant, and quiet.  The waitress was also friendly and helpful...being my first experience in korean food...I had to make her explain the menu.  Ordered the combination tofu soup, spicy, which turned out not too spicy, anyway.  I like the raw egg you crack on top of the boiling broth, I like to dip the rice in the broth before drinking the soup .  The little side dishes- maybe 8-9 items were very good---the little fishes were so good, and the kimchee compliments the soup very well.  So...now, anytime I hear Korean food, I'm for it.
author: Kui T.

description:
Don't let the name fool you.  This place is all about meat in addtion to the yummy tofu soup.  In my book it is a good sign when you go into a Korean restaurant and it is all Koreans eating there.  
If you are there for some hot soup you can get it either super spicy or not spicy at all. 
The meals come with Kimchi appetizers that I guarantee you will like (one if not all of them).
As far as the meat goes, the bulgoki(sp?)beef and dakgui(sp?) chicken are good starters for first timers. 
Service used to be spotty, now it is very good, also family friendly, we brought our 7 month old with no problem.
author: John S.

description: good tofu stew in SF.  only 4 stars because its too expensive for compare to its quality.  I'm going back to LA tomorrow...where the tofu stew is 2 bucks cheaper.  Still, it's close to my parents' biz and i like the quality of the side dishes.
author: joseph k.

description: The food was too bland for my taste. I had to add a lot of spice and salt, and I myself am not much of a spice eater. However, compared to other Korean places I have been to, this definitely was better than the rest. Even so, the taste of the food served was just about ok.
author: Venkat K.

description: Oh My Tofu House, how you have spoiled me rotten all these years. It wasn't till recently until I discovered how awesome you guys are. Soondubu (soft tofu stew) is my comfort food so 90% of the time I eat at Korean restaurants, that is what I order. I didn't realize that it's not customary at every Korean restaurant to give raw eggs for the soondubu (you have to ask for it if you want it). My Tofu House always provided me the raw egg when I ordered this dish. I will never take you guys for granted again. Their banchan is plentiful and tasty as well. I love the brown rice tea they serve. I also think it's awesome that they bring a stone pot with rice and serve it to you at the table. Never again will I be unfaithful to you guys.
author: Kit K.

description:
I was out and about and stopped in here for lunch yesterday.  I was initially disappointed they didn't have any bibimbap lunch specials, but that is what we really wanted so we had two of the beef BBQ variety. 

The kimchi was pretty good and I enjoyed the rest of the small plates that accompanied the meal but the bibimbap was good yet rather plain.  

Pre-tip the lunch for two was $33.
author: Adam C.

description:
The fifth star is missing because a piece of melon chewing gum just does NOT cut it for dessert :-(  And the prices here are somewhat inflated.  I would've expected pay at least a third less than what we actually did.  Having said this, don't let me dissuade you:

I liked the way they receive guests during busy times - a sign up sheet on the wall.  Outsource the problem to the patrons - it was great.

We waited 15 minutes to be seated, with at least 20 people ahead of us - but we enjoyed gawking over the small divider wall to see what others were feasting on.

The restaurant has a rear section which is completely separate from the front - a room with 3 tables/4 chairs each.  Probably a pantry or storage room prior to being converted to a dining room.  The couple ahead of us let us go - they weren't interested in the room - but we went regardless - hunger prevails when you're a food-addict.

We ordered the Kal-bi (which was great), tofu soup (standard) and seafood pancake.  The servers were attentive, refilling our appetizers (I'm not well versed in Korean food names, but you know, the kimchi, the sprouts, they even had interesting small sardines).

The best part of the evening (besides the food and service) was the conversation we struck up with a group of Thai students.  We walked away with laughs, and the names of the top 3 Thai restaurants (according to Thai people) in SF.  I look forward to yelping about those come next time!
author: That's For N.

description: This place is great to go to on a cold day in San Francisco. The blue sign outside is like a mecca of warmth...telling you to "come inside". On my last visit here I had the the Broiled Short Ribs and Original Soft Tofu w/ beef and made it spicy. It was just delicious. the ribs were perfectly braised, full of flavor, and charred to a nice crisp. The tofu soup was just the right spiciness that I like, the tofu was soft, and the beef was tender. Added with some rice and an egg, it was a warm bliss in my tummy. I love coming here b/c they give you a large variety of complementary kimchi and side dishes. you never leave this place still hungry!
author: Ivy L.

description: The service was good but the food was disappointing. The kimchi was bland and the ramen i ordered was actually the packaged kind you can get at any grocery/convenience store. Since they were charging $9 for it I thought it would be the kind of ramen that they make fresh, in-house. The korean pizza and tofu fish egg combo were tasty but nothing extraordinary. Maybe I just ordered the wrong things, but I don't plan on going back cause I felt many of the menu items were overpriced. However if you like to eat a lot of the complimentary side dishes it would be worth it. They probably charge more on their menu items to make up for the cost of the numerous "complimentary" side-dishes.
author: Merri K.

description: i went here with my 11 family members, a total of 12 people. We sat in a long table, perfect. We began to order slowly, unsure of what wed like. The one of two waitors working this evening gave us a mad, irritated unpatient look. We ordered many tofu soups, which were about 15 bucks each, incuding tax and tips. NOT WORTH IT. 20 something dollar plate of rib eye steaks were also not impressive, and prolly only worth five bucks. The female waitress was very nice, but she was very busy, being there was only two employees for a full house. The litle dishes of pickled cucumbers were good, free refills. The rice was 5 dollars for seconds, we had like five extra bowls. Iced water and tea free. Bibimap was good. Seafood pancake also very nicely prepared , crispy and yummy. However, the check was 220$ !!!!! so not worth the terrible slow service and crappy, tofu soups and dishes. Not good. Ciuld have had a much nicer meal for 220 bucks. Plus, they charged us  18% tax beause we had more than 6 people. What nice service. NOT . WILL NEVER BE RETURNING!!! i advise nobody to come here unless they like bad service, not satisfying food and dishes and overpriced prices. NEVER AGAIN, MY TOFU HOUSE!!
author: michelle w.

description: first discovered tofu house in southern california and was so excited when this opened in san francisco. hot tofu soup is a perfect meal on a cold day. it also comes with lots of free appetizers with refills.
author: Diana B.

description: So I came back with my boyfriend because we were around the area and I was craving for tofu soup. IT WAS WONDERFUL!  I'm a fan now. yay!
author: A L.

description: I came here when they first opened few years ago. That time Korean food wasn't so famous, so it was cheap and goodies. Throughout the years, I think I came like 2-3 times every year. Last time I was here was like 2 months ago and it was as nice as always. The food is always easy-going but the line isn't. I like the place, but I hate waiting especially on weekends, so I'd rather cook it myself if I have to go there on the weekends. The line is better on weeknights, so yeah... come on weeknights to try Korean spicy tofu stew. I won't go for bulgogi or bimbimbap here, though. There are other better restaurants for those.
author: dannydan d.

description:
real good for korean tofu soup lovers. hated the svc. just a regular joint w/a tiny menu, simple.

FOOD: ~tofu soup was pretty good. 

~bulgogi was grrreat. 

~i loved loved loved the fried fish that came w/the side dishes mmmmmm. but then i was saddened when i saw they gave the table of 2 next to us TWO fried fishes, & they only gave our table of 3 ONE fried fish. maybe b/c we weren't korean like them. wtf!

SERVICE: terrible. HIRE ANOTHER SERVER b/c 1 dude just ain't cutting it. they tried to stick us in the unappealing back rm by the bathrm, but i said we'd wait.

DECOR: plain.

BATHROOM: eh.

OVERALL: i have friends who fricking love tofu soup, so i guess i'll take them there.
author: miss b.

description: Pricey, but the mushroom tofu is pretty delicious. Excellent and appropriate comfort food for dreary Richmond district weather.
author: Maximillian M.

description: When i crave for some tofu, i go to My Tofu House - make sense? sure! If you feel like some korea tofu soup but don't want to walk out the restaurant smelling like BBQ, then this is the place to go. Plus,  you don't need to share your tofu, everyone can afford getting his/her own individual clay pot (about $9.00) + the usual korean appetizers - quite a few of them. My Tofu House also serves grilled/sauteed chicken/beef/pork there, but i am there for the tofu! Different level of spiciness and type of soup (seafood, beef, vegetarian, etc) to choose from.
author: Angela H.

description:
so far, this is my favorite korean place in san francisco.  yes, there are probably better in oakland, but that's a trek.

i always get the seafood tofu bowl.  piping hot, so make sure you don't burn your tongue.  

i'd recommend staying away from the vegetarian bim bim bop that's not spicy.  an unadventurous vegetarian friend had that - bland, bland, bland.

good prices, unlimited small dishes to start out with, and piping hot tofu soup.
author: kim n.

description: Yummy tofu in my tummy. Best seafood soft tofu stew.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Service is fast, but no refill on side dishes. The side dishes were small and skimpy, nothing to rave about. Nothing surprising, the typical kimchee.....  I go to a lot different Korean restaurant in bay area, they all have their special side dishes. Usually I get a nice surprise because I get something new. 
  
We came out disappointed. We just wonder what the rave is all about, with Zagat sign and posters of recognitions, I have been to other Korean restaurants, any average Korean restaurants serve the same side dishes or even better selections and the rice is not plain white, the BBQ chicken was average tasting. The portion was decent. 
But not juicy or sweet, just lots of soy sauce.

I won't go there again. The Zagat sign is misleading. The servers were nice, but did not see her again after we got our food.  Also, all the Korean restaurants serve house green Tea, I have to say this one was weak, like water. Hey, it was warm and free.

Dinner is not a good deal.  Not many selections on the menu, just soup, red meat and chicken, no seafood choices. Side dishes, typical. Nothing to write about.  The person from Zagat must have been half asleep when he/she choose this place.
author: A Z.

description: Just a-ok. There isn't any ambiance BUT there was a line on a random Monday around 1pm. Lots of banchan (even whole grilled fish - you don't get that kinda thing at Ktown in NYC). The pa-jeon was super thick and dough-y! I like the thinner crispier version. I prob wouldn't go back to this place for no other reason than it just didn't stand out to me.
author: Jess M.

description: My Tofu House on Geary is a nice, clean Korean restaurant with a very specific menu: its a tofu house. The only one in SF I know of, I think its rather new. The staff is courteous, and the crowd is fairly young. We usually get the Kimchi Soon Doobu and Daeji Bulgogi (Spicy Pork). The rice comes in a stone bowl, like it should, and is very moist. Ask for everything extra spicy, and order a can or two of Coke to cool your palate. My only complaint would be that they close waaaay too early for this type of restaurant. My guess is the young staff want to be able to go clubbing after work. Get there by 8:00, you will be glad you did!  I will go back...Sunday night.
author: Johnny O.

description: One of the better Korean tofu places around SF.  There's something about their kimchee that just sits right with me.  Very simple decor, helpful staff.  And if it's your first time: when the soup comes out boiling, crack that egg, drop it in and mix to taste.  Pretty good selection of kimchee's and they'll bring you more if you've eaten all of your favorite (what is that mystery radish I love so?)
author: San B.

description: If your looking for vegetarian food dont let the title fool you! I was driving up geary looking for a quick bite. I went there thinking they might have tofu dishes but I was wrong. For korean food it was good. As usual they did bring a whole fried fish to the table and eggs so if your vegetarian I wouldnt reccommend this place. I ordered the tofu mushroom soup which was good but I think this was mostly a mistake on my part taking a risk on a new place. Despite the title they didnt have many tofu dishes, the soup I ordered was the only one I could find on the menu. Compared to other korean places Ive been it wasnt the best and service was slow. The tea was good.
author: M K.

description: I have had mixed experiences at My Tofu House. Every time I've gone in with an 'asian' person, we've had great service and great food. I usually get the spicy vegetarian soon du bu. Finally I went with a non-asian and the service was horrendous! Our orders were mixed up, we had to ask for our drinks 3 times before we got them, and the soon du bu itself tasted like colored, salty water instead of tofu soup. I was very much disappointed, especially for the soon du bu first timer I took with me. I had raved about My Tofu House to him. Well, I'll probably go back again- with an 'asian'.
author: S K.

description: I love their tofu soup! Too bad they sont serve alcahol and closes really early
author: Boji I.

description: For die hard soon doobu fans like myself, I'm just happy this place exists within city limits.  Having said that, I have had my share of soon doobu all over -- Los Angeles, New York, Annandale VA -- this one stacks up somewhere in the middle: better than NYC but not as good as Annandale VA!  The service wasn't great, as we had to pour our own water into the stone pots after the rice was scooped out to make our own porridge, but the stewed tofu itself was plenty YUMS.  And they don't skimp terribly on the seafood ingredients like some other places (BCD in LA).  The place gives you five small pre-dishes... I like places that give you at least seven and has the egg pre-dish.  But overall, you find me there again and again.  Word of warning, I like spicy, but "spicy" is too spicy here so I get the "medium."
author: Sindy Lin M.

description:
atmosphere: 4
food: 3
service: 3.5

I'm so torn. Sigh... alas this will probably end up being my soondubu staple by default.

Seating for lunch was easy. 

The service was a little slow, but they tried to make up for it in smiles...

what i always get is seafood soondubu medium. Always. I guess they can't all be BCD! It was to salty and not spicy enough. The rice was perfect. It helps that I love peas and other legumes in my rice. 

The banchan was a 3. Just kind of basic stuff that i'm feeling I could make at home-- cucumber kimchi in plain ole vinegar, really ripe gakdoogee, and some kongnamul which looked "mature". 

The gulbi (fish) was RIGHT ON though. good job there. granted, gulbi is hard to mess up so that's expected!

A little pricey for lunch! $13 before tip seems a little steep.. sigh.. no BCD...

still need to try the dolsot bibimbap.. to be updated!
author: Miss C.

description: Combination soup spicey like momma makes it!  I love this place.  It is a favorite spot for friends to come after happy hour at Badlands on Fridays.  The food is great, but the wait can be a little long on weekend nights.  The waiters aren't bad to look at either ;)
author: Michael H.

description:
simple menu, just soondoboo, bulgogi/ kalbi,, that's all you need.
the soondoboo is great (you should order spicy though or medium at least :-)), the bulgogi/ kalbi is average.
author: Suki S.

description:
Great place to go to on a cold night, especially if you have been out all day working up a big appetite.  

Always has a long line and watchout for people trying to cut.  Make sure you sign up for a table at the front of the line.
author: CGI I.

description:
I had Soon doo boo (spelling?) in K. town and Irvine, but they do not compare to the one here, which is next to my home in SF. The menu selection is very limited, but the flavor of the tofu and its soup is just right, and the price is great. Definitely one of my favorite restaurant of all time.

A lot of people would think that their soup is not very spicy or hot, but I think they are just right for me (I am not Korean). 

This place is close Saturday lunch time, which is a bummer, and it is PACKED to a point that you may have to wait outside in the cold weather. This neighborhood is also almost impossible to find parking.
author: Shing W.

description: This is my favorite Korean tofu house in SF.  It doesn't really compare to my favorite Korean tofu house in LA, but it's always satisfying.  I've been coming here on and off for almost 5 years or so, and have seen the slow uptick in prices and waiting time as it got more popular (from what I remember).  But the tofu soup, which you can order in mild, medium, or spicy, is solid.  Even ordering the mild for the first time (I usually go for the medium or spicy), I realized that the soup is still tasty when not covered up or overpowered by all the chili powder.  Bibimbap, kalbi, and bulgogi are great too.  The banchan is ok, and I like that it comes with the salty fish.  But I love the tofu soup the best!
author: Allison M.

description:
Hard to admit...but I was at a loss. I've had Korean food before but not homestyle like this. I was familiar with all the ingredients-- but wasn't quite sure what the "etiquette" or intention was for everything laid out before me. Soon enough, I realized that this really didn't matter: you can't make a mistake here and you'll have fun getting the flavors just right for your palette. The food was on fire-- in all senses of the word! The temperature was scorching, the spices were tongue shredding (even at medium heat), and the red colors in my soft-tofu ramen bowl were eye-popping. Everything stayed warm in the stone pots-- which is a huge factor considering you want to take your time and smell the kimchee here! If I lived in the city, they'd be seeing a lot of me. Since I'm just getting familiar with SF and didn't have a clue about the Inner Richmond neighborhood, I'm so very glad for Yelp!

Lucky for us, there wasn't a line until after we were already eating. I was also very pleased with the service and the fact that my vegan partner could enjoy a massive bowl of food here without feeling like a burden. They didn't seem affected by her request to eliminate the eggs in her bibimbap and quickly pointed out all of her options. Considering the short menu, four options was quite impressive. I must add that the portions were "odd" and the price tag threw me off a bit. The lunch to dinner price difference was staggering (upwards of 5-9 dollars). Still, if you're getting fantastic food and the expense of it quickly becomes a non-entity. If you eat here family style, you're in for quite a feast.
author: OKAY O.

description:
my mom loves this place. i like it but i feel like its not my first choice when someone asks me where to get korean. i think its bc the place doesnt look that cozy, kinda like a cafeteria. however:

the food is definitely delicious! comes with many dishes of ban chan and that makes me happy! i love the rice in the stone pot that comes with the soup. hot rice is always a plus!
author: L M.

description: Love the food here! All the tofu soups are great, and the rice comes in stone pots. Sooo delicious! It's a popular place, so expect a bit of a wait, but it's well worth the wait! They've expanded their menu, and I am liking the new items as well so far :)
author: fumiko t.

description:
mmmm...i love soondubu jigae! 
get your own bowl, cause i am NOT sharing! =P

For primarily being known for their soups; their kalbi is pretty darn good. Let's just say my first time here was so good, i went back...the very next day!


My Tofu equation:
one bite kalbi (short ribs)
+
one bite of gakdoogi (spicy pickled radishes)
+
couple spoonfuls of soondubu (i recommend the spicy one)
+
swig of coke to wash it all down
=
one very happy and satisfied me
author: Kristina L.

description:
ok im frm the southbay, where on elcamino, tofu houses actually HAVE COMPETITION. so it's not "my tofu house"s fault that it got 2 stars. or is it?

if this place was called "my fried fish bahn-cchan house" itd get prolly 4 stars because that stuff was good. their kimchi wasn't ee-guhed (i dont know how that translates into english... i guess its like trying to eat a pickle that hasnt been soaked enough so it jus tastes like a pickle dipped in vinegar...) and their cucumber side dish was bland. 

their soondooboo was very bland. not only bland but not hot enough (temperature, not spicy-wise) because when i cracked my egg into it, it didnt cook right away so all throughout my meal i had slightly raw egg in my soondooboo. i got the mushroom soondooboo but there were hardly any mushrooms. soondooboo is supposed to hav more than just soup, some tofu and a few mushrooms. it's sposed to be PACKED with veggies. 

my mom got their seafood bimbimbap, and that was very dissapointing as well. not enough sauce, again not hot enough to cook the egg or the raw shrimp that was inside, very very very very bland, very dry, and again, not enough veggies!

the place started gettin really packed as i was finishing my meal and i was confused as to why people would wait that long for what i had just consumed.

the place is very clean, and service is... alright.... i guess... but i would never reccomend this place to someone. if you want some real soondubu go to el camino in san jose. if you love korean food thats where it's at. that or k-town in LA.

DISCLAIMER: i feel like this entry made me sound like korean is my first language but it's not. but korean is my first food.
author: Lillian P.

description:
YUM!

The dumpling soon dubu is delicious, but I didnt get enough of the small snowmen looking rice-cake in my dish.

Prices are slightly higher than other tofu soup joints in the Bay Area, but I think its worth it for the quality. The soup isnt too salty either, and the mild version that I tried was still tasty without the heat.
author: Retired B.

description:
My non Korean friends think that since I'm Korean kalbi is my favorite food, and that I eat it morning, noon and night.  I cannot deny that I do like my korean meats, but my favorite korean dish is soon dubu.

My friends and I have defined our favorite food as something that you enjoy eating whether is high or low quality.  Example:  fried chicken.  I can enjoy KFC friend chicken as well as fancy fried chicken from Magnolias.  So when I go to My Tofu House, I enjoy the soon dubu not because it's the best I've had, but because of the overwhelming joy that I'm struck with when I dive into a bowl of mushy, spicy goodness.

In regards to the menu beyond soon dubu, the choices are limited.  The ban chan (side dishes) are ok.  If you want to eat Korean food like jo mama would make it (or if you're not korean...how my mama would make it)  head over to Mogaboka.
author: Doris K.

description: Good, cheap, quality Korean food.  One of my favorite places in the city.  Order a bowl of Sundubu on a cold day, it'll definitely hit the spot.
author: Brian H.

description: YUM! Soon doo bu chiggae! If you want good tofu soup come here! Nuff said.
author: Chrissy E.

description: One of my favorite K-restaurants in SF.  The bibimbobs (sp?) and the tofu soups are awesome.  It does get a fairly busy, so get there early, unless you don't mind waiting in line.
author: David C.

description:
I love tofu soup and this place does not disappoint. The tofu is perfectly soft and the soup has enough heat to satisfy. The wait staff is also very nice.

Only downside is that that don't give all the nice sides I am used to with tofu soup, e.g. seaweed and no ice cream to finish off your meal.
author: Sam H.

description:
my love of korean food grew deeper and deeper as i spent more and more time in china (weird huh?). i lived in an area where the majority was korean. food there was good and inexpensive (totaling at about 3USD per head to fill our bellies with food and alcohol)... i guess, all foods brings me back to something, one time or another...

so for this i give you "my tofu house" 5 stars because you warm me up on those cold foggy sf nights and brings me back to my times in beijing enjoying a boiling pot of tofu soup in the middle of summer.

when i got my kimchee-pork-tofu soup, it was still boiling hot. i immediately cracked my egg into the soup and watch the translucent egg white turn white. our rice came cooked in it's own stoneware pot and formed a layer of (what we call in chinese "rice banana") crispy rice on the bottom of it. the waiter allowed that to soak in tea so we can enjoy it at the end of meal. great thinking! less work for the kitchen and more for us to enjoy.

i may not be an expert on korean food but i know what i like. and i like my tofu house.

personal fave: i guess this will hold true for all korean restaurants but i love all the small dishes you get and the wheat tea.
author: Mei N.

description: I love this place! Great spot to grab tofu stew (I like the dumpling version) and bibimbop (spicy bbq pork - thumbs up). The pancakes are $17 - haven't tried them yet, but they kind of look like a smaller version of a deep dish pizza...so basically, only order that if you're with a group of 4+ people. Also - the wait is long...this place is super popular. Either go right when it opens or be prepared to wait.
author: Adrienne C.

description: I come here at least twice a month just for tofu soup. It's pretty good compare to all the other restaurant since they are well known for their tofu soup. Among other things in the menu... it's not so great, like the pancake, tofu salad, galbi, etc. The downfall is that their side dish is so limited, though I do enjoy their kimchi since it taste sweet to me. Other places has too much vinegar in their kimchi. Ya don't know what else to say... if you want good tofu soup, come here but everything else is like ehhh....
author: Will C.

description: Food good. Been twice in a week tall Korean waiter with bushy hair never washes hands. Blew nose 3-4 times while seating people 3 times in an hour. Wiped tables and hardwood floor not once washed his hands. Witnessed this both times and hope he didn't bring us our food. This is a health department violation who knows what kind of illness he has.
author: Poi L.

description:
om nom nom nom!!!

this tofu soup is outta this world, no joke! if you like your food as spicy and hot as me and my man...hoo wee! you ain't gonna be disappointed here. unlike other joints, when you ask for spice, they give it to you.

forget the bim bim bap (though sweetie pie loves it) it's all about the spiciest tofu soup. this is the place to go when you have the bad chest cold. i'm going back tonight!

practical details: line is often very long, but it moves really fast. service is also very efficient and they don't serve bbq, ok?
author: G Z.

description:
Excellent food, excellent service. Anytime I bring out-of-town friends here they are always impressed not only with the food but with the awesome service!

the wait is awful after 7pm but that's just cause people want their spicy tofu dammit. just jot your name down on the list and glare at those who had been seated before you to hurry up so you can get their seat. 

Spicy isn't unbearable it's just the right amount of redness (but i may be a biased korean) and it comes from the kitchen screamin hot. 

parking's tricky but hey, it's geary street. 

Heaven in a clay pot
author: Jen K.

description: I liked their spicy mushroom tofu stew sooo much that I burned my mouth from the intense heat and spiciness. My tongue and the roof of my mouth hurt the next day, but it was worth it.
author: Sheena U.

description:
After an intense afternoon of hiking and kite flying, I tried My Tofu House with my friend (he claims it' s the BEST tofu soup in town). All the running with our kites to force some action on a wind-wimpy day had us ravenous before 6pm. This was good news for us because after we were seated, the restaurant quickly filled up. 
I got the tofu combo soup medium hot and my friend got the (classic?) plain tofu mild. The service is pretty spotty and we had to practice the stare-and-hold method on the waiters for our orders to be taken. The table next to us were more passive and they received their appetizers and placed their order 20 min after our dishes arrived - and they were seated pretty much the same time!
The appetizers were really fresh and good - crisp on items that should be (cucumbers, turnips, bean sprouts, etc.) and crunchy yet soft enough on the fried fishy. Our soups arrived hot and boiling in their respective clay pots. It was so fragrant I almost passed out from happiness - a perfect blend of kimchee spice and seafood saltiness. I've ordered tofu/seafood soups from other places where it was downright fishy (not good). I guess there's a fine line separating fragrant and pungent! 
All in all I would love to come back to this restaurant! There are some large booths which appear to fit around 6 ppl just fine. But due to the small size and popularity of this place, I wouldn't want to come around rush time with a group bigger than that!
author: Kelly K.

description: YUM! I love this place.  I think this is the best soondoobu in SF!
author: Gillian F.

description:
yAY! I love My Tofu House. It tastes like what Soon Tofu Soup should taste like.

I usually get the mixed one..I guess I should try the others, huh?
I also like their non-tofu stuff...like spicy pork and haemul pajun...seafood pancake.  They're both really expensive in my opinion, but they taste just fine...and large portions.

I am not that partial to the banchan though. Kimchi and basic banchan tastes good but the fish, everytime it smelled fishy. Not fresh. There was no visual appeal, either...it looked a day old.

BUT I love the soup and rice...luuuuuv the hot stone bowl rice. And at the end how the server pour hot water over the leftover rice in the stone bowl. I drink that at the end and it soothes my stomach...washes everything down...
author: Nayeoung K.

description: OH I always ordered the original tofu soup, with chicken and mushroom and SPICY!!! It's awesome.. I am not a big fan of Korean food, especially when it comes to kimchi and "friends". But I LOVE the spicy tofu soup and I guess I will never get bored. The service is good, friendly people! :)
author: Marlis T.

description:
Me: "Do you guys have beer?"
Waiter: "No"
Me: "Can I bring my own?"
Waiter: "No, the owner is a hardcore Christian and doesn't allow it."

Whoa.  That's bs.  I won't patronize any establishment that imposes their (foolish) morality on me.

I thought the food was at best ok.  Soups and rice dishes were decent but the BBQ (the essence of Korean) was greasy and spicy dishes not very spicy or otherwise interesting.  I'd much rather go down the block and across the street to Brothers.  Other than making your clothes smell, that place rocks.
author: David P.

description: They serve the best soon du boo in the city! I've yet to find another place that does an equally good job. I just wished they wouldn't keep raising their prices:(
author: Moxie C.

description: Okay, this place is alright.  I ate 2 dishes (the chicken bibimbop and some beef shredded dish).  Did not try any tofu, maybe next time.  The side orders were alright.  Nothing special, although you can ask for more side dishes.  Prices are about $10/dish for lunch.  Seems fair since they give you the side dishes.  If not for the side dishes, they are not even close to being worth it.  There was noting special about the taste but my 2 friends love it.  They love the clay pot style.  I am not much into clay pot so maybe that's why I cannot enjoy it as much.  Most likely will not come again unless I am hungry for some tofu which I should've tried since their store name is "My tofu House".
author: John W.

description: My Tofu House has DAMN GOOD TOFU!  Minus one star for long waits and difficult parking.  I've watched a car get towed from that Jack in the Box...
author: Sarah Z.

description:
i went there just now... i ordered original beef tofu soup...
it's good. Price $10.50 + tax.
it comes with rice.
author: Elisabeth T.

description:
Though the service was good, the food was not. The sides were not very flavorful and my Bee Bimp Bop (however you spell it) was not cooked well. The rice was not crispy--it was just mush. Again, the ingredients used in the main dish were skimpy and not flavored. 

I went with a party of 13 (big Asian-family gathering) and from what I gather the meat dishes were better. Still, the general consensus is that we will not be returning.

Frankly, based on the dish I ordered and side dishes, there is better Korean food out there ... in my opinion.
author: Mel E.

description:
Let's just say my boyfriend and I had a really bad experience when we got home after our first meal.  

However, we did manage to come back a second time because we wanted to give this place the benefit of the doubt.  We ordered the spicy seafood tofu soup and the non-spicy original soup.  The spicy was not spicy enough so maybe I'll try super spicy next time.  Both however, were absolutely delicious.  I also ordered the seafood pancake, which wasn't that great.  The outside of the pancake was nice and crispy, but the inside was somewhat mushy, sort of like uncooked batter.  

Thank god we survived the second time.  We will be back.  
P.S. Please DO NOT underestimate the free fish they give you because it's actually pretty good!
author: Emily L.

description: I think this is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF.  The prices are great, and the service is always prompt.  It can be crowded at times, so be prepared to wait.  It is bigger on the inside then it looks, so there is quite a lot of space and seating.  The best part of Korean cuisine are all the side dishes, and Tofu house has the best I feel.  One downside is the location... though it's on Geary, parking can be hard depending on the time of day it is.
author: Derrick D.

description: This place is quite small and normally you would have to wait for a table, but I love their tofu soup. I like how it's sizzling hot, full of flavor and you can get it extra spicy. I used to go all the time, but less now because this place is getting popular and there's usually a wait. If you decide to go, go a little early so you can beat the dinner crowd.
author: Gina P.

description: I don't have much experience with korean food except for this place.  But I'd think this one is pretty good for a first time.  The tofu soup is more like a small stew you can order for just yourself.  Great strong spicy  flavors - especially after adding some of the kim chee-little chunks of your choice of beef, pork or seafood and duh, Tofu. Try the combo if you want a little of each.  Also try the grilled meats- not bad.  After the rice pot is nearly empty the server will come by and pour some hot water into it and turn it into a quicky rice soup - or at least I think that's what it's supposed to be.  I'll always go back, but looking to try others.  Anything cheaper out there and just as good?
author: greg e.

description: pretty good because it reminds me of BCD from down in LA.  I always get the tofu pot/bul go gi combo. price is good but there can be a wait.  service isnt' bad either for a busy restaurant.  haven't had better tofu pots in the city yet so I give it four stars.
author: Peggy W.

description: Love it, great food, the people are kind (especially to non koreans) and i think all around, this was worth my trip from chicago. well, not by itself, but it adds the the fun journey
author: B H.

description: Good to eat on a cold day! The place is small and they only have two waiters there. Bad service and their food is so-so. Nothing compared to tofo houses in Southern California. According to many, My tofo house is probably one of the best in San Francisco. Gotta try it for yourself to decide.
author: Jenny K.

description:
i actually find this place to be very reasonable for korean style tofu stew.  2 ppl, 2 tofu stews, 'bout 7 little pickled side dishes, rice from a super hot stone container which the wait staff will pour water into after scooping out the rce...  about 22 bucks.

the stew is good.  personally i find it pretty difficult to screw it up because the flavor is usually very spicy and garlicy... But, apparently it does happen.  

in anycase, go here on any chilly san francisco evening, and it'll warm you up without breaking the bank.

service is SLOW.
author: shaun l.

description: YUMMY.  Simple menu, you basically can only order three things: the tofu soups, the bibimbop, and the meats....all of which are winners.  I don't recommend the tofu salad, save space for the rest of the goodies.  I must admit, I was very annoyed my first visit because of the extremely long and unexpected wait but the food made it all worth it.  Be prepared to overeat and be over satisfied.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Want soup? Choose your variety. My favorite the KimChi Chige.
author: Judy L.

description: This place seems to be a popular joint but I just wanted to say that despite the decency in food flavor, there is just too much MSG or something in the soup.  Each and every time I eat there, it never fails to surface....
author: Mashimaro M.

description: Yummy yummy tofu. The best in town, (its cuz i don't want to stop coming to this place) The tofu is served hot off the bat, and you get all these korean side dishes as well. Love em. Somehow, this place always have a long line, if you come at peak times and it is a little pricey for some tofu. =(
author: Monika T.

description: I love the tofu bowls at My Tofu House.  When I was in dental school my roomate and I would eat here all the time after our workouts.  Biggest gripe about this place is the service and the fact that they do not have an alcohol license.  There meat dishes are average, I mainly go for the Tofu bowls.  Services is usually good after you are seated.  I would not recommend this place if you are in a hurry.
author: Christopher D.

description:
my sis tried twice, and it was my first time to try.

she gave high scores about last visit, but this time she complained a little bit. She didn't like the bbq pork rice pot.. she thinks even steamed rice is better...

the TOFU seafood soup is very delicious, and of coz she tried twice, and still wants to eat the 3rd times or more..

very fresh tofu and other raw materials, and the soup is soooooo yummy that she had it all except the tofu -_-
author: Sue S.

description: One of my fav. korean restaurants, will definitely drop by when I come back for visit.  I usually order their dumpling/rice cake tofu stew (hot) and it comes with 4 sides and a fried fish.  Try going during their off hours when things aren't too busy, you'll get better service at that time.
author: J J.

description: I'm writing this review just to remind myself to go to doobu if I'm ever craving for korean food.  Once in a while I forget why I hardly ever come back to this place.  They have raise their prices.  Again, I feel like I'm paying for the side dishes that come with your meal because of how much they charge you for a plate of kalbi.  Tried the korean pancake tonight and it was pretty bland.  Doobu makes a better pancake...actually, I think I can make a better korean pancake.
author: Katniss B.

description: This place specializes in Korean tofu stew, known as "sundubu chigae". There are other options on the menu (dol-sat bibim bap, and a few other things) as well. I found the sundubu to be decent... but, nothing spectacular. The dol-sat bibim bap is also average (although very pricey here, for whatever reason).
author: Sunny Y.

description: Great Korean tofu soup--I don't know the Korean names for everything, but the original tofu soup is my favorite and like others mentioned, it comes with some side dishes and yummy rice.  If you're going for a BBQ dish, I prefer the chicken over the beef (chicken is grilled with a lot of onions, but it's tasty; beef tends to be on the ever-so-slightly mushy side).  I tried one of those rice dishes (cooked in the stoneware) with seafood...I wasn't too impressed.  Service can be a little rough around the edges, but it's only because they're busy and short-staffed.  The servers are actually quite nice.  Cozy little place; be prepared to wait if you go during peak dinner hours!
author: Joyce L.

description: Tasty tofu soup and clean and smoke free place....Bulgogee is yummy too and decently priced.
author: Yan M.

description:
edit 2/2/08
tofu house twice in one week!! hell yah! hahah this is definitely one of the places that i can eat at all the time and not get sick of.. my favorite is the dumpling tofu soup.. medium please! hah oh and i love their fried fish.. the beef stuff that they have is extremely yummy too.. just go and try it, you wont be disappointed.. theres always a long line but it moves pretty fast.

old review:
really wanted some tofu soup one day and decided to go here since it was close to work... i read some reviews on yelp and decided to get mild because they said medium was too spicy! dammit.. mild wasnt even spicy at all... next time im getting medium! blahh!!

anyways.. it was good.. just not spicy.. but good
author: JUDY L.

description: Ouch that food is sizzlin!  If you order just one entree you will be fine for a dinner for two.  But sometimes I like to get piggy like and order one whole entree for myself.  Nothing beats the side dishes.  I could get full off of that by itself.  And what a way to finish off the meal:  there is no dessert but you do get a sweet juicy melon stick of gum.  The good kind of gum, the kind you buy at the Nijiya market, or any local Asian grocer.
author: Annster L.

description: Decent soondubu. Plenty of banchan (side dishes) are served alongside your meal. I like the variety of dol sot bibimbap (stone pot mixed rice) offered here. The food is reasonably priced and pretty good overall. Service can be slow and there is often a line so come patient.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Took the crew for some stew. MTF specializes in tofu-based soups. For the Korean novice, think stew, more than soup as these beauties come in lava-hot, stone bowls and are thick enough to support a fork vertically.
Don't come looking for BBQ here. Go down the street for that. Soup and one other Korean mainstay, Bibimbap are the reason to wait in line here. The latter dish being a rice-based concoction topped with meat, vegetables and bound together by a chili paste. Nice.
Big picture, MTF moves to the top of my list for two reasons, its clean (God-forbid, there actually IS a clean Korean restaurant!) and the quality and quantity of the Panchan, or side dishes. Until recently, we'd make the trek to Kukje Supermarket (the restaurant is located in the market) for their very good tofu soups, but MTF is better overall.
MTF rocks, and is the perfect place for a cold Winter (Summer in the Richmond) evening.
author: Mr. S.

description: Ah my tofu house.. I've been to 2 korean places and they are both pretty good. When i'm craving korean food near my house, I'd go here! I LOVE there spicy tofu soup! So tasty esp. with rice. For some reason whenever I eat korean I always order way to much for the people we have. HAHA. The veg & beef bibimbap is really good and you know how they always serve you extra side dishes, the broiled fish is one of the better because its not so fishy..? The bulgogi pretty good as well.
author: Lily K.

description: This place rocks!  It's great soondubu and especially on a cold day it really hits the spot.  I was seated promptly and was served quickly.  I really love the kimchee though it was one looooonnggg piece of cabbage.  But my friend tells me that's a good sign since it's better if it's fermented in one piece then chopped to order.  But they didn't chop it really.  Tasty food, wish it was cheaper.
author: Eileen L.

description: Does Tofu erase your memory?  I can't remember what I ate exactly but the tofu soup, tofu salad, and bulgogi was good.  Service was also up to par.  LA Korean food is TOFU-mazing but no complaints here.
author: Po L.

description: I love tofu stew. Since I can't eat spicy food, I appreciate that they make mine "white".
author: Julie K.

description: I always love the variety of pickled veggies they serve before the meal.  Yummy tofu stews and piping hot bibimbaps.  I just wish they were cheaper :\
author: Samantha L.

description: Being a SoCal native I'm pretty picky about my Korean food since good, cheap restaurants there are a dime a dozen.  But the soondubu here is comparable to the better places down there and it's reasonably priced.  I give it the five star rating not only for taste but also the serving size -- they do not skimp you on the food.  And I really like how they serve the rice in a clay pot and make you nurongjee afterwards (adding warm water to the browning rice on the bottom making a very smoky porridge).  Their BBQ pork is also very tasty and tender.
author: Helen C.

description: this was my first visit to the tofu house, and i loved it. there aren't too many non-koreans in here, so that's a plus! I had no idea what to expect, but i was plesantly surprised by the time i was done. the meals are pretty close to traditional and they can make it as spicey as you can take it.
author: carli m.

description: Consistently good tofu soup served piping hot. The selection of panchan is nice and the food is always on the table in a timely manner, even when it's busy. I haven't tried the BBQ yet, mainly because this is a tofu house, but it does look good when I've seen other people order it.
author: Kristi K.

description: Everyone goes there for their soondubu, but I am here to tell you that their bi bim bap with chicken is the bomb.  It is easily the best tasting Korean restaurant I have been to in the city.
author: Tim G.

description: Excellent bibimbap! The medium-spice tofu soup was amazing, too. You get a lot of food for not very much money. I'm going back to try the kalbi.
author: Priya S.

description: Hands down one of my favorite Korean food places in the continental US. The taste is authentic and ... I just salivate thinking of it. Mmmm... The tofu is definitely what I come here for, but I get other stuff as well. The marinated pork (the pork bulgogi) is pretty good. There's usually a decent wait but always worth it! Ah!
author: June P.

description: Just think about this place already makes me drool.  The tofu soup is really really good.  The level of spiciness in this place is really high, I would recommend to go for mild if you can eat only a little spicy, medium if you think you can handle it morderately. Make sure to put your name on the list at the front, the wait is about 20 minutes on Friday and Saturday night but it totally worths it.
author: Lily K.

description: I haven't been to many Korean restaurants but off all of the ones I've been to this is great.  The bugolgi is sweet and tasty.  The sides are wonderful especially the kimchi.  The tofu is soft and tender.  Very good
author: Stevezee C.

description:
I went here for the first time and I loved everything that I tried. I was there on Sunday early evening and there wasn't too much of a crowd. Overall, this place is great --- I think it's on the cheaper side, so not sure why people think this is expensive compared to other Korean places. 

MENU
- They don't have a full Korean menu, but they have my 3 favorite Korean dishes - soondobu jig gae (tofu stew), dolsot bi bim bap (rice and veggies in hot pot), and daeji bul go gi (spicy bbq pork) - so I was good to go. 
- Daeji Bulgogi - This was probably the best quality of meat that I've had at a Korean place in a long while. It wasn't very fatty as I've found Brothers, Wooden Charcoal, and Korea House - so I was super happy with this dish. 
- Soondoobu Jigae - The tofu stew was above average, not the best, most flavorful I've found, but above average yummy.

I didn't try the bibim bap, but I'll have to go back for another visit for that dish. 

ATMOSPHERE
- Normally I'd give a star off for bright fluorescent lighting, but the meats made me so happy that it all evened out. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: J K.

description: Although I was in search of a Korean restaurant that offered a lot of the authentic favorites including a soup dish I love, My Tofu House turned out to be a great find. I should have been a bit brighter considering it was called My Tofu House as it pretty much served spicy tofu, bimbimbap, and grilled meats. The side dishes were very tasty and the bimbimbap in the stone pot was excellent!  One of the best I've had in SF. I do have to say that it was slightly overpriced but the serving was generous.
author: Josephine H.

description: Great korean food at reasonable prices. We had the seafood tofu soup but the clams had some sand in it that make it a tad difficult to eat but not runining the spicy goodness of the soup nonetheless. The kalbi was good but I would prefer it if it was grilled a lil bit more to have the burnt bits at the side. Hopefully you get a table on the inside so that you do not have hungry waiting patrons staring down at you somewhat pressuring you to finish off your meal faster! Service can be a little bit slow though!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Everyone loves this place.  My fiancee loves this place but I can't come here with her. 

It has nothing to do with the food.  It more has to do with me. 

I don't like the signature dishes here so I can't really enjoy the place.  I never got anything else.  I'd rather go to a Korean bbq place than a tofu place.  

Still, if everyone loves it, you should still try it out.
author: Scott L.

description: Great tofu soups, excellent kalbi and bulgogi and great atmosphere.  Clean, neat, white walls with wood accents-- just the perfect place for my type A personality.  Service is wonderful, though a little slow but that's just cause the line snakes to the door everytime I have come here.  But I still keep comin' cause it's well worth the wait!
author: Helen T.

description: Oh how I love My Tofu House. I've been living in Berkeley now for the past year due to school and I was beginning to lose faith in good Korean tofu soup. I come home one weekend and stop by Tofu House to see if it was still worth eating and of course, how could I ever doubt My Tofu House's soup. Actually everything on their menu is pretty tasty. Their kalbi is pretty good but they use the leaner meats than over places so I guess it's preference. At night it does get pretty busy for dinner so waiting is involved most of the time after 6ish. My main complaint about this place is how the prices have soared over the years. Oh well, it's always worth it!
author: Julie L.

description:
small, hole in the wall kinda place full of charm and great value.

service was good. food was sizzling hot when it came out. the tofu soup was realllly spicy--- too spicy, at least for me. i can handle a good amount of spiciness but wow--- i couldn't handle it! my taste buds were melted away and at one point all i could taste was the tingling taste of HOTness.

marinated beef dishes were all really yummy. i love eating korean bc of all of the fun little side dishes they bring it. feels like christmas :)
author: Amanda N.

description:
All of the sudden, I've become a Korean "Soft Tofu" fan...trying almost everywhere from Milpitas to San Francisco.  I've heard so much about this that I've decided to give this place a try.  There's actually another Korean restaurant right next door, which offered something different (Goat meat...not a fan!--especially for $40....HELL NO!)  

I usually go for the samo...(Seafood combination with soft tofu).
